lead_paragraph: When the designer Jeremy Anderson, 44, was a kid growing up in suburban Minneapolis, his favorite toys were paper dolls, though he rarely played with them. “It wasn’t something little boys did,” he remembers. “It was this secret thing I loved.” Decades later, Anderson traces a link between that furtive interest and his heretofore behind-the-scenes ceramics practice, throwing chubby anthropomorphic vessels that he “dresses up” with hand-painted stripes and raised ridges that bend and vibrate to trippy effect.

headline: Poems of Love and Desire That Push Back Against Oppression
abstract: In “Postcolonial Love Poem,” Natalie Diaz takes a traditional form and makes it her own, centering the experiences of queer women of color.
lead_paragraph: Early in Natalie Diaz’s second book, the speaker has an epiphany that she’s “the only Native American / on the 8th floor of this hotel or any” in New York City’s smallest borough. The poem, “Manhattan Is a Lenape Word,” grieves the fact that “nobody asks, Where have all / the Natives gone?” even as it recognizes where the Natives are: “Not here.” Violence against Indigenous people is not just historical but ongoing, systemic and institutional, Diaz reminds us. “Native Americans make up less than / 1 percent of the population of America,” she writes in “American Arithmetic,” but “Police kill Native Americans more / than any other race.” This knowledge, however fraught, emboldens Diaz to celebrate her survival as a queer Aha Makav woman living in the 21st century.

headline: When Classical Composers Did the Fox Trot
abstract: Listen to Jazz Age composers try their hand at the pop styles of the day.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of his 1933 novel “Romance in Marseille,” newly and belatedly published for the first time by Penguin Classics, the Harlem Renaissance writer Claude McKay moves toward an operatic climax by steering several characters into a bar.

headline: Miu Miu: Fall 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Miu Miu: Fall 2020 Collection.
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Miu Miu: Fall 2020 Collection.

headline: As Gymnasts Who Were Abused Seek Answers, They Are Offered Only Money
abstract: Despite multiple investigations and a settlement offer worth millions of dollars, Simone Biles, Aly Raisman and many other abuse victims feel justice is a long way away.
lead_paragraph: With less than five months left before the Tokyo Olympics, the governing body for gymnastics in the United States has proposed a multimillion-dollar legal settlement to close a dark and painful chapter in which hundreds of gymnasts were sexually assaulted by a former team doctor.

headline: Everyone’s a Curator Now
abstract: When everything is “curated,” what does the word even mean?
lead_paragraph: Recently Maryellen Stewart, a freelance copywriter for luxury brands, was window-shopping in SoHo when she noticed a large sign in a restaurant window advertising a “curated” menu.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.

headline: Real Wedding Day Looks
abstract: A selection of outfits worn by men and women featured in our wedding announcements.
lead_paragraph: Wedding attire often tells a story. Brides and grooms may choose to highlight a side of themselves very few people see. Some look to symbolize a pinnacle point in their lives, while others pay homage to their heritage. The men and women featured in our wedding announcements wore outfits that told many tales, but ultimately, all were meant to express the same testament of love. Here is a selection of photographs from their weddings, with details on what they wore.

headline: All the French Favorites
abstract: Le Crocodile, in Brooklyn, is a modern take on the brasserie.
lead_paragraph: Le Crocodile, in Brooklyn, is a modern take on the brasserie.

headline: Le Crocodile Shows How a New York Brasserie Should Look and Taste
abstract: The new restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has a menu that goes on and on. Nearly everything on it makes you want to come back for more.
lead_paragraph: At Chez Ma Tante in Brooklyn, the first restaurant Aidan O’Neal and Jake Leiber ran together, early press reports portrayed Mr. O’Neal as the executive chef and Mr. Leiber as his second in command. But in interviews they gave — always in tandem — it was clear that they were equal partners and that they agreed about everything from their preferred cooking surface (Teflon) to the ideal art to hang in the dining room (none).

headline: Tornadoes Kill 25 in Tennessee, Shredding Buildings in Nashville Area
abstract: A powerful storm system cut a path through the middle of Tennessee early Tuesday morning, toppling electrical lines and littering streets with debris.
lead_paragraph: DOUBLE SPRINGS, Tenn. — Jean Gregory had been fast asleep when her husband yanked her to the floor and flung himself on top of her for six, seven, maybe 10 minutes, as they waited for the tornado that had descended on their small community in Putnam County, Tenn., to finally pass.

headline: Iran’s Coronavirus Response: Pride, Paranoia, Secrecy, Chaos
abstract: Iranian leaders once predicted the coronavirus epidemic ravaging China would not affect their country. Now Iran has among the most coronavirus deaths outside China, and Iranian medical workers have been told to keep quiet.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three dozen Iranian government officials and members of parliament are infected and a senior adviser to the supreme leader has died.

headline: Peak, With 101st-Floor Views, Opens in Hudson Yards
abstract: An American brasserie in Long Island City, Vietnamese in Williamsburg, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: At the pinnacle of 30 Hudson Yards, the tallest tower in the complex, will be this sleek restaurant with stunning views from the 101st floor. The architect David Rockwell’s company, the Rockwell Group, has given the space a richly elegant but subdued look with shades of gray as the dominant palette. The Peak experience involves entering through a dim, plush lounge for cocktails and bar snacks on the fifth floor of Hudson Yards’s retail building. From there, an elevator speeds up and docks at a spacious lobby, with the restaurant to one side and private dining rooms and an event space opposite. The restaurant dips gradually from a curved, brass-trimmed 45-seat bar area to a 110-seat dining room, where sculptural light sticks hang from the ceiling and bare tables on a few levels afford views like a bird’s-eye of the Empire State Building. Does it remind you of Windows on the World? Of course, but with less grandeur and gilt. The restaurant is run by RHC, the English company that also manages Wild Ink in Hudson Yards. The executive chef, Christopher Cryer, who was in that role at the Seamore’s seafood restaurants, has created a fairly brief menu of sophisticated yet accessible American fare like Atlantic scallops with cauliflower purée, beef tartare, rigatoni with lamb sausages, roasted monkfish with littleneck clams, cauliflower steak, braised short rib, rotisserie chicken and a fried potato terrine. Local ingredients dominate. (Opens March 12)

headline: How to Disinfect Your Space on an Airplane
abstract: Here are some tips for cleaning your area of a plane and keeping healthy on a flight.
lead_paragraph: [This article is part of the developing coronavirus coverage, and may be outdated. Go here for the latest on the coronavirus.]

headline: Matvey Natanzon, a.k.a. Falafel the Backgammon King, Dies at 51
abstract: A Russian-born émigré by way of Israel, he made a gambler’s living taking on challengers, and often hustling them, in becoming the world’s ranking player.
lead_paragraph: Matvey Natanzon, who was known as Falafel because he subsisted on deep-fried chickpea balls while hustling gullible opponents in Washington Square Park in Manhattan while he groomed himself to be the world’s greatest backgammon player, died on Feb. 14 in Clarence, N.Y., near Buffalo. He was 51.

headline: Can the Fed and Friends Save the Economy?
abstract: On putting too much faith in central bankers.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Paul Krugman’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it every Tuesday.

headline: ‘Fire Carranza!’: Why Asian-Americans Are Targeting Schools Chief
abstract: Protesters say the New York chancellor’s integration agenda harms their children, but he responds that it would benefit “all cultures and all ethnic groups.”
lead_paragraph: Dozens of Asian-American parents filtered into a Queens auditorium in January, gathering to protest a local school desegregation plan that they said would drive their children to low-performing schools in far-off neighborhoods. But their anger was really directed at one person: Richard A. Carranza, the leader of New York City’s schools.

headline: ‘Incantata’ Review: An Elegy in Words, Video and Potatoes
abstract: A solo stage adaptation of Paul Muldoon’s poem considers whether making art can offer solace in the wake of grief.
lead_paragraph: Even the word sounds spellbinding: “Incantata” is Italian for “enchantment.”

headline: Why Lena Waithe Had to Wait Until Her 30s to Make ‘Twenties’
abstract: Her new BET series is a semi-autobiographical story she started writing a decade ago. It just took a while — and an Emmy — before the world was ready for it.
lead_paragraph: It took winning an Emmy for Lena Waithe to prove there was room in Hollywood for stories like hers.

headline: How to Cook With Plant-Based Meats
abstract: You may have tried restaurant versions, but making them at home is another matter. J. Kenji López-Alt has tested them and offers practical advice.
lead_paragraph: SAN MATEO, Calif. — Even before opening my restaurant, Wursthall, here a couple years ago, I knew that taking vegan and vegetarian options seriously — with both traditionally vegan foods and modern meat alternatives — would be a central element of its success.

headline: In an Enchanted World, Echoes of Today’s Political Dramas
abstract: Living in a haunted nation, the 11-year-old hero of Pam Muñoz Ryan’s “Mañanaland” faces difficult questions about refugees and altruism.
lead_paragraph: Eleven-year-old Maximiliano Córdoba is full of wondering. He wonders about his mother, who disappeared when he was a baby. He wonders about the stories and legends of his small town, which exists in the fictional nation of Santa Maria, “somewhere in the Américas.” He wonders why his father — a bridge-builder — is so overprotective, solemn and secretive.

headline: Any American Can Now Be Tested for the Coronavirus, Pence Says
abstract: The vice president said the C.D.C. had lifted all restrictions on testing for the virus and would be releasing new guidelines to fast-track testing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Mike Pence said the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention had lifted all restrictions on testing for the coronavirus and would be releasing new guidelines to fast-track testing for people who fear they have the virus, even if they are displaying mild symptoms.

headline: How Do They Make Plant-Based Meat Behave Like Beef?
abstract: J. Kenji López-Alt explains the science behind the new vegan products.
lead_paragraph: Texture, appearance and flavor: These are the elements of meat that the new vegan alternatives from Impossible Foods and Beyond Meat are trying to capture, with varying degrees of success. Here’s how they do it:

headline: As Trump Botches the Coronavirus Crisis, I Long for … Giuliani
abstract: Believe it or not, after 9/11 “America’s mayor” was calm, honest and humble — three things our president can’t manage.
lead_paragraph: On Monday morning, I watched the news conferences held by Rudolph Giuliani on Sept. 11, 2001, when he was still the mayor of New York. Eighteen-plus years later, they look like dispatches from a remote and impossible universe, a place where dolphins roamed the earth and the sun shone pink.

headline: Kim’s Sister Slams South Korea in 1st-Ever Statement
abstract: Kim Yo-jong, the leader’s sister and one of his closest aides, called the South “idiotic” after it denounced the North’s weapons test, another sign of chilling ties.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The sister of North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un​, attacked South Korea’s presidential office on Tuesday, calling it idiotic a day after the South denounced the North’s first weapons test this year.

headline: Why 2019 Was a Breakthrough Year for Women in the Boardroom
abstract: Public pressure to diversify boards forced public companies to change. And private ones, too.
lead_paragraph: — Malli Gero, a co-founder of 2020 Women on Boards

headline: Putin Proposes Constitutional Ban on Gay Marriage
abstract: Seeking to build interest in an impending referendum, the Russian president offered divisive new proposals on hot-button cultural issues.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin has proposed a constitutional amendment banning gay marriage in what political analysts suggest is an effort to raise turnout for a constitutional referendum that could keep him in power but has so far stirred little enthusiasm among Russians.

headline: Faulting the U.S. Response to the Coronavirus
abstract: Health care providers and other readers worry about inadequate testing, quarantines and protective equipment.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Lunch With Freeman Dyson, in 196,883 Dimensions
abstract: “Some mathematicians are birds, others are frogs,” Dr. Dyson once wrote. He was both.
lead_paragraph: Lunchtime in the cafeteria at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J. — sometimes called the Institute for Advanced Dining — is a heady scene, and Freeman Dyson, who died last week at 96, was a regular fixture, arriving with reading material tucked under his arm.

headline: As Coronavirus Disrupts Factories, India Curbs Exports of Key Drugs
abstract: The outbreak has hobbled Chinese factories that supply India’s vast drug industry with ingredients for antibiotics and vitamins, raising the prospect of global shortages.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — The spreading coronavirus may soon affect people’s health in a different way: The outbreak is now starting to hurt the supply of essential drugs.

headline: Spike Lee on Knicks Dispute: ‘Dolan Is Harassing Me’
abstract: Lee, the Oscar-winning filmmaker, said he would not attend another home game this season. He and James L. Dolan, the team’s owner, are at odds because Lee was pulled aside after entering Madison Square Garden on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Spike Lee, the Oscar-winning filmmaker and most famous fan of the Knicks, has accused the franchise and its owner, James L. Dolan, of repeatedly lying about why he was stopped shortly after entering Madison Square Garden before a game on Monday night.

headline: Senator Rick Scott: ‘Communist China Cannot Be Trusted’
abstract: The Florida Republican takes strong issue with an Op-Ed article by a Chinese official about Beijing’s response to the coronavirus. Also: The role of hospitals in their communities.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Oklahoma College Recruiter Lined Up High School Students by Skin Color and Hair Type
abstract: Cedric Sunray, an Oklahoma Christian University recruiter, said he had no intention of “promoting a racist agenda” with his presentation to students.
lead_paragraph: A college recruiter from Oklahoma Christian University is no longer working for the school after he told a group of high school students to line up organized by their skin color and hair texture, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in March
abstract: Our picks for March, including ‘Lost Girls,’ ‘Ozark’ and ‘Making the Cut’
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for March.

headline: High-Flying Trading App Robinhood Goes Down at the Wrong Time
abstract: Robinhood remained down part of Tuesday as the markets bounced around, leaving customers angry and nursing big losses.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Robinhood has become a Silicon Valley darling by presenting itself as a tech-savvy alternative to traditional stock trading platforms. But this week, with the financial markets in chaos, the start-up’s technology failed at the most crucial moment.

headline: The Fed Has No Tools for an Outbreak. Here’s Why It Acted Anyway.
abstract: Think of its role by imagining a town with a looming crisis: a major hurricane.
lead_paragraph: The list of reasons that the Federal Reserve shouldn’t have cut interest rates on Tuesday is long.

headline: Review: A New ‘Flying Dutchman’ Makes Landfall at the Met Opera
abstract: François Girard’s ultimately frustrating production presents the story as taking place within its heroine’s fevered imagination.
lead_paragraph: A stranger comes to town.

headline: Carmen Herrera Mural to Grace East Harlem
abstract: The artist’s design will be executed by students from Publicolor, an arts and education program, and Manhattan East School for Arts and Academics.
lead_paragraph: Soon you won’t have to go to the Metropolitan Museum of Art or the Museum of Modern Art to see artwork by Carmen Herrera. By the end of May, one of her abstract paintings will be visible from Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in Upper Manhattan.

headline: A Trump Plan Breaks a Great Deal for Ranchers and Park Lovers
abstract: A free-market solution to protect a spectacular landscape was working.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration has struck another blow to common-sense management of public lands in the West. Virtually all the spectacular country neighboring the Escalante River in the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument in Utah will be reopened to cattle grazing, thanks to a new plan for managing the monument released by the Interior Department last month.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘How Do You Think I Got Thighs Like These?’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: We were lying on the shaggy carpet of my 500-square-foot apartment, playing Bananagrams, deciding what love feels like. I said, “It’s the workout where you squat and catch the medicine ball at the same time. It’s falling and lifting at once.” Paul said, “How heavy is the ball?” I thought about it — about his depression and compulsiveness, my type-A personality and body-image issues. Just because we are in love doesn’t mean things have been easy. I replied, “I mean, how do you think I got thighs like these?” — E.J. Schwartz

headline: How to Survive a Quarantine
abstract: I spent 10 days in a Chinese quarantine facility after being exposed to swine flu. Bootleg iced coffee helped.
lead_paragraph: [This article is part of the developing coronavirus coverage, and may be outdated. Go here for the latest on the coronavirus.]

headline: Mike Bloomberg Heads South
abstract: Campaigning for black votes ahead of Super Tuesday, the former New York mayor was a long way from home.
lead_paragraph: Inside the celebrated Brown Chapel A.M.E. Church in Selma, Ala., on Sunday, Michael Bloomberg looked, as the kids tend to say, shook.

headline: Forget Super Tuesday. It’s the Day After That Matters.
abstract: Democrats, it’s Super Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: News Update: Michael Bloomberg announced Wednesday morning that he was quitting the presidential race, and endorsed Joe Biden.

headline: Supreme Court Divided on Trump’s Power to Fire Head of Consumer Bureau
abstract: The justices seemed split along familiar lines in a case challenging the independence of the director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Paul D. Clement, a lawyer appointed by the Supreme Court to defend the independence of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau after the Trump administration refused, gave a timely example on Tuesday to illustrate why it can be a good idea for agencies to be insulated from politics.

headline: Louis Vuitton :Fall 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Louis Vuitton: Fall 2020 Collection.
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Louis Vuitton: Fall 2020 Collection.

headline: Nets Guard Kyrie Irving Has Shoulder Surgery
abstract: Irving, 27, is out for the rest of the N.B.A. season. He appeared in just 20 games because of injuries.
lead_paragraph: Nets point guard Kyrie Irving had arthroscopic shoulder surgery on Tuesday, and the team called it “successful.” He will miss the rest of the season.

headline: California Had Its Driest February on Record. Here’s How Bad It Was.
abstract: Parts of the state received no rainfall at all last month and the number of wildfire calls were above average as well.
lead_paragraph: Parts of the state received no rainfall at all last month and the number of wildfire calls were above average as well.

headline: Coronavirus in Iran, Markets, Israel Elections: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: For Questlove, ‘Soul Train’ Is His Happy Place
abstract: A founding member of the Roots shares the TV shows, artists and “robe type things” that top his list of essentials.
lead_paragraph: “I’m a world-famous celebrity hoarder,” says Ahmir “Questlove” Thompson, a founding member of the Roots and current bandleader and drummer on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon.” “I have about 15 storage spaces, so basically I’m a firm believer in throwing nothing away.”

headline: Trump Speaks With a Taliban Leader
abstract: The direct contact between an American president and a top Taliban official would once have been unthinkable, showing President Trump’s drive to make a peace deal stick.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump spoke on Tuesday with the deputy leader of the Taliban, Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar, in the latest sign of his determination to see that a peace deal signed Saturday with the Afghan insurgent group holds, allowing him to withdraw thousands of American troops in an election year.

headline: Global Health Crisis 1, Economic Policymakers 0
abstract: As leaders of the world’s wealthiest countries pledged to limit the damage from the coronavirus, they appeared to be operating with limited options.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The people who control money had hoped for so much more. The news that the world’s wealthiest countries were convening to orchestrate a response to the deadly coronavirus outbreak had resonated across economies like the sound of whirring helicopters bringing relief to a disaster zone.

headline: Hilary Mantel’s Triumphant New Novel Brings Thomas Cromwell Across the Finish Line
abstract: At the start of “The Mirror and the Light,” the concluding volume of a trilogy that began with “Wolf Hall,” Cromwell is 50 years old, rich beyond all his imagining and very much alone.
lead_paragraph: How suitably some writers come named. Muriel Spark, of the scorching short fiction. Judy Blume, of stories of young girls coming of age. Ann Patchett, in whose work families desperately try to repair their tattered ties.

headline: Yankees May Begin Season Without Aaron Judge or Giancarlo Stanton
abstract: After working through a raft of injuries last season, the team is once again scrambling to plug holes ahead of opening day.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees are likely to be without two star players, the outfielders Aaron Judge and Giancarlo Stanton, for opening day on March 26 against the Orioles in Baltimore, General Manager Brian Cashman told reporters at the team’s spring training facility in Tampa, Fla., on Tuesday. Both could return as soon as April.

headline: Live Analysis: Super Tuesday
abstract: Follow live coverage and analysis from Times reporters.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage and analysis from Times reporters.

headline: Live Forecast: Who Will Win Super Tuesday?
abstract: The Times plans to publish estimates around 7 p.m., Eastern.
lead_paragraph: The Times plans to publish estimates around 7 p.m., Eastern.

headline: Super Tuesday: Live Primary Election Results
abstract: Get the latest primary election results from California, Texas and 12 other states on March 3.
lead_paragraph: Get the latest primary election results from California, Texas and 12 other states on March 3.

headline: How to Respond to Microaggressions
abstract: Should you let that comment slide, or address it head on? Is it more harm than it’s worth? We can help.
lead_paragraph: For many of us, microaggressions are so commonplace that it seems impossible to tackle them one at a time. Psychologists often compare them to death by a thousand cuts.

headline: Trump Campaign Sues The Washington Post for Libel
abstract: The lawsuit concerns two opinion articles that tied the 2016 Trump election campaign to Russia. A week ago, the campaign filed a similar action against The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s re-election campaign sued The Washington Post for libel on Tuesday, citing two opinion articles from last year that linked Mr. Trump to Russian election interference. The action came a week after Mr. Trump’s campaign filed a similar lawsuit against The New York Times.

headline: The Wall Some Texans Want to Build Against Abortion
abstract: Around the country, a “sanctuary city” movement is growing on the right and the left, as people seek to keep out views they don’t agree with, legal or not.
lead_paragraph: LINDALE, Texas — A small group of women at a recent City Council meeting held hands and offered hushed prayers in an otherwise silent room.

headline: Doubts Linger as Democrats Vote: ‘I Don’t Think We Have a Perfect Candidate’
abstract: Many Super Tuesday voters across the nation made last-minute decisions, sometimes on the way to the polls. Even afterward, some weren’t sure they had chosen correctly.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — After all the debates and forums, after the candidate surges, withdrawals and endorsements, voters in large numbers across the country finally had to land on a choice on Tuesday.

headline: Worried About Coronavirus on the Subway? Here’s What We Know
abstract: As the M.T.A. vows to regularly disinfect a system used by millions of people a day, here are some tips for trying to stay safe.
lead_paragraph: There is perhaps no place in America harder to escape crowds than the New York City subway, which, as the nation’s largest transit system, carries more than five million people every weekday.

headline: Bobbie Battista, a Mainstay Anchor at CNN, Dies at 67
abstract: She covered world events in the 1980s and ’90s and was the host of “TalkBack Live,” a program in which the audience posed questions to guest newsmakers.
lead_paragraph: Bobbie Battista, one of the original anchors of CNN Headline News and a veteran of various anchor jobs at CNN over two decades, died on Tuesday in Davenport, Iowa, where she lived. She was 67.

headline: Stanislaw Kania, 92, Polish Leader During Solidarity’s Rise, Dies
abstract: Mr. Kania walked a tightrope between demands for reform within Poland and the Soviet threat of intervention.
lead_paragraph: Stanislaw Kania, who as Poland’s Communist leader for 13 tumultuous months in the early 1980s steered a delicate course for his country, avoiding both open confrontation with Solidarity, the rising independent labor movement, and military intervention by the Soviet Union, died on Tuesday in Warsaw. He was 92.

headline: Waive Fees for Coronavirus Tests and Treatment, Health Experts Urge
abstract: As the number of U.S. cases mounts, officials and advocates want to ensure that medical bills, especially for the poor or uninsured, are not an obstacle to seeking care.
lead_paragraph: New York is among the first states in the country to waive some fees and expenses for people who undergo testing for the coronavirus, as public health officials are increasingly worried that medical bills will discourage the poor and uninsured from getting medical care.

headline: After Super Tuesday, What Happens if There’s No Winner?
abstract: It’s possible that no Democrat will come out of the primaries with a majority of delegates.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Covid in the U.S.: Latest Map and Case Count
abstract: A detailed county map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with tables of the number of cases by county.
lead_paragraph: A detailed county map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with tables of the number of cases by county.

headline: What Happens in Vegas if No One Stays in Vegas?
abstract: Companies that rely on people traveling around the globe for business and pleasure are struggling to predict exactly how the coronavirus will ultimately affect them.
lead_paragraph: This week, thousands of people will travel to Las Vegas for business conferences. The annual South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., is scheduled for this month.

headline: Ace of Base: Why Netanyahu Seems Unsinkable
abstract: The Israeli prime minister’s fervent base can make President Trump’s look pallid. And they don’t care that he has been charged with corruption.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — What does Benjamin Netanyahu have to do to get defeated?

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: U.S. officials ramp up testing, after weeks of setbacks and missteps.
lead_paragraph: American officials are scrambling to ramp up testing for the coronavirus, after weeks of setbacks and missteps that may have allowed the virus to gain a foothold.

headline: Iran Crosses a Key Threshold: It Again Has Sufficient Fuel for a Bomb
abstract: So far, the evidence suggests that Iran’s recent actions are calculated to pressure the Trump administration and Europe rather than rushing for a bomb.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran’s growing stockpile of nuclear fuel recently crossed a critical threshold, according to a report issued Tuesday by international inspectors: For the first time since President Trump abandoned the 2015 nuclear deal, Tehran appears to have enough enriched uranium to produce a single nuclear weapon, though it would take months or years to manufacture a warhead and deliver it over long distances.

headline: Super Tuesday, Coronavirus, Tennessee Tornadoes: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘First Cow’ Review: The Milk of Human Kindness
abstract: Set in the mid-19th-century Oregon Territory, Kelly Reichardt’s latest film is a fable, a western, a buddy picture and a masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: Behind every great fortune, someone once said — not quite Balzac, though he often gets the credit — lies a great crime. The fortune amassed by Cookie (John Magaro) and King-Lu (Orion Lee), partners in a mid-19th-century artisanal snack-food start-up in a rough section of the Oregon Territory, is a modest one: a cloth sack filled with shells, cutup coins and company scrip. The crime that brings them that bounty is correspondingly small-scale. Under cover of night, the two men sneak over to a pasture near the cabin they share and milk someone else’s cow. (King-Lu takes lookout duty in a tree, while Cookie fills the pail.)

headline: Want to Know Who Won Super Tuesday? Get Ready to Wait.
abstract: The polls in California, the state with more than 30 percent of the delegates at stake on Tuesday, closed at 11 p.m. Eastern. It will take a long time to count all the votes.
lead_paragraph: As Super Tuesday votes were being counted on Wednesday morning, the biggest question was how many delegates each candidate would win.

headline: In Bernie Sanders Country, It’s Super Tuesday. It’s Also ‘Town Meeting Day.’
abstract: “Would people shut up and let Dave run the meeting?” Highlights of direct democracy, and a Democratic primary, in Vermont.
lead_paragraph: JERICHO, Vt. — Tuesday was Town Meeting Day in Vermont, and the engaged citizens of Jericho were talking at cross-purposes. At issue was a possibly incorrectly introduced amendment from the floor, and also the fact that people were not speaking directly into the microphone.

headline: ‘Imagine This Were Your Sister,’ Ronan Farrow Tells Woody Allen’s Publisher
abstract: The author of “Catch and Kill,” which was published by a division of Hachette Book Group, said he wouldn’t work with the company again after it announced plans to publish his father’s memoir.
lead_paragraph: The journalist Ronan Farrow, the author of the best-selling book “Catch and Kill,” said on Tuesday that he would cut ties with his publisher, 3, after it announced that one of its divisions was publishing Woody Allen’s autobiography next month.

headline: Chemical Industry Executive Nominated to Lead Consumer Watchdog Agency
abstract: Nancy B. Beck, who once directed science policy at the American Chemistry Council, was nominated to lead the Consumer Product Safety Commission, which guards against dangerous products
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has tapped Nancy B. Beck, a former chemical industry executive, to lead the Consumer Product Safety Commission, an independent federal agency charged with protecting the public against dangers like toxic substances in products.

headline: Rafael Cancel Miranda, Gunman in ’54 Attack on Congress, Dies at 89
abstract: He and three others opened fire on a crowded House chamber in the cause of Puerto Rican independence. Some saw him as a terrorist, others as a hero.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Cancel Miranda, the last survivor among the four revolutionaries who shot up the United States Capitol on March 1, 1954, in the name of independence for Puerto Rico, died on Monday at his home in San Juan, the island’s capital. He was 89.

headline: Long Waits Frustrate Los Angeles Voters
abstract: There were also reports of voting machines malfunctioning.
lead_paragraph: As Election Day wore on, reports of hourslong lines and frustrated voters started to trickle out across Los Angeles, where poll workers were navigating a new system.

headline: Virginia Is First Southern State to Ban Conversion Therapy for Minors
abstract: Gov. Ralph Northam signed a bill prohibiting medical professionals from using the widely discredited practice on minors.
lead_paragraph: Virginia became the first Southern state to ban licensed medical professionals from practicing conversion therapy on minors, as Democrats in the state pass expansive civil rights bills after gaining control of the legislature and governor’s mansion for the first time in nearly 30 years.

headline: London’s ‘Cyrano,’ With James McAvoy, Is Headed to BAM
abstract: The postmodern take on the classic, directed by Jamie Lloyd, will have a limited run in May.
lead_paragraph: The Jamie Lloyd Company’s West End revival of “Cyrano de Bergerac” is coming to the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music for a limited run in May. Directed by the theater company’s namesake, Jamie Lloyd, the adaptation by Martin Crimp is a postmodern take on the Edmond Rostand love story, featuring beatboxing, silver-tongued characters in street clothes.

headline: We Are Ignoring One Obvious Way to Fight the Coronavirus
abstract: Paid sick leave could slow the spread of the disease and its impact on the economy.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve did what it could Tuesday to offset the growing economic impact of the coronavirus by announcing a supersize reduction in its benchmark interest rate — the first time the Fed has acted between its regularly scheduled meetings since the financial crisis in 2008.

headline: Trump Meets With Key Republicans Amid Stalemate Over Surveillance Laws
abstract: The legal authority for some F.B.I. surveillance tools expires next week, and law enforcement officials and lawmakers are divided.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump met on Tuesday at the White House with Attorney General William P. Barr and key Republican lawmakers in an effort to resolve a fight in Congress over domestic spying powers before three F.B.I. counterintelligence investigation tools expire next week.

headline: Bar Association Leader Is New Caretaker of Aretha Franklin’s Estate
abstract: The contentious process of distributing the star’s assets is out of the family’s hands for now. A probate judge has assigned the president-elect nominee of the American Bar Association to the task.
lead_paragraph: PONTIAC, Mich. — Reginald M. Turner, president-elect nominee of the American Bar Association, was appointed temporary caretaker of Aretha Franklin’s disputed estate on Tuesday as her sons continue to battle in court over who controls the rights to her image and music and how her assets should be distributed.

headline: Biden Revives Campaign, Winning Nine States, but Sanders Takes California
abstract: The voting on the biggest day of the Democratic presidential campaign increasingly suggested a two-person race between candidates representing competing wings of the party.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic presidential race emerged from Super Tuesday with two clear front-runners as Joseph R. Biden Jr. won Texas, Virginia, North Carolina and at least six other states, largely through support from African-Americans and moderates, while Senator Bernie Sanders harnessed the backing of liberals and young voters to claim the biggest prize of the campaign, California, and several other primaries.

headline: Coronavirus Deaths Tied to Nursing Center Came Earlier Than Anyone Knew
abstract: “They are prisoners with no information in there,” said a relative of a resident of the nursing center where dozens of patients remain, waiting in their rooms.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The first public indication that something was wrong inside the Life Care nursing care center in Kirkland, Wash., came on Friday, prompting an alarming sign to go up on the front door: “WE ARE HAVING RESPIRATORY OUTBREAK.”

headline: Trump Makes Room for Experts, but Still Takes a Leading Role on Coronavirus
abstract: Appearing before cameras sometimes multiple times a day to talk about the outbreak, the president has offered rosy assessments and unproven or even false assertions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a campaign rally this week in North Carolina, President Trump reassured the crowd that he had jawboned the nation’s pharmaceutical companies into quickly tackling the coronavirus.

headline: ‘Coal Country’ Review: Songs and Stories in a Disaster’s Aftermath
abstract: Jessica Blank and Erik Jensen’s show at the Public Theater, with live music by Steve Earle, is based on a real-life West Virginia mining tragedy.
lead_paragraph: At the very beginning of the new play “Coal Country,” we are told it is “a West Virginia story about 29 men and a big machine.” This is an understated way to inform the audience that what follows will be devastating.

headline: Review: In ‘The Perplexed,’ Moral Gridlock on Fifth Avenue
abstract: Richard Greenberg’s overstuffed new play about family feuds and ethical choices turns a wedding comedy into a crisis.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of plays, from “Hamlet” to “Hamilton,” feature a restless title character itching for action. But “The Perplexed,” which opened on Tuesday at New York City Center Stage I, has six — and that’s not even counting the audience.

headline: What an Acrobat Needs to Be
abstract: Tracy Gray turns things on their heads.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — We continue the week of puzzles made by women, and I wouldn’t blame you if this puzzle by Tracy Gray made you stand on your head. For some of us, that might be the only way to figure out what’s happening in her grid.

headline: Jeff Sessions Forced Into Runoff in Fight to Reclaim Senate Seat in Alabama
abstract: The former attorney general is seeking to win back the Senate seat he held for two decades in a primary contest that has turned into a contest of loyalty to President Trump, who fired him.
lead_paragraph: MOBILE, Ala. — Jeff Sessions, the former attorney general who emerged from political exile and defied President Trump to run for the United States Senate in Alabama, suffered a setback on Tuesday in his fight to win back the seat he held for 20 years, falling well short of a majority and landing in a runoff election where he will compete with a Republican rival from a weakened position.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Quarantined, Then Stuck With a Bill
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, March 4, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “I love my daughter to death, but being in the same room that long, she is not a great conversationalist.”

headline: Corrections: March 4, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, March 4, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about efforts to increase testing for the coronavirus in the United States, relying on remarks by Dr. Stephen Hahn, the commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, referred imprecisely to the availability of coronavirus testing in the United States. Dr. Hahn intended to say that the administration could have the capacity for approximately one million tests by the end of the week, not that one million tests could be administered by the end of the week. (The error was repeated in a separate article on Tuesday about missteps by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that left the potential for the virus’s spread.)

headline: Cruise Ship Held Off California Becomes New Focus of Concern
abstract: A cruise liner bound for San Francisco from Hawaii is believed to be linked to two coronavirus cases, one of them fatal. More cases were found in a number of states, including Texas and New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced on Wednesday that a cruise ship returning to California from Hawaii that had suspected links to two coronavirus cases, one of them fatal, was being held off the coast of San Francisco, as public health officials prepared to screen everyone on the ship.

headline: Democrats Decide That Joe Biden, as Risky as He Ever Was, Is the Safest Bet
abstract: The former vice president had the Super Tuesday of his dreams, winning in places he hasn’t even set foot in recently.
lead_paragraph: The scene, on its face, might not have been surprising a year ago: Joe Biden — appraised among Democrats as a decent man and affable sidekick to the party’s most popular figure — racking up primary victories and having fun talking about it.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Slides to Third Place in Massachusetts
abstract: The result was a worst-case scenario for the senator in her home state, which surprisingly tilted toward Joe Biden.
lead_paragraph: [Elizabeth Warren has dropped out of the 2020 Democratic presidential race.]

headline: Super Tuesday, Coronavirus, Iran: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Twenties’ and ‘Dave’
abstract: Two new comedy series — BET’s “Twenties” and FXX’s “Dave” — follow creative protagonists building careers.
lead_paragraph: TWENTIES 10 p.m. on BET. After Lena Waithe’s groundbreaking 2017 Emmy win — in which she became the first African-American woman to receive an Emmy for outstanding writing in a comedy series — the filmmaker Ava DuVernay posted to social media a photograph of a young Waithe balancing trays of coffee in the back seat of a car. It was a throwback to Waithe’s early career, in which she was an assistant to people in Hollywood, including DuVernay. That period of Waithe’s life provides the basis for her new, semi-autobiographical comedy series, “Twenties,” which centers on a 24-year-old aspiring television writer, Hattie (Jonica T. Gibbs) — though it moves the action to the present day. “This is our world post my character on ‘Master of None;’ it’s a world post ‘Get Out’; it’s a world post ‘Moonlight,’” Waithe said of the show in a recent interview with The New York Times. “This is the first time a masculine-of-center black woman has been the center of a show on prime-time TV.”

headline: At Fashion Week, Comeback Queens Rule the Catwalks
abstract: It wasn’t just the return of vintage trends that had the industry excited this season. It was the older models wearing them.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When the last model stepped off the runway at Louis Vuitton and the fall 2020 shows drew to a close this week, it was clear that diversity on the catwalks had become a genuine reality and not just a seasonal trend — at least as far as race was concerned. But in show after show, from New York to London to Milan to Paris over the past month, diversity of another kind also took a step forward.

headline: Word + Quiz: bivouac
abstract: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: In Germany’s Bundesliga, a Power Struggle Plays Out on Banners
abstract: German fans protest anything that they feel threatens soccer as they know it. But do the people who have fought the battles for years really speak for everyone?
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — There is a single black flag where the heart of the Commerzbank Arena should be. All around it, in the stadium’s Kurve, the terraces that are ordinarily home to Eintracht Frankfurt’s most ardent and raucous fans are empty. Exposed, they are just concrete: desolate, silent and gray.

headline: Trevor Noah Picks a Sure Bet for Super Tuesday: Old Men
abstract: Noah joked that the Tuesday primaries were a chance for 14 states to “decide whether the Democratic nominee should be an old man or an even older man.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Brick Wall
abstract: What do you think this image is saying?
lead_paragraph: What is this illustration saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or the world today? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Indians’ Carlos Carrasco Turns a Cancer Ordeal Into a Ray of Light
abstract: The longtime Cleveland starter received a diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia last spring, then spent much of his recovery time helping others.
lead_paragraph: GOODYEAR, Ariz. — Whenever he reaches into his glove for a baseball, Carlos Carrasco sees an image of triumph from a season of trials. Stamped in the pocket of his red Wilson A2000, model B125, is an imprint of himself from Sept. 22, pumping his right fist and roaring on his way to a win in the Cleveland Indians’ final home game.

headline: At N.H.L.’s Trade Deadline, Rangers and Islanders Looked Ahead
abstract: Injuries in February prompted a flurry of player swaps around the league. The Rangers mostly stood pat while the Islanders announced a relocation.
lead_paragraph: Last month’s streaks and injuries were overshadowed at month’s end by a hectic Feb. 24 trade deadline. There were more trades (32) moving the most players (55) than in any year since tracking started more than 40 years ago.

headline: ‘A Slap in the Face’: Chinese Readers Share Their Coronavirus Stories
abstract: One wrote about being asked to move out by a landlord in Europe. Others described fleeing China to escape the epidemic.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus outbreak has radiated to at least 77 countries, killing more than 3,200 people and infecting more than 93,000. It has paralyzed cities and towns, disrupted business, travel and schools. But no place has seen more devastation than China, where the overwhelming majority of deaths and infections have occurred.

headline: Stocks Surge as Biden Leads Super Tuesday Results
abstract: Health care stocks led the gains, as investors reacted to the latest Democratic primary results.
lead_paragraph: Shares on Wall Street rose on Wednesday, bouncing back from a steep drop the day before, as investors responded to Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s strong showing in the Democratic Party’s primaries and congressional efforts to combat the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Taliban Ramp Up Attacks on Afghans After Trump Says ‘No Violence’
abstract: Deadly assaults against Afghan forces have increased since the U.S. and Taliban signed a deal to end their war. Afghans worry about the ambiguity of the Taliban’s promises.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban have resumed attacks against Afghan forces soon after signing a deal to end their war with the U.S. military, raising concerns that the Americans are leaving their Afghan allies vulnerable to an insurgency unwilling to let go of violence as its main leverage.

headline: From Plagues to Floods to Black Tuesday, Fashion Goes On
abstract: The shows ended with a clash of the centuries at Louis Vuitton, heroics at Alexander McQueen and — hot pants at Chanel?
lead_paragraph: PARIS — That the final day of Paris Fashion Week was also a Mardi Noir — a Black Tuesday, with massed demonstrators marching furiously across the Place de la Concorde to the National Assembly to protest pension reform — seemed inevitable. Of course there would be revolt. There have been fires, plague, floods. How else would anyone have expected this discombobulating, fraught fashion month to end?

headline: Why the Coronavirus Isn’t What This Canadian in Hong Kong Fears Most
abstract: “The most important thing right now is to rally,” said Lindsay Jang, an expatriate who has decided to remain in the city during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The streets of this city, usually teeming with people, are practically empty, and no one knows when Hong Kong might recover from the coronavirus outbreak that has crippled the economy and devastated tourism. But Lindsay Jang, a Canadian restaurateur, said she is prepared to ride it out.

headline: How to Threaten a Political Movement, 30 Seconds at a Time
abstract: Ads against Medicare for All aired during the Democratic debates. Between the lines, you could almost hear an industry putting party leaders on notice.
lead_paragraph: A mother stands outside her house, ushering two adorable kids into the family minivan. A gray-haired man sits in a diner, his newspaper in front of him. A fresh-faced young guy in a button-down shirt pushes a bicycle out of an office building. A doctor stands in an examining room, surrounded by the tools of her trade. All four characters look straight into the camera, wearing the kind but concerned expressions of people who know you might not love what they have to say but feel a solemn duty to tell you anyway, for your own good.

headline: French as Apple Pie
abstract: This cross between a galette and a pie is hearty enough for two, but you’ll be forgiven if you eat it all yourself.
lead_paragraph: In Paris this winter, with the weather seesawing between frigid and mild, I found myself baking with apples. I made pandowdy, twice. I made a few apple crisps, one with a gingerbread spice that I liked a lot. I made an apple tart that had a layer of applesauce and a pinwheel of sliced apples. And I made baked apples. Yet every morning, my husband, Michael, would go to the Circus bakery for a baguette and return with an apple pie. My feelings were hurt only until I took my first bite: The pie looked familiar, but it was different from what I was baking and different from what other Paris shops were baking too.

headline: A Novelist-Turned-Cabby Hates His Life. Thanks to Uber, It’s About to Get Worse.
abstract: Lee Durkee’s sophomore novel, “The Last Taxi Driver,” mirrors his own experience behind the wheel of a cab.
lead_paragraph: The novelist Edmund White has observed that a remarkable number of American writers, from Hawthorne to Pynchon, have endured the shock and strain of class descent, and that an entire undercurrent in American fiction is driven by the fear of such a loss in status.

headline: A $60 Billion Housing Grab by Wall Street
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of single-family homes are now in the hands of giant companies — squeezing renters for revenue and putting the American dream even further out of reach.
lead_paragraph: Chad Ellingwood wasn’t really in the market for a home in the summer of 2006. But when his best friend came across an intriguing listing in Woodland Hills — a bedroom community in Los Angeles County’s San Fernando Valley — the two men decided to visit on a whim.

headline: How Exercise May Affect Your Immunity
abstract: Does exercise help or hinder our bodies’ ability to fight off infections? It depends.
lead_paragraph: Does exercise help or hinder our bodies’ ability to fight off infections?

headline: The Return of Gage & Tollner, a Victorian Haunt With a New Vibe
abstract: The owners of the Good Fork, Insa and Fort Defiance are reviving the 19th-century New York dining institution.
lead_paragraph: The plastic sign, about 10 feet long with A-R-B-Y-’S spelled vertically, lay on its side by a ladder and some construction tools.

headline: My Father at 100, as Seen From the Age He Died
abstract: At 56, I now understand how brief his time on earth was. His centennial is a strange comfort.
lead_paragraph: My father turned 100 last week. Not in a nursing home or at an awkward family gathering with 1-0-0 candles on a cake. Not in his physical form at all — he died in 1976. But I marked his centennial because, to the few people left on earth who still grieve for him after nearly 44 years, it had to matter for just one day, as just a fleeting number in this life of constant additions and subtractions.

headline: Anatomy of a Parisian Sex Scandal
abstract: There’s a big difference between knowing that your politicians cheat and seeing their sexts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Like everyone else in France, when I heard that Benjamin Griveaux was quitting the Paris mayor’s race because someone released his sex tape online, I immediately searched for the tape.

headline: Your Building Can Make You Sick or Keep You Well
abstract: Proper ventilation, filtration and humidity reduce the spread of pathogens like the new coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: [This article is part of the developing coronavirus coverage, and may be outdated. Go here for the latest on the coronavirus.]

headline: Trump Has His Sights Set on Black Voters
abstract: Democrats need to realize that in 2020 nothing is automatic. The president’s campaign has tentacles in many surprising places.
lead_paragraph: The Trump campaign is investing more money and resources in an attempt to attract African-American voters than any Republican presidential campaign in recent memory.

headline: Coronavirus Is What You Get When You Ignore Science
abstract: Scientists are all we have left. Pray for them.
lead_paragraph: Let us pray, now, for science. Pray for empiricism and for epidemiology and for vaccines. Pray for peer review and controlled double-blinds. For flu shots, herd immunity and washing your hands. Pray for reason, rigor and expertise. Pray for the precautionary principle. Pray for the N.I.H. and the C.D.C. Pray for the W.H.O.

headline: What It’s Like to Come Home to the Stigma of Coronavirus
abstract: A growing number of people around the country say they know what it is like to be treated like a pariah.
lead_paragraph: Frank King has gotten death threats. So many angry strangers have called his phone in recent weeks that he changed his number. And his neighbors have offered to bring food to his doorstep if he would just agree to stay inside his house.

headline: No Auto Show in Geneva, but the Car of the Year Must Go On
abstract: Considered a “supermini” in Europe, the Peugeot 208 beat out seven finalists, including Tesla’s Model 3 and the Porsche electric Taycan.
lead_paragraph: As if the climate for automobile shows worldwide wasn’t already depressed — with dwindling attendance and cash-conscious brands pulling their exhibits — the Geneva International Auto Show in Switzerland was called off this year over coronavirus fears.

headline: How Hayley Williams Saved Herself (and, BTW, Paramore)
abstract: An eclectic, unexpected, ambitious solo project let the singer and songwriter exorcise demons and stretch her creative powers. That’s good news for her long-running band.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — It was 16 degrees out in mid-November, and Hayley Williams was sprinting through the Tennessee woods, naked. As far as metaphors go, this one was chillingly apt.

headline: An Afghan Bargain Likely to Fail
abstract: After 14 months, the United States would be left without any military or counterterrorism capacity in Afghanistan, effectively subcontracting America’s security to the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, foreign policy consists of trying to make lemonade out of lemons.

headline: How to Micro-Nest in Economy
abstract: To have a comfortable flight, many economy travelers rely on their own ingenuity and, increasingly, specialized products.
lead_paragraph: When Martha Rose Ormerod, an engineering student from Wales, travels by air, she has a ritual. As soon as she is seated in her tiny economy-class seat, she sets out to personalize the space.

headline: Joe Biden Just Performed a Miracle
abstract: On Super Tuesday, he roared back to the front of the pack.
lead_paragraph: What a difference a few days make. They brought Joe Biden back from the dead.

headline: They Wanted the Apartment. Then the Broker Asked for a $2,850 Fee.
abstract: Brokers and landlords in New York City are defying sweeping protections in the state’s new rent laws, tenants say.
lead_paragraph: State lawmakers in New York sent shock waves through the real estate industry last year, passing sweeping rent laws to protect tenants.

headline: Justices Give Few Hints on How They Will Rule on Louisiana Abortion Law
abstract: The Supreme Court is considering whether Louisiana can require doctors who perform abortions to have admitting privileges at nearby hospitals, in a case likely to yield an unusually telling decision.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The argument at times sounded like a sterile analysis undertaken by management consultants: What were the benefits of requiring doctors who perform abortions to have relationships with nearby hospitals? Would requiring such relationships force abortion clinics to close?

headline: Ice Fishing Is Fun!
abstract: No, really. A trip with a New Hampshire guide reveals how much the sport has evolved, while keeping the eternal battle of angler and fish at its heart.
lead_paragraph: With frozen dirt road crunching under the car tires, my longtime fishing buddy (and paleontologist) Mike and I pull out of the driveway of my family cottage in New Hampshire for the hour drive north east toward the White Mountains , where an invite we’ve long coveted has us giddy.

headline: Get the Most Out of Your Fancy Smartphone Camera
abstract: The latest Apple and Google models have software that automatically enhances your photos, but you can also take control to get your perfect shot.
lead_paragraph: It’s getting harder to take a truly bad photo on a good smartphone. Thanks to better lenses, robust processors and integrated computational photography software to process images under the hood, even scenes in low-light, no-flash situations that used to be hopelessly murky can now turn out nicely.

headline: Inside China’s All-Out War on the Coronavirus
abstract: Dr. Bruce Aylward, of the W.H.O., got a rare glimpse into Beijing’s campaign to stop the epidemic. Here’s what he saw.
lead_paragraph: As the leader of the World Health Organization team that visited China, Dr. Bruce Aylward feels he has been to the mountaintop — and has seen what’s possible.

headline: What’s Old Can Be New Again for Businesses
abstract: Remanufacturing involves taking products to a like-new condition and is accomplished through a variety of processes and advanced by new technologies like 3-D printing.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our continuing Fast Forward series, which examines technological, economic, social and cultural shifts that happen as businesses evolve.

headline: Living In ... the West 90s
abstract: New developments are making the area denser and more expensive. But residents say it’s still a friendly neighborhood where people want to settle down.
lead_paragraph: New developments are making the area denser and more expensive. But residents say it’s still a friendly neighborhood where people want to settle down.

headline: What You Get for $1.7 Million
abstract: A Tudor Revival home near Milwaukee; an adobe house in Scottsdale, Ariz.; and a condo in a 19th-century Jacobean-style estate in Princeton, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A Tudor Revival home near Milwaukee; an adobe house in Scottsdale, Ariz.; and a condo in a 19th-century Jacobean-style estate in Princeton, N.J.

headline: The West 90s: An Increasingly Upscale Area Between Two Parks
abstract: New developments are making the area denser and more expensive. But residents say it’s still a friendly neighborhood where people want to settle down.
lead_paragraph: Edward Soloway was impressed by the quiet of the three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bathroom apartment that he and his wife, Marcie, found 26 years ago on Riverside Drive near West 94th Street. “It had double-paned windows,” he said. “You couldn’t hear a thing.”

headline: $1.7 Million Homes in Wisconsin, Arizona and New Jersey
abstract: A Tudor Revival home near Milwaukee, an adobe house in Scottsdale and a condominium in a 19th-century Jacobean-style estate in Princeton.
lead_paragraph: A village of about 6,600 people, 10 miles north of downtown Milwaukee, Fox Point was the home of affluent businessmen in the early 20th century; it was incorporated in 1926, two years before this house was built. The property is at the end of a road, with winter views of Lake Michigan. The Riverpoint Village Shopping Center, at the intersection of two highways, is two miles northwest, and Doctors Park, a green space and beachfront reserve, is a mile and a half north.

headline: Coronavirus in New York: The Latest
abstract: After a new case emerged in Westchester, the state and the city are testing for infections and tracking possible contacts.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Super Tuesday, Coronavirus, Supreme Court: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: 5 Takeaways From a Super Tuesday That Changed the Democratic Race
abstract: From Maine to California, the results clarified a race that is increasingly a two-person contest between Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: From Maine to California, the results clarified a race that is increasingly a two-person contest between Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders.

headline: How Super Tuesday Unfolded
abstract: Two different coalitions emerged in support of two very different candidates, turning the Democratic race into a two-person contest between Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Water Main Break Disrupts L Train, With Brooklyn-Manhattan Service Briefly Shut
abstract: The L train was shut down between Brooklyn and Manhattan  as crews worked to fix a water main break near the Bedford Avenue Station in Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: A water main break caused a major disruption on the L train subway line on Wednesday, forcing transit officials to briefly shut service between Brooklyn and Manhattan and upending the morning commute for thousands of people.

headline: That Didn’t Take Long
abstract: Markets rose after the Fed cut rates, for 15 minutes.
lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: On Politics: Biden’s Big Comeback
abstract: The race suddenly narrows, and Sanders faces a major challenge: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: The Dallas County Young Democrats hosted a Super Tuesday results watch party at the Texas Theater in Dallas.

headline: Super Tuesday Is Over. What Just Happened?
abstract: Joe Biden had a strong showing, Bernie Sanders picked up the biggest prize of the night, California, and Michael Bloomberg dropped out. Alex Burns, a Times political reporter, lays out what happened, and what it means for Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden had a strong showing, Bernie Sanders picked up the biggest prize of the night, California, and Michael Bloomberg dropped out. Alex Burns, a Times political reporter, lays out what happened, and what it means for Democrats.

headline: Are You a Good Person?
abstract: What makes someone a good person? Do you strive to be one?
lead_paragraph: Has anyone ever said that you were a good person? Is being good something you strive to be or aspire toward?

headline: Why Does My Kid Prefer My Partner?
abstract: Rude.
lead_paragraph: A lot of parenting questions boil down to: Is this a thing, or is something wrong? We’re doing an occasional series explaining why certain things seem to happen to your kid (or to your body or to your relationships) as your child grows. This week, we’re talking about when children prefer one parent to the other. Read previous “Is this a thing?” newsletters here. If you have a question for a future “Is this a thing?” email us.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘5 Takeaways From a Super Tuesday That Changed the Democratic Race’
abstract: In this lesson, students analyze and react to the results of the biggest day of the Democratic presidential campaign. We then invite them to share evidence-based predictions for the future of the race.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “5 Takeaways From a Super Tuesday That Changed the Democratic Race”

headline: Long Lines and a Surge for Sanders
abstract: Wednesday: What to know about what happened on Super Tuesday in California.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ‘The Way Back’ Review: Seeking Redemption on the Basketball Court
abstract: Ben Affleck stars in this film that has the outward trappings of an inspirational sports drama, but is primarily a recovery movie.
lead_paragraph: The sunlight over Los Angeles looks unusually gray and muted throughout “The Way Back,” set largely in the isolated coastal neighborhood of San Pedro, where, in the late 1920s, homes toppled into the ocean. Although “The Way Back” takes place in the present, a sense of disordered lives pervades this tough-minded studio film, which has the outward trappings of an inspirational sports drama but is primarily a recovery movie. The star, Ben Affleck, has been open about drawing on his own experiences with drinking for the role.

headline: Cover Story: The Forward March of Men’s Fashion
abstract: Utilitarian pieces and bondage-inspired accessories make for a radical new look, conferring strength in a harsh world.
lead_paragraph: The stylist Ibrahim Kamara has spent some time considering alternate realities. His work, which incorporates both current high-fashion looks and pieces from his personal collection (some of them are even sourced from dumpster dives), often weaves together what’s traditionally termed masculine and feminine; as part of 2026, a project with the South African photographer Kristin-Lee Moolman that appeared in a group exhibition at Somerset House in 2016, he imagined how men’s wear might reflect changing attitudes about masculinity a decade later. For the cover of T’s spring Men’s Fashion issue, Kamara partnered with the photography duo Mert Alas and Marcus Piggott to conjure a hauntingly dissonant landscape. They imagined an apocalyptic wasteland where delicate decorative accents — like floral headpieces and billowing sleeves — and bondage-inflected leather and metal hardware come together with hardy utilitarian underpinnings to create something radical and new.

headline: Spectacular Views on St. John
abstract: This three-bedroom mountainside house in the U.S. Virgin Islands is on the market for $1.65 million.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom mountainside house in the U.S. Virgin Islands is on the market for $1.65 million.

headline: House Hunting on St. John: A Mountain Perch for $1.65 Million
abstract: After two hurricanes in 2017, the tiny U.S. Virgin Island has seen sales rebound, although the priciest homes are the slowest to move.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bathroom house sits on Bordeaux Mountain, just outside the boundaries of Virgin Islands National Park, on the island of St. John in the U.S. Virgin Islands.

headline: 9 New Cases of Coronavirus in N.Y., All Connected to Westchester Man
abstract: New Jersey announces its first case, and officials in both states scramble to trace the spread of the virus.
lead_paragraph: Just a day after a Westchester County man was confirmed as New York’s second case of the new coronavirus, the authorities revealed on Wednesday just how readily it was spreading, saying that nine people connected to the man had all tested positive.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Had a Good Run. Maybe Next Time, Ladies.
abstract: So much for the most diverse presidential field in history.
lead_paragraph: Update: Elizabeth Warren is planning to drop out of the presidential race on Thursday.

headline: I Was a Teenage Riverdancer
abstract: As the “Riverdance” 25th-anniversary tour approaches New York, a critic takes stock of her nearly lifelong relationship with the Irish dance extravaganza.
lead_paragraph: When the question “what do you do?” comes up with people I’ve just met, I know it won’t be long before I need to make a delicate calculation. I usually explain that I’m a dance critic, and that I used to dance professionally.

headline: All In on the Milwaukee Bucks, Still
abstract: In this week’s newsletter, Marc Stein is reporting from London on soccer, the Bucks and the only five teams with, he says, a real chance at a championship this season.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: When the Show Must Go On, Even Amid a Coronavirus Outbreak
abstract: Learning to perform without live audiences, or sometimes even theaters, as artists adapt to trying circumstances.
lead_paragraph: Venice’s ornate opera house, La Fenice, has survived floods and been rebuilt after devastating fires. So it was determined to keep going after the coronavirus forced it to cancel its performances: This week a string quartet gathered in the empty, eerily silent theater and played Beethoven, streaming the concert online and winning an ovation of handclap emojis.

headline: Bloomberg Endorses Biden as Sanders Laments Turnout of Younger Voters
abstract: After Mr. Biden’s big wins on Super Tuesday Mr. Bloomberg endorsed him and said that he planned to remain involved in the 2020 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg dropped out of the presidential race and backed Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday, throwing the financial might of the Democratic Party’s biggest benefactor behind the former vice president’s campaign as Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont vowed to wage a long battle for the nomination.

headline: A Tornado Decimated North Nashville. The Rebuilding May Destroy Its Soul.
abstract: A devastating tornado in 1998 transformed East Nashville and forced many African-American residents to relocate. Now, North Nashville residents fear the same will happen to them.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Adia Victoria huddled with her cat under the covers in the North Nashville home she shares with her mother, her ears popping as a tornado roared across their neighborhood, among the oldest in this booming city.

headline: How to Cook Fake Meat
abstract: J. Kenji López-Alt has looked back on two-and-a-half years of experimentation with plant-based protein mixes, and has brought back three recipes: a burger, a kebab and chili.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. J. Kenji López-Alt has a fascinating story on the cover of The Times’s food section this week, a look back at his two-and-a-half years of experimentation with cooking plant-based protein mixes designed to taste, look and feel like ground meat. Vegan meat, he calls this stuff, made mostly by two companies, Impossible Foods and Beyond Meat.

headline: Louvre Reopens, but the Crowd Will Have to Control Itself
abstract: Employees returned on Wednesday after a three-day closure over coronavirus fears. But the guards won’t move around to maintain order in the room where the Mona Lisa hangs.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The line of around 600 people outside the Louvre on Wednesday was a swirl of rumor, with people wondering if the world’s most-visited museum would open after a three-day closure. Since Sunday, the Louvre’s staff had been refusing to work, fearful they might catch the coronavirus from someone among the museum’s more than 30,000 daily visitors.

headline: ‘When Can We Go to School?’ Nearly 300 Million Children Are Missing Class
abstract: The global scale and speed of the educational disruption from the coronavirus epidemic is “unparalleled,” the United Nations said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The coronavirus epidemic has reached deeper into daily life across the world, with a sweeping shutdown of all schools in Italy, a suspension of classes in India’s capital and warnings of school closures in the United States, intensifying the educational upheaval of nearly 300 million students globally.

headline: Review: ‘Devs’ Is a Cold and Beautiful Machine
abstract: The sci-fi director Alex Garland constructs a tech thriller in his first series, which accents both his strengths and weaknesses.
lead_paragraph: Forest (Nick Offerman) is a know-it-all. That’s not to say that he’s a polymath, or wise, or even especially well-informed. Forest is a tech mogul, and his project is building a computer that uses the principle of determinism — that everything that happens is physically foreordained — to calculate the cause and outcome of any event in the universe. Its function is literally to Know. It. All.

headline: Deadlocked After 3 Elections, Israel Seeks Ways to Avert a 4th
abstract: The prospect of yet another failure to form a government raises questions about the functioning of Israeli democracy and has lit a fire under politicians, who are desperate to avoid further stalemate.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — After three brutal campaigns, three elections and three failed attempts at forming a government, Israel now finds itself right back where it was over a year ago: deadlocked over the fate of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: Why Joe Biden Is Winning
abstract: It’s a version of John McCain in 2008.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: How Floral Arrangements Began to Take Over the Table — and the Entire Room
abstract: In recent years, once-tidy bouquets have become boundless, their diverse tangles of blooms, branches and weeds looking ever more like art installations.
lead_paragraph: A plate is dually useful, holding food or church collections, and so, too, is the cup, at once a trophy and a grail. But the vase has always simply held flowers, the vessel and its mate inseparable. Inside, greens stand upright, just as they grow in the fields, the reservoir of water at the bottom a magic trick that prolongs the illusion of life.

headline: London Book Fair Canceled Over Coronavirus Fears
abstract: The annual publishing event was scheduled to begin next week, with more than 25,000 expected to attend.
lead_paragraph: The London Book Fair, one of the publishing industry’s biggest international events of the year, was canceled on Wednesday because of concerns related to the coronavirus in Europe.

headline: Biden’s Delegate Lead Is Small, but Could Be Hard to Overcome
abstract: Bernie Sanders had an advantage on Super Tuesday he will not see again: many early votes cast before moderates coalesced around one candidate.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden not only reclaimed his status as a front-runner on Super Tuesday, but his victories also gave him a clear path to amassing enough delegates to clinch the nomination by the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Can You Really Hire a Hit Man on the Dark Web?
abstract: A collection of online stores offer murder for pay. Researchers say they are scams, but people who want someone dead aren’t listening.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On a website called Azerbaijani Eagles, you can commission a murder for $5,000. The site Slayers Hitmen provides more options, with a beating going for $2,000. Death by torture costs $50,000.

headline: The Unlikely Life of a Socialist Activist Resonates a Century Later
abstract: In “Rebel Cinderella,” Adam Hochschild writes about the life of Rose Pastor Stokes, whose life and activism coincided with the roiling decades of the early 20th century.
lead_paragraph: She was an impoverished Jewish immigrant from Russia who had started working in a cigar factory at the age of 11; he was the scion of an old-money Episcopalian family who enjoyed a mansion on Madison Avenue and a weekend house with a bowling alley.

headline: A ‘Blue Great Wall’ Divides a City as It Battles the Coronavirus
abstract: With a name evoking another era, the blue sheets of metal also tell a tale of China’s growth — and of the steep bills coming due.
lead_paragraph: They call it the “Blue Great Wall.”

headline: An Undiplomatic Diplomat Wins Power in Trump’s Washington
abstract: Richard Grenell, prone to pique and caustic tweets, is running the intelligence agencies in an acting capacity. He could be there for a while.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For a diplomat, Richard Grenell has a remarkable record of being undiplomatic.

headline: ‘Sorry We Missed You’ Review: The Human Toll of That One-Click Buy
abstract: In this Ken Loach film, a British family that’s barely getting by faces the peril that is the gig economy.
lead_paragraph: I’ll never forget the pleading that goes on in “Sorry We Missed You.” It’s desperate but futile. Life goes on, they say. So does the global marketplace. If you order a shower curtain or diapers or a new phone, you probably need it yesterday. Ken Loach’s brutally moving agitprop drama demands a thought be spared for the anonymous souls who drop this stuff off. That shower curtain might be the death of them.

headline: Tornadoes Cut a Swath Through Nashville’s Restaurant Scene
abstract: As many businesses dig out, others are pitching in to help.
lead_paragraph: Freddy Schwenk woke up at 2 on Tuesday morning to a barrage of texts and calls: people asking if he was safe, people asking if he knew what had happened. And then photographs of Geist, a bar and restaurant in Nashville’s Germantown neighborhood where he is the managing partner.

headline: She Was Excited for a New School. Then the Anti-Semitic ‘Jokes’ Started.
abstract: First, a deeply offensive photo. Three students’ college plans were soon derailed, and a community closed ranks.
lead_paragraph: The letters stretch over 30 feet, written into the sand on a beach in New Jersey. The teenager in the photo rests casually on his side above the words, smiling, his head propped up in his hand.

headline: Climate Change Affected Australia’s Wildfires, Scientists Confirm
abstract: Human-caused climate change had an impact on Australia’s wildfires, a new attribution study confirms. The 30 percent figure they calculated is a minimum.
