headline: António Guterres Wants Gender Parity at the U.N. It May Take Time.
abstract: We sat down with the United Nations secretary general to talk about how one wrests a patriarchal organization into the future.
lead_paragraph: [In Her Words is available as a newsletter. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox.]

headline: When Coronavirus Quarantine Is Class Warfare
abstract: A pandemic offers a great way to examine American class inequities.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a big week for what I refer to as “Hermit Tech.” Stock in technology companies that facilitate working from home have soared in a spiraling market otherwise anxious by an impending coronavirus pandemic. Netflix is preparing for the server strain of the bored but quarantined masses. Expensive Peloton stationary bikes and streaming workout services are seeing substantial spikes in interest. Tech guides are popping up suggesting everything from noise-canceling headphones, Wi-Fi signal boosters, and productivity hacks for families who’ll need to make close quarters work and life livable.

headline: As Supreme Court Mulls Dreamers, Kushner Revives Immigration Plan
abstract: The president’s son-in-law is hoping that a looming ruling will spur interest in his proposal, which is similar to one he tried to push last year.
lead_paragraph: [Read more on the Supreme Court’s decision on President Trump and DACA.]

headline: Brazen Shooting From a Window Terrifies Manhattan Neighborhood
abstract: Chaos erupted, and passers-by ran for cover, when the police warned about a gunman firing from above. One man was shot in the face.
lead_paragraph: Juan Manuel Gonzalez was looking for parking on a sunny, quiet street in Upper Manhattan when the sound of three gunshots startled him.

headline: Tracking Trump’s Claims on the Threat From Coronavirus
abstract: President Trump has made a series of rosy — and sometimes false — statements on the virus and the U.S. response.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has made a series of rosy — and sometimes false — claims about the coronavirus, including the risks to Americans and how his administration is responding.

headline: I Was Part of the Weather Underground. Violence Is Not the Answer.
abstract: Fifty years ago, a deadly explosion in Greenwich Village forced me to confront our warped sense of morality.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, on March 6, 1970, an explosion destroyed a townhouse on West 11th Street in New York’s Greenwich Village. Three people — Terry Robbins, 22, Ted Gold, 22, and Diana Oughton, 28, all close friends of mine — were obliterated when bombs they were making exploded prematurely. Two others, Kathy Boudin, 26, and Cathlyn Wilkerson, 25, escaped from the rubble.

headline: Mika Zibanejad’s 5 Goals for the Rangers Help Bring the Playoffs Into View
abstract: After a stunning 6-5 overtime win on Thursday, the Rangers and their young core find themselves within striking distance of the team’s first postseason berth since 2017.
lead_paragraph: Mika Zibanejad on Thursday night became the third Ranger ever to score five goals in a game, definitively pulling his team into the swirl of a playoff race.

headline: ‘It’s Pure Panic’: A Wrenching Wait at Nursing Home Where Coronavirus Took Hold
abstract: Cut off from their relatives inside a virus-stricken nursing center, families are frantically searching for help and basic information.
lead_paragraph: KIRKLAND, Wash. — The hardest day of Debbie de los Angeles’s life had been the day she put her mother into a nursing home. That was before coronavirus.

headline: Elizabeth Warren and the Curse of ‘Electability’
abstract: There are many reasons for Warren dropping out. But a key one may have been the near-constant refrains about her “electability.”
lead_paragraph: [In Her Words is available as a newsletter. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox.]

headline: Biden Looks to Expand Staff as Bloomberg Weighs How to Help Him
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s team is eager to tap into the enormous pool of Democratic talent now available. Some support could come from Michael Bloomberg’s vast resources.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr., emboldened by his unexpectedly strong Super Tuesday performance and flush with cash, is moving to hire new aides who he hopes can quickly help him secure the Democratic presidential nomination and then guide him through the general election.

headline: Was It Always Going to Be the Last Men Standing?
abstract: For Elizabeth Warren, the historic number of women in the 2020 field and the Democrats who supported them, the question will linger.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the end, the pink wave carried two white men ashore.

headline: Yankees’ Aaron Judge on Injuries: ‘Tough Trying to Describe What I’m Feeling’
abstract: Judge publicly discussed his shoulder and chest muscle injuries for the first time, but was at a loss to explain what exactly had gone wrong.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — A frustrated Aaron Judge on Thursday publicly discussed his shoulder and chest muscle injuries for the first time, but was unable to provide much clarity about what is causing his discomfort.

headline: As Coronavirus Spreads, Olympics Face Ticking Clock and a Tough Call
abstract: During a conference call with the World Health Organization last week, sports federations discussed holding the Tokyo Games without fans.
lead_paragraph: It is the option that nobody in the Olympic movement wants to talk about, but it is the one staring everyone in the face: a Tokyo Games this summer with no fans, just 10,000 athletes competing in front of seas of empty seats.

headline: Behind the Story: Searching for Sanders in a Russian Archive
abstract: An obscurely named entry, discovered after days of searching, offered up an unexplored trove of material.
lead_paragraph: As Bernie Sanders became one of the front-runners in the presidential race, journalists in the Moscow bureau of The New York Times began thinking about the days he spent in the Soviet Union in 1988, when he was the mayor of Burlington, Vt.

headline: Excerpts from the Sanders Files in a Russian Archive
abstract: Here are five excerpts from an 89-page Soviet-era file that tracked the efforts made by Bernie Sanders in the 1980s to find a sister city in Russia for Burlington, Vt.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times reviewed 89 pages of letters, telegrams and internal Soviet government documents revealing in new detail the extent of Bernie Sanders’s effort in the late 1980s to establish sister-city ties between Burlington, Vt., and a city in the Soviet Union.

headline: As Bernie Sanders Pushed for Closer Ties, Soviet Union Spotted Opportunity
abstract: Previously unseen documents from a Soviet archive show how hard Mr. Sanders worked to find a sister city in Russia when he was a mayor in the 1980s. Moscow saw a chance for propaganda.
lead_paragraph: YAROSLAVL, Russia — The mayor of Burlington, Vt., wrote to a Soviet counterpart in a provincial city that he wanted the United States and the Soviet Union to “live together as friends.”

headline: In Biden’s Hometown, Trump Says He’s Ready to Face Off Against Him
abstract: The president, at an event hosted by Fox News, ridiculed the former vice president and said he was shifting his focus from Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: SCRANTON, Pa. — President Trump came to Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s hometown on Thursday and said he was prepared to run against the former Democratic vice president in November, changing gears after being “mentally” ready to take on Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont.

headline: Armory Show to Trade Piers for the Javits Center
abstract: The next edition of the art fair will take place at the Javits in September, 2021.
lead_paragraph: After 19 years at the Piers, the Armory Show will move to the Javits Center in 2021. The high-profile art fair, which opened its 2020 edition earlier this week, has also been rescheduled for the fall, with the start of the galleries’ art season. The next show will take place Sept. 9 through Sept. 12, 2021.

headline: Fed Official Says Central Bankers Are Aligned in Coronavirus Response
abstract: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York president, John C. Williams, said central banks were working in tandem to tackle the global economic threat.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York president, John C. Williams, made clear on Thursday evening that officials viewed the emergency rate cut they approved earlier this week as part of an international push to cushion the economy as the coronavirus threatens global growth.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: A little? A lot? This weekend offers time travel, true crime and an underappreciated mini-series.
lead_paragraph: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every week for new suggestions on what to watch.

headline: ‘It’s a Weird Feeling’: Seattle Hunkers Down Amid Coronavirus Outbreak
abstract: County officials have urged people to telecommute. Streets were quieter than usual. Coffee sales dropped.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Just after dawn on Thursday morning, a Microsoft shuttle bus idled at its regular stop in North Seattle — but no passengers were there to board.

headline: ‘Girl From the North Country’ Review: Bob Dylan’s Amazing Grace
abstract: This ravishing and singular musical, written and directed by Conor McPherson, hears America singing — Dylan — during the Great Depression.
lead_paragraph: A nation is broken. Life savings have vanished overnight. Home as a place you thought you would live forever no longer exists. People don’t so much connect as collide, even members of the same family. And it seems like winter is never going to end.

headline: Sets Out on the Highway
abstract: Caitlin Reid’s puzzle gets our motors running.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — The first themeless crossword in our week of puzzles made by women is by the constructor Caitlin Reid, and it made me smile from ear to ear. That’s not even a pun. I was really entertained.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Two-Man Race? Women Aren’t Surprised
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, March 6, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “One of the hardest parts of this is all those little girls who are going to have to wait four more years.”

headline: Corrections: March 6, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, March 6, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about a record number of parliamentary seats won by Arab-led parties in Israel’s election referred incorrectly to the number of Israelis who are of Arab ethnicity. It is about one in five, not two in five. The article also misstated Arab turnout in Israeli elections. It fell below 50 percent in the April election, but it is not the case that turnout has been below that level historically.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Coronavirus, Syria, Elizabeth Warren: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The number of new coronavirus cases rose sharply in the U.S. and Europe on Thursday, as stocks fell on both sides of the Atlantic and Britain and Switzerland reported their first fatalities.

headline: ‘I’m Gutted’: An Institution Closes, Testing Australian Media
abstract: The announcement that the Australian Associated Press was closing shocked journalists, who called it another blow to public interest and transparency in the country.
lead_paragraph: The Australian Associated Press said this week that it will be closing its doors in June, ending an 85-year history in which the national news organization became known for fair coverage and its fast response to breaking news.

headline: He Saved His Last Lesson for Me
abstract: Company policy forbade her from getting personal with her online students. Whoops.
lead_paragraph: “Can you see and hear me OK?” I said for at least the eighth time that day.

headline: Red Space Lettuce Might Feed Red Planet Astronauts
abstract: Leafy vegetables grown by astronauts aboard the International Space Station were as healthful as lettuce on Earth, a study found.
lead_paragraph: When astronauts head for Mars, perhaps sometime in the 2030s, there is a good chance that they will be growing their own vegetables to eat along the way.

headline: Loaded Gun Found Smuggled Into Jail Where Jeffrey Epstein Killed Himself
abstract: The discovery came during a weeklong lockdown at the Manhattan jail, which has faced scrutiny since the disgraced financier’s suicide.
lead_paragraph: Federal investigators on Thursday found a loaded gun that had been smuggled into the Manhattan jail where the financier Jeffrey Epstein hanged himself last summer while awaiting trial on sex-trafficking charges, officials said.

headline: In the U.S., More Than 300 Coronavirus Cases Are Confirmed
abstract: Stocks fell as Europe and the U.S. struggled to contain the virus, while the Chinese province at the center of the outbreak reported no new infections outside its capital, Wuhan.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. Read about the latest developments in the coronavirus epidemic here.]

headline: Quinnen Williams of the Jets Is Arrested on Weapons Charge at La Guardia
abstract: The authorities said that the defensive lineman did not have a New York permit for an unloaded pistol found in his checked luggage.
lead_paragraph: Quinnen Williams, a defensive lineman for the Jets who was the third player chosen in last year’s N.F.L. draft, was arrested on a weapons possession charge on Thursday night while trying to board a flight at La Guardia Airport, the authorities said.

headline: Why Is Europe So Islamophobic?
abstract: The attacks don’t come from nowhere.
lead_paragraph: We live in a time of Islamophobia.

headline: ‘Like Licking an Ashtray’: Fires’ Invisible Threat to Australia’s Wines
abstract: The smoke produced by the blazes that ravaged the country may ruin entire vintages, but detecting contamination is a guessing game.
lead_paragraph: HUNTER VALLEY, Australia — The hills are lush and green, the grapes plump and ripe. But one bite of this famed valley’s most prized product reveals a winemaker’s worst nightmare.

headline: Word + Quiz: chiaroscuro
abstract: This word has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Late Night Says Elizabeth Warren ‘Realized She Was Overqualified’
abstract: Jimmy Fallon can’t blame the senator for not wanting to shake people’s hands right now. Stephen Colbert says her departure proves America can’t have nice things.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Mall Rats
abstract: Do you enjoy going to the mall?
lead_paragraph: For decades, shopping malls were a bustling gathering place for millions of Americans. But 21st-century shopping habits have had a deteriorative effect on them, according to a recent Times article that reports on a spate of retail store closings nationwide.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Hillary’ and ‘Spenser Confidential’
abstract: A four-part documentary about Hillary Clinton debuts on Hulu. And an action-comedy with Mark Wahlberg hits Netflix.
lead_paragraph: HILLARY Stream on Hulu. “We want to hear your story, unvarnished, beginning to end,” the filmmaker Nanette Burstein tells Hillary Clinton at the start of this documentary. “Hillary” relays that story in four parts, beginning with her path from a childhood in the Chicago suburbs to becoming the first lady of Arkansas in the early 1980s. Subsequent installments cover her time as the first lady of the United States, as a United States senator and ultimately as a presidential candidate. The documentary places interviews with Bill Clinton and the journalist Joe Klein, among others, alongside archival footage, thought it’s built largely around Burstein’s interviews with Clinton herself. The first question: “Do you feel frustrated that you’ve been in public life for 30 years, yet people feel that they don’t know who you are, that you seem inauthentic?” (It surely can’t be a spoiler to reveal that Clinton’s answer is yes.)

headline: The Corner of N.Y.C. That’s Overrun by Deer, Turkeys and Feral Cats
abstract: Some Staten Island residents would like to hunt deer to reduce their numbers, but the city is pushing a vasectomy program.
lead_paragraph: You would think that Staten Island has plenty of room to share space with wildlife.

headline: How a Positive Thinker Took Swarthmore From Nowhere to No. 1
abstract: Coach Landry Kosmalski told his recruits that the lowly Division III basketball team would become one of the nation’s best. “I’d say it’s come true,” one of his seniors said.
lead_paragraph: SWARTHMORE, Pa. — A handwritten letter from Landry Kosmalski, the Swarthmore College men’s basketball coach, has been framed and hanging in Nate Shafer’s bedroom at his family’s home in McLean, Va., since he received it in high school.

headline: ‘Spenser Confidential’ Review: Good Guy P.I.
abstract: The movie may be an easily forgettable action comedy, but as a Mark Wahlberg vehicle it is also easily watchable.
lead_paragraph: For their fifth movie together, the director Peter Berg and the star Mark Wahlberg have gone Netflix light. You could easily picture a future in which they alternate between theatrical releases like “Deepwater Horizon” and “Patriots Day,” and sequels to the breezy “Spenser Confidential.”

headline: News Quiz: Coronavirus, Super Tuesday, Israel
abstract: Did you follow the headlines this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the headlines this week?

headline: Gunmen Kill Dozens at Event Attended by Afghan Politicians
abstract: At least 32 civilians were killed at a politically tense time in the country, just days after the United States and the Taliban signed a deal for American troops to withdraw.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan —  Two gunmen opened fire on a crowded event in Kabul attended by the opposition leader Abdullah Abdullah on Friday, and officials said at least 32 civilians were killed and dozens wounded. The attackers struck Afghanistan’s capital less than a week after the United States and the Taliban signed an agreement aimed at ending the 18-year-old war.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘When Can We Go to School?’ Nearly 300 Million Children Are Missing Class.
abstract: In this lesson, students will understand the impact of the coronavirus on students around the world.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “When Can We Go to School?” Nearly 300 Million Children Are Missing Class, by Vivian Wang and Makiko Inoue

headline: Stocks and Bond Yields Sink, Capping a Week of Wild Trading
abstract: Stocks fell and investors rushed to the safety of government bonds.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street was gripped by another wave of worry over the spreading coronavirus on Friday. Stocks tumbled, investors rushed into the safety of government bonds, and oil prices nose-dived.

headline: China Pushes Back as Coronavirus Crisis Damages Its Image
abstract: The country is appealing for sympathy while attacking those who blame its leadership for making the situation worse.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When the coronavirus epidemic began its relentless march around the world, China’s diplomats reacted harshly toward countries that shut their borders, canceled flights or otherwise restricted travel.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Working-Class Life Is Killing Americans, in Charts
abstract: It’s not just older Americans dying of “despair.”
lead_paragraph: It’s not just older Americans dying of “despair.”

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Women’s Work’ and ‘What You Have Heard Is True’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: WOMEN’S WORK: A Personal Reckoning With Labor, Motherhood, and Privilege, by Megan K. Stack. (Anchor, 336 pp., $16.95.) Stack, a former international correspondent for The Los Angeles Times, explores her decision to employ Chinese and Indian women to care for her children, traveling to visit the women in their difficult home environments. “Stack is unflinching in her account,” our reviewer, Lauren Hilgers, wrote.

headline: In Mexico, Women Break the Silence Against Femicide
abstract: Most women’s attackers remain free while the Mexican government does next to nothing to prevent and punish gender violence.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — María de Jesús Jaime Zamudio, also known as Marichuy, died a week after falling from the fifth floor of the building in Mexico City she lived in, in the night between Jan. 15 and 16, 2016. Her mother, Yesenia Zamudio, has never believed the fall was an accident or a suicide attempt, as the local authorities suggested at the time of the tragedy. For the past four years she has insisted that her daughter was murdered.

headline: What Used to Be, and What Is
abstract: My mother will tell you she doesn’t miss New York, but the past wraps the present with its ribbons.
lead_paragraph: My mother and I returned to her childhood apartment in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, in 2015. It had been 52 years since she moved away. She will tell you she doesn’t miss New York. She will tell you she has survived because she adapts, and that the past belongs in the past, no matter that I keep telling her the past wraps the present with its ribbons.

headline: Would You Allow an Ex-Prisoner to Live With You?
abstract: A new program pairs the recently incarcerated with homeowners. Would you be willing to open your home?
lead_paragraph: Do you believe that people who have committed a crime deserve a second chance?

headline: I’m Going to Die. I May as Well Be Cheerful About It.
abstract: While death is inevitable, our attitude about it is not.
lead_paragraph: Generally, I don’t think about death during the day. My schedule is full, and I focus on what is right before my eyes. It’s usually only when I go to funerals that I reflect upon deaths past, present and future; most of the time I think about life. Still, about once a month I wake in the night and know with absolute clarity that I will soon be gone.

headline: The Job of a Moscow Correspondent: Putin, Politics and Frozen Reindeer Meat
abstract: Anton Troianovski has traveled to the far reaches of the Russian Arctic to better understand life across the country’s 11 time zones.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: J.B. Smoove of ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’ Shops the Diamond District
abstract: Larry David’s motor-mouthed television roommate talks apocalypse, past lives and pocket watches.
lead_paragraph: On HBO’s “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” Larry David plays himself. Ted Danson plays himself. Richard Lewis plays himself. So it’s easy to assume that J.B. Smoove, who plays Leon, Larry’s motor-mouthed, freeloading roommate, plays himself, or at least a close facsimile.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Coronavirus, Exercise and Prostate Cancer
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: He Played With Charlie Parker. For $15 He’ll Play With You
abstract: Barry Harris has been offering a weekly jazz workshop since the 1970s. Everybody’s welcome, but they’d better love bebop.
lead_paragraph: If you want a spot near the maestro at Barry Harris’s jazz workshop, you’re going to have to fight for it.

headline: Bernie Sanders Might Have a Michigan Problem
abstract: An analysis of how states have voted so far, particularly white voters, shows he’s vulnerable to a reversal of his striking victory there in 2016.
lead_paragraph: It seems clear that Bernie Sanders needs to change the fundamental trajectory of the Democratic primary over the coming 12 days. And at first glance, the next contests — the states voting Tuesday — would seem to offer a promising set of opportunities. Among them is Michigan, where he posted the signature victory of his 2016 bid.

headline: Coronavirus School Closings: Don’t Wait Until It’s Too Late
abstract: History teaches us that keeping children at home early in an outbreak can save lives.
lead_paragraph: [This article is part of the developing coronavirus coverage, and may be outdated. Go here for the latest on the coronavirus.]

headline: In ‘Hillary,’ a Political Warrior Weighed Down by Her Armor
abstract: A four-part documentary about Hillary Clinton revisits some much-told history but has insight about the public fixation on her.
lead_paragraph: During the 2016 election, the director Nanette Burstein got exclusive behind-the-scenes access to the campaign of the candidate everyone knew would be the first female president of the United States, Hillary Clinton. So it’s tempting to say that “Hillary,” the four-part documentary that arrives on Hulu Friday, is one more in the long list of works that plays much differently than intended before Nov. 8, 2016.

headline: The Tax Code Is Overtaxed
abstract: The I.R.S. has become the de facto administrator of a startling number of social welfare programs.
lead_paragraph: When a working-class divorced couple takes turns caring for the kids, who deserves a hefty income subsidy to help offset the cost?

headline: How Iran Completely and Utterly Botched Its Response to the Coronavirus
abstract: We were doctors in the Iranian health system for years. This is what happens when you make health policy subservient to politics.
lead_paragraph: Iran has one of the very best health care systems in the Middle East, a decentralized system with thousands of medical centers across the country that provide primary, secondary and tertiary care with an effective referral system. We worked as doctors in that system for years.

headline: F.D.A. Bans School Electric Shock Devices
abstract: The ban is national, but it is squarely targeted at a single school in Massachusetts that has been using electric shocks to condition students’ behavior for decades.
lead_paragraph: In a rare and sweeping decision, the Food and Drug Administration announced this week that it was banning the use of electric shock devices to correct self-harming or aggressive behavior.

headline: U.S. Added 273,000 Jobs in February Before Coronavirus Spread Widely
abstract: The monthly employment report left unanswered questions about the potential economic impact of the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: For the second month in a row, the economy churned out a blockbuster number of jobs, the government reported Friday, an impressive performance in an era of slow-and-steady employment growth.

headline: Why the Coronavirus Could Threaten the U.S. Economy Even More Than China’s
abstract: If people stop traveling and going to the dentist, the gym or even March Madness basketball games, the impact could be enormous, an economist says.
lead_paragraph: After a string of deaths, some heart-stopping plunges in the stock market and an emergency rate cut by the Federal Reserve, there is reason to be concerned about the ultimate economic impact of the coronavirus in the United States.

headline: This Black Hole Blew a Hole in the Cosmos
abstract: The galaxy cluster Ophiuchus was doing just fine until WISEA J171227.81-232210.7 — a black hole several billion times as massive as our sun — burped on it.
lead_paragraph: If there were ever sentient beings in the Ophiuchus cluster, a faraway conglomeration of galaxies in the southern sky, they are long gone. A few hundred million years ago, a mighty cosmic storm swept through that region of space. Hot gas suffuses the cluster, but the storm blew a crater through it more than a million light-years wide, leaving just a near-vacuum, a nattering haze of ultrahot electrical particles.

headline: Top Coronavirus Official for U.S. Has Fought an Epidemic Before
abstract: Dr. Deborah Birx was appointed by President Barack Obama in 2014 to lead the government's fight against the global AIDS epidemic. Now she is coordinating the response to the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the spring of 1983, even before the virus that causes AIDS had a name, a young Army doctor named Deborah L. Birx suffered excessive bleeding while giving birth. Moments before she passed out from pain, she screamed an order at her husband: “Do not let them give me blood!”

headline: How Brian and Jamie Stelter, News Anchors, Spend Their Sundays
abstract: With a toddler, an infant, and alarm clocks going off at the wee hours of the morning, sleep rules abound.
lead_paragraph: The married media duo Jamie and Brian Stelter reach distinct audiences. As the traffic anchor and a “Mornings on 1” co-host at NY1, Ms. Stelter, 38, wakes New Yorkers up and helps them navigate traffic snarls. And as the chief media correspondent for CNN Worldwide and the anchor of CNN’s “Reliable Sources” on Sunday mornings, Mr. Stelter, 34, breaks down the week’s top stories for a global viewership.

headline: It Takes Two to Tango
abstract: Grab a good book and get out on the dance floor.

headline: No Cell Signal, No Wi-Fi, No Problem. Growing Up Inside America’s ‘Quiet Zone’
abstract: Green Bank, W.Va., is home to a telescope so large that it requires near radio silence to operate, a technological restriction that has created a unique kind of modern childhood.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BANK, W.Va. — Viral dance memes and dance challenges on TikTok largely bypass Green Bank, W.Va. So do viral sensations like augmented reality filters on Snapchat and Instagram.

headline: What Would a World Without Prisons Look Like?
abstract: The architect Deanna Van Buren designs civic spaces that are healing alternatives to correctional facilities.
lead_paragraph: Vicente Martinez, 18, was apprehensive the first time he visited the former drug house in Syracuse, N.Y. The building had been transformed into the Center for Court Innovation’s peacemaking program, where issues can bubble up and be resolved outside of the traditional criminal justice system. “I was messing up a lot,” Mr. Martinez recalled of his two previous stints in jail for driving a stolen vehicle across county lines. “I was doing dumb kid’s stuff.”

headline: The Neighborhood Name Game
abstract: Place names come and go — with help from (surprise!) the real estate industry — but a few that have stuck around offer a window onto the city’s past.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan, for all its charms, can sometimes fail the imagination.

headline: From Coughing Fits to Closings, Cultural World Girds for Coronavirus
abstract: Museums, theaters and concert halls in the United States are steeling themselves for fearful patrons, lighter crowds and possible government shutdowns.
lead_paragraph: Ushers in some theaters are wearing latex gloves. Museums are installing hand sanitizer dispensers as if they were pieces of art. Audience members are being told: If you have a cough, please, trade in your tickets and stay home.

headline: Trump’s Calamitous Coronavirus Response
abstract: A whole-of-government mobilization to protect the president’s ego.
lead_paragraph: Last month, after analyzing figures on epidemics since 1960, The Economist concluded that people die at a higher rate from such disease outbreaks in authoritarian countries than in democratic ones, even controlling for income levels.

headline: Anxiety in New York Over Coronavirus Spread
abstract: The number of cases in the state has doubled, and thousands of people in the city are being monitored in home quarantine.

headline: Coronavirus, Elizabeth Warren, Syria: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.

headline: With a 7-Hour Saga, Robert Lepage Returns to Safer Ground
abstract: The Canadian director’s “The Seven Streams of the River Ota” is set for a world tour, after his most recent productions were embroiled in debates about cultural appropriation.
lead_paragraph: After a tumultuous few years, the revered Canadian theater director Robert Lepage is returning to a tried-and-tested production.

headline: Bill Clinton Explains Monica Lewinsky Affair as ‘Managing My Anxieties’
abstract: Mr. Clinton was asked about the scandal for the Hulu documentary series “Hillary.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton, recalling the sex scandal that led to his impeachment in 1998, says in a new documentary series that his extramarital affair with Monica S. Lewinsky was a way of “managing my anxieties.”

headline: The Almost-Peace Deal
abstract: After more than a year of talks, the U.S. and the Taliban have signed an agreement to end the war in Afghanistan. But will it work?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Coronavirus Puts a Wrinkle in Wedding Industry
abstract: Some couples are cautiously moving ahead, while others are forced to delay their ‘I do’s’ for now.
lead_paragraph: JoAnn Gregoli, a 30-year veteran of wedding and event planning, has advice for couples with weddings on the horizon: don’t cancel because of the coronavirus, but instead, postpone.

headline: A ‘Dreamer’ Finds His Sense of Belonging
abstract: “I miss my son, and I wish I could meet Allison,” said the groom’s mother, through tears, from Bangladesh. “I hope that one day we can all be together.”
lead_paragraph: A few weeks after Fariaz Rabbani proposed to Allison Tyndall, he took her to a bank in Queens, where he opened a safe deposit box filled with jewelry once worn by his mother.

headline: Suicide Bombers Attack Near U.S. Embassy in Tunisia
abstract: Two assailants arrived by motorcycle and targeted a security patrol, killing a police officer, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Two suicide bombers blew themselves up near the United States Embassy in Tunis on Friday, killing one police officer and injuring four more and a civilian in the most serious attack to hit Tunisia in months.

headline: Boeing’s C.E.O. Throws His Predecessor Under the Plane
abstract: In a wide-ranging, eye-opening interview, David Calhoun, the plane maker’s new chief, took some direct shots at Dennis Muilenburg over the 737 Max crisis.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon is recovering from emergency heart surgery. More on that below. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

headline: On Politics: Warren’s Out but Not Down
abstract: Endorsement speculation, voter-desire divination: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: With her golden retriever, Bailey, in tow, Elizabeth Warren held a news conference on Thursday in front of her house in Cambridge, Mass., announcing her exit from the presidential race.

headline: In Las Vegas, the Home-Style Pizza Is an Everything Pie
abstract: The city has developed a thriving pizza scene, embracing the influence of outsiders who bring hometown ideas to a city without a pizza style of its own.
lead_paragraph: In a city with the Eiffel Tower, the Space Needle and an Egyptian pyramid all along the LED screen-lined Las Vegas Strip, it should be no surprise that seemingly every regional variety of pizza is available.

headline: City Pleads for More Coronavirus Tests as Cases Rise in New York
abstract: The city told the federal government that a shortage of tests for the virus had “impeded our ability to beat back this epidemic.”
lead_paragraph: [Update: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has declared a state of emergency in New York over the coronavirus.]

headline: On the Cliffs of Italy, a Fortress for Rent
abstract: Forte San Giorgio, dating to the 16th century, is the rare Italian monument in which you can stay overnight.
lead_paragraph: Sitting 500 feet above the sea, atop a cliff on Capraia, Italy — one of seven islands making up the Tuscan Archipelago — is a restored 16th-century fortress built to house Genoan soldiers. After hundreds of years of raids and takeovers by the French and British empires, Forte San Giorgio is a testament to a bygone era of both geopolitics and architecture: The property includes a 66-foot-tall watchtower and is surrounded on three sides by stone ramparts. It’s also the rare Italian monument in which you can now stay overnight, through the London-based villa-rental company the Thinking Traveller.

headline: Lies, Spies and Double Agents: On the Trail of Peter Nygard in the Bahamas
abstract: We switched hotel rooms every few days so no one could track us. A Courtyard Marriott worker gave me an alias.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Trump Says ‘People Have to Remain Calm’ Amid Coronavirus Outbreak
abstract: During a visit to the C.D.C., the president sought to play down the risk from the virus and said he would not be inclined to cancel events and travel except to infected areas.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — President Trump sought to play down the coronavirus outbreak on Friday and offered a vote of confidence to besieged federal health officials as infections spread further, markets tumbled again and the authorities scrambled to accelerate the availability of testing kits across the country.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Season 1, Episode 7 Recap: Will Riker Makes Pizza
abstract: In this week’s episode, Picard reunites with his old Number One and his trusted counselor, Deanna Troi.
lead_paragraph: This week’s “Star Trek: Picard” is less about the central story arc and more about taking stock of who Picard is at this point in his life, as well as his android friend. The series creators have said that the show should be viewed more as a character study than anything else. And who better to assess the captain than his former “Number One,” William Riker? And his former ship’s counselor, Deanna Troi, the Betazoid who can sense emotions?

headline: The Week in Tech: Welcome to the Age of Mandatory Videoconferencing
abstract: Telling employees to work from home. Bearing down on misinformation removal. Here is how the coronavirus is affecting the industry.
lead_paragraph: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: How Not to Become a Victim of Social Security Fraud Calls
abstract: Regulators report thousands of complaints about the calls. Here are some tips on protecting yourself, and your money.
lead_paragraph: You’ve probably received one: A recorded call warns of a problem with your Social Security number. To fix it and avoid legal action, you’re told, you must call back immediately — and pay up.

headline: Kenzo Takada’s Antique Artifacts
abstract: The designer, who founded the Kenzo label in 1970, relishes the storytelling powers of these ancient objects.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese designer Kenzo Takada first began collecting antiquities in the early 1990s while decorating his 14,000-square-foot townhouse in Paris’s Bastille neighborhood. The 81-year-old — who founded the fashion house Kenzo in 1970 and retired as its creative director in 1999 — is drawn to ancient statues, instruments, figurines and masks from Africa, Asia and Greece. “Once I started learning about these artifacts and the stories they told, I began to appreciate their history as much as their beauty as decorative objects,” he says. His collection has grown to include over 300 pieces, which he houses in a Haussmannian-style apartment beside the Seine, where he moved to in 2009. Takada sources many of his items from Japan and Hong Kong (he travels to Asia six times a year) and his favorite Paris antique shops. In January, the designer launched K三 (pronounced “K3”), a colorful home-décor line with Eastern influences that will introduce textiles, wallpaper, bedding, ceramics and rugs over the course of this year.

headline: Found in the Attic at Gage & Tollner: Historic Treasure
abstract: Decades-old menus, notes and letters are found in a crawl space just as the new owners are bringing the Brooklyn restaurant back to life.
lead_paragraph: For an individual, it’s almost a cliché of personal discovery: while poking around in Grandma’s attic, you stumble upon a trunk stuffed with long-lost family artifacts. But for a venerable old restaurant — particularly a defunct one carved up over the past 15 years by a costume jewelry store, a tattoo parlor and an Arby’s — such a find is markedly more surprising.

headline: What to Know About the Coronavirus Spread in California
abstract: Friday: Anxiety rose as more cases were discovered. Also: More election results; and a recommendation for finding an outdoor escape.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The Handshake Is on Hold
abstract: And so is the hookup. Here’s how some people were dealing with social contact in the early time of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: [This article is part of the developing coronavirus coverage, and may be outdated. Go here for the latest on the coronavirus.]

headline: Yachts Are for More Than Lounging
abstract: Some who own or charter superyachts want to take them on adventures, but the risks are high and insurers are balking.
lead_paragraph: Yachts — the mere word connotes luxury and easy living. They are a symbol of wealth second only to private jets.

headline: The Woman Who’s Shaking Up Britain’s Labour Leadership Campaign
abstract: The scion of a leftist family from northern England, Lisa Nandy offers a different view of what the party should stand for.
lead_paragraph: SOWERBY BRIDGE, England — Shaking the raindrops from her waterproof jacket, its oversized hood nearly covering her eyes, Lisa Nandy bundled into the Willow Cafe with a smile and an easy hello.

headline: Josef Newgarden, a Two-Time IndyCar Champion, Is Still Looking to Win Indy
abstract: Ahead of his ninth season, Newgarden dug in on downforce, Derek Jeter and going shirtless on “American Ninja Warrior.”
lead_paragraph: At 29, Josef Newgarden, already a two-time IndyCar champion, is readying for his ninth season in the sport. But Newgarden, a Nashville native, will tell you that winning the Indy 500, where his best finish so far is third, is what he most wants to achieve.

headline: Condo Sales Begin at the Revamped Waldorf Astoria
abstract: The project includes a refurbished hotel operated by Hilton in addition to the residential portion, and both are set to open in 2022.
lead_paragraph: When the Anbang Insurance Group paid $1.95 billion for the Waldorf Astoria, the famed Art Deco hotel in Midtown Manhattan, in 2015, it was one of the priciest hotel deals ever.

headline: TEFAF Art Fair Carries On. But Business Isn’t Usual.
abstract: With coronavirus-wary collectors staying away, attendance is down at Europe’s top fair for traditional art and antiques.
lead_paragraph: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands — “He’ll sort coronavirus for us. He conquers epidemics,” said the antiques dealer Paul Moss, gesturing toward a monumental gilded statue of  the Medicine Master Buddha that his gallery was exhibiting at a subdued preview of the TEFAF Maastricht art and antiques fair on Thursday, overshadowed by the Covid-19 crisis.

headline: Do You Use CBD Oils for Your Child?
abstract: We want to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: If you use CBD oils for a child 6 or younger, we want to hear your story. Fill out the form below and a reporter may be in touch.

headline: Why Warren Supporters Aren’t a Lock to Get Behind Sanders
abstract: Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders are longtime allies on the left. But her pool of voters generally doesn’t look like his base.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Poll Watch, our weekly look at polling data and survey research on the candidates, voters and issues that will shape the 2020 election.

headline: ‘Look Up Here!’: 5 Female Directors Reject the Male Gaze
abstract: These directors are acutely aware of Hollywood’s tendency to objectify female characters. So in their own work, they’re taking steps to avoid that trap.
lead_paragraph: International Women’s Day arrives Sunday on the heels of another season of #OscarSoMale and another prize for the director Roman Polanski, who fled the United States in 1978, after he was convicted of unlawful sex with a minor.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Feed your friends and family Margaux Laskey’s chicken Vesuvio, Alison Roman’s spiced chickpea stew, or Tejal Rao’s cannellini bean pasta.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I don’t know if you went bulk shopping last weekend, but enough people were anxious and jittery at my local gigantimart this week to suggest that the next couple of days are going to continue to be doozies, with some piling up stacks of canned goods and packages of toilet paper; pounds of rice; shelf-stable milk; dried fruit and nuts; the makings of a modern pantry.

headline: Adam Ondra’s Race to the Top
abstract: Adam Ondra is the best climber in the world. But to win Olympic gold he needed to learn a new way to climb. Fast.
lead_paragraph: BRNO, Czech Republic — The world’s best climber is a wiry 27-year-old with a curly mop of hair and a noticeably long neck. His name is Adam Ondra, and on a misty fall day in an industrial valley on the outskirts of his hometown, he was inside the massive metal silo of a former rock quarry that had been converted into a climbing gym.

headline: First U.S. Colleges Close Classrooms as Virus Spreads. More Could Follow.
abstract: The University of Washington is moving to online classes for its 50,000 students. With colleges nationwide about to empty for spring break, students fear they might not be coming back.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The University of Washington said on Friday that it would cancel in-person classes and have students take courses and finals remotely while the Seattle area grapples with a growing coronavirus outbreak, in a move that other colleges around the country are preparing to follow if the virus becomes more widespread.

headline: As Coronavirus Spreads, How You Can Protect a Family Member in a Nursing Home
abstract: Residents of care facilities can be especially vulnerable to respiratory illnesses. Here’s what you can do to help.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of people in the United States have died and tens of thousands have been sickened after contracting the coronavirus that continues to spread around the globe.

headline: Why Was ‘Amazing Stories’ Rebooted? These 7 Episodes Help Explain
abstract: Created by Steven Spielberg in the 1980s, the pulpy, star-studded original was an expensive flop. But much of it was extremely good.
lead_paragraph: When “Amazing Stories” premiered on NBC in 1985, “peak TV” was, by most definitions, still a glimmer in premium cable’s eye. In hindsight, the series presaged what would come to be a new gold standard for television: big budgets, A-list talent and an auteur creator — in this case Steven Spielberg, whose Amblin Entertainment spent up to $1 million per half-hour episode.

headline: For Paris Olympics, Surfing Will Head to Tahiti’s ‘Wall of Skulls’
abstract: Instead of the coast of France, surfers in 2024 will travel to Teahupo’o, home to some of the world’s most dangerous waves.
lead_paragraph: The Seine has many charms, but heavy surf is not among them.

headline: The Miracle of Moving a Piano in New York City
abstract: How do you get a 800-pound grand piano up a narrow staircase in a Harlem townhouse?
lead_paragraph: How do you get a 800-pound grand piano up a narrow staircase in a Harlem townhouse?

headline: How to Make Money in Your Sleep
abstract: Some TikTok users are going viral, gaining followers and even making cash by live-streaming themselves overnight.
lead_paragraph: Many fledgling creators dream of waking up to viral fame and riches. Now that dream is beginning to look a lot like reality.

headline: When All You Ever Wanted Is No Longer Enough
abstract: For Liverpool, winning the Premier League would end a desperate 30-year wait to be champion of England again. So why is it being told its season is on the brink of failure?
lead_paragraph: Enjoying this newsletter every week? Send it to a friend, or six, and tell them to sign up at nytimes.com/rory.

headline: Marc Jacobs, Sofia Coppola and Orville Peck on the Charity Circuit
abstract: Benefits for the Jewish Museum, the Bronx Museum and MoMA.
lead_paragraph: Benefits for the Jewish Museum, the Bronx Museum and MoMA.

headline: Spring Art Season Is Here
abstract: Benefits were held for the Jewish Museum, the Bronx Museum of the Arts and MoMA.
lead_paragraph: The Jewish Museum held a Purim Ball at the Pierre on March 3. The Bronx Museum of the Arts held a gala at Capitale on March 2. And the Armory Show (which takes place March 5 to March 8) held a party benefiting the Museum of Modern Art on March 4.

headline: Why a Coronavirus Recession Could Be Extra Painful: Its Suddenness
abstract: Although the immediate shock could be greater, recovery could also be quicker, given the economy’s underlying strength.
lead_paragraph: Often, when the economy runs into trouble, it goes through a slow glide from good times to bad. Other times, it is more like a fast car slamming on the brakes.

headline: Rome Celebrates the Short, but Beautiful, Life of Raphael
abstract: Amid new coronavirus restrictions on museums in Italy, a blockbuster show  traces the artist’s life from finish to start.
lead_paragraph: ROME — To commemorate the 500th anniversary of the death of Raphael, curators of the blockbuster exhibition that opened this week at the Scuderie del Quirinale exhibition space here have gone for a Benjamin Button approach.

headline: HuffPost’s Top Editor Leaves for a Podcasting Company
abstract: Lydia Polgreen, who has been the editor in chief at the news website since 2016, is stepping down for a role at Gimlet Media.
lead_paragraph: In another shake-up of the digital news landscape, HuffPost’s editor in chief, Lydia Polgreen, announced Friday that she was departing the website for a sector that many in media see as more of a growth area: podcasting.

headline: After Inquiry, Plácido Domingo Withdraws from London Performances
abstract: It was the latest indication that the opera star’s support in Europe, which stuck by him after allegations of sexual harassment, is weakening.
lead_paragraph: The Royal Opera House in London announced on Friday that the opera star Plácido Domingo had withdrawn from his upcoming performances there this summer. It was his latest European engagement to be called off since an American opera union’s investigation found last week that Mr. Domingo had engaged in “inappropriate activity” with women.

headline: The Networks That Ruled Earth’s Ancient Seas
abstract: Fossils of rangeomorphs, which dominated the oceans more than a half-billion years ago, show the thin threads that connected them.
lead_paragraph: More than half a billion years ago, peculiar beings called rangeomorphs ruled the seas. They looked like modern ferns, with leaflike protrusions that branched off in a fractal pattern. Some stood over three feet tall, while others lay flat.

headline: Shortcuts We Love
abstract: Frozen puff pastry, boneless chicken breasts and canned beans: This week’s recipes lean heavily on delicious timesavers.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes, where each Friday we present five different answers to the eternal question: What’s for dinner? Depending on the distractions of any given day, this question penetrates my consciousness some time between 12 and 6 p.m. The hour helps determine the answer and how much time I have to cook.

headline: With ‘The Trade,’ Matthew Heineman Puts a Human Face on a Divisive Issue
abstract: The Oscar-nominated director talked about Season 2 of his Showtime documentary series, which explores the Central American migrant crisis from both sides of the border.
lead_paragraph: The director Matthew Heineman has an uncanny ability to get his camera into difficult places. For his Oscar-nominated documentary “Cartel Land,” he embedded himself with armed vigilante groups fighting the Mexican drug cartels. For “City of Ghosts,” he filmed a group of Syrian journalists in Raqqa who risked their lives to expose ISIS atrocities.

headline: Henri Richard, Hall of Fame Center for Montreal Canadiens, Dies at 84
abstract: Richard played on 11 Stanley Cup-winning teams — five of them with his illustrious brother Maurice — and holds the record for game appearances with the Canadiens.
lead_paragraph: Henri Richard, the Montreal Canadiens’ Hall of Fame center who played on an N.H.L.-record 11 Stanley Cup winners and skated alongside his brother Maurice the Rocket when the Canadiens ruled hockey in the 1950s as the Flying Frenchmen, died on Friday in Laval, Quebec. He was 84.

headline: How I Came to Cook in French
abstract: For Melissa Clark, the food she grew up eating in Brooklyn, and the French cuisine her parents adored, laid the foundation for how she still cooks.
lead_paragraph: I can’t really speak French, but I cook in French. For years, I studied conjugations and the passé simple, practiced pronouncing yaourt and grenouille, but try as I might I just couldn’t seem to master it beyond the essentials like “deux pains au chocolat, s’il vous plaît.”

headline: Florida Lobster Got a Break on China Tariffs. Then Came Coronavirus.
abstract: China, the biggest customer, took aim at the U.S. catch as the trade war escalated. Relief came this week, but now no one there is buying.
lead_paragraph: MARATHON, Fla. — Like other commercial fishermen along the east and west coasts, Ethan Wallace had been waiting 18 months for China — the world’s largest importer of live lobster — to lift its crushing retaliatory tariffs on American seafood that had whittled down his profits.

headline: Murders Most Foul
abstract: Marilyn Stasio finds much to like in the latest crop of crime novels.
lead_paragraph: Coming-of-age novels aren’t my particular passion — unless there’s a murder in the story. There’s a doozy of a murder in Kate Weinberg’s hypnotic debut mystery, THE TRUANTS (Putnam, 311 pp., $26), one that might have met with the approval of the Queen of Crime, Agatha Christie. Dame Agatha happens to figure tangentially in this uncommonly clever whodunit, which makes plentiful references to her books, plot twists, settings and even the 11 days in 1926 when she inexplicably disappeared — all while coming across as madly original.

headline: Can Teenagers Fix Our Government?
abstract: “You Call This Democracy?” shows the rising generation how our government falls short of its democratic ideals. And what they can do about it.
lead_paragraph: The recent Iowa caucus debacle could serve as a primer on America’s not-quite-representative system of government. The malfunctioning app. The reporting delays and inconsistencies. The delegates determined by coin tosses and names in hats, the confusing first and second alignments, the discrepancy between who got the most delegates and who got the most votes, the built-in barriers to access created by having to stand in a gym for hours at a specific time of a specific day. Is this really the best we can do?

headline: Can You Dismantle White Supremacy With Words?
abstract: In “Stamped,” Ibram X. Kendi and Jason Reynolds team up to help teenagers understand — and combat — racism.
lead_paragraph: Americans have always assumed that the key to undoing the all-encompassing framework of white supremacy lies, in part, in literacy. Literacy helped combat slavery in practical ways — reading and writing meant you could more easily escape by forging free papers, for example. But there was also literacy’s metaphysical promise — that you could write your way into new futures, into places that existed outside of imaginations made narrow by anti-blackness. Think of Frederick Douglass tricking white boys into teaching him to form letters, or Toni Morrison proudly displaying a letter from the Texas Board of Corrections declaring that it had banned her novel “Paradise,” because of its potential to start a riot. Books and reading are dangerous, which is why the question of which books are made available to children is always contested.

headline: Review: A Conductor Makes His Philharmonic Debut, at Last
abstract: Louis Langrée, a Lincoln Center regular, led the New York Philharmonic for the first time this week.
lead_paragraph: Louis Langrée is no stranger to David Geffen Hall. For nearly two decades he’s been its summer tenant as music director of the Mostly Mozart Festival. And the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, which he has led since 2013, has even stopped by for a visit.

headline: Military to Be Sent to Border Before Supreme Court’s ‘Remain in Mexico’ Ruling
abstract: Customs and Border Protection said the deployment of 160 troops was in response to crowds of migrants that rushed the border last week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration will deploy 160 troops to two ports of entry along the southwestern border before a Supreme Court decision that officials fear could prompt large crowds of migrants to seek entry into the United States.

headline: Dixie Chicks’ Fiery Return, and 10 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Jarvis Cocker, Diet Cig, Blueface, Lauv and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: On ‘Oprah’s Book Club,’ ‘American Dirt’ Author Faces Criticism
abstract: Jeanine Cummins, whose novel about a Mexican woman and her son ignited a backlash, heard from some of her detractors in an episode that Apple TV Plus began streaming Friday.
lead_paragraph: When Oprah Winfrey selected “American Dirt” by Jeanine Cummins as her January book club pick, the novel seemed poised to be one of the year’s major releases. It follows a mother and son fleeing Mexico for the United States to escape cartel violence and was described by its publisher as a modern-day version of “The Grapes of Wrath.”

headline: Immigration Officers Say Asylum Deal With Guatemala Is Unlawful
abstract: The policy returns a vulnerable population “to countries in which their lives and freedom are directly threatened,” a union of asylum and refugee officers said in a brief.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A union representing federal asylum officers said on Friday that a Trump administration policy that diverts migrants at the southwestern border to Guatemala unlawfully sends a vulnerable population to a country “in which their lives and freedom are directly threatened.”

headline: 21 Coronavirus Cases on Cruise Ship Near California
abstract: More than 3,500 people are aboard the ship, which will dock at a noncommercial port this weekend. “We will be testing everyone,” Vice President Mike Pence said.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twenty-one people on board a cruise ship off the coast of California have tested positive for the coronavirus, Vice President Mike Pence announced on Friday evening, a significant escalation in the spread of the virus on the West Coast.

headline: Love Letter: Learning the Meaning of Love
abstract: Plus: Coronavirus upends wedding plans.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up here to receive Love Letter, a weekly newsletter about relationship highs, lows and woes, in your inbox every Friday.]

headline: Bonds Hit Historic Lows, Prompting Fed to Ponder: What More Can We Do?
abstract: The Federal Reserve, running low on ammunition as the coronavirus threatens economic growth, may need to buy assets beyond government-backed debt, one official suggested.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, watched warily as diagnosed cases of coronavirus ticked higher and the stock market sank lower through the final week of February.

headline: Coronavirus Could Slow Efforts to Cut Airlines’ Greenhouse Gas Emissions
abstract: Air France, citing the virus, has called for relief from taxes designed to curb global warming emissions. Other efforts could be disrupted as well.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus outbreak is pushing the world’s airlines toward financial crisis — and that is starting to complicate efforts to tame airlines’ greenhouse gas emissions, which had been growing rapidly in recent years.

headline: Mark Cuban Fined $500,000 for Criticizing N.B.A. Referees
abstract: Cuban, the owner of the Dallas Mavericks, spoke out after his team lost to the Atlanta Hawks on Feb. 22.
lead_paragraph: The wallet of the Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban is about to be a bit lighter.

headline: McCoy Tyner, Jazz Piano Powerhouse, Is Dead at 81
abstract: With his rich, percussive playing, he gained notice with John Coltrane’s groundbreaking quartet, then went on to influence virtually every pianist in jazz.
lead_paragraph: McCoy Tyner, a cornerstone of John Coltrane’s groundbreaking 1960s quartet and one of the most influential pianists in jazz history, died on Friday at his home in northern New Jersey. He was 81.

headline: Paid to Stay Home: Europe’s Safety Net Could Ease Toll of Coronavirus
abstract: Europe’s social policies are sometimes seen as overly generous. Yet they may help cushion the economic impact of the virus.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Keeping your salary while caring for a quarantined child. Exercising the right to not work if you are afraid of getting ill. Sick-leave pay for up to six months.

headline: The Sydney Opera House Goes Quiet. Finally.
abstract: A renovation costing nearly $200 million has shut the famed theater for two years, the first closure in its history.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Just after dawn one recent morning, Lou Rosicky was walking, slightly stooped, through a covered catwalk tucked just below the tip of one of the famous, towering concrete sails of the Sydney Opera House.

headline: Girl, Interrupted
abstract: In her unsettling debut novel, “My Dark Vanessa,” Kate Russell juxtaposes a creepy account of abuse and a love story.
lead_paragraph: MY DARK VANESSABy Kate Elizabeth Russell

headline: In Stephen Curry’s Return, the Raptors Reign Again
abstract: The Warriors guard came back for a changed team against a redrawn foe, but his brilliance, and Toronto’s resilience, remained the same.
lead_paragraph: It was Stephen Curry vs. Kyle Lowry again Thursday night, as the Golden State Warriors faced off against the Toronto Raptors in their first matchup since last year’s N.B.A. finals. The game went back and forth, and just like in the series-clinching Game 6 of the finals at Oracle Arena, the Raptors prevailed in the final minutes.

headline: Welcome to the Armory Fair. It’s Huge. It’s Hectic. Would You Like an Audio Guide?
abstract: Like sex with a new partner, my first audio tour was not all I imagined it would be.
lead_paragraph: How far will art fairs go to make themselves educational affairs on par with museum exhibitions? What can these events, where dealers convene to sell their wares to well-heeled collectors, do to set themselves apart from their competitors? As fairs proliferate, to about 300 worldwide, their organizers introduce new features, like panel discussions and concerts, meant to add intellectual heft and to cultivate and entertain broader audiences. (Confession: I myself recently served as the inaugural “writer in residence” at the Untitled San Francisco fair.)

headline: I Am Burning With Fury and Grief Over Elizabeth Warren. And I Am Not Alone.
abstract: She might not be bound for the presidency, but she has lodged herself in another powerful place: the female psyche.
lead_paragraph: WICHITA, Kan. — Consider every moment, since the dawn of woman, when a female aspired but to no avail. She asked to attend school but was denied. She raised her hand but wasn’t called on. She applied but wasn’t hired. She enlisted but wasn’t deployed. She created but wasn’t credited. She ran but wasn’t elected.

headline: Biden vs. Sanders: The Next Leg of the Democratic Race
abstract: Readers discuss a possible deal between the front-runners, Mike Bloomberg’s influence on the race and running mates.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: With Coronavirus, ‘Health Care for Some’ Is a Recipe for Disaster
abstract: The Trump administration’s treatment of immigrants could make the epidemic worse.
lead_paragraph: In late January, as the new coronavirus was making its first incursion into the United States, the Supreme Court upheld the Trump administration’s contested “public charge” rule, which enables federal officials to deny green cards to immigrants who use social safety net programs. The decision received scant media attention, in part because it was overshadowed by the emerging epidemic. But public health experts warn that the two stories are intimately, perhaps disastrously, related: Infectious disease outbreaks have a long history of preying on society’s most vulnerable, disenfranchised members. Noncitizens who don’t have access to health insurance, nutritious food or safe, affordable housing fall squarely into that category.

headline: What You Do to Your Women, You Do to Your Nation
abstract: Gender isn’t just a human interest sideshow to high politics.
lead_paragraph: In 1995, the U.N. World Conference for Women in Beijing championed the idea that the fate of nations was tied to the status of their female citizens. In 2000, U.N. Security Council Resolution 1325 asserted that peace is inextricably linked with gender equality.

headline: Sorry, but It’s Tax Time, and You Should Probably Read All This Stuff
abstract: Here are survival tips and extensive coverage of what’s new for 2020.
lead_paragraph: I dread filing taxes. At best, after preparing my return, I learn that I’ll get a modest refund, one that isn’t worth all the trouble. At worst, I get news like I did last year.

headline: D.N.C. All but Confirms Next Debate Will Include Just Biden and Sanders
abstract: Tulsi Gabbard, the third and final candidate remaining in the Democratic primary, has essentially no chance of qualifying.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The next Democratic presidential debate is almost certain to feature just two candidates: former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont.

headline: Oil Prices Nose-Dive as OPEC and Russia Fail to Reach a Deal
abstract: Coronavirus has sapped the world’s demand for oil, and major producers cannot agree on what to do.
lead_paragraph: Oil prices plummeted on Friday after major producers failed to reach an agreement to reduce production, as concerns about coronavirus’s impact on the economy spread across the globe.

headline: The Bernie Sanders Personality Test
abstract: Some candidates try to soften their image to broaden their appeal. This one, not so much. But is there a “real” Bernie the public doesn’t get to see?
lead_paragraph: [Read more: Bernie Sanders has officially ended his 2020 presidential campaign.]

headline: How Rebecca Solnit Found Her Voice
abstract: In her new memoir, “Recollections of My Nonexistence,” the admired author and activist recalls coming of age and acquiring confidence as a woman and a writer.
lead_paragraph: RECOLLECTIONS OF MY NONEXISTENCE By Rebecca Solnit

headline: Linda Sue Park Rewrites ‘Little House on the Prairie’ with an Asian-American Heroine
abstract: Laura Ingalls Wilder’s classic pioneer series is often called racially insensitive. With “Prairie Lotus,” a Korean-American author offers an alternative.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1880, in a railroad town in Dakota Territory, a girl in her 15th year bends over her sewing to help support her family. This might be “Little Town on the Prairie,” the seventh book in Laura Ingalls Wilder’s iconic series about a pioneer family. But it also describes PRAIRIE LOTUS (Clarion, 272 pp., $16.99; ages 10 and up), the captivating new novel by the Newbery medalist Linda Sue Park, whose heroine, Hanna Edmunds, is half Chinese.

headline: Hachette Says It Won’t Publish Woody Allen’s Book
abstract: The publisher planned to release the filmmaker’s autobiography in April but reversed course after a protest by its own workers.
lead_paragraph: Hachette Book Group on Friday dropped its plans to publish Woody Allen’s autobiography and said it would return all rights to the author, a day after its employees protested its deal with the filmmaker.

headline: Defending Bernie Sanders’s Sister-City Efforts in the U.S.S.R.
abstract: A former U.S. ambassador to the Soviet Union notes that sister-city programs were strongly supported by the U.S. government. Also: Voting rights in Florida; New York’s plastic ban.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Trump Administration Blocks Chinese Acquisition of Hotel Software Company
abstract: The decision, based on national security concerns, is the latest example of a stricter approach to policing Chinese investment in the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration ordered a Chinese company on Friday to separate itself from an American maker of cloud-based hotel management software over national security concerns, the latest example of the more stringent approach American officials have taken to policing Chinese investment in the United States.

headline: ‘Close Call’: NASA-Boeing Investigation of Starliner Flight Finds Lapses
abstract: The uncrewed December space mission could have ended in disaster.
lead_paragraph: An uncrewed test flight of Starliner, a Boeing spacecraft designed to carry NASA astronauts, could have ended in disaster in December because of lapses that allowed software errors to slip through undetected and unfixed before the spacecraft launched, according to a review by NASA and Boeing that was announced on Friday.

headline: James McBride Talks About ‘Deacon King Kong’
abstract: McBride discuss his latest novel, and Rebecca Solnit talks about “Recollections of My Nonexistence.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: South Bend Officer Will Not Be Charged in Shooting Death of Black Resident
abstract: The fatal shooting highlighted a strained relationship between former Mayor Pete Buttigieg and black residents in the Indiana town.
lead_paragraph: A police officer in South Bend, Ind., who fatally shot a resident last summer will not be charged, a prosecutor said Friday, capping a case that put a spotlight on the strained relations between Pete Buttigieg, then a presidential candidate and the mayor, and black residents in the town.

headline: Sanders Continues Attacks on Trade but Concedes Biden Could Beat Trump
abstract: “As we enter the moment in this campaign where we come down to a two-person race, I think it important for us to differentiate our records, and I intend to do that,” Mr. Sanders said.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Calibrating his approach for a tough head-to-head primary matchup in a year when many Democratic voters want to put up a united front, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont on Friday renewed his attacks on former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s record on trade while also conceding that Mr. Biden could defeat President Trump.

headline: Quibi Is Coming. Here Are the Famous People Making Shows for It.
abstract: The bite-size video start-up is live, and nearly everyone in Hollywood seems to be involved.
lead_paragraph: The new short-form streaming service Quibi, which debuted April 6, was meant to be ideal for smartphone users on the go. But now that no one’s going anywhere, what’s the main attraction?

headline: As Death Toll Mounts, Governments Point Fingers Over Coronavirus
abstract: The head of the World Health Organization said it was “not a time for excuses,” but some countries have been busily exchanging blame.
lead_paragraph: An Iranian official claimed without evidence that the epidemic could be an American bioweapon, after some U.S. officials said the same about China. Saudi Arabia said its cases were Iran’s fault. South Korea lashed out at Japan over travel restrictions and responded in kind.

headline: Alan Turner, Artist of the Evocative and the Odd, Dies at 76
abstract: Some of his paintings were of shimmering forests. Others were of disarranged body parts.
lead_paragraph: Alan Turner, who drew on Surrealism, Abstract Expressionism and more in acclaimed paintings and drawings that could be humorous, disturbing or poignant, died on Feb. 8 at his loft in Lower Manhattan. He was 76.

headline: The Special Kind of Impostor Syndrome That Comes When You’re Not Broke Anymore
abstract: In the rush to manage and make more money, don’t forget to manage your mental health, too.
lead_paragraph: You might’ve heard of impostor syndrome, the feeling of inadequacy that can bubble up in your mind when you think everyone else earned their seat at the table, but you don’t belong. While this phenomenon is well documented, a less well-known version can occur when you start making decent money for the first time. Despite making a living wage, you still feel poor.

headline: Read T a Poem | Vanessa Williams
abstract: The actress recites an excerpt from Maya Angelou’s “Phenomenal Woman.”
lead_paragraph: The actress recites an excerpt from Maya Angelou’s “Phenomenal Woman.”

headline: A Poem for International Women’s Day, Read by Vanessa Williams
abstract: As part of our series “Read T a Poem,” the actress performs a work by Maya Angelou.
lead_paragraph: Over her nearly 40-year career, Vanessa Williams has proved herself to be a master of reinvention. In 1983, she made history as the first African-American woman to be crowned Miss America, and later that decade she became a chart-topping musician with multiple platinum albums and a slew of Grammy nominations. From there, she moved on to theater, television and film acting — appearing most memorably as the witch in the 2002 Broadway revival of the musical “Into the Woods” and as the scheming magazine director Wilhelmina Slater in the TV series “Ugly Betty” — and in more recent years, she has co-written a memoir and introduced a fashion line. Now 56, the actress is embarking on yet another stage project: starring in a new production of the musical comedy “City of Angels,” which is currently in previews at the Garrick Theater in London.

headline: ‘America Needs Her’: Readers React to Elizabeth Warren’s Exit
abstract: The news led to an outpouring of reactions across America, on social media, and in our comments section.
lead_paragraph: The news that Senator Elizabeth Warren was exiting the Democratic presidential primary led to an outpouring of reactions across the country.

headline: Saudi Prince Detains Senior Members of Royal Family
abstract: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has detained a brother of the king, a former crown prince and a cousin, royals who may have been seen as threats to his rule.
lead_paragraph: In a fresh episode of Saudi palace intrigue, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has detained three members of the royal family, including a brother of the king and a former crown prince who had been potential obstacles to his power.

headline: South by Southwest Is Canceled as Coronavirus Fears Scuttle Festival
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of people were expected to arrive in Austin next week, but a number of companies had pulled out and on Friday, city officials called off the whole event.
lead_paragraph: The 34th annual edition of South by Southwest, the sprawling festival of music, technology and film in Austin, Texas, that has become a highlight on the global cultural calendar, was canceled by city officials on Friday over fears about the rapid spread of coronavirus.

headline: Overlooked No More: Audrey Sutherland, Paddler of Her Own Canoe
abstract: Long before solo adventure travel became a trend among women, Sutherland was a pioneer, traveling around the world in her inflatable kayak.
lead_paragraph: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: ‘The Only Choice Is to Wait for Death’
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of people fleeing Syria’s war ended up in Idlib city. But with the front line just five miles away, the city may not be a refuge much longer.
lead_paragraph: IDLIB, Syria — Before the war in Syria, Idlib city, with its tree-lined avenues and white-stone buildings, was known for its calm, provincial air.

headline: Alexei Botyan, Soviet Spy Hailed as ‘Hero,’ Dies at 103
abstract: The Russians say he saved the Polish city of Krakow from being destroyed by the Nazis, but historians say that is a fiction of the Putin era.
lead_paragraph: As far as many Russians are concerned, Alexei Botyan, a Soviet spy during World War II, was a hero whose daring actions saved the Polish city of Krakow from destruction by the Nazis.

headline: Don’t Let Trump Pay Back Evangelicals Like This
abstract: New rules promulgated by his administration to advance ‘religious freedom’ will actually restrict it.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans know by now that when Christian nationalists talk about “religious freedom” they are really asking for the privilege to impose their religion on other people. What Americans may not yet understand is that they are also demanding money from taxpayers to do so.

headline: Truck Crashes Into an Easter Island Statue
abstract: The truck rolled down a slope and hit an ahu, a ceremonial platform where one of the island’s famous statues was already on its side.
lead_paragraph: The statues on Easter Island have stood for centuries, facing inland to watch over a community that reveres them as memorials of their ancestors. Made of volcanic rock, they have braved many challenges over the years: climate change, lichen growth, damage from livestock and the encroaching development of tourism.

headline: The Hunt for Tape
abstract: How we tracked down a campus speech from 1988.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday’s show, at minute 11:12, you hear a piece of archival tape. It’s the kind of historical audio we play all the time, in this case of former Vice President Joe Biden, delivering a speech in the late 1980s.

headline: Eva Szekely Dies at 92; Survived Holocaust to Win Olympic Gold
abstract: Szekely, a Hungarian, became an Olympic champion after she was nearly killed during the Nazi occupation of Hungary.
lead_paragraph: Eva Szekely, an Olympic champion swimmer and an athletic hero in her native Hungary, narrowly escaped being murdered by fascists before she could achieve greatness.

headline: Crisis Deepens in Tiny Guyana, the World’s Newest Petro State
abstract: A decision by electoral authorities to declare the government the de facto winner in the March 2 elections is the catalyst for a wave of unrest. Billions in new oil revenue are at stake.
lead_paragraph: CORRIVERTON, Guyana — Guyana, the world’s newest oil producer, hurtled deeper into political crisis on Friday, a day after the electoral authorities announced the government had won the most votes in the March 2 elections, overriding objections from judges, international observers and the opposition.

headline: Coronavirus, Bernie Sanders, Woody Allen: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Baseball Radical Infiltrates the Reds. They Couldn’t Be Happier.
abstract: Kyle Boddy has helped pitchers for years as a baseball outsider. He’s gone mainstream, but he’s not wearing a uniform — yet.
