headline: Taking ‘Having It All’ Out of America
abstract: My husband wanted to fix our family’s work-life balance problems by moving to the suburbs. Instead, I moved us to Senegal.
lead_paragraph: One morning not long ago, I plopped down on a sidewalk in Maradi, Niger, alongside an Islamic judge who was hearing divorce cases at his sidewalk court. He was barefoot and sat on a sheepskin rug as he strained to hear the complainants over the bleating of passing flocks.

headline: Joe Biden Takes Command
abstract: The former vice president again won the majority of delegates in Tuesday’s primaries. But will his moderate coalition be able to win over Bernie Sanders’s progressive supporters?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Why the U.S. Wasn’t Ready for the Coronavirus
abstract: “Are we ready to respond to a pandemic? I fear the answer is no,” one senior U.S. health official said in 2018.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Sorting the Pieces of a Life Interrupted
abstract: A mother teaches her son how to tackle problems, and finds the strength to follow her own advice.
lead_paragraph: On his 12th birthday, my son received a gift from his former nanny. She remembered carefree, preschool afternoons creating skyscrapers out of blocks and T. rexes out of puzzle pieces. The box boasted 1,000 pieces, about 900 more than any I’d seen him complete.

headline: The Prado Museum’s Unsung Workers Step Into the Limelight
abstract: An Instagram video series that puts the artistic insights of guards and moving staff on equal footing with those of curators has become a hit.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Manolo Osuna lacks a formal art education, but he has spent years roaming the galleries of the Prado Museum as a guard and leader of a seven-person moving brigade that hefts national treasures by Spanish masters like Velázquez and Goya around the building.

headline: ‘If We Work Sick, Then You Get Sick’
abstract: As the coronavirus spreads, the public interest demands that employers abandon their longstanding resistance to paid sick leave.
lead_paragraph: Walmart, the nation’s largest private employer, set a standard for the rest of the private sector on Tuesday by announcing that, in addition to its existing paid sick leave policy, it would provide up to two weeks of paid leave for employees who fall ill or are quarantined because of a confirmed exposure to the coronavirus.

headline: As the Coronavirus Damage Spreads, Talk Turns to Bailouts
abstract: We’ll be hearing a lot about the idea of plowing taxpayer money into the U.S. economy as the outbreak spreads.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England announced an emergency rate cut this morning, and the European Central Bank is expected to unveil new stimulus tomorrow. Later today, Wall Street bank chiefs will meet with the White House to discuss the fallout from the coronavirus and what they can do about it. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

headline: Alcoholics Anonymous vs. Other Approaches: The Evidence Is Now In
abstract: An updated review shows it performs better than some other common treatments and is less expensive.
lead_paragraph: For a long time, medical researchers were unsure whether Alcoholics Anonymous worked better than other approaches to treating people with alcohol use disorder. In 2006, a review of the evidence concluded we didn’t have enough evidence to judge.

headline: On Politics: Biden Cruises
abstract: Hope fades for Sanders, and Biden talks unity. This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Biden and his wife, Jill, appeared at the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia after the primary results began to emerge.

headline: Coronavirus Case Total Climbs in New York
abstract: Organizers of the St. Patrick’s Day Parade decided to reschedule the Manhattan event.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York Area, read Wednesday’s live coverage.]

headline: Insulin Costs May Be Capped in a Medicare Program
abstract: If drug companies and insurers agree to participate, the Trump administration proposes limiting insulin costs to $35 a month for some older Americans.
lead_paragraph: A new Medicare pilot program would lower the cost of insulin to $35 a prescription for older Americans who need the lifesaving drugs, the Trump administration announced Wednesday.

headline: Harvey Weinstein’s Stunning Downfall: 23 Years in Prison
abstract: Mr. Weinstein, the movie mogul who was convicted of sex crimes, could very well spend the rest of his life behind bars.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Weinstein, the movie producer who dominated Hollywood for decades, was sentenced on Wednesday to 23 years in prison for sex crimes, as the six women who had testified against him watched from the courtroom’s front row, holding one another, some in tears.

headline: Why Workplace Hygiene Should Be More Than Just Hand-Washing
abstract: Wednesday: An expert says businesses should research their own best practices.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Jet Crash Kills Pilot in Rehearsal for Pakistan Parade
abstract: The F-16 crash in Islamabad occurred during preparation for the annual Pakistan Day commemoration.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Pakistani Air Force pilot died when his F-16 fighter jet crashed in the capital, Islamabad, on Wednesday during a training exercise for a military parade celebrating the country’s national day, officials said.

headline: Bags Packed, Sanitizer on, Americans Travel as Coronavirus Worries Grow
abstract: One doesn’t find outright panic in airports and on airplanes across the United States. Rather, it’s anguish that the next sneeze might be the fateful one.
lead_paragraph: IN THE AIR OVER AMERICA — The scene that played out in a secluded corner at Newark Liberty International Airport the other evening could have been called love in the time of coronavirus.

headline: A Classic Luxembourg Home With Modern Touches
abstract: This 18th-century house with a contemporary interior renovation in Hautcharage, Luxembourg, is on the market for $3.08 million.
lead_paragraph: This 18th-century house with a contemporary interior renovation in Hautcharage, Luxembourg, is on the market for $3.08 million.

headline: House Hunting in Luxembourg: A Restored Classic for $3 Million
abstract: Long a haven for foreign companies and their employees, the small nation is facing a housing squeeze as Europe restructures its business.
lead_paragraph: This four-bedroom, three-bathroom farmhouse is in Hautcharage, a small town in the southwestern corner of Luxembourg, about 10 miles west of Luxembourg City, the country’s capital.

headline: Democrats’ Best News
abstract: Turnout is up. Way up.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Democrats Aren’t in the Mood for Your Revolution
abstract: Another big night for Joe Biden, as voters seem to embrace the reassuring and the familiar.
lead_paragraph: Another round of Democratic voters registered their presidential preferences on Tuesday, sending a message strikingly similar to the one from Super Tuesday: They are tired of being scared, they are tired of being angry and they are not in the mood for a revolution.

headline: Visualizing the Refugee Experience
abstract: The goal of an exhibition at the American Visionary Art Museum in Baltimore is to underscore the danger of demonizing any human being as an undesirable “other.”
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest special report on Museums, which focuses on the intersection of art and politics.

headline: At Michigan State, Bold Statements About Big Issues
abstract: Two exhibitions at the Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum explore racism as well as social and political movements.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest special report on Museums, which focuses on the intersection of art and politics.

headline: Double Trouble for the Knicks and the Nets
abstract: In this week’s newsletter, Marc Stein explores the turbulent seasons of the Knicks and the Nets, and a coaching controversy in San Antonio.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: ‘About Love’ Review: Turgenev With Songs and Heartbreak
abstract: Despite charming performances, a Culture Project production works too hard bringing a delicate novella to the stage.
lead_paragraph: The work of translation that is theater — scripted dialogue and scored music transcribed via performance, design and direction — is tricky. That’s even more so when the original material is already a work in translation. Case in point: the Culture Project’s unsteady production of “About Love,” which awkwardly wrestles “First Love,” a novella by the Russian writer Ivan Turgenev, to the stage of the Sheen Center.

headline: Makeup and the Coronavirus: An Uneasy Mix
abstract: Customers cling to their products and treatments while the industry puts a brave face on a bad situation.
lead_paragraph: It was business as usual at Sephora in the SoHo neighborhood of Manhattan Monday evening, give or take a few face masks not of the soothing mud variety.

headline: Two Artists, Two Views of the Human Figure
abstract: Salman Toor’s show in New York and Christina Quarles’s in Chicago reveal the enduring — but continually evolving — style of the centuries-old art form known as figuration.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest special report on Museums, which focuses on the intersection of art and politics.

headline: Paris Court Convicts 6 in $50 Million Fake-Identity Scheme
abstract: The group used a silicone mask to impersonate a French defense minister in video calls, asking wealthy individuals and groups to pay millions for fake government operations.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Six men who netted over $50 million in a brazen and elaborate scheme by impersonating a French defense minister and asking wealthy individuals and institutions to pay for fake, off-the-book government operations were convicted on Wednesday of fraud by a criminal court in Paris.

headline: What to See Right Now in New York Art Galleries
abstract: Ja’Tovia Gary’s film installation; Trevor Shimizu’s landscapes; Kurt Schwerdtfeger’s light-and-color work; Cinga Samson’s portraits.
lead_paragraph: Rhythm is central to Ja’Tovia Gary’s “The Giverny Suite” (2019), a nearly 40-minute, three-screen film installation that is the centerpiece of “flesh that needs to be loved,” Ms. Gary’s first show at Paula Cooper.

headline: With the Census Approaching, a Look at Its History and Lore
abstract: An exhibition at the New-York Historical Society explores how the census has shaped America.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest special report on Museums, which focuses on the intersection of art and politics.

headline: Following the Civil Rights Trail
abstract: The time seemed just right for a personal journey to revisit an era of political turmoil in America.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest special report on Museums, which focuses on the intersection of art and politics.

headline: Beneath the Waves, a Warning
abstract: In Mira Lehr’s art, a celebration of the sea and its creatures and a lament for what lies ahead.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest special report on Museums, which focuses on the intersection of art and politics.

headline: Dinner in French!
abstract: Melissa Clark has a delicious excerpt, and four recipes, from her book, including a Campari cake that may just transport you to Aix.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark and I were in Toronto over the weekend, eating marvelous fried ocean smelts among about a thousand other things at Brothers on Bay Street, before taking the stage at the Hot Docs festival with the reporter and critic Chris Nuttall-Smith to talk about Melissa’s new book, “Dinner in French.” (We also talked about my new book, “See You on Sunday.” But this story’s about Melissa.) During our discussion, Melissa riffed about a late-night dinner of sardines on baguette, the bread toasted and rubbed with a clove of garlic and plenty of tomato before she lays the fish out across it to eat with a glass of wine. The audience swooned and I got hungry and that’s our no-recipe recipe of the week. Won’t you give it a try?

headline: Activist Museum Director Named New York Cultural Affairs Commissioner
abstract: Gonzalo Casals of the Leslie-Lohman Museum of Art wants to increase opportunities for people like him, in “immigrant communities, queer communities, Latinx communities.”
lead_paragraph: If there is a museum director who embodies Mayor Bill de Blasio’s commitment to empowerment and inclusion, it is Gonzalo Casals, who leads the Leslie-Lohman Museum of Art in SoHo, which is devoted to queer art. Now the mayor has given Mr. Casals a new title: New York City’s Cultural Affairs Commissioner, for the largest local funder of arts and culture in the United States.

headline: What You Get for $300,000
abstract: An Art Deco condominium in Miami Beach, Fla.; an 1802 village house in Wiscasset, Maine; and a two-story cottage in Charlottesville, Va.
lead_paragraph: An Art Deco condominium in Miami Beach, Fla.; an 1802 village house in Wiscasset, Maine; and a two-story cottage in Charlottesville, Va.

headline: $300,000 Homes in Florida, Maine and Virginia
abstract: An Art Deco condominium in Miami Beach, an 1802 village house in Wiscasset, and a two-story cottage in Charlottesville.
lead_paragraph: This apartment is in an 18-unit, four-building Art Deco complex known as the Dixon, after its architect, Lawrence Murray Dixon, who designed several Miami Beach hotels, including the Marlin, Raleigh, Tudor, Tides and Tiffany. It is in the South Beach neighborhood, a third of a mile west of Ocean Drive and the beach. The shops along Lincoln Road are less than a mile north and those on Washington Avenue are several short blocks east. The 36-acre Flamingo Park, which has an aquatics center with an eight-lane lap pool, is a block north.

headline: Behind Bernie Sanders’s Decision to Stay in the Race
abstract: Mr. Sanders said he was not dropping out, but aides said he recognized time was running short. He listed a series of policy items in what could be seen as a wish list of concessions he would want.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Senator Bernie Sanders on Wednesday made a defiant case for his liberal policy agenda despite suffering big losses in the Democratic primaries this week, saying he planned to continue his bid for the presidency. But he acknowledged that he was “losing the debate over electability” to his rival, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: U.S. to Suspend Most Travel From Europe as World Scrambles to Fight Pandemic
abstract: President Trump addressed the nation from the Oval Office on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Wednesday night blocked most visitors from continental Europe to the United States and vowed emergency aid to workers and small businesses as the World Health Organization declared the coronavirus a pandemic, stock markets plunged further and millions of people cut themselves off from their regular lives.

headline: 10 Bright White Accessories to Lighten Up Your Look
abstract: On backpacks, Chelsea boots and derbies, the most basic monochrome is anything but. Just steer clear of mud.

headline: U.S. Lawmakers Propose Tough Limits on Imports from Xinjiang
abstract: A bill cites reports of mass detention of minority groups in China and concerns about forced labor. This could spell problems for brands like Calvin Klein, Tommy Hilfiger, Nike and Patagonia.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — American lawmakers unveiled legislation on Wednesday that, if passed, would tightly restrict imports to the United States from the Xinjiang region of western China, the toughest response yet to Beijing’s mass detention of minorities and coercive labor practices there.

headline: ‘The Hunt’ Review: The Culture War, With Heavy Casualties
abstract: Betty Gilpin battles the snowflakes in a bloody satire of polarized America.
lead_paragraph: Late last summer, “The Hunt,” a mean little horror/satire from the clever devils at Blumhouse, looked like a culture war casualty. The movie’s fanciful premise — that a bunch of blue-state Americans were killing some of their red-state fellow citizens for sport — upset a few people who hadn’t seen it and who may have been looking for something to get upset about. Can you imagine: A liberal Hollywood blueprint for anti-conservative violence!

headline: Democrats and White House Race to Strike Deal for Coronavirus Relief Package
abstract: Democrats planned a Thursday vote on an aid package as the Treasury secretary said he hoped for a deal on a first phase of economic stimulus within 48 hours.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House and Democrats rushed on Wednesday to reach agreement on emergency legislation to provide a first tranche of economic assistance to help Americans cope with the fast-moving coronavirus pandemic, with the hope of sending it to President Trump for his signature by the end of the week.

headline: Early James Is a Rootsy Throwback in an Uncertain Present
abstract: On his debut album for Dan Auerbach’s label, the 26-year-old sings about disillusion in styles that glance back to the 1970s and before.
lead_paragraph: Early James — the Alabama-born singer and songwriter Frederick James Mullis Jr. — just sidles his way into the first song on “Singing for My Supper,” his debut album. “Blue Pill Blues” has an instrumental intro that lasts more than a minute, with its riffs bubbling up out of what might be a late-1960s Jefferson Airplane jam, before James starts singing. His first lyrics are, “What’s roiling and churning in my poor mind.”

headline: For Italians, Dodging Coronavirus Has Become a Game of Chance
abstract: Daily life in Italy is now a roll of the dice. Just ask residents of Pavia, once home to a founder of modern probability theory.
lead_paragraph: PAVIA, Italy — As his glasses fogged up from the mask he wore over his mouth and nose, Riccardo Rosso, a historian of mathematics, scribbled on a blackboard the possible outcomes of a dice game, substituting the chances of getting the coronavirus.

headline: Coronavirus and Climate Change
abstract: Also this week: A record, and a glitch, on an Arctic science expedition
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Swimrun, Sweden’s Island-to-Island Race, Comes to America
abstract: The popular endurance race, which combines trail running and open water swimming and has multiple transitions, is starting to catch on with American triathletes.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CATALINA ISLAND, Calif. — When the gun went off, I was near the back of the pack, wedged in a crush of over 250 runners. Some were tethered together. Most were jogging slower than I had anticipated. My goal: Don’t come in last.

headline: Skull of Smallest Dinosaur Discovered in Amber
abstract: Researchers say it is tinier than the smallest living bird, the bee hummingbird, and raises questions about bird evolution.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, Lida Xing of China University of Geosciences first examined a piece of amber — or fossil tree resin — that came from a mine in northern Myanmar. He took one look at the fossil, and he knew that he had to send it to his colleague, Jingmai O’Connor of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing.

headline: ‘Bloodshot’ Review: Shoot to Kill? Good Luck With That.
abstract: Vin Diesel brings the right balance of contemplativeness and meatheadedness to this action film.
lead_paragraph: Ray Garrison, Vin Diesel’s character in “Bloodshot,” could be a distant relative of the Terminators. A dead soldier returned to life, Ray has a new bloodstream made up of “nanites,” insectlike robots that quickly heal his wounds. He can punch through concrete. He can have his face blown apart and keep shooting while it reassembles. He is — this may not be the technical term — Wi-Fi-enabled, meaning he can instantly download and digest a piloting manual, just like in “The Matrix.”

headline: Home Visits. Handwritten Notes. How Reporters Contact a Jury.
abstract: Journalists for The Times spent a week reaching out to jurors in the Harvey Weinstein case to understand how they arrived at the verdict in the film producer’s trial for sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: How Joe Biden Wins It All
abstract: He doesn’t let President Trump tug him into the mud.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Frank Bruni’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it every Wednesday.

headline: What Does the Coronavirus Do to the Body?
abstract: Here’s what scientists have learned about how the new virus infects and attacks cells and how it can affect organs beyond the lungs.
lead_paragraph: As cases of coronavirus infection proliferate around the world and governments take extraordinary measures to limit the spread, there is still a lot of confusion about what exactly the virus does to people’s bodies.

headline: Writing a Family Memoir When Your Grandfather Was Stalin’s Bodyguard
abstract: “Young Heroes of the Soviet Union,” by Alex Halberstadt, is a moving and often funny memoir about the author’s family and their history.
lead_paragraph: When the poet Osip Mandelstam was arrested by the Soviet secret police in the 1930s, he was taken to the notorious Lubyanka prison for interrogation. He drew a distinction between the guards “on the outside” — village youths doing terrible things out of a dim sense of duty — and the interrogators “on the inside,” who seemed like specialists in cruelty. “To do that job, you have to have a particular vocation,” Mandelstam said. “No ordinary man could stand it.”

headline: Senate Rejects DeVos Rule Restricting Debt Relief for Bilked Students
abstract: The rule, struck down by a bipartisan majority, sought to rewrite Obama-era debt relief measures, which allow students misled by schools to request that their loan debts be forgiven.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a bipartisan rebuke, the Senate voted on Wednesday to overturn a major Trump administration rule that would sharply limit debt relief for students misled by schools that lured them in with false claims about their graduates’ career and earning prospects.

headline: Postpone the Olympics? Tokyo Official Backtracks After Causing Confusion
abstract: A member of the Tokyo organizing committee suggested delaying the Games. Organizers said he spoke out of turn.
lead_paragraph: Organizers of this summer’s Tokyo Olympics sought to dispel confusion on Wednesday over whether the Games would proceed as scheduled, after a member of the local organizing committee said he would recommend a postponement of the event because of the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Not a Size 2? Luxury Fashion Finally Wants You
abstract: 11 Honoré is disrupting plus-size, high-end shopping. One rule: Don’t offer only basics.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Herning has a vision for the future of plus-size shopping.

headline: Creating a Name for Themselves
abstract: As some married couples seek to join their identities, while also acknowledging they are equals, they are combining surnames or are creating entirely new ones.
lead_paragraph: Tasha Mente, a 31-year-old marketing vice president in Oakland, Calif., had a note in the program on the day she married Joe Mente, a 34-year-old engineering manager.

headline: & Sons, a Sommelier’s Ham Bar, Opens in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens
abstract: The restaurant in the Brooklyn Museum is changing its personality; the Mermaid Inn gets a fourth location; and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: André Hueston Mack, a sommelier and winemaker, started feeling that the expanding roster of well-made American cured hams was not being given its due. “There are ham bars in Spain and France, but nothing like them in New York,” he said. So he has now become a hammelier and opened his own spot, a sliver of brick walls and mirrors with just 20 seats in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, where he lives with his wife, Phoebe Damrosch, a writer and a partner in the restaurant, and their four sons. They have at least 11 American cured heritage-breed hams on the menu. Some are from venerable producers that have been curing hams for 100 years or more, and others are the work of newcomers. Many of the hams are from Kentucky, and some, like the ruddy Dakota, are on a more-or-less exclusive basis. The chef Cesare Casella’s prosciutto from upstate New York also gets its turn on the vintage slicer. Cornmeal madeleines and American cheeses are served, and Mr. Mack limits his wines to American selections. “I have about 320 labels, many from vintages going back to the 1970s and ’80s,” he said. He grew up in Texas, and began his wine career at the French Laundry. He went on to work at Per Se, and left to start making his own wine, which he still does, with Maison Noir Wines, in Oregon. He also runs a wine shop, VyneYard, nearby. In a few months, he plans a retail shop, & Sons Buttery, selling hams, cheeses, condiments and table accessories, next door to the restaurant.

headline: Make T Something | Katie Stout
abstract: The furniture designer Katie Stout sprinkles a little glitter on T’s ongoing challenge: to make an entirely new art object in under an hour with just six materials.
lead_paragraph: The furniture designer Katie Stout sprinkles a little glitter on T’s ongoing challenge: to make an entirely new art object in under an hour with just six materials.

headline: A Glitter-Loving Designer Puts Her Craft Skills to the Test
abstract: Katie Stout is the latest subject to take our “Make T Something” challenge.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn-based designer Katie Stout creates imaginative, unconventional housewares that often eschew utility. In fact, her pieces — which include dramatically spiked ceramic lamps and floppy chairs made from brightly hued fabric wrapped in vinyl — “could potentially cause more trouble” to live with than not, she says with a laugh. She has also become known for her ongoing series of cartoonlike “girls,” candy-colored ceramic sculptures of nude women performing various tasks, such as holding up lampshades or mirrors, that playfully call attention to the multiple roles women are often expected to take on in domestic spaces.

headline: Where the Coronavirus Is Not Stopping Sports: Las Vegas
abstract: What do college basketball tournaments look like as the country starts to make decisions about crowds and the coronavirus outbreak? We went to Las Vegas to find out.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Hand-sanitizing dispensers stationed outside locker rooms and along arena concourses. Workers wearing rubber gloves and spritzing hand railings with disinfectant up and down aisles while games are going on. Players keeping a healthy distance — no selfies or slapping hands — from the fans who traveled far to cheer them.

headline: Dinner for 300 at Chelsea Market
abstract: The James Beard Foundation held its annual fund-raising dinner.
lead_paragraph: The James Beard Foundation held its annual fund-raising dinner.

headline: Mussels and Purell at the James Beard Dinner
abstract: The New York party scene goes on, until it doesn’t.
lead_paragraph: A small square package, bound by an elegant white ribbon, greeted the 300 diners who showed up last weekend for the James Beard Foundation’s annual Super Sunday at Chelsea Market.

headline: From Seattle to Kentucky, Churches Cancel Religious Services
abstract: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Seattle suspended all public Masses, and Kentucky’s governor recommended that the state’s churches cancel services.
lead_paragraph: In a dramatic move to slow the spread of the coronavirus in one of the most affected regions of the country, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Seattle suspended all public celebration of Mass, effective immediately, becoming the first Catholic archdiocese in the country to do so.

headline: Barbara Neely, Activist Turned Mystery Writer, Dies at 78
abstract: Her creation Blanche White was probably the first fictional black maid to solve a murder while working for a wealthy white family.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Neely, an unheralded social activist who in her 50s became an award-winning writer of mystery novels centered on a savvy black maid who doubles as an amateur detective, died on March 2 in Philadelphia. She was 78.

headline: Read Bernie Sanders’s Full Speech About Staying in the Race
abstract: After another disappointing primary night, Mr. Sanders said he would debate Joe Biden on Sunday, and laid out the questions he planned to ask him. Here’s a full transcript.
lead_paragraph: After a disappointing showing in Tuesday night’s primaries, Senator Bernie Sanders addressed his future in the 2020 primary race in a news conference Wednesday afternoon.

headline: U.K. Shields Its Economy From the Virus, but Not Yet Its People
abstract: The government is spending $38 billion to mitigate the effects of the coronavirus outbreak, but so far has ruled out aggressive measures to fight it.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain moved decisively on Wednesday to cushion its economy from the ravages of the coronavirus, as it prepared to toughen a more cautious medical response that had come under fire, particularly after a health minister who had mingled at a reception with Prime Minister Boris Johnson fell ill from the contagion.

headline: Shabaka and the Ancestors Are Making Their Own Jazz History
abstract: The partnership between the British saxophonist Shabaka Hutchings and a group of South African musicians has produced an imaginative second album.
lead_paragraph: If jazz is looking to reinvent itself — or catch its breath and take stock of how much it already has in the past 10 years or so — the music of Shabaka and the Ancestors might be a good place to start.

headline: ‘Conscience’ Review: The Woman Who Stared Down the Red Scare
abstract: The hero of Joe DiPietro’s new comic drama is Margaret Chase Smith, a U.S. senator who had the rare courage to stand up to McCarthyism.
lead_paragraph: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — The woman behind me was talking about her memories of McCarthyism, and I assumed she must be speaking of her childhood.

headline: A Big Idea and a Big Donor Bring a New Art Museum to Austria
abstract: The Albertina Modern, a satellite of the venerable Vienna institution, aims to highlight overlooked Austrian artists in a newly restored historic building.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Amid hammering and drilling, works by the Austrian artists Valie Export, Arnulf Rainer and Günter Brus waited quietly in a row against a white wall, ready to be hung.

headline: A Rare Look Inside the Hospital Where 15 Coronavirus Patients Have Died
abstract: A suburban hospital in Kirkland, Wash., has faced the brunt of the coronavirus outbreak. Here is their story.
lead_paragraph: KIRKLAND, Wash. — At 6:04 p.m. on Tuesday night, the staff at EvergreenHealth in Washington State got another warning: Two more patients with respiratory troubles were on their way to an emergency ward that had already been flooded with coronavirus patients.

headline: Sports Leagues Bar Fans and Cancel Games Amid Coronavirus Outbreak
abstract: The N.B.A. abruptly suspended its season after a player tested positive for the coronavirus. The N.H.L., M.L.B. and men’s tennis are also poised to make changes or have already done so.
lead_paragraph: A steady trickle of cancellations and other disruptions in the sports world caused by the coronavirus outbreak erupted into an avalanche on Wednesday, with the N.B.A. abruptly suspending its season and the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament and other events barring most spectators. A major tennis tournament was also in doubt.

headline: As Coronavirus Testing Increases, Some Labs Fear a Shortage of Other Supplies
abstract: Lab directors and federal officials are keeping a close eye on the supply of other materials needed to conduct the tests.
lead_paragraph: Laboratories around the country are now facing potential shortages of key materials and chemicals needed to run tests for the novel coronavirus, as cases spread to more than two-thirds of the states and the global pandemic strains testing resources even further.

headline: Supreme Court Revives ‘Remain in Mexico’ Policy for Asylum Seekers
abstract: A federal appeals court had found that the policy, which was put in place early last year, violated federal and international law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday allowed the Trump administration to maintain a program that has forced about 60,000 asylum seekers to wait in Mexico while their requests are heard. An appeals court had blocked the program, saying it was at odds with both federal law and international treaties and was causing “extreme and irreversible harm.”

headline: Coronavirus Resources: Teaching, Learning and Thinking Critically
abstract: A page we will continue to update with ideas for working, at school or at home, with content from The Times and other reliable sources about this global pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Updated: April 20

headline: Some Paleontologists Seek Halt to Myanmar Amber Fossil Research
abstract: The substance has driven remarkable discoveries about the prehistoric world, but concerns about its sourcing are growing.
lead_paragraph: Fossils preserved in amber are giving paleontologists exceptional glimpses into the age of the dinosaurs, be it through the preserved tail of a dinosaur that still bears feathers, or a frog frozen in time.

headline: Review: Scottish Ballet Plays Dress Up and Dress Down
abstract: Celebrating its 50th anniversary, the company brought an uninspiring program, “This Is My Body …,” to the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: It’s a strange time to be going to a theater in New York. As you and dozens of others settle into your seats, armrest to armrest, you might ask yourself a question that wouldn’t have crossed your mind a few weeks ago: Should I be here? Or should I be practicing social distancing?

headline: As Biden Widens His Lead Over Sanders
abstract: Readers analyze the reasons for Joe Biden’s momentum and offer critiques of both candidates.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How the Coronavirus Is Disrupting Sports Events
abstract: A look at postponements, cancellations and adjustments made in response to growing fears about the virus.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus toll has risen to 100,000 infections and 4,000 deaths. With governments imposing lockdowns and travel and border restrictions, sports events worldwide continued to be postponed, canceled or played without spectators.

headline: Please, Listen to Experts About the Coronavirus. Then Step Up.
abstract: This crisis has an absence of authority. Let’s fill it.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus is spreading faster than we can contain it, faster than municipalities can track it and here in the United States, much faster than our testing capacity can handle. By the time you read a statistic, chances are it’s outdated.

headline: TV Talk Shows Throw Out the Audience
abstract: “The View,” Stephen Colbert and Jimmy Fallon are among those deciding to give up the usual studio enthusiasm, because of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: “It feels like we’re auditioning,” a dazed Ryan Seacrest said on live television Wednesday morning, before a sea of empty seats.

headline: Could an Invasive Snail Save Your Morning Coffee?
abstract: Coffee leaf rust has long been the enemy of coffee growers, but a snail from Southeast Asia may give them hope.
lead_paragraph: It’s not exactly what you want to think about when you’re sipping your morning coffee or waiting for your favorite pour over. But a potential solution to one of the biggest threats of coffee production has been found in the bright orange excrement of a voracious gastropod called the Asian trampsnail.

headline: With a Torrent of Money, Britain Takes Aim at Coronavirus and Austerity
abstract: The central bank and the government unleash funds directed at rescuing Britain from the outbreak, while repairing tattered budgets.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In one action-packed day, the people who oversee money in Britain sought Wednesday to ease a pair of economic crises — the immediate emergency of the coronavirus outbreak, and the long, entrenched decline assailing national life through budget austerity.

headline: Fashion’s Coronavirus ‘Patient Zero’ Speaks
abstract: Nga Nguyen and what happens when Instagram, money, fashion shows and Covid-19 collide.
lead_paragraph: Just over a week ago, Michael Burke, the chief executive of Louis Vuitton, stood in the darkened space in Paris where his show — the last of fashion month — was about to take place and noted that, despite all the anxiety over the new coronavirus, there had been very few cancellations. He pointed out that many of the hundreds of people in the room had been traveling together and in enclosed spaces for weeks.

headline: Why Young People Don’t Show Up at the Polls
abstract: The challenge “is to demonstrate how voting can affect the daily lives of these young Americans,” a reader writes. Also: President Trump’s efforts against human trafficking; investing in science.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Presidents Forge Their Legacies in Crises
abstract: It is too early to say how President Trump’s actions in the coronavirus outbreak will affect his legacy, but history is filled with lessons.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Riding Air Force One with President Trump back to the nation’s capital on Monday afternoon felt eerily like that grim day in 2005 when President George W. Bush was flying to the White House to confront the catastrophe of Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Coronavirus Pandemic, Angela Merkel, Markets: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Dow Ends 11-Year Bull Market as Coronavirus Defies Economic Remedies
abstract: Stocks plunged anew as the outbreak was officially declared a pandemic and policies to address its impact proved lacking or ineffective.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus outbreak ended one of the longest winning streaks in market history on Wednesday as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged and global policymakers grappled with the growing economic crisis.

headline: Banned Events. Empty Arenas. Cities Retrench in the Face of Coronavirus.
abstract: The strict new controls on events in the Northwest are an attempt to slow the spread of a virus that already has taken 24 lives in Washington State.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In Ohio, Gov. Mike DeWine said a ban on large events was imminent. In San Francisco, the Golden State Warriors were set to play in an empty arena — and then the N.B.A. suspended play across the league. And in Washington State, Gov. Jay Inslee said on Wednesday that people should no longer cram shoulder-to-shoulder in local bars — in the era of coronavirus, he said, such socializing has become “just totally unacceptable.”

headline: Coronavirus Has Become a Pandemic, W.H.O. Says
abstract: But the virus can still be stopped if nations are willing to take aggressive measures, said the organization’s director-general.
lead_paragraph: The spread of the coronavirus is now a pandemic, officials at the World Health Organization said on Wednesday.

headline: My People Have Been Through Worse Than a Twitter Mob
abstract: When you’re a black woman in America with a public voice, a trivial math error can lead to a deluge of hate.
lead_paragraph: Late Thursday night, I appeared on TV. On Friday morning, I woke up to a text message from a friend.

headline: Walmart, Uber and Others Tweak Sick-Leave Policies as Coronavirus Spreads
abstract: The companies, and other businesses, like Instacart, have also said they would compensate workers who contract the virus or are subject to quarantine orders.
lead_paragraph: Walmart, Uber and other major companies announced new policies this week to grant paid leave or other compensation to workers who contract the new coronavirus or are quarantined by order of the government or their companies.

headline: A New ‘Emperor’: Russia Girds for 16 More Years of Putin
abstract: ‘Do you want an eternal Putin?’ a critic asked after Parliament paved the way for the president to serve well beyond the end of his current term.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — One of Russia’s most influential business magnates on Wednesday said the country has become a “quasi-monarchy” — a sign of how President Vladimir V. Putin’s move this week to clear the way to rule until 2036 has changed the landscape of Russian politics.

headline: An Update to The 1619 Project
abstract: Today we are making a clarification to a passage in an essay from The 1619 Project that has sparked a great deal of online debate.
lead_paragraph: Today we are making a clarification to a passage in an essay from The 1619 Project that has sparked a great deal of online debate. The passage in question states that one primary reason the colonists fought the American Revolution was to protect the institution of slavery. This assertion has elicited criticism from some historians and support from others.

headline: Peregrine Pollen, Who Livened Up Auctions, Dies at 89
abstract: Running Parke-Bernet in New York in the 1960s after a merger with Sotheby’s, Mr. Pollen injected fun into the proceedings while expanding the business.
lead_paragraph: Peregrine Pollen, who brought a sense of showmanship to the sedate New York auction scene of the 1960s and early ’70s while helping to implement a startling consolidation of two auction-house giants, died on Feb. 18. He was 89.

headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.: Desperate for a Test, They Couldn’t Get One
abstract: New York has struggled to expand its testing system to meet the need. Now, Gov. Andrew Cuomo is vowing to expand the number of tests significantly.
lead_paragraph: One woman in Harlem who wanted to be tested was told by health care workers not to worry about her coronavirus-like symptoms. In Brooklyn, a woman had to wait to get tested until her mother tested positive for the virus. One doctor at a hospital network has turned away patients who probably had the coronavirus because they did not meet the current testing criteria.

headline: Coronavirus and Plane Travel: What to Expect if You’re Flying
abstract: If you are getting on an airplane, here’s what may have changed, both on the ground and in the air.
lead_paragraph: Travel restrictions have become more serious and widespread over the past few days. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has now categorized about 30 countries as Warning Level 3 and is requiring anyone entering from those places to stay home for 14 days. President Trump shut down most travel from Europe to the United States beginning March 13.

headline: Coronavirus Leads N.C.A.A. to Bar Fans From National Basketball Tournaments
abstract: Faced with an epidemic, college sports leaders spent weeks debating whether or how to move forward with one of the country’s biggest athletic events.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The grandest annual exhibition in college sports — the N.C.A.A. men’s and women’s Division I basketball tournaments — will be played without spectators in the arenas as the United States grapples with the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: South Korea: What We’re Doing to Fight the Coronavirus
abstract: “From an early stage, the Korean government has set key principles to combat Covid-19: Be quick, transparent and pre-emptive,” a Foreign Ministry official writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Broadway Usher Tests Positive for Coronavirus
abstract: The employee worked in recent days at “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” and “Six,” prompting a scramble to inform the public and clean the theaters.
lead_paragraph: A part-time usher who recently worked at two Broadway theaters has tested positive for Covid-19, the disease caused by the new coronavirus, prompting a scramble to inform the public and clean the buildings, according to the theater owners.

headline: The Future Unseen
abstract: Born blind in Lebanon, Kohdr Farhat has a grand vision for the disabled built upon not being able to see. After all, he did it, why shouldn’t they?
lead_paragraph: Born blind in Lebanon, Kohdr Farhat has a grand vision for the disabled built upon not being able to see. After all, he did it, why shouldn’t they?

headline: The Freedom To Be
abstract: Okporo fled the hate crimes he experienced in Nigeria to seek a normal life in the United States. Once a refugee, he now helps others land safely.
lead_paragraph: Okporo fled the hate crimes he experienced in Nigeria to seek a normal life in the United States. Once a refugee, he now helps others land safely.

headline: Finding Each Other, and Art, in the City
abstract: For this couple, collecting was a pursuit discovered together — after they discovered each other in New York. They haven’t looked back.
lead_paragraph: Maneesh Goyal, who grew up in Dallas, and his husband, Andrew Wingrove, from Hilton Head, S.C., met more than 12 years ago as recent transplants to New York City. Neither had a particular interest in collecting art until then.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Gugu Mbatha-Raw Reads ‘Recognizing What They Had, 20 Years Too Late’
abstract: The “Misbehaviour” star reads an essay about an emotional connection that defies categorization.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: House Passes Bill Preserving F.B.I. Surveillance Powers
abstract: An unusual collection of lawmakers backed the legislation, which would give Americans some new privacy protections and extend legal authority for some F.B.I. investigative tools.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House passed a bipartisan adjustment of key surveillance laws on Wednesday, cobbling together an unusual coalition of lawmakers to approve some new privacy protections for Americans and extend three expiring F.B.I. tools for investigating terrorism and espionage.

headline: Dow Skids Into Bear Market, Heralding an Uncertain Future
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average closed down more than 20 percent from its high last month, ending a bull market that ran for more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: The 11-year bull market, which grew in tandem with one of the longest economic expansions in United States history, weathered a European debt crisis and survived President Trump’s trade war with China, is dead — a casualty of the global coronavirus pandemic.

headline: ‘I’m Baffled’: What It’s Like to Be a Black Sanders Supporter in the South
abstract: A small minority of older black voters in the South support Sanders, and they are discouraged and baffled by the near-universal rejection of his campaign.
lead_paragraph: OKOLONA, Miss. — Miles from anything like a town and halfway down a dead-end county road lives Mamie Cunningham, 78, a retired schoolteacher, lifelong Mississippian — and die-hard supporter of Senator Bernie Sanders.

headline: House Sends Trump Bill to Restrict War Powers on Iran, Setting Up Veto
abstract: The bipartisan measure amounts to an unusual rebuke of the president’s expansive war powers. President Trump has promised to veto it.
lead_paragraph: The House gave final approval on Wednesday to a bipartisan resolution aimed at forcing President Trump to get explicit approval from Congress before taking further military action against Iran, in a bid by lawmakers to reassert congressional war powers that is all but certain to be thwarted by a presidential veto.

headline: Rocket Attack Kills Three U.S. Coalition Members in Iraq
abstract: Rockets struck Camp Taji where Iraqi, American and other coalition troops are based.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A volley of rockets struck a sprawling military base north of Baghdad Wednesday evening, killing three service members, two of them Americans and one British, according to a United States official and an Iraqi military officer, both in Iraq.

headline: Coronavirus, Bernie Sanders, Dinosaurs: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Elizabeth Warren Is Unlikely to Endorse Bernie Sanders. Here’s Why.
abstract: Though Ms. Warren and Mr. Sanders agree on many progressive issues, her campaign has highlighted a rift over how they build political coalitions. And she doesn’t think he can win.
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren, whose endorsement became highly coveted in the Democratic presidential race after she dropped out last week, is unlikely to endorse her ideological ally Senator Bernie Sanders, according to several people close to her, even though Mr. Sanders is looking for political lifelines as he struggles against former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Why Sanders Is Staying In
abstract: He got trounced last night. His path forward is exceedingly steep. But he has reasons to fight on.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Joe Biden Will Host ‘Virtual Events’ as Coronavirus Fears Heat Up
abstract: The Biden campaign’s move to limit in-person campaigning marked the beginning of an extraordinary new chapter in an already tumultuous presidential race: campaigning amid a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. is drastically modifying his campaign schedule in the coming days in response to mounting anxieties about the coronavirus, trading traditional get-out-the-vote-style gatherings for “virtual events,” his campaign announced Wednesday.

headline: ‘Lost Girls’ Review: Honoring the Gone Girls, With Sorrow and Rage
abstract: Amy Ryan stars as a mother searching for her daughter in a movie that revisits a spate of unsolved murders on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Few deaths in movies are handled with the contempt that some filmmakers show murdered sex workers. It’s one reason that the true-crime drama “Lost Girls” feels so bracing: It humanizes women often represented as disposable, more props than people. When a mother in the movie laments that her missing daughter, a sex worker, has been forgotten along with other women, her words feel like an accusation. When “our girls” are remembered, she says, it’s never as “friend, sister, mother, daughter.”

headline: Atlético Madrid Stuns Liverpool as Coronavirus Pierces Champions League
abstract: Two goals by Marcos Llorente made for another dramatic night in Europe’s top club competition, but news of an infected Juventus player threatened the tournament.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — Diego Simeone raced down the side of the field, hurtling toward Atlético Madrid’s delirious fans. Álvaro Morata knelt in front of them, a picture of stillness, arms aloft. He looked out on a crashing, bounding sea of bodies, a whole section of the stands transformed into a single, writhing mass.

headline: What Hospitals and Health Care Workers Need to Fight Coronavirus
abstract: Many hospitals are running dangerously low on protective equipment for staff members as they make room for an influx of Covid-19 patients.
lead_paragraph: Many hospitals are running dangerously low on protective equipment for staff members as they make room for an influx of Covid-19 patients.

headline: Impact of Coronavirus Is Felt on an Arctic Science Expedition
abstract: A member of a team that is to fly research missions as part of the Mosaic expedition has tested positive for the virus in Germany.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus outbreak has now had an impact on a large climate research expedition in the frozen Arctic Ocean.

headline: Bernie Sanders Made a Big Concession Speech. Just Not the Usual Kind.
abstract: In a stark moment of political de-escalation, Mr. Sanders signaled that he wants to press Joe Biden on issues but may not want to fight to the bitter end like he did against Hillary Clinton in 2016.
lead_paragraph: It was a concession speech, of a kind: Addressing reporters on Wednesday, Senator Bernie Sanders bowed not to Joseph R. Biden Jr., who trounced him in a second consecutive week of primary elections, but to the reality of his political predicament. Stripped of his briefly held status as the Democratic front-runner, Mr. Sanders acknowledged that he was “losing” to Mr. Biden but stopped short of accepting defeat.

headline: Meet the Trump Fan Accused of Registering Democrats as Republicans
abstract: A woman in Florida charged with 10 felony counts of submitting false voter registration forms had filed hundreds of forms before her arrest.
lead_paragraph: Wherever crowds gathered in the flat, lake-dotted swath of Florida between Orlando and Ocala, it seemed that Cheryl Hall was there: clad in red, white and blue, clipboard in hand, signing up new voters at the Mount Dora Arts Festival, the Ocoee Founders’ Day party, the Taste of South Lake fair in Clermont and more.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The W.H.O. declared the outbreak a global pandemic, and said it was vital to keep fighting its spread.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus outbreak is not just an epidemic, it’s also a global pandemic, the World Health Organization declared on Wednesday.

headline: Coronavirus Has Caused a Hand Sanitizer Shortage. What Should You Do?
abstract: Using hand sanitizer helps prevent the spread of coronavirus. So what do you do when it’s sold out?
lead_paragraph: Alarm over coronavirus has caused a run on hand sanitizers. And now, sanitizers from Purell and other brands are exceedingly hard to come by. Where it isn’t sold out, enterprising sellers are charging outrageously inflated prices simply because they can. If you don’t have any hand sanitizer, you’re not likely to get some while the manufacturers create enough supply to meet the frenzied demand caused by panic over coronavirus. (To be clear, we don’t think anyone should panic.)

headline: Critics Hear Political Tone as Pompeo Calls Out Diplomatic Rivals Over Human Rights
abstract: China, Cuba, Iran and Venezuela were cited as among the worst violators. All four are targets of pressure campaigns by the Trump administration to install sweeping change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four nations that are among the Trump administration’s top diplomatic adversaries were singled out on Wednesday for rampant human rights violations, raising questions of whether the State Department’s annual review of civil liberties protections worldwide was being politicized.

headline: Merkel Gives Germans a Hard Truth About the Coronavirus
abstract: The famously no-nonsense chancellor, keeping to form, braced Germany for an epidemic that may reach extraordinary scale.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel is on her way out and her power is waning, but in her typically low-key, no-nonsense manner, the German leader on Wednesday laid out some cold, hard facts on the coronavirus in a way that few other leaders have.

headline: A Fumbled Global Response to the Virus in a Leadership Void
abstract: While world leaders are at last speaking out about the gravity of the pandemic, their voices are less a choir than a cacophony, with the United States absent from its traditional conductor role.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In Frankfurt, the president of the European Central Bank warned that the coronavirus could trigger an economic crash as dire as that of 2008. In Berlin, the German chancellor warned the virus could infect two-thirds of her country’s population. In London, the British prime minister rolled out a nearly $40 billion rescue package to cushion his economy from the shock.

headline: How Right-Wing Pundits Are Covering Coronavirus
abstract: Following President Trump’s lead, many commentators have played down fears.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Charlie Says’ and the Dixie Chicks
abstract: A drama about the Manson cult airs on Showtime. And the Dixie Chicks perform on “The Late Show with Stephen Colbert.”
lead_paragraph: CHARLIE SAYS (2019) 9 p.m. on Showtime. Mary Harron vacillates between prison and movie ranch in “Charlie Says,” her drama about the Charles Manson cult. Though she is best known as the director of the satirical serial-killer study “American Psycho,” Harron here pays relatively little attention to Manson himself (played by Matt Smith), instead focusing on three of his female followers (played by Hannah Murray, Marianne Rendón and Sosie Bacon). That trio tells the story here. The movie shows them both during their time with Manson and after the fact, in prison, where they recount their story to a graduate student (Karlene Faith, played by Merritt Wever). “It’s a tough, difficult story that, anchored by Guinevere Turner’s script, Harron recounts with lucid calm, compassion and intelligent interpretive license,” Manohla Dargis wrote in her review for The New York Times. “She revisits some of the familiar locations, including the dusty California ranch where the Manson family set up house, and she carefully restages some of the murders. For those familiar with the horrific details of those crimes, the movie may seem wholly uninviting, but bear with Harron — she has something to say.”

We asked his admirers, some of them also his collaborators, to reflect on the songs — with music and/or lyrics by Sondheim — that have stayed in their hearts. headline: 36 Hours in Aruba
abstract: Mesmerizing sunsets, a windblown park, fantastic wreck-diving and romantic dining on the beach: just a few reasons travelers find this island in the southern Caribbean so irresistible.
lead_paragraph: For decades, thanks in no small part to the Beach Boys’ song “Kokomo” (“Aruba, Jamaica, oh, I wanna take you”), Aruba has been synonymous with paradise for American travelers. Even though Aruba sits just north of Venezuela, in the far south of the Caribbean, that doesn’t dissuade cruise ships from stopping at the island’s capital city, Oranjestad, or time-share vacationers from filling up its resorts. But while the resorts that line some of its beaches might make the island seem like many other vacation hot spots, around its edges, Aruba, a constituent country of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, contains unique treasures: a windblown national park of volcanic crags and raging waves; a revitalizing town lined with mosaics and murals; and an offshore shipwreck considered one of the best wreck dives in the world.

headline: This Movie Is Streaming Only. Should We Lower Our Expectations?
abstract: As more films skip theaters and head straight to streaming, we asked our critics to talk openly about what many whisper about: that many of these films are just good enough.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, Tom McCarthy made the journalism drama “Spotlight,” which won the Oscar for best picture. This year his follow-up feature, “Timmy Failure: Mistakes Were Made,” skipped theaters and headed directly to Disney Plus. Best picture it won’t be. As the streaming landscape expands and more movies bypass a theatrical release to land on your welcome screen, we wondered: do these movies have a quality issue? Or should we accept that most streaming-only movies are “good enough”? We put these questions to critics who regularly review these movies for The Times.

headline: ‘Stargirl’ Review: A Familiar but Charming Romance
abstract: This kindhearted novel adaptation offers a welcome message of embracing one’s true self.
lead_paragraph: Film adaptations of popular Y.A. romance novels have proven such a boon to Netflix that it’s not surprising to see Disney Plus getting into the game. The novel in question is Jerry Spinelli’s best seller “Stargirl.” The film is noteworthy, beyond that target audience, for the participation of the director Julia Hart, the force behind last year’s breathtaking and brilliant “Fast Color.”

headline: ‘Heimat Is a Space in Time’ Review: All History Is Personal
abstract: Thomas Heise, the German documentarian, shares his family’s stories, and Germany’s, through letters and other writing in an experimental format.
lead_paragraph: “Heimat Is a Space in Time” observes Germany for more than a century through the experiences of one family. The bulk of this  experimental essay film, which runs almost four hours, consists of the unseen writer-director, Thomas Heise, reading documents in voice-over — generally letters to and from his relatives, but also résumé drafts, diary entries and, from the Cold War era, a surveillance report.

headline: ‘Human Nature’ Review: We Can Now Alter Our DNA. But Should We?
abstract: Adam Bolt’s new documentary focuses on Crispr technology, which can edit genes, thus giving people the ability to change human, animal and plant life.
lead_paragraph: Every “Oh wow” in “Human Nature” is matched by an “Oh no” somewhere down the line. Together, these two competing emotions — excitement and unease — make for one pretty fascinating documentary.

headline: ‘Big Time Adolescence’ Review: Pete Davidson as Role Model
abstract: A high school student comes of age under the misguidance of his stoner B.F.F. in this comedy by Jason Orley.
lead_paragraph: Pete Davidson, the “Saturday Night Live” bad boy, is a natural at playing the guy your parents want you to stay away from. His character in “Big Time Adolescence,” the tatted, platinum-haired, foul-mouthed Zeke, feels like an extension of the Davidson we see in the tabloids. A 23-year-old slacker who never grew up, Zeke spends his time smoking weed and being a bad influence on his fawning minion, the 16-year-old Mo (Griffin Gluck), his ex-girlfriend’s younger brother.

headline: ‘The Roads Not Taken’ Review: Alternate Lives, All of Them Hellish
abstract: Sally Potter’s new film stars Javier Bardem as a man tormented by visions of his other potential lives. But there’s little lightness negotiating with the dark.
lead_paragraph: Right off the bat, a new movie written and directed by Sally Potter does not take it easy on the viewer. It opens with plain white-on-black titles followed by the sight of Javier Bardem in a bed, in a barely furnished apartment. He lies alone, staring at the ceiling, grunting and mumbling. His guttural utterances are sometimes more frightening than pitiful.

headline: ‘The Dog Doc’ Review: How Puppies Heal (and Heel)
abstract: In this documentary, the animal patients at one veterinary clinic are treated with a standard of care that might make a person jealous.
lead_paragraph: Early on in the documentary “The Dog Doc,” one of the veterinarians working at the Smith Ridge clinic in South Salem, N.Y., mentions that each animal who comes into the clinic is blood tested and offered a nutrition plan based on the results. It’s the first time in “The Dog Doc” that the standards of care practiced at Smith Ridge deliver a jolt. In this compelling film, it’s not the medical miracles that most impress. Instead, the movie makes its biggest impact with treatments that feel like common sense.

headline: Investors Nervous About Coronavirus Ask: Should I Put My 401(k) in Bonds?
abstract: Readers want to know how the outbreak will affect their finances. We have answers.
lead_paragraph: One personal finance question asked widely online recently was: “Should I put my 401(k) in bonds?”

headline: Women’s Art Is Every Kind of Art
abstract: Action painting, textiles, photography — any medium female artists have tried, they’ve excelled in. Now an exhibition in Boston is giving them credit.
lead_paragraph: By 1973, Linda Nochlin was a famed feminist art historian, but a portrait of her from that year at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, highlights another, equally important role she held: as a mother.

headline: De Blasio Declares State of Emergency in N.Y.C., and Large Gatherings Are Banned
abstract: The number of coronavirus cases in the city and state continue to climb.
lead_paragraph: Broadway will go dark for at least a month beginning Thursday after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced restrictions on public gatherings, an extraordinary step to fight the growing outbreak of the coronavirus.

headline: For Mikaela Shiffrin, a Week Without Races Is a Resounding Success
abstract: After flying to Sweden and steeling herself for her first event since her father’s death, Shiffrin declared victory despite never leaving the starting gate.
lead_paragraph: ARE, Sweden — The course was steep, treacherously so, and the snow beneath Mikaela Shiffrin’s skis had the consistency of sliced bread left uncovered all morning. It called to mind the hard and crusty conditions she was exposed to as a child in Vermont and New Hampshire rather than the pillowy foam stuff she skied on, when she skied at all, during her recent month-and-a-half hiatus from competition.

headline: Germany Places Part of Far-Right Party Under Surveillance
abstract: The intelligence agency labeled a wing of the Alternative for Germany extremist, warning of a “danger for democracy.”
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In an unusually strongly worded warning, Germany’s domestic intelligence agency on Thursday officially classified a part of the far-right Alternative for Germany party as extremist and said it would place some of its most influential leaders under surveillance.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Unseen images from a photography legend — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Flashback to the ’80s
abstract: In “We Ride Upon Sticks,” Quan Barry transports readers to the heyday of leg warmers and hair spray.
lead_paragraph: WE RIDE UPON STICKSBy Quan Barry

headline: ‘Inside the Rain’ Review: A Dramedy About Mental Illness
abstract: Aaron Fisher’s movie has a strange, inconsistent rhythm that ultimately works as a reflection of its lead character’s manic and depressive states.
lead_paragraph: “Inside the Rain” begins as a kind of college caper, although in an unusual location: the student disabilities office. Ben Glass (played by the film’s writer and director Aaron Fisher) is a 20-something film major with  bipolar disorder, borderline personality disorder, A.D.H.D., O.C.D. and a host of other conditions.

headline: Coronavirus, Testing Delays Push Europe-Russia Mars Mission to 2022
abstract: “We cannot really cut corners,” said the head of the European Space Agency.
lead_paragraph: A European-Russian mission to put a rover on Mars and look for signs of life there has been postponed, to 2022.

headline: Finger Licking in the Time of Coronavirus
abstract: We’re in the midst of a global pandemic, but my husband can’t give up the crumbs.
lead_paragraph: My husband believes that I am a germaphobe, and I believe he could be more vigilant. I love him, but he has a habit of touching his face during meals, then bringing his fingers to his mouth (to lick crumbs from them or put more food in). With the coronavirus, much of the media has been telling us that touching our faces is a big no-no. How do I gently impress on him that his habit is gross, as well as a potential gateway for infecting himself and others?

headline: Billionaire Confessional: David Rubenstein on Wealth and Privilege
abstract: “Growing up in a family where your father’s pretty wealthy is much more complicated than growing up in a family where your father is not wealthy.”
lead_paragraph: David Rubenstein grew up in a low-income home in Baltimore, the son of a Jewish mailman and a stay-at-home mom. Today he is one of the richest people in the world, worth some $3 billion. It’s an up-by-the-bootstraps story that informs his views on education, income inequality, taxes and more.

headline: Where the Meadows Bloom
abstract: Dan Pearson’s expansive Somerset estate celebrates the English countryside.
lead_paragraph: Dan Pearson’s expansive Somerset estate celebrates the English countryside.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a six-bedroom in Dix Hills, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in South Orange, N.J.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a six-bedroom in Dix Hills, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in South Orange, N.J.

headline: A Garden Grows in Somerset
abstract: For a decade, the master gardener Dan Pearson has been creating a landscape that’s a testament to both his singular eye and Britain’s natural beauty.
lead_paragraph: PRODIGIES FASCINATE: We are riveted by the 7-year-old violinist ripping through Beethoven’s “Kreutzer” sonata and the 13-year-old Oxford University graduate breaking new ground in mathematical knot theory. But what of another rara avis: the horticultural savant? The British garden designer Dan Pearson was 6 when he helped his father engineer a lily-pad pond at their Arts and Crafts-style home in the south of England; at 8, he was tending an elderly neighbor’s greenhouse. He won a seat at the Royal Horticultural Society school at Wisley at 17, and at 25 was named house garden designer at the Conran Shop on Fulham Road, then at the forefront of British interiors; within a year, he had opened his own studio. (My personal connection with him goes back nearly that far: In the mid-1990s, he designed the gardens of Torrecchia Vecchia, the 1,300-acre estate of my late uncle Carlo Caracciolo, south of Rome.)

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the East Village, and Jackson Heights, Queens.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the East Village, and Jackson Heights, Queens.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties include a six-bedroom in Dix Hills, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in South Orange, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens
abstract: This week’s properties are in Williamsburg, the East Village and Jackson Heights.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Trump Attacks Democrats Hours After Calling for Bipartisanship
abstract: The president woke up on Thursday morning and immediately assailed Senator Chuck Schumer and Speaker Nancy Pelosi, just hours after he implored the nation’s political leaders to “stop the partisanship.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Wednesday night, President Trump implored the nation’s political leadership to “stop the partisanship” and come together to confront the coronavirus pandemic. On Thursday morning, he woke up and immediately issued partisan attacks on Democratic congressional leaders.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Mental Health of Teenagers
abstract: What percentage of teenagers see problems like anxiety, bullying, drug addiction and gangs as either major or minor among their peers?
lead_paragraph: This graph, showing the percentage of American teenagers, ages 13 – 17, who feel certain problems are major or minor among people their age in their community, appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com. The data is from a representative sample of 920 teens surveyed from September to November 2018.

headline: Striking a Pose for What It Means to Be a Man
abstract: A photography show at the Barbican Art Gallery presents 50 years of cowboys, skater dudes, frat boys and leather men. But it says little about masculinity today.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — I know we all have bigger concerns now — the swelling hospitals, the swooning markets — but I can’t stop turning over the case of Benjamin Griveaux, the French politician who dropped out of the race for Paris mayor last month.

headline: What Does It Mean for California to Be in a State of Emergency?
abstract: Thursday: California has been in a state of emergency for roughly a week. Here’s what that entails.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ‘Agnes of the Desert’ Joins Modernism’s Pantheon
abstract: The first New York museum exhibition on a still-mysterious painter inspired by the abstract beauty of the American desert.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I interrupted a panel discussion at the Guggenheim as it moved toward the dead-horse question of whether painting was still viable. How, I asked, uninvited, from the audience, could people talk of the end of painting when so many women were just beginning to paint? With hindsight I should have added that we were also still learning about the female painters of the past whose newly recovered works could very well influence the medium. History had in a sense not yet happened to their achievements.

headline: The Most Popular Properties of January and February
abstract: The most viewed listings on The New York Times’s Find a Home site in January and February included a Greenwich Village property that previously set a price record, as well as homes in Louisiana, Oklahoma and Missouri.
lead_paragraph: The most viewed listings on The New York Times’s Find a Home site in January and February included a Greenwich Village property that previously set a price record, as well as homes in Louisiana, Oklahoma and Missouri.

headline: The Exquisite Details of a Fifth Avenue Apartment Renovation
abstract: A couple, and their cultures, harmonize in a place that is reintroduced to the sky.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest special report on Design, which is about getting personal with customization.

headline: 5 Wedding Traditions You Can Skip
abstract: Weddings have evolved and so have the rituals that were once rooted in archaic or sexist practices.
lead_paragraph: Couples are swapping dated wedding traditions for more forward-thinking options: beachfront celebrations for church ceremonies, web-ordained co-workers for religious leaders, and off-the-rack dresses instead of grandma’s heirloom gown. Other traditions, now considered chauvinist or archaic, are also being nixed.

headline: Champions League and Euro 2020 in Jeopardy as Teams Enter Quarantine
abstract: Real Madrid joined Juventus in isolation after contact with an athlete who tested positive for the coronavirus, and UEFA said it would meet to discuss the effects on its competitions.
lead_paragraph: The Champions League, the richest, grandest tournament in club soccer, and other top competitions faced an uncertain future Thursday as positive tests and growing wariness about exposure to the novel coronavirus continued to wreak havoc on the global sports calendar.

headline: Airlines Cancel Flights and Lay Off Workers as Stocks Plummet
abstract: The Trump administration’s 30-day ban on most travelers from Continental Europe because of the coronavirus has dealt a fresh blow to the industry. Norwegian will temporarily halve its staff.
lead_paragraph: Airlines around the world on Thursday scrambled to cancel flights, lay off workers and reassure anxious travelers, capping a dizzying period of weeks in which bookings have evaporated and investors have lost confidence in the industry.

headline: Troubles Percolate in the Plumbing of Wall Street
abstract: Even Treasury bonds were hard to trade Wednesday, and funding markets have shown hints of strain. Investors are looking to the Fed.
lead_paragraph: While most investors have been focused on the rapid decline in the stock market, which had its worst day since the crash of 1987 on Thursday, a different drama is going on behind the scenes on Wall Street — potentially with bigger implications for the economy.

headline: Why Have So Few Americans Been Tested for Coronavirus?
abstract: Europe is not the problem. The small number of tests performed in the United States is.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Francis and the Lights, Pop Star Interrupted
abstract: Three days in the creative wilderness with Francis Farewell Starlite, the reclusive muse to Kanye West, Bon Iver and Drake.
lead_paragraph: SEBASTOPOL, Calif. — On the morning of Dec. 1 last year, the musician Francis Farewell Starlite posted an announcement to his nearly 28,000 followers on Twitter. The message wasn’t an apology, per se, but its pointed brevity and dispassion conveyed a certain amount of heartache and embarrassment.

headline: Out of the Spotlight, Still a Star: The ‘Backstage Diva’
abstract: If you’ve done a musical in Marin County, you know the name Marilyn Izdebski, who has directed more than 10,000 kids over 41 years. Many cities have someone like her.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANSELMO, Calif. — When I arrive at the theater — a barnlike building on the leafy campus of the San Francisco Theological Seminary — to watch the dress rehearsal for “42nd Street,” a petite, bright-eyed woman in her mid-60s warmly greets me. She has perfect posture; her dark hair is in a bun with a pencil stuck through it, and a pair of reading glasses hangs around her neck. She wears black yoga pants, a black zip-up sweater, a black scarf around her neck, white athletic socks and black clogs. This is Marilyn Izdebski’s uniform.

headline: Will ‘Soul’ Put Pixar Back on Track? The Trailer Is Promising
abstract: In an unusual year with two titles, the studio stumbled a bit with “Onward.” But the clip for its next film, due in June, has a lot going for it.
lead_paragraph: With a $39.1 million domestic opening, Pixar’s “Onward” was considered a box-office disappointment last weekend, at least by the animation label’s elevated standards. Disney usually puts out only one Pixar film a year, but that’s not the plan for 2020. “Soul” is slated to come out in June, and the studio just released the film’s first full trailer.

headline: Something Weird Is Happening on Wall Street, and Not Just the Stock Sell-Off
abstract: A sinking feeling reminiscent of the global financial crisis, when all kinds of obscure markets went haywire.
lead_paragraph: It has been an unsettling week on global financial markets, and not just because the stock market has fallen sharply enough to bring a decade-plus bull market to an end.

headline: Is Obsessing Over Daily Coronavirus Statistics Counterproductive?
abstract: Some amount of information is necessary to be prepared, but we also must avoid needless worry.
lead_paragraph: My husband tells me that he looks at coronavirus statistics “once a day — or so.” I know he looks at the numbers at least two or three times a day, but he’s not willing to admit it. He’s a statistics stalker.

headline: Trump’s Travel Ban Leaves Americans in Europe Scrambling to Get Home
abstract: With little clarity on the rules of the 30-day suspension set to take effect on Friday, many are feeling stranded and confused.
lead_paragraph: Across Europe on Thursday, Americans scrambled to make sense of conflicting messages from Washington about if and when they would be allowed to return to the United States.

headline: How Big Pharma Grew Addicted to Big Profits
