abstract: One consequence of coronavirus: It will become more apparent that good online education is easier said than done.
lead_paragraph: Nobody planned for an abrupt mass migration of traditional college courses to the internet.

headline: Worst-Case Estimates for U.S. Coronavirus Deaths
abstract: Projections based on C.D.C. scenarios show a potentially vast toll. But those numbers don’t account for interventions now underway.
lead_paragraph: Officials at the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and epidemic experts from universities around the world conferred last month about what might happen if the new coronavirus gained a foothold in the United States. How many people might die? How many would be infected and need hospitalization?

headline: Learning to Live With the Coronavirus
abstract: Our science reporter answers your questions about how to protect yourself and your loved ones from the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Meet the Woman Who Outsmarted Boko Haram
abstract: Kidnapped and ordered to carry out suicide bombings, Balaraba intentionally botched her missions, buying time before her dramatic rescue.
lead_paragraph: Balaraba was 19 when she was kidnapped from her home in northeastern Nigeria by Boko Haram militants. With murderous blows from their machetes, they made her a widow and a captive.

headline: In a Texas Oil Town, Pain but No Panic as Prices Crash
abstract: The shale drilling peak of a decade ago may never return, but the coronavirus fallout is being taken in stride: “Everyone knows oil is boom and bust.”
lead_paragraph: KARNES CITY, Texas — Leaner days are back in the oil patch of South Texas.

headline: They Ordered Her to Be a Suicide Bomber. She Had Another Idea.
abstract: Hundreds of women in Nigeria have been recruited by Boko Haram as suicide bombers, but some managed to outsmart the terrorist group. This is one woman’s story.
lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — The six young women set down their bombs and stood around the well, staring into the dark void.

headline: Tom Sachs, Emily Ratajkowski and David Byrne at Art Production Fund Gala
abstract: One last big bash — for a while, at least.
lead_paragraph: One last big bash — for a while, at least.

headline: One Last Hurrah?
abstract: Artists, patrons and young socialites gathered for the Art Production Fund gala.
lead_paragraph: Could it be the last gala of the month? Possibly longer? On March 9, a few days before New York State banned most gatherings of more than 500 people because of the coronavirus outbreak, the Art Production Fund held its 10th annual gala at the Seagram Building. The fund, which commissions public art projects, honored Tom Sachs and Sarah Hoover.

headline: Mayor Declares State of Emergency in New York City
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio declared a state of emergency in New York City.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: They’ve Contained the Coronavirus. Here’s How.
abstract: Singapore, Taiwan and Hong Kong have brought outbreaks under control — and without resorting to China’s draconian measures.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — While the spread of Covid-19 is picking up speed in Europe and the United States, among other regions, the outbreaks in some countries in Asia seem to be under control.

headline: Coronavirus, Sophie Grégoire Trudeau, U.S. Soccer: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Behind the ‘Love Is Blind’ Wall
abstract: We have questions for Lauren Speed and Cameron Hamilton, everyone’s favorite couple from the Netflix reality show.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to win over fans on a romantic reality show. But Lauren Speed and Cameron Hamilton did.

headline: A Leap Into Their First Marriage
abstract: Rebecca McIntyre and David Corrsin met 34 years ago. They dated for some of those years. But, why rush things?
lead_paragraph: Before Rebecca Pomeroy McIntyre and David John Corrsin got married on Feb. 29, they came up with a couple of quips about why they chose leap day. Mr. Corrsin joked that he likes the idea of having to remember his anniversary only every four years. Ms. McIntyre declared that marriage is a leap of faith, so the day seemed fitting.

headline: The Games Will Come Back. The Moments We’ll Miss Are Already Gone.
abstract: A March without its usual madness. Shots with no buzzers to beat. It’s not just games that sports is losing. It’s memories and, for some athletes, precious time.
lead_paragraph: The sports seasons of 2020 are about to take a place in the realm of what if.

headline: After the Market’s Worst Day in Decades, Where Do We Go From Here?
abstract: Trillions of dollars in market value were erased after several global exchanges suffered their steepest fall since the Black Monday crash of 1987.
lead_paragraph: It’s Friday the 13th. Stay safe out there. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

headline: On Politics: ‘A Major War’
abstract: The health crisis engulfs the political world: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders spoke in Burlington, Vt., on Thursday about how he would handle a crisis like the coronavirus if he were president.

headline: Trump Falsely Tries to Tie Obama to C.D.C.’s ‘Inadequate’ Testing System
abstract: President Trump, who took office in 2017, criticized the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and his predecessor.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Friday again claimed that his response to the coronavirus was hindered by the Obama administration, which left office three years ago.

headline: De Blasio Stays Firm on Keeping N.Y.C. Schools Open as Outbreak Spreads
abstract: Attendance plunged in New York City schools and the number of coronavirus cases climbed above 400.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Saturday’s live coverage.]

headline: 3 Men Sentenced to 125 Years Each in Drowning of Syrian Refugee Boy
abstract: A Turkish court sentenced each man to 125 years in jail for the death of five refugees, including Alan Kurdi, 2, whose body washed up on a beach.
lead_paragraph: Three Turkish men were sentenced this week to 125 years in jail for their part in the drowning of a boy whose death in 2015 became a worldwide symbol of the suffering caused by the Syrian war and the European refugee crisis it triggered.

headline: Mapping the Social Network of Coronavirus
abstract: To slow the virus, Alessandro Vespignani and other analysts are racing to model the behavior of its human host.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The offices of the Network Science Institute at Northeastern University sit 10 floors above Boston’s Back Bay. Wraparound windows offer a floating panorama of the city, from Boston Common to Fenway Park, as a half-dozen young analysts toil quietly at computers.

headline: In Los Angeles, a Dinner Where Dessert Is Picked From the Trees
abstract: The chef and stylist Gina Correll Aglietti, a co-founder of Yola Mezcal, shares her tips for hosting a casual backyard meal.
lead_paragraph: “I fell madly in love with Mexico City,” says the Los Angeles-based chef and stylist Gina Correll Aglietti of the 2010 trip on which she met one of her business partners, Yola Jimenez. “We had one of those really long Contramar lunches, like four hours,” says Jimenez, referring to a meal they shared at the acclaimed seafood restaurant after connecting through a mutual friend. It’s a summerlike evening in February at Aglietti’s home in Silver Lake, and Aglietti is sautéing fresh blue prawns in mezcal and chili oil while Jimenez leans against the kitchen counter, keeping her company. Later, at golden hour, just before sunset, guests will filter into the house — an R.M. Schindler-designed residence, built in 1934, with a floating, gabled roof and custom-built furniture — to celebrate the musician Danielle Haim’s 31st birthday. “Danielle loves seafood,” explains Aglietti, who is also planning to prepare red rock cod à la plancha.

headline: China Spins Tale That the U.S. Army Started the Coronavirus Epidemic
abstract: After criticizing American officials for politicizing the pandemic, Chinese officials and news outlets have floated unfounded theories that the United States was the source of the virus.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China is pushing a new theory about the origins of the coronavirus: It is an American disease that might have been introduced by members of the United States Army who visited Wuhan in October.

headline: Updates on Sports Canceled by Coronavirus
abstract: The Masters and the Boston Marathon join in the postponements.
lead_paragraph: A day after nearly every major sporting event in the United States had been suspended or canceled because of the coronavirus, it became a question of which sports were on, not which were off.

headline: Film Club: ‘Fear, Humor, Defiance: How the World Is Reacting to Coronavirus’
abstract: What can we learn from others’ experiences of the coronavirus?
lead_paragraph: Teachers: Please note that this week’s film includes powerful and disturbing images — including death and grieving. Be sure to review the film before screening with your class.

headline: Philadelphia Police Officer Is Killed in a Shooting While Trying to Arrest a Suspect
abstract: Cpl. James O’Connor was shot through a closed door while serving an arrest warrant near a church in Northeast Philadelphia. Two people involved in the shooting were injured.
lead_paragraph: A Philadelphia police officer was shot and killed early Friday morning, hit by gunfire through a closed door as his police unit tried to arrest a murder suspect in the Frankford section of the city, the police said.

headline: The Week in Tech: Gigs at Home, but Not What Start-Ups Intended
abstract: Many tech employees have the luxury of working from home in an emergency. But companies like Uber, Airbnb and WeWork could end up hurting.
lead_paragraph: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: The Dollhouses of Instagram
abstract: Instagram-inspired enthusiasts are making their interior-design dreams real — only 12 times smaller.
lead_paragraph: The kitchen that Jessica Coffee designed checked all the trendy boxes: white Shaker cabinets, a subway-tile backsplash, wide oak-plank floors and an open-concept floor plan, with views into the living room’s shiplap walls. The photographs she posted on her Instagram page evoked enthusiastic comments from followers, who gushed about high-end details like the water filler above the stove.

headline: Why Stimulus Matters
abstract: Economic crises are reinforcing.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: U.S. Airstrikes Kill Iraqi Soldiers and Police, Iraqi Officials Say
abstract: Iraqi officers said that the retaliatory strikes against pro-Iranian militias instead hit regular forces, police officers and a civilian.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi military officials strongly condemned the United States military on Friday for airstrikes launched overnight that they said killed three Iraqi soldiers, two police officers and a civilian worker, and damaged an unfinished civilian airport.

headline: ‘What’s the Right Thing to Do Here?’
abstract: Friday: Gov. Gavin Newsom announces new containment measures and Californians grapple with a new reality.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Trump Administration Moves to Speed Coronavirus Testing
abstract: The Department of Health and Human Services and the Food and Drug Administration are funding private companies that are rushing faster tests to the market.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration, facing fierce criticism over a failure to test broadly for the coronavirus, said on Friday that it would set up drive-through testing, start a website to help Americans find a test, and set up new private partnerships to speed tests to the market.

headline: Outfitting a Home for a Child on the Autism Spectrum
abstract: Simple design changes can help create a safe and comforting space for children with autism or sensory processing issues.
lead_paragraph: Many of us have a special spot at home that helps us hit the reset button. It might be a favorite chair, a quiet nook, or simply under the covers, in bed. But for children on the autism spectrum or who have sensory processing issues, finding this kind of sanctuary can be challenging, because ordinary items in the home, like a bright lamp or a textured rug, can trigger a negative reaction.

headline: E.U. to Offer 2,000 Euros to Migrants in Greece to Go Home
abstract: An official said she hoped that up to 5,000 migrants would participate in the voluntary scheme, which had caveats.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Thousands of migrants who have been stranded on Greek islands will be offered 2,000 euros, or $2,230, to return to their home countries, the European Union said on Thursday, in an attempt to ease overcrowding in the camps and lighten the burden on Greece, which has faced an influx of arrivals in recent weeks.

headline: These Ants Have a Revolutionary Escape Strategy
abstract: Why reinvent the wheel when you can become it?
lead_paragraph: Ants are bristling with defense weaponry. Different species might sting their enemies, bite them with powerful jaws or shoot them with jets of formic acid. Some even explode.

headline: Coronavirus Is Shutting Schools. Is America Ready for Virtual Learning?
abstract: Educators experienced with remote learning warn that closures can affect children’s academic progress, safety and social lives.
lead_paragraph: More than 30,000 K-12 schools in the United States are being shuttered because of worries about spreading the coronavirus, affecting at least 20 million students, most of whom will be asked to shift to online learning. Though health experts disagree to what extent school closures will help, entire states, including  Ohio, Illinois and Maryland, and some of the nation’s largest cities, including Los Angeles and Houston, announced closings in recent days.

headline: Don’t Toss This Food Scrap (It Could Be Vastly Improving Your Dishes)
abstract: Many seasoned cooks save their leftover Parmesan rinds to impart umami to brothy dishes. It’s a smart move.
lead_paragraph: Parmesan broth is proof that one cook’s scraps are a better cook’s liquid gold. With just some basic aromatics and cheese rinds that may have otherwise been destined for the trash, you can have a bombastic base for soups, and a flavor infusion for braised vegetables, grains and beans.

headline: David Chang Loves Beethoven’s Ninth (but Won’t Finish ‘Infinite Jest’)
abstract: The chef, author and television personality, whose second season of “Ugly Delicious” just arrived on Netflix, also puts a baby monitor, the Bhagavad Gita and “Gattaca” on his list of essentials.
lead_paragraph: David Chang, the bad-boy chef behind the Momofuku empire, isn’t exactly the guy you would think of when it comes to baby food. But there he is in Season 2 of “Ugly Delicious,” one of his Netflix series, applying his immersion blender to a rainbow of fruits and veggies and then subjecting a 9-month-old baby to a taste test. Smiles (bananas), smears (black beans and beets) and even tears (peas?!) ensue.

headline: At the Armory, Monteverdi’s ‘Vespers’ Are Newly Immersive
abstract: Pierre Audi’s staging of the composer’s “theater in the sound,” opening this month, is centered on a haunting and an enormous wax sculpture.
lead_paragraph: Note: The production in this article has been canceled as part of the response to the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: 6 Podcasts for the Theater Buff
abstract: Whether you’re a stage door regular or an occasional theatergoer, these shows will make you feel as if you’ve got the best seats in the house.
lead_paragraph: Despite perennial concerns about the cultural relevance of one of the oldest art forms, theater is booming. Broadway attendance has risen significantly in recent years, along with profits. But unlike more mainstream formats of scripted storytelling like movies and TV, there is a significant hurdle for anyone trying to keep up with the latest theater in New York and London — namely, easy access. Even for those within commuting distance of Broadway and the West End, the high price tag can create inaccessibility of a different kind.

headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Pressure to Close School System, Nation’s Largest
abstract: The mayor said the city would “try its damnedest” to keep public schools open. But the Council speaker just called for them to shut.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, school districts have shut down to curb the spread of coronavirus. But in New York City, Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo have resisted doing so, despite facing mounting demands.

headline: With Masters Postponed, Not Canceled, Golfers Hope for a Do-Over
abstract: Golf’s first major tournament of the season was postponed indefinitely on Friday because of the spread of coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The 2020 Masters Tournament, golf’s first major championship and a signature, springtime event in American sports, was postponed Friday morning by its host, the Augusta National Golf Club, because of the coronavirus pandemic that has led to sweeping changes across the world.

headline: The Essential Indian Recipes
abstract: Tejal Rao, our California restaurant critic and part of the Indian diaspora, has put together a rich portrait of the country’s home cooking.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. How are you doing? These are unsettling, anxiety-producing times, all over the world. We’re worried — about those we love and about ourselves, about the economy and politics and health of our nation and the ones at and beyond our borders. We’re freaked out about the person shuffling in line at the bank, by her dry cough and damp forehead, not to mention what we make of that character in vinyl gloves and a gas mask at the bagel store. (He’s not robbing the place, but calmly ordering a pound of blueberry cream cheese to take home to quarantine!) I myself bought four pounds of dried black beans at the market, 10 cans of tomato soup for $10, a sleeve of Irish Spring, a lot of bacon and butter and flour, frozen fruit, rice, two boxes of Red Zinger, shelf-stable milk. I don’t know what’s going on with me. You may feel similarly.

headline: Boston and London Marathons Postponed Until Fall
abstract: The Boston Marathon, which was scheduled for April 20, has been postponed until Sept. 14. The London Marathon has been rescheduled for Oct. 4, instead of April 26.
lead_paragraph: After resisting calls to cancel the race for weeks, the Boston Athletic Association announced Friday that the Boston Marathon would be postponed until September because of mounting concerns about the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: ‘The Hunt’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Craig Zobel narrates a sequence from his horror satire starring Betty Gilpin.
lead_paragraph: The director Craig Zobel narrates a sequence from his horror satire starring Betty Gilpin.

headline: How ‘The Hunt’ Makes a Convenience Store Inconvenient
abstract: Craig Zobel narrates this scene from his horror satire featuring Betty Gilpin.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: The Manhattan Private School That Tore Itself Apart
abstract: St. Bernard’s, the renowned boys’ school, removed its beloved headmaster — and a war between very wealthy parents erupted.
lead_paragraph: Six days before Christmas, the headmaster of St. Bernard’s, the 116-year-old boys’ school on the Upper East Side, sent a letter to parents announcing that he would retire in the spring of 2021. For an institution profoundly rooted in its own traditions and protocols and rarely trafficking in the unexpected, the news had a jolting effect.

headline: You Hate Risk. You Need Growth. What Do You Do?
abstract: Getting out of stocks and bonds may shelter you from volatility — but the alternatives have their own perils.
lead_paragraph: Does the stock market’s nose dive make you want to shift into full retreat — no stocks, no bonds at all?

headline: Markets Plunge. Economies Stall. Panic Spreads. It All Feels Very 2008.
abstract: Ineffective monetary policy, scant action from governments, and fear of a leadership void is raising alarm about the pandemic’s economic shock.
lead_paragraph: The last time the world seized with panic over an economic catastrophe, those given the job of limiting the damage knew what to do. The global financial crisis of 2008 presented a textbook case of what happens when people lose faith in the banking system all at once. World leaders could rely on lessons gleaned from history to forge a plan: They flooded the markets with money and waited for calm to return.

headline: Dana Zatopkova, Champion Javelin Thrower, Is Dead at 97
abstract: She is best remembered for winning the gold medal at the 1952 Helsinki Olympics, just an hour after her husband, Emil Zatopek, won the men’s 5,000-meter run.
lead_paragraph: Dana Zatopkova, who won the women’s javelin throw for Czechoslovakia in the 1952 Olympics an hour after her husband, Emil Zatopek, won the men’s 5,000-meter run, died on Friday in Prague. She was 97.

headline: Six Decades After the Banana Boat, Harry Belafonte’s Archive Sails Home
abstract: Mr. Belafonte’s personal archive, acquired by the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, provides a snapshot of a life that mingled art and activism.
lead_paragraph: When Harry Belafonte turned 93 on March 1, he celebrated with a tribute at the Apollo Theater in Harlem, which ended with a thunderous audience singalong to a riff on his star-making 1956 hit, “The Banana Boat Song,” complete with the rapper Doug E. Fresh beatboxing over its famous “Day-O!” refrain.

headline: Spring Fashion: Outerwear Lightens Up
abstract: Trenches, slickers, hats and gloves for the first sight of green.

headline: Opioid Settlement Offer Provokes Clash Between States and Cities
abstract: The big drug distributors would pay $19.2 billion over 18 years. Some 30 states have signed on so far but most cities and counties hate the deal.
lead_paragraph: The three giant drug distributors are negotiating a deal with the states to end thousands of opioid lawsuits nationwide, in which they would pay $19.2 billion over 18 years and immediately submit to stringent monitoring requirements to assure that suspicious orders for prescription opioids would be halted.

headline: Accessories in ’60s Prints That Pack a Graphic Punch
abstract: With their vivid berry hues and blocks of colors and pattern, these shoes and bags add a mod accent to any look.
lead_paragraph: Clockwise from top left: Gianvito Rossi shoes, $995, gianvitorossi.com. Lanvin bag, price on request, similar styles at lanvin.com. Clergerie Paris shoes, $695, us.clergerieparis.com. Hermès shoes, $1,200, hermes.com. Gucci bag, $5,500, gucci.com. Bally bag, $1,750, bally.com. Missoni shoes, $1,330, missoni.com.

headline: American Astronomy’s Future Goes on Trial in Washington
abstract: As competition with Europe heats up, astronomers pitch their dreams of giant telescopes astride the Earth.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Recently, in what amounted to a kind of cosmic Supreme Court hearing, two giant telescope projects pleaded for their lives before a committee charged with charting the future of American astronomy.

headline: When Humans Are the Prey: A Plot Made for Every Era
abstract: “The Hunt” puts a satirical, political spin on a premise that has been remade many times. Why is it so attractive to filmmakers?
lead_paragraph: A young woman awakens in the woods, gagged, confused and afraid. Wandering through the trees and brush, she spots several other people similarly constrained, and together they move toward an open field, where a giant wooden crate awaits them. Inside they find, strangely, a fully clothed pig — and an arsenal of weapons. No sooner have they armed themselves than the carnage begins, and these confused strangers are picked off in a flurry of gunfire, land mines and hand grenades. They’re being hunted.

headline: The World Needs Masks. China Makes Them, but Has Been Hoarding Them.
abstract: As China grappled with the coronavirus, it kept the masks it made. Now that other nations need them, pressure is rising on Beijing to resume exports.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — As hospitals and governments hunt desperately for respirators and surgical masks to protect doctors and nurses from the coronavirus pandemic, they face a difficult reality: The world depends on China to make them, and the country is only beginning to share.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: Notes from a former teenage Riverdancer. What it’s like to be haunted by a gene. Working from home. Essential Indian recipes. Billie Eilish. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. The reads list is back in its old format this weekend.  Here are some amazing articles you may have missed as you tried to keep up with coronavirus news. Take care of yourself, you know, wash your hands and take  precautions. But try not to let worry and fear take over your life.

headline: Searching for Candor in a Dreary, Uncertain and Dishonest Time
abstract: Three-quarters of a century after the United States burned Japanese neighborhoods to the ground, stories  retain an essential vitality, and gain power through candid retelling.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading this week’s At War newsletter. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox every Friday. Email us at atwar@nytimes.com.

headline: Is That a Dalí Among the Tchotchkes?
abstract: A thrift store volunteer in North Carolina noticed something unusual among the donations. It turned out to be a print based on Salvador Dalí’s “Divine Comedy” works.
lead_paragraph: The frame and images looked old, but there was something about the artwork in the thrift store that struck Wendy Hawkins as remarkable.

headline: The Government Has Failed on Coronavirus, but There Is Still Time
abstract: It will require swift, clear and aggressive action, but the country can avoid a worst-case scenario.
lead_paragraph: In times of national crisis, the American people look to our president for leadership and direction. Until recently, President Trump had confronted few, if any, significant national security challenges that were not substantially of his own making. Then came the Covid-19 pandemic, and suddenly the health of all Americans depends on the competence of the president and his team to confront this deadly global threat.

headline: Gothic Horror Fiction, Old and New
abstract: In these books, demons infest an elderly tutor, a ghost roams an opera house and a doctor embalms some very strange and horrible things.
lead_paragraph: Lately, my favorite fiction has transported me out of the terrors of the present and thrust me back in time. Take Jess Kidd’s utterly mesmerizing third novel, THINGS IN JARS (Atria, 369 pp., $27), set in a Victorian-era London of gargoyles that “vomit rainwater” and “labyrinthian alleys, twisting passages, knocked-up and tumbling-down houses.” Bridie Devine, a pipe-smoking, cross-dressing investigator, walks these streets solving crimes.

headline: Pilot in Emiliano Sala Crash Lacked Commercial License
abstract: A report from Britain’s air accident investigation body said both the pilot in the fatal crash, David Ibbotson, and the small plane were cleared only for private flights.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The pilot of a small plane that crashed into the English Channel last year, killing the Argentine soccer player Emiliano Sala, was not licensed to fly commercially, and neither was the aircraft, investigators said in a report released on Friday.

headline: What Are the Stephen Sondheim Songs Close to Your Heart?
abstract: What is your favorite Sondheim song and why?
lead_paragraph: To celebrate Stephen Sondheim’s 90th birthday, we’re pulling out all the stops in the March 15 issue of Arts & Leisure. Jesse Green, one of our co-chief theater critics, makes the case for him as “an artist to place in the line of America’s foundational 20th-century playwrights.” Ben Brantley, our other co-chief theater critic, wrote, “when it comes to emotions, Sondheim — more than any other composer from the Broadway songbook — is the one I trust to tell me the truth.”

headline: How to Fix the Coronavirus Testing Mess in 7 Days
abstract: President Trump finally put someone in charge. Here’s what needs to be done next.
lead_paragraph: The director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention was asked at a congressional hearing on Thursday who was in charge of making sure that people can be tested for Covid-19, especially health care workers.

headline: Irresistible Garlicky Noodles
abstract: Ready in 45 minutes, Andrea Nguyen’s recipe is hearty, savory and relies heavily on (mainly) shelf-stable ingredients.
lead_paragraph: Hello, friends of Five Weeknight Dishes. During these strange days, are you spending more time than usual in the kitchen? I certainly am, what with all the canceled events, plus the added job of getting food on the table — not just at dinner! — for those of us sticking close to home. Fortunately NYT Cooking has pulled together a collection of lunch recipes.

headline: Andrew Gillum in Miami Beach Hotel Room as Man Overdosed, Police Say
abstract: The police are not pursuing criminal charges in an apparent overdose involving a friend of Mr. Gillum’s, the former Democratic nominee for Florida governor.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Andrew Gillum, one of the Democratic Party’s fast-rising political stars, was in a Miami Beach hotel room early on Friday when emergency workers were called to treat another man suffering from a probable drug overdose, the police said.

headline: How to Stop Worrying and Love a Falling Stock Market
abstract: It's perfectly natural to be terrified. But big losses bring certain benefits, too.
lead_paragraph: When the stock market falls as far and as fast as it has in the last three weeks, it is perfectly natural to be terrified.

headline: Drake and DaBaby Join Lil Yachty’s Shtick, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Margo Price, Natalia Lafourcade, Ava Max and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Comforting Streaming TV Shows for Stressful Times
abstract: When the world feels exhausting, sometimes you want shows that offer a simple escape. Here are a few shows that will envelop you in their warm embrace.
lead_paragraph: Streaming links are for subscriptions services only. Share your own recommendations in the comments section.

headline: Joe Biden’s Young Voter Problem: They Don’t Think He’s Listening
abstract: Older voters have easily carried Mr. Biden to victory in multiple primaries. But if he wants to beat President Trump, he will have to win younger voters too — and that may not be easy.
lead_paragraph: The magnitude of former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s recent primary victories has obscured an important schism within the Democratic Party: between the older voters who carried Mr. Biden to victory and the younger voters who overwhelmingly rejected him.

headline: The Beauty Is in the Details
abstract: What one artist learned when she sat down to talk with Lynda Barry.

headline: ‘Westworld’ Season 3 Is Here. Wait, What Happened in Season 2?
abstract: It’s been a while since the last season finale, and the details were a little fuzzy the first time around. Here’s some help before the start of Season 3.
lead_paragraph: It has been about a year and a half since the second season of “Westworld” ended with “The Passenger,” a feature-length episode so loaded with timelines and twists that even explainer articles became their own Russian nesting dolls.

headline: The ‘Man Show’ Diaspora
abstract: The Comedy Central raunch-fest didn’t seem like it would be politically relevant two decades later. But that was long before Joe Rogan interviewed presidential candidates and Pete Buttigieg filled in for Jimmy Kimmel.
lead_paragraph: It’s possible you do not remember “The Man Show.” Or perhaps you don’t want to.

headline: Trump Won’t Be Getting a Coronavirus Test, His Doctor Says
abstract: The statement from President Trump’s physician came just hours after Mr. Trump himself said he would be tested “fairly soon.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There was one big question looming on Friday over the Rose Garden, where President Trump held an afternoon news conference and announced new emergency measures to combat the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: 500 Years of Pregnant Women in Art
abstract: An exhibition in London examines how expecting mothers have been portrayed from the Middle Ages to to the digital era. Here are some of the highlights.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The actress Demi Moore stands sideways to the camera, one hand splayed around a breast, another cupping her 7-months-pregnant stomach. The 1991 Annie Leibowitz photograph on the cover of Vanity Fair was a culture-changing moment; an unashamed representation of the pregnant body that shocked the world.

headline: Fears Rise for World Leaders as Officials Test Positive for Virus
abstract: The global pandemic has reached into the circles of political elites around the world, as their top aides, ministers and even a spouse test positive for the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Even as governments around the world struggle to contain the coronavirus pandemic, many officials are themselves falling victim to the pathogen, undermining global efforts to address the crisis.

headline: Buying a Home During a Pandemic
abstract: The coronavirus is scary. But those willing to enter the housing market have the benefit of low rates — and the wisdom of those who bought during the last crisis.
lead_paragraph: Your down payment fund was safely in cash. You’d planned, perhaps for years, for the 2020 home-buying season. Then, just as the perfect home hit the market, the coronavirus turned the world on its head.

headline: Coronavirus Testing Goes Mobile in Seattle
abstract: In the center of the U.S. outbreak, one medical center has begun screening workers for the new virus by setting up a mobile clinic in a parking lot where cars serve as isolated waiting rooms.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — On an overcast day in Seattle, a few dozen medical staff members, students and emergency workers with symptoms of the fast-spreading coronavirus spent their lunch break driving to a parking garage.

headline: Rushing to Refinance Your Mortgage: 6 Tips and What to Avoid
abstract: Communicate constantly, document everything — and definitely don’t apply for a new credit card.
lead_paragraph: When mortgage rates fall to record lows, as they have in recent weeks, homeowners who see a chance to save some money race to refinance. Just be sure you don’t get stuck at the end of the line.

headline: Alex Jones Is Told to Stop Selling Sham Anti-Coronavirus Toothpaste
abstract: Mr. Jones, who has used his radio show and website to promote conspiracy theories, is falsely claiming his products can fight the virus.
lead_paragraph: The New York State attorney general has issued a cease-and-desist order to Alex Jones, the conservative radio host, alarmed by false claims on his website that his diet supplements and toothpaste could be used to fight the coronavirus.

headline: Procrastinate Much? Manage Your Emotions, Not Your Time.
abstract: It isn’t about avoiding work; it’s about avoiding negative emotions.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1980s, Douglas Adams was struggling to make progress on the fourth installment in his beloved series, “The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy.” The great sci-fi humorist had learned from writing the previous books that good ideas usually came to him in the bath, so he would spend his mornings soaking in the tub until he had a eureka moment. Then he would get out to start writing, only to forget the idea while getting dressed, which meant he had no choice but to head right back to the tub.

headline: Can Our Political Leaders Still Reassure Us?
abstract: People in a country in trouble look to the president to help soothe and to tell them that although things might be bad, we will eventually be all right.
lead_paragraph: It seems almost churlish to compare a speech by President Donald J. Trump in 2020 to one by Prime Minister Winston Churchill in 1940. In the canon of reassurance — the model for how a leader might address a nation on edge — Churchill’s “We Shall Fight on the Beaches” address to the House of Commons after the mass evacuation of British forces at Dunkirk during World War II sets an extremely high bar.

headline: Behind the Cover: The Music Issue
abstract: For this issue, a look at the 25 songs that matter right now.

headline: Overlooked No More: Ni Gusti Ayu Raka Rasmi, Balinese Dancer
abstract: At the age of 12 she was the star of a troupe that performed in 1952 at theaters in the United States and Europe.
lead_paragraph: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Europe Pledges Billions in Economic Aid in Rare Sign of Unity
abstract: Announcements from government leaders contrast with the bickering that characterized Europe’s response to the financial crisis a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: In an unusual show of unity and resolve, European leaders said they would spend hundreds of billions of euros to prevent the coronavirus outbreak from provoking a deep recession or financial crisis.

headline: With Echoes of 2008, Mnuchin and Pelosi Hammer Out a Rescue Deal
abstract: The Treasury secretary has emerged as President Trump’s bridge across the aisle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When America’s financial system teetered on the brink in September 2008, the Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr., knelt down in the White House’s Roosevelt Room and pleaded with Speaker Nancy Pelosi not to withdraw her support for a $700 billion bailout package that was intended to fend off an economic collapse.

headline: How the Coronavirus Is Changing Everything
abstract: Readers urge officials to stop playing politics and offer ideas for coping and preventing future outbreaks.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bernie Sanders and the Case of the Missing Youth Vote
abstract: Apathy is not the problem.
lead_paragraph: Young voters want Bernie Sanders to be the Democratic nominee for president. But they don’t seem to want to turn out for him, or at least not in the numbers he needs to win.

headline: Love Letter: Life After ‘Love Is Blind’
abstract: Plus: Bonding over divorce.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up here to receive Love Letter, a weekly newsletter about relationship highs, lows and woes, in your inbox every Friday.]

headline: Miami Mayor Tests Positive for Coronavirus
abstract: Mayor Francis Suarez was tested after being in close contact with an aide to President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The scene was jarring: The mayor of a major American city communicated with the citizenry via video on a big screen at City Hall to deliver frightening news. He was placing himself in isolation in case he had contracted the coronavirus.

headline: How to Wash Your Hands
abstract: It’s one of the most important things you can do to protect yourself, your family and your community. And if you’re like us, you’ve probably been doing it wrong.
lead_paragraph: We asked the experts how to wash our hands. After they taught us the proper technique (above), we had a few more questions:

headline: In a Pandemic, Musicians Play in Empty Halls for Audiences Online
abstract: Bans on large gatherings have meant those tuning in aren’t aping the live listeners. They are the only listeners.
lead_paragraph: I was watching on my computer at home on Thursday afternoon as the Berlin Philharmonic finished a streamed performance of Luciano Berio’s “Sinfonia.” The cameras panned over rows of seats. No one was there. The musicians, dressed in their black-tie best, seemed not to know quite what to do. Finally, they began greeting each other cheerily, then stood and faced the empty hall.

headline: Panicked Shoppers Empty Shelves as Coronavirus Anxiety Rises
abstract: The scene inside one crowded store: There was no chicken available, nor garbanzo beans or chips. Another had no flu or cold medicines.
lead_paragraph: They grabbed milk and aspirin, paper towels and spaghetti. Cans of soup and bottles of laundry detergent. Olive oil and sanitizing wipes. With futures suddenly thrust into the unknown, they did what felt reassuring: panic shop.

headline: Israel’s Coronavirus Crisis Lets Netanyahu Seize the Initiative
abstract: Amid a yearlong political and legal imbroglio, a deadly contagion may give Israel’s embattled prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, a new lease on political life.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The scourge of coronavirus converged this week with Israel’s yearlong electoral impasse, creating a crisis that could politically benefit the country’s embattled but indefatigable prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: From the Archives: Michael Lewis and Tana French
abstract: Lewis discusses “The Fifth Risk,” and French talks about “The Witch Elm.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Finally, a Plan for New York’s Sidewalk Trash Bag Mountains
abstract: City officials want additional storage inside buildings and attractive street-side bins.
lead_paragraph: They are piled all over New York — unsightly monuments of trash blocking sidewalks and threatening pedestrian safety. For years, overstuffed garbage bags awaiting pickup have looked like an unavoidable fact of life.

headline: House Passes Coronavirus Relief After Democrats Strike Deal With White House
abstract: Democrats dropped a proposal to establish a new paid sick leave entitlement for public health emergencies and added tax credits for small- and medium-size businesses requested by Republicans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump declared a national emergency on Friday over the coronavirus pandemic and announced steps he said would speed the availability of testing, and early Saturday, the House passed a bill reflecting a deal with his administration to provide billions of dollars to help sick workers and to prop up a slumping economy.

headline: C.D.C.’s Dr. Robert Redfield Confronts Coronavirus, and Anger
abstract: He has been cautious, technical and reserved in the face of intense criticism for the agency’s delay in rolling out testing for the infection.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Robert R. Redfield, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, was in the hot seat — again.

headline: Social Distancing? You Might Be Fighting Climate Change, Too
abstract: Isolation and other shifts in behavior during the coronavirus outbreak could also alter our greenhouse gas emissions. But will the changes stick?
lead_paragraph: As the nation shifts abruptly into the fight against coronavirus, a question arises: could social isolation help reduce an individual’s production of greenhouse gases and end up having unexpected consequences for climate change?

headline: Something Else Troubling Is Going Around: Dubious Investments
abstract: As markets plunge, investors are likely to see more pitches from annuity brokers peddling complex products. Buyer beware.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the stock market began its initial descent, Rob Phelan, a high school math teacher in Maryland, received an email sales pitch: “The Coronavirus may be Fatal — to Your Retirement Savings!”

headline: The Exponential Power of Now
abstract: The explosive spread of coronavirus can be turned to our advantage, two infectious disease experts argue: “But only if we intervene early. That means now.”
lead_paragraph: In early December, Britta Jewell, an infectious disease epidemiologist at the MRC Centre for Global Infectious Disease Analysis, Imperial College London, began researching some of the novel respiratory viruses that were then circulating.

headline: Le Bernardin, Daniel and Other Top New York Restaurants Temporarily Close
abstract: Others are likely to follow as owners’ worries shift from canceled reservations to survival.
lead_paragraph: Some of New York City’s leading restaurants, including Le Bernardin and Daniel, announced Friday that they would close indefinitely after dinner that night. All 19 of the Union Square Hospitality Group’s restaurants in New York City closed after lunch on Friday and will remain closed until further notice, said Danny Meyer, the group’s founder and chief executive.

headline: Spain Becomes Latest Epicenter of Coronavirus After a Faltering Response
abstract: The government declared a state of emergency Friday, days after it allowed mass gatherings in the capital and cases jumped to 4,200.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Just last weekend, about 120,000 people marched through downtown Madrid to celebrate International Women’s Day. Some 60,000 soccer fans filled one of the city’s largest stadiums. And 9,000 supporters of Vox, Spain’s third-largest party, gathered inside a former bullring.

headline: Spring Break Was in Full Mode, and Then It Got Canceled
abstract: As bad news continued to mount, the coronavirus sucked the fun and money out of Florida’s annual spring break.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — Dryden Quigley, a junior at Duke University, and three friends began making plans to spend spring break in Miami Beach about six weeks ago when the coronavirus still felt relatively distant. It does not feel distant now.

headline: When Coronavirus Cancels Concerts, Critics Put on Headphones
abstract: Our homebound writers choose their favorite recordings of works they were scheduled to hear live.
lead_paragraph: With concert halls and opera houses closed around the world as part of bans on large gatherings aimed at curbing the coronavirus outbreak, what are homebound classical critics to do? Listen to favorite recordings of the music they were scheduled to hear live, of course! Enjoy.

headline: Young, Confident and Flying, Virus Be Damned
abstract: For some people, a $50 plane ticket is too good a deal to pass up, even during a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: As people self-quarantine, work from home and generally wall themselves off from the outside world, Joe DeSimone is preparing to travel the globe.

headline: Making the Show Without a Studio
abstract: This week, we took our work home with us.
lead_paragraph: By the middle of this week, The Times had made it official: It wanted employees to begin working from home by Friday to limit potential exposure to the coronavirus.

headline: Broadway Is Closed, but London’s Theaters Carry On
abstract: Britain has taken a more relaxed approach to coronavirus prevention than the rest of Europe and the United States.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On Broadway, theater doors are shut. In Milan, the Teatro alla Scala opera house is silent. In Paris, theaters including the storied Comédie-Française announced on Friday they were closing down temporarily, too.

headline: 12 Recent Netflix Originals Worth Streaming While Stuck at Home
abstract: The streaming service constantly pumps out new original TV series, making it tough to keep up. These are the best from the past few months.
lead_paragraph: Keeping up with everything new on Netflix these days is practically a full-time job. Just consider the Netflix original TV shows alone: The streaming service’s business model involves producing or distributing more than a dozen entirely new shows each month, in a variety of genres, pitched to wildly diverging audiences. It’s easy for even the most dedicated watchers to fall behind.

headline: How to Answer Common Difficult Interview Questions
abstract: Don’t be stumped in your next job interview. These tips can help.
lead_paragraph: In its simplest form, a job interview is an attempt to impress someone at the other end of the table. Your résumé and qualifications got your foot in the door, but the in-person interview is where potential hires most often succeed or flounder.

headline: Those Long Lines? People Stocking the Liquor Cabinet, Not the Pantry
abstract: Consumers preparing to hole up at home are adding wine, beer and spirits to their list of must-haves, but shopkeepers worry it’s just the storm before the calm.
lead_paragraph: People have been clearing grocery aisles of toilet paper, peanut butter and pasta as they prepare to hunker down at home during the coronavirus pandemic. Now, liquor is the next must-have item for many consumers wondering how they are going to cope during the current global public health crisis.

headline: Making Connections: 56 Teenagers Suggest Creative Ways to Link School Curriculum to the World of 2020
abstract: Whether they studied the French Revolution, the Röttgen Pietà or “Grapes of Wrath,” our winners made thoughtful parallels to the news of today.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 1,600 students took us up on our third annual December challenge to “connect what you’re learning in school with the world today,” and, as was true in both 2018 and 2019, what we liked best was seeing your thinking in action.

headline: I Practiced Social Distancing Before Coronavirus. It Works.
abstract: Self-isolating may sound excessive and inconvenient, but it kept my premature babies alive.
lead_paragraph: Infections and deaths from the new coronavirus continue to spread worldwide, and the World Health Organization has officially declared the outbreak a pandemic.

headline: California Man Pleads Guilty in $6 Million Art Fraud Case
abstract: Prosecutors said that Philip Righter forged documentation for fake paintings and used the artwork as collateral for loans.
lead_paragraph: A California man pleaded guilty in federal court in Florida to charges that he tried to sell more than $6 million in counterfeit art, which he falsely claimed was created by the likes of Andy Warhol and Jean-Michel Basquiat, prosecutors said this week.

headline: R. Kelly Knowingly Exposed Sex Partners to Herpes, Prosecutors Say
abstract: The new allegations against the singer were revealed ahead of a trial set for July in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: For months, the singer R. Kelly has faced federal charges that he sexually exploited underage girls and young women, but on Friday prosecutors added a lurid wrinkle: They accused him of knowingly exposing two people to a venereal disease.

headline: Coronavirus Silences the Met Opera, and Poses an Economic Threat
abstract: The Met, the biggest performing arts organization in the nation, will lose millions in ticket revenues.
lead_paragraph: During the last few performances before the coronavirus outbreak silenced the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday, posters placed discreetly in the theater’s restrooms offered tips for staying healthy: Avoid contact with the sick. Cover coughs. Wash hands.

headline: Andreas Brown, Longtime Owner of Gotham Book Mart, Dies at 86
abstract: An appraiser and archivist, he bought the celebrated mid-Manhattan shop in 1967 from its founder, Frances Steloff and ran it for 40 years.
lead_paragraph: Andreas Brown, a bibliophile since childhood who bought the revered Gotham Book Mart in Midtown Manhattan from its idiosyncratic founder, Frances Steloff, and kept it alive as a frowzy literary shrine for four more decades, died on March 6 in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Turkey Steps Back From Confrontation at Greek Border
abstract: The country is winding down an aggressive two-week operation to move tens of thousands of migrants to its frontiers. But relations with Greece and Europe have suffered.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Turkey has signaled that it is winding down its two-week operation to aid the movement of tens of thousands of people toward Europe, following a tough on-the-ground response from Greek border guards and a tepid diplomatic reaction from European politicians.

headline: The Night TV Went It Alone
abstract: Late-night’s coronavirus-driven goodbye to the studio audience was a reminder of how much we’re used to that virtual connection.
lead_paragraph: “As you may have noticed,” Stephen Colbert told the camera Thursday, “none of you are here right now.”

headline: At the Iranian Border, Iraqis Try to Keep a Virus From Entering
abstract: Iran has one of the world’s largest concentrations of the coronavirus. Iraq has had few cases, and wants to keep it that way. Things can get testy.
lead_paragraph: ZURBATIYA, Iraq — The voices rose angrily and a knot of people gathered on the Iraqi side of the border crossing with Iran. Two Iranian diplomats were trying to get relatives out of Iran, where the coronavirus is rampant, and into Iraq.

headline: A Brain Hack to Break the Coronavirus Anxiety Cycle
abstract: Uncertainty about coronavirus spreads anxiety through social contagion. Here’s a way to minimize that.
lead_paragraph: Anxiety is a strange beast.

headline: Charles Wuorinen, Uncompromising Modernist Composer, Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Wuorinen won a Pulitzer Prize at 31 and went on to write a large body of mainly atonal works, including the opera “Brokeback Mountain.”
lead_paragraph: Charles Wuorinen, a Pulitzer Prize-winning composer and formidable advocate for modernist music, high culture and the composer’s worth, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 81.

headline: 9 Shows for Social Distancing
abstract: What do a musical mockumentary, an addiction sitcom, two true-crime docs and a pottery competition have in common? They can all help you remove yourself from society.
lead_paragraph: Staying home should be the easy part, but pandemics and snow days are not quite the same. Looking for a few hours of distraction between vigorous hand-washings? Need a moment away from Twitter? These are some wonderful shows to get you through.

headline: Coronavirus, Iraq, Pi Day: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Amid a Pandemic, Trump Moves Forward With Safety Net Cuts
abstract: As the coronavirus upends the economy, the Trump administration plans to make changes to the food stamp program that could lead to nearly 700,000 people losing assistance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite the worsening pandemic, the Trump administration is pushing ahead with tougher work requirements for food stamps, and so far has not offered states the opportunity to cover the uninsured on an emergency basis under Medicaid.

headline: Bill Gates Stepping Down From Microsoft’s Board
abstract: Mr. Gates, who founded the company with Paul Allen four decades ago, will also step down from the board of Berkshire Hathaway.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Bill Gates is stepping down from the board of Microsoft, the software giant he helped found more than four decades ago.

headline: Their School Is Open. But the Kids Are Staying Home.
abstract: As the coronavirus continues to spread, some parents think that sending their children to school and day care is too risky.
lead_paragraph: Each day, more and more schools across the country are closing to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus. On Thursday, officials in Ohio and Washington State announced closures for many kids in kindergarten through 12th grade. Today, the Los Angeles Unified School District — which serves more than 600,000 students and is the second largest district in the nation — said it was closing its public schools for two weeks. Yet in many regions of the United States, schools remain open, business as usual, even when other schools mere blocks away have shut down.

headline: How Far Can Canada Go to Slow Spread of the New Coronavirus?
abstract: In this week’s Canada Letter, we speak with an expert on public health law about the government’s powers in an extraordinary time.
lead_paragraph: It’s well beyond the space limitations of this newsletter to summarize the new coronavirus developments of the last week internationally, let alone in Canada. Here at The Times, we’ve been drawing on our journalists around the world to produce a steady flow of reporting on the health crisis.

headline: Tom Turnipseed, a ‘Reformed Racist’ After Backing Wallace, Dies at 83
abstract: He supported George Wallace’s 1968 presidential bid. But after a change of heart, he worked for civil rights and other progressive causes.
lead_paragraph: Tom Turnipseed, who after working on the presidential campaign of the segregationist George C. Wallace in 1968 took a 180-degree turn and became a prominent champion of civil rights, died on March 6 at his home in Columbia, S.C. He was 83.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: President Trump declared a national emergency.
lead_paragraph: President Trump declared a national emergency for the growing coronavirus pandemic on Friday, capping a week in which the virus began to alter nearly every part of life in the United States. Cases in the U.S. have climbed to almost 2,000, even with sparse testing, and the death toll has risen to 41.

headline: The Stranded Stars of Wuhan F.C.
abstract: A professional soccer team from Wuhan, China, went to Spain for preseason training. And got stuck. For six weeks. On Thursday, they let @tariqpanja in to talk about how they are holding up.
lead_paragraph: MARBELLA, Spain — Many times, Yao Hanlin has pictured what his homecoming will look like. There will be a tearful reunion with his wife and his infant son, an embrace for his mother and then there will be bowls full of spicy, dry noodles. Oh, how he has craved those noodles.

headline: Coronavirus Is Causing Chaos for Travel Influencers
abstract: When your income depends on promoting travel, staying home comes at a cost.
lead_paragraph: As flights, events, and media trips are canceled and hospitality marketers tighten their budgets over coronavirus fears, travel influencers are scrambling.

headline: As Europe Shuts Down, Britain Takes a Different, and Contentious, Approach
abstract: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has largely kept Britain open, opting for more targeted measures, a strategy that has startled some epidemiologists.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain once said his political hero was the mayor in the film “Jaws,” praising him for defying mass hysteria to keep the beaches open after a constituent is eaten by a shark.

headline: Administration Offers Guidance to Schools as They Shut Down on Their Own
abstract: Facing pressure from parents, conflicting messages from experts and initial silence from the federal government, superintendents began making their own decisions to close.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention advised schools on Friday that closings for at least eight weeks might be the most effective way to contain the coronavirus. The Education Department released school districts from a slew of testing and accountability measures required by federal law.

headline: Is There Really a Toilet Paper Shortage?
abstract: The household staple has consistently been out of stock during the coronavirus outbreak. Manufacturers may not be willing to increase supplies.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one image that captures the panic seeping through the United States this week, it might be the empty store shelves where toilet paper usually sits.

headline: Why Young Latinx Voters Rallied Behind Sanders
abstract: The answer is not very complicated.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders’s message has resonated among young people, particularly younger Latinx voters. In California, where they make up about a third of the constituency, Latinx voters under 30 overwhelmingly supported Mr. Sanders. That electorate helped his campaign carry enough delegates in California and Texas to keep the nomination contest within 100 delegates after the Super Tuesday contests. Though he didn’t win Michigan, they also backed him there. So why are young Latinx voters rallying behind Mr. Sanders?

headline: Past Issues of T Magazine
abstract: A complete archive starting in 2008.
lead_paragraph: A complete archive starting in 2008.

headline: Stocks Surge After Trump Promises Speedier Coronavirus Testing
abstract: President Trump, surrounded by business leaders, said coronavirus tests would soon be more widely available. Investors pushed the market up nearly 10 percent.
lead_paragraph: The stock market roared back to life on Friday, with the S&P surging 9.3 percent after President Trump said the government would speed up coronavirus testing for Americans. In doing so, he delivered investors exactly the message they had been waiting to hear — a half-hour before the market closed.

headline: Mary Shelley Created ‘Frankenstein,’ and Then a Pandemic
abstract: Her novel ‘The Last Man’ predicted the political causes of and collective solutions for global plague.
lead_paragraph: The world teeters in collective anxiety in the midst of a pandemic. A novel and lethal plague spreads its tentacles around the earth. It ravages human populations and simultaneously undermines their interconnected economic and political systems. An elite group of political leaders gathers to ask, What should be done in the face of a worldwide public health crisis?

headline: What Are the Rules for Play Dates During the Coronavirus Crisis?
abstract: We asked the experts.
lead_paragraph: Schools and day care centers are closing, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is telling us to limit close contact with others if the coronavirus is known to be spreading within our community. But what does close contact mean, exactly? Should we stop letting our kids have play dates? Is it OK to go to the museum or playground or indoor trampoline park? And what about birthday parties?

headline: Transcript: Trump’s Coronavirus News Conference
abstract: President Trump held a news conference on Friday with health and business leaders during which he declared a state of emergency over the coronavirus. Here are his opening remarks.
lead_paragraph: “Today I’d like to provide an update to the American people on several decisive new actions we’re taking in our very vigilant effort to combat and ultimately defeat the coronavirus.

headline: Justice Dept. Religious Freedom Training Spurs Concern Among Lawyers
abstract: Some department lawyers expressed worries that the workshops were held to teach ways to limit civil rights protections for gay and transgender people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department this week hosted training for its lawyers on religious liberty laws as part of Attorney General William P. Barr’s push to prioritize religious freedom cases, but the workshops prompted concern among some career lawyers that they were being educated on ways to blunt civil rights protections for gay and transgender people.

headline: When New York’s Cultural Centers Shut Down, They Made Lemonade
abstract: Resourceful tourists whose dream trips to New York have been upended by the pandemic are doing their best to cobble together alternative entertainment.
lead_paragraph: Patty Schlafer flew in late Thursday from Wisconsin, and her sister, Kathy Coughlin, flew up from Atlanta the same night, for a trip of a lifetime that had been a year in the works.

headline: Trump Declared an Emergency Over Coronavirus. Here’s What It Can Do.
abstract: The president’s action will free up funds and lower legal barriers for responding to the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday signed an emergency declaration over the coronavirus pandemic, unlocking certain government powers to deal with the public health challenge. Here’s a breakdown of what that means on a legal and practical level.

headline: Trump Meets Nemesis, Punisher of Hubris
abstract: A virus exposes the folly of what the president’s base believes.
lead_paragraph: The word “nemesis” is too often misused. We tend to think of it as meaning a powerful, nefarious, but ultimately conquerable enemy: Vader; Voldemort; the Wicked Witch of the West. But the original Nemesis was not a villain. She was a goddess — an implacable agent of justice who gives the arrogant, insolent and wicked what they deserve.

headline: An Isolation Center Opened to Protect People From Coronavirus. Then Someone Wandered Out.
abstract: A homeless person being tested for the coronavirus wandered out of a new isolation housing facility south of Seattle, prompting alarm from neighbors who wish their town hadn’t been chosen.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Washington State had a problem: there were sure to be more coronavirus cases, and not enough safe places to isolate them. Officials found what they thought was a solution in the form of a shuttered Econo Lodge Motel in the city of Kent, south of Seattle, and modular housing units in another mostly lower-income neighborhood.

headline: Full Appeals Court to Decide Whether Congress Can Sue Executive Branch
abstract: The court took up disputes over funding for President Trump’s border wall and a subpoena to Donald F. McGahn II, his former White House counsel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The entire federal appeals court in Washington said on Friday that it would take up two cases that raised the question of whether and when Congress may sue to resolve a dispute with the president, setting up a double-barreled test for establishing when the judicial branch can resolve disputes over separation of powers.

headline: Special Episode: A Bit of Relief
abstract: Three Times journalists share what they’re turning to right now for comfort.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Seeking Advice on the Coronavirus, Jared Kushner Enlists a Doctor in the Family
abstract: Dr. Kurt Kloss, whose daughter, the model Karlie Kloss, is married to Mr. Kushner’s brother, solicited suggestions from a medical Facebook group.
lead_paragraph: One night this week an urgent appeal went out to a Facebook group of emergency room doctors. “If you were in charge of the Federal response to the Pandemic what would your recommendations be?” asked Dr. Kurt Kloss, a physician based in New York.

headline: Trump’s False Claims About His Response to the Coronavirus
abstract: The president inaccurately described travel restrictions he had announced, falsely blamed his predecessor for testing shortages and misstated the role Google was playing in mitigating the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: As he declared a national emergency over the coronavirus outbreak, President Trump attempted to deflect criticisms of his administration’s response to the virus with inaccurate claims. Here’s a fact-check.

headline: Cap and Gone? College Commencements Confront the Coronavirus
abstract: The University of Michigan canceled its planned ceremony while students at the University of Maine threw an impromptu “Coronamencement.”
lead_paragraph: The University of Michigan on Friday canceled its commencement planned for May over fears of the coronavirus — one of what is likely to be many such college ceremonies to be reconsidered in the face of the pandemic.

headline: It’s Office-Bound
abstract: Peter Wentz brings us flowers and a vibrant Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I trust that everyone is enjoying a little extra puzzle time and staying productive, not getting stir crazy at all. Today we have a Peter Wentz construction, his first for 2020; it comes with 10 debuts and a generous sprinkle of fun clues and misdirects.

headline: Trump’s Chernobyl
abstract: Thirty-four years ago in Moscow I watched the government mishandle a disaster. Why does it feel like it was just yesterday?
lead_paragraph: It seems terribly wrong that so fine a spring day should be carrying a deadly danger. The daffodils and cherry blossoms proclaim renewal and hope; the crisp, clear air seems incapable of anything so treacherous.

headline: Fox Business Benches Trish Regan After Outcry Over Coronavirus Comments
abstract: The host of “Trish Regan Primetime” told viewers this week that concerns about the coronavirus were “yet another attempt to impeach the president.”
lead_paragraph: The Fox Business anchor Trish Regan, whose on-air dismissal of the coronavirus as “another attempt to impeach the president” left her cable network facing a firestorm of criticism this week, has been removed from her prime-time slot for the foreseeable future, the network said on Friday.

headline: N.B.A. Stars and Owners Say They’ll Cover Workers’ Lost Wages
abstract: With the season suspended for at least 30 days because of the coronavirus, lower-paid workers at the league’s arenas are getting help from their famous colleagues.
lead_paragraph: Some of the N.B.A.’s biggest stars — including Zion Williamson and Giannis Antetokounmpo — and several team owners said they would help cover the lost income of everyday arena employees while the league goes dark for at least 30 days because of the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: ‘Am I on Camera?’ Joe Biden’s Foray Into Virtual Campaigning
abstract: Technical glitches disrupted Mr. Biden’s virtual town hall with voters in Illinois on Friday. Bernie Sanders held an online “fireside chat’’ on Saturday. It’s the new paradigm for candidates amid a health crisis.
lead_paragraph: For Joseph R. Biden Jr., campaigning these days means virtual fund-raisers. Shuttered field offices. And rallying support by live stream, a tactic vulnerable to severe technological difficulties, as he discovered on Friday evening.

headline: Corrections: March 14, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 14, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about a secret extrajudicial location where the Greek government is detaining migrants referred incompletely to the nationality of Somar al-Hussein. While Mr. al-Hussein is a Syrian Kurd, he is also one of a small minority of Syrian exiles to recently receive a Turkish passport.

headline: Trump Tests Negative; Long Waits at U.S. Airports for Inbound Passengers
abstract: Spain and France have announced countrywide restrictions, and the White House physician says President Trump’s test came back negative.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. Read the latest updates on the coronavirus epidemic here.]

headline: Canadian and Italian Hostages Are Freed in Mali After 15 Months
abstract: Edith Blais and Luca Tacchetto went missing in December 2018, in an area known to be an Islamic State stronghold.
lead_paragraph: A Canadian woman and an Italian man who were abducted 15 months ago in Burkina Faso have been released in the neighboring country of Mali, a United Nations official confirmed Saturday.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Hobbs & Shaw’ and ‘Funny Women’
abstract: The “Fast & Furious” spinoff starring Dwayne Johnson and Jason Statham airs on HBO, while veteran comedians perform on Showtime.
lead_paragraph: FAST & FURIOUS PRESENTS: HOBBS & SHAW (2019) 8 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. We have come a long way since Vin Diesel and Paul Walker played Californian street racers in 2001’s “The Fast and the Furious.” The franchise has ballooned since then, and its latest offering is this spinoff. In “Hobbs & Shaw,” which takes place between “Fate of the Furious” (2017) and the upcoming “F9,” Dwayne Johnson and Jason Statham reprise their roles from earlier “Furious” movies, reluctantly teaming up to keep a genetically enhanced supervillain (Idris Elba) from getting his hands on a deadly virus. Their mission ties in Shaw’s formidable sister (Vanessa Kirby), a rogue MI6 agent, and takes them to Chernobyl and then Samoa. The plot is hardly the point — the main attraction is the scathing banter between the leading men and the over-the-top, gravity-defying stunts. It may not be the strongest film in the saga, but it’s a fun escape.

headline: How Every House Member Voted on the Coronavirus Relief Bill
abstract: The sweeping legislation passed the House, 363-40, and will allow for free testing, paid sick leave, stronger unemployment benefits and food security assistance.
lead_paragraph: The sweeping legislation passed the House, 363-40, and will allow for free testing, paid sick leave, stronger unemployment benefits and food security assistance.

headline: She Wanted to Revive a Park. First She Had to Take On the Rats.
abstract: One woman’s mission to breathe new life into a small slice of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Aleya Lehmann watched Verdi Square decay over 16 years of walks down Broadway, from her home on 93rd Street to the Lincoln Center Cinema at 68th Street, a favorite place for a movie and  a box of Cookie Dough Bites.

headline: An Important Year for Women’s Sports, Paused by Coronavirus
abstract: Female athletes already fight for money, screen time and other resources. Work stoppages over coronavirus concerns threaten opportunities to move forward.
lead_paragraph: This was set to be a groundbreaking year for women’s sports.

headline: For Many Athletes, Coronavirus Means the End of College Careers
abstract: “It feels like all the hard work — I don’t want to say it’s for nothing, but you want to compete.”
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — As the final seconds wound down, Utah State guard Sam Merrill dribbled the ball back and forth between his legs and rocked closer to the 3-point line until, with a burst, he took a hard dribble followed by a crow hop to his left. He then let fly a 25-foot jumper over the outstretched hand of San Diego State guard K.J. Feagin, who had been hounding Merrill.

headline: Getting The New York Times Magazine to Jump Off the Page
abstract: The Music Issue, out on March 15, introduces a multimedia experience that bridges print and digital through your smartphone.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Curbing Hidden Wedding Costs
abstract: Don’t let surprise wedding expenses put a dent in your wedding budget. Here are a few hidden fees and miscellaneous items that you can prepare for in advance.
lead_paragraph: Creating and sticking to a budget can be a challenge for couples planning a wedding. The national average cost currently stands at $33,931, according to wedding website the Knot.

headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.: Will a Surge in Patients Overwhelm Hospitals?
abstract: “We are not prepared,” one doctor said. New York City’s hospitals may be moving too slowly as the outbreak spreads, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Two of the biggest hospital systems in the Northeast — New York City’s Health and Hospitals Corporation and NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital — plan to cancel nonemergency surgeries. NYU Langone Medical Center’s Tisch Hospital turned a pediatric emergency room into a respiratory ward for adults. Northwell Health, which has a sprawling network of hospitals, is asking retired nurses to return to work.

headline: The Rich Have a Coronavirus Cure: Escape From New York
abstract: When fake rumors inspired a run on toilet paper, the 1 percent made a panicked exodus to their second homes.
lead_paragraph: By Thursday afternoon, texts and emails circulating among New York’s professional class warned that perhaps it was time to leave. The city was going into lockdown, or at least that’s what people were saying — probably by Friday morning. No one really knew this but now, you did.

headline: A Surge in Biking to Avoid Crowded Trains in N.Y.C.
abstract: More New Yorkers are turning to cycling to minimize their coronavirus exposure. Citi Bike trips surged to more than half a million this month.
lead_paragraph: Halimah Marcus’s bike had been collecting dust for five years.

headline: Throw Out the Debate Playbook: Biden and Sanders to Clash Amid Crisis
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Bernie Sanders will be auditioning for the presidency, trying to convey leadership, against the backdrop of an unfolding national emergency.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in the long Democratic primary campaign, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will meet in a one-on-one debate, facing off Sunday night as Mr. Sanders fights for the future of his candidacy against a rival who has taken a commanding position in the race.

headline: Riding the Rails With the Man in Seat 61
abstract: For train travelers, Mark Smith’s website is the go-to source for timetables, maps and booking details in more than 100 countries.
lead_paragraph: Before the coronavirus pandemic caused major disruptions to travel worldwide, train travel found itself going through a bit of a renaissance as people reconsidered the carbon emissions squashed seating and increasing fees of flying. The man with a front-row seat to the rail resurgence is Mark Smith, the founder of the train travel website The Man in Seat 61. His site has timetables, maps, reviews, booking details and everything else needed to plan train (and even some ferry) trips in more than 100 countries.

headline: The Coronavirus Swamps Local Health Departments, Already Crippled by Cuts
abstract: Many state and municipal health departments saw budget and staffing cuts a decade ago that were never restored.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A widespread failure in the United States to invest in public health has left local and state health departments struggling to respond to the coronavirus outbreak and ill-prepared to face the swelling crisis ahead.

headline: As China Cracks Down on Coronavirus Coverage, Journalists Fight Back
abstract: The Communist Party is trying to fill the airwaves with positive stories about its battle against the virus. Chinese reporters, buoyed by widespread calls for free speech, are resisting.
lead_paragraph: When Jacob Wang saw reports circulating online recently suggesting that life was getting better in Wuhan, the center of the coronavirus outbreak, he was irate.

headline: Saudi Law Granted Women New Freedoms. Their Families Don’t Always Agree.
abstract: Women in the conservative kingdom are finding they have to negotiate with their relatives newly granted permissions to work, drive and travel.
lead_paragraph: MEDINA, Saudi Arabia — On the question of women working, the law of the land was crystal clear. Raghda and Rafaa Abuazzah’s parents had ruled otherwise.

headline: He Has 17,700 Bottles of Hand Sanitizer and Nowhere to Sell Them
abstract: Amazon cracked down on coronavirus price gouging. Now, while the rest of the world searches, some sellers are holding stockpiles of sanitizer and masks.
lead_paragraph: On March 1, the day after the first coronavirus death in the United States was announced, brothers Matt and Noah Colvin set out in a silver S.U.V. to pick up some hand sanitizer.
