headline: Man Who Stabbed Sisters on BART Platform Was Sane at Time, Judge Says
abstract: John Lee Cowell faces life in prison after a San Francisco judge ruled that he was sane when he fatally stabbed Nia Wilson on an Oakland train platform.
lead_paragraph: A Bay Area man who stabbed two sisters on a commuter train platform in Oakland, Calif., two years ago, killing one and wounding the other, was sane at the time of the murder, a judge ruled Monday.

headline: Palmer With an ‘Army’
abstract: Ross Trudeau is neither here nor there.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — I started this column intending to write just a brief one, as we are most likely all thinking about other things, but it turned into a much longer piece. I will try to make this as coherent as possible.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 5, Episode 5 Recap: A Tale of Two Coots
abstract: Mike will not be fenced in. Everett Acker will not be thrown out. And Kim does a strangely scintillating impression of a middle-aged banker.
lead_paragraph: There’s a pleasing symmetry to “Dedicado a Max,” an episode that could be more accurately titled “A Tale of Two Coots.” The bifurcated plot revolves around a pair of ornery old men. Both are natural-born fighters who don’t like to be told what to do. One is in a house that people want him evicted from, that he refuses to leave. The other is in a house that people want to stay in that he would like to flee.

headline: As Market Convulses, Big Banks Plan to Borrow Funds From Fed
abstract: Led by Morgan Stanley, which borrowed from the Fed’s so-called discount window on Monday, seven other firms will follow.
lead_paragraph: Eight major financial-services firms are borrowing money from the Federal Reserve, a day after the central bank urged them to tap its short-term funding facility to make it easier for credit to continue flowing through the economy, as the coronavirus pandemic continues to roil markets.

headline: Kentucky Derby Is Postponed Until September Because of Coronavirus
abstract: The last time the race was not held on the first Saturday in May was 75 years ago.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since the end of World War II, the Kentucky Derby will not take place on the first Saturday in May.

headline: Stocks Rebound From Monday’s Collapse
abstract: Investors are still looking to Washington for a large scale effort to help businesses and workers affected by the virus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus and the economy.

headline: Corrections: March 17, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, March 17, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about Trump supporters’ unwavering trust in the president misstated the surname of a Tennessee state legislator representing Jonesborough. He is Micah Van Huss, not Jones.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Top Court Rules Putin Can Bypass Term Limits
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 17, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “It is rare that the spirit of slavery and intellectual cowardice express themselves with such fullness in a written text.”

headline: Crackdown on Southern Border Is Planned; U.S. Records 100th Death
abstract: The stock market partially rebounded as the federal government considered a broader $850 billion stimulus proposal, including the idea of sending direct payments to Americans.

headline: Germany Has More Than Enough Ventilators. It Should Share Them.
abstract: Without health, all is nothing.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — Europe may be the epicenter of the coronavirus pandemic, as the World Health Organization said last week. But for all those struck down by the virus — past and to come — the crisis has brought Europe’s nations one consolation: When faced with the choice between economic damage and human suffering, they knew what to do.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Jumanji: The Next Level’ and ‘Inside No. 9’
abstract: Celebrate St. Patrick’s Day with a hefty dose of humor: The latest “Jumanji” flick hits Amazon, while a British anthology returns to BritBox.
lead_paragraph: JUMANJI: THE NEXT LEVEL (2019) Rent on Amazon. Set three years after 2017’s “Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle,” a reboot of the 1995 movie, this adventure film brings back the core gang — Dwayne Johnson, Kevin Hart, Karen Gillan and Jack Black — along with a few new faces. As the friends plan to reunite during winter break, one, Spencer, delves back into the Jumanji video game, and the rest of the group has no choice but to follow him. But the game malfunctions, leaving Bethany, another of the friends, in the real world and dragging in Spencer’s grandfather (Danny DeVito) and his old friend (Danny Glover). What’s more, the youngsters don’t have the same avatars as before — which makes for some amusing and not-so-amusing performances. (Hart channeling Glover? Sure. Johnson playing DeVito? Not quite.) Critics said the movie doesn’t live up to “Welcome to the Jungle,” but carries enough laughs and tantalizing action scenes to keep you in the game.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Coronavirus, France, Italy: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The European Union is expected to approve today a proposal to shut down nonessential travel into the bloc for at least 30 days to stem the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Word + Quiz: genome
abstract: This word has appeared in 106 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Why Birds Are the World’s Best Engineers
abstract: A nest is “a disordered stick bomb,” resilient in ways that humans have hardly begun to understand, much less emulate.
lead_paragraph: The term “bird’s nest” has come to describe a messy hairdo, tangled fishing line and other unspeakably knotty conundrums. But that does birds an injustice. Their tiny brains, dense with neurons, produce marvels that have long captured scientific interest as naturally selected engineering solutions — yet nests are still not well understood.

headline: St. Patrick’s Day
abstract: What foods and rituals do you associate with the holiday?
lead_paragraph: Today is St. Patrick’s Day. Although parades around the world have been canceled to help contain the coronavirus outbreak, the holiday can still be enjoyed in a number of other ways.

headline: Can the Olympics Take Place in July? (This July?)
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic has brought most of the world’s sports to a standstill, but the Tokyo Games remain scheduled to begin in late July. Is that even possible?
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has brought most of the world’s sports to a standstill, but the Tokyo Games remain scheduled to begin in late July. Is that even possible?

headline: Fix Everything Wrong at 23 Subway Stations? It Beats His Last Job
abstract: The group manager is responsible for everything from broken elevators to smashed lights to overflowing toilets.
lead_paragraph: Even on a good day, Michael E. Brown’s job is infinite.

headline: India Scrambles to Escape a Coronavirus Crisis. So Far, It’s Working.
abstract: Fears are growing about what happens if community transmission takes off in the crowded areas of the world’s second-most-populous nation.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Over the weekend in Lucknow, one of India’s bigger cities, young people packed into pubs. Despite the Indian government scrambling to lock things down, few on the bar scene were taking the coronavirus very seriously.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Procrastinate Much? Manage Your Emotions, Not Your Time.’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn the real reasons we avoid work and strategies for overcoming them.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Procrastinate Much? Manage Your Emotions, Not Your Time.” by Adam Grant

headline: Tom Hanks and Rita Wilson Are Released From the Hospital
abstract: The actors will remain in self-isolation in a rented home in Australia but are “feeling a lot better,” their son Chet Hanks said.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The actors Tom Hanks and Rita Wilson have been released from an Australian hospital and will remain in self-isolation after being treated for Covid-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus, their son said in a video statement on Monday.

headline: A Sobering Look at How Quickly Hitler Transformed Germany
abstract: In “Hitler’s First Hundred Days,” Peter Fritzsche charts the audacious and swift changes that occurred once Hitler had been appointed chancellor.
lead_paragraph: The right-wing elites were confident they could use him to their advantage. Yes, Adolf Hitler was ridiculous and vulgar, a tin-pot demagogue instead of a smooth politician, but he knew how to excite the nationalist base and deliver a whopper of a speech. Germany’s conservative politicians assured one another that they would still be the ones to pull the puppet strings. As one of them put it, “In two months, we’ll have pushed Hitler so far into a corner that he’ll squeal.”

headline: How to Read Faster
abstract: It might be fine to skim through a user manual for an office printer, but don’t skim “Anna Karenina” and expect to understand it.
lead_paragraph: “There are no shortcuts,” says Elizabeth Schotter, an assistant professor of psychology at the University of South Florida, where she runs the Eye Movements and Cognition Lab. College-educated adults usually read between 200 and 400 words per minute (a comfortable listening rate is around 150 words per minute). The speediest speed readers claim as many as 30,000 words per minute, at which point research would suggest a significant loss of comprehension. It might be fine to skim through a user manual for an office printer, but don’t skim “Anna Karenina” and expect to understand it. “In this modern age, we always want to do everything faster,” says Schotter, whose lab uses high-speed video to analyze readers’ eyes as they dart across text. America’s speed-reading obsession confounds Schotter; on average, people read twice as fast as they can comfortably listen. Reading is visually and cognitively complicated; it’s OK to reread a line because it’s confusing or, better yet, to linger on a phrase so beautiful that it makes you want to close your eyes.

headline: Is It Wrong to Donate to Candidates You Can’t Vote for?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on supporting politicians in other districts and states, and what transgender medical providers must disclose to their patients.
lead_paragraph: I have felt uncomfortable with the idea of donating money to candidates in elections in which I have no voting rights — such as senators in states other than my own. I always believed that only those able to vote in an election and who will be directly affected by it have the right to donate to the candidates. It has become clear to me, however, that individual senators and other elected officials outside my state do indeed have a powerful effect on the entire country. Is it appropriate for me to donate to candidates in elections in which I cannot vote? Christine, Seattle

headline: Thinking About Empire and Economy, With a Poet’s Mind and a Lawyer’s Words
abstract: For almost 40 years, the poet and law professor Lawrence Joseph has embraced big questions. “A Certain Clarity: Selected Poems” shows the path his work has traveled.
lead_paragraph: A CERTAIN CLARITYSelected PoemsBy Lawrence Joseph

headline: The Jewish Race-Car Driver Who Outpaced the Nazis
abstract: In “Faster,” Neal Bascomb brings to life a vivid chapter in auto-racing history.
lead_paragraph: FASTERHow a Jewish Driver, an American Heiress, and a Legendary Car Beat Hitler’s BestBy Neal Bascomb

headline: How the White Working Class Is Being Destroyed
abstract: “Deaths of Despair and the Future of Capitalism,” by Anne Case and Angus Deaton, describes the growing dysfunction of blue-collar workers in white communities.
lead_paragraph: DEATHS OF DESPAIR AND THE FUTURE OF CAPITALISMBy Anne Case and Angus Deaton

headline: New & Noteworthy Audiobooks, From ‘The Office’ to Eating Well
abstract: A selection of recent audiobooks of note; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: THE OFFICE: The Untold Story of the Greatest Sitcom of the 2000s: An Oral History, by Andy Greene, read by a full cast. (Penguin Audio.) A Rolling Stone writer goes behind the scenes of the NBC series that ended in 2013, with input from the creators, cast and crew.

headline: This Evangelical Megachurch in Ohio Isn’t What You Think
abstract: One of the country’s fastest-growing churches turned conversations about race into political victories.
lead_paragraph: Ohio went for Donald Trump by a solid margin in 2016. But the story of what happened in one county that bucked the trend that year offers a surprising blueprint for how to mobilize evangelicals in support of racial justice in politics.

headline: The Class of COVID-19
abstract: For seniors set to graduate college this spring, one loss hurts above all others: Graduation, and the traditions that came with it. At Wellesley, students decided to make their own.
lead_paragraph: For seniors set to graduate college this spring, one loss hurts above all others: Graduation, and the traditions that came with it. At Wellesley, students decided to make their own.

headline: U.S. Lags in Coronavirus Testing After Slow Response to Outbreak
abstract: It has tested at a much lower rate than Italy, which has outpaced the rest of Europe, and South Korea, where testing and monitoring have slowed the growth of new cases.
lead_paragraph: It has tested at a much lower rate than Italy, which has outpaced the rest of Europe, and South Korea, where testing and monitoring have slowed the growth of new cases.

headline: What Role Does Poetry Play in Your Life?
abstract: How do you experience poems? Do you turn to them for inspiration or joy? For solidarity in moments of sadness?
lead_paragraph: How do you feel when you read a poem? Does it make a difference if you have to read a poem for school rather than for pleasure? Do you ever seek out poems on your own or share poems on social media?

headline: When Mies van der Rohe Went on Trial
abstract: In “Broken Glass,” Alex Beam revisits the saga of the Farnsworth House — a tale of modernism, a broken heart and a transparent house with too few closets.
lead_paragraph: BROKEN GLASS Mies van der Rohe, Edith Farnsworth and the Fight Over a Modernist Masterpiece By Alex Beam

headline: For Black and Mixed-Race Women, Hair and Identity Are Tangled Together
abstract: In “That Hair,” the Portuguese writer Djaimilia Pereira de Almeida uses a young half-Angolan girl in Lisbon to explore her own Afro-European selfhood.
lead_paragraph: THAT HAIRBy Djaimilia Pereira de Almeida

headline: Why We Should Abolish the Electoral College
abstract: Jesse Wegman’s “Let the People Pick the President” is a readable account of how the Electoral College distorts our political system.
lead_paragraph: LET THE PEOPLE PICK THE PRESIDENTThe Case for Abolishing the Electoral CollegeBy Jesse Wegman

headline: The Ghost Writer: An Author Imagines a Letter From Her Late Grandmother
abstract: “Nobody Will Tell You This but Me,” a memoir by Bess Kalb, traces her family history from the Russian pogroms to the American dream.
lead_paragraph: NOBODY WILL TELL YOU THIS BUT ME A True (as Told to Me) Story By Bess Kalb

headline: Is Closing the Schools a Good Idea?
abstract: Weighing the advantages gained in slowing down coronavirus transmission versus the problems such closures create.
lead_paragraph: Even as we take significant steps to distance ourselves from one another to “flatten the curve” of the coronavirus pandemic, one of the hardest decisions has been whether to close schools.

headline: Has Physics Lost Its Way?
abstract: In “The Dream Universe,” David Lindley argues that physicists have become too enamored of theoretical phenomena like parallel universes and black holes.
lead_paragraph: THE DREAM UNIVERSE How Fundamental Physics Lost Its Way By David Lindley

headline: Samsung: The Tech Monster That Conquered the World
abstract: Geoffrey Cain’s “Samsung Rising” tells the full story of the giant corporation from its beginnings as a shop selling vegetables.

headline: Is There Cosmic Meaning in Life’s Randomness?
abstract: In a new memoir, “My Meteorite,” the artist Harry Dodge searches for the grand pattern in his life’s myriad coincidences.
lead_paragraph: MY METEORITE Or, Without the Random There Can Be No New ThingBy Harry Dodge

headline: He Questioned the Meaning of Life. William James Answered.
abstract: In “Sick Souls, Healthy Minds,” John Kaag looks to the 19th-century psychologist and philosopher for answers to life’s big questions.
lead_paragraph: SICK SOULS, HEALTHY MINDSHow William James Can Save Your LifeBy John Kaag

headline: Someday, We’ll Look Back on All of This and Write a Novel
abstract: Writers are taking notes on the pandemic, says Sloane Crosley. But now’s not the time for your coronavirus book.
lead_paragraph: Things are moving far too quickly, and not just from an epidemiological perspective. Yesterday was approximately six and a half years ago. For writers, as the tentacles of the coronavirus unfurl each day, everything is copy. But what happens when every writer on the planet starts taking notes on the same subject? Will we all hand in our book reports simultaneously, a year from now? The nature of tragedy is that it takes more than it gives, but it’s also produced some of our most iconic literature. The Great Depression brought “The Grapes of Wrath.” The Spanish Inquisition helped inspire “Don Quixote.” Cholera gave Camus “The Plague” (so to speak). Shakespeare, Twitter has been quick to remind us, wrote under quarantine. There’s something comfortingly glib about art-shaming in the midst of being told you’re a vector for death. The Accidental Murderer: And Other Stories.

headline: Our Internet Isn’t Ready for Coronavirus
abstract: Many people are having to work and learn from home. Residential broadband networks might not be able to keep up.
lead_paragraph: The morning after my university announced classes would be moved online because of the coronavirus, the power went out on campus. It was restored just a few hours later, but the outage was a stark reminder of how dependent we are on our electrical and online infrastructure as more and more of us are moving to remote learning and work.

headline: The Wing Is a Women’s Utopia. Unless You Work There.
abstract: The social club’s employees have a story to tell about the company that sold the world Instagram-ready feminism.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers, like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: His Nation in Turmoil, One Boy Finds Refuge and Adventure in Friendship
abstract: In Romesh Gunesekera’s “Suncatcher,” set in 1960s Ceylon, the narrator reflects on a bond marked by differences in class and power.
lead_paragraph: SUNCATCHER

headline: A Stirring Family Saga Tells a Taboo History of Vietnam
abstract: “The Mountains Sing,” the first novel in English by the Vietnamese poet Nguyen Phan Que Mai, imagines her country’s traumatic 20th century through the stories of three generations of women.
lead_paragraph: THE MOUNTAINS SINGBy Nguyen Phan Que Mai

headline: The Mask
abstract: The surgical face mask has become a symbol of our times.
lead_paragraph: If there is a symbol of the current confusion and fear, the misinformation and anxiety, generated by the spread of the new coronavirus, it is the surgical face mask. When history looks back on the pandemic of 2020, those white or baby blue rectangles that hide the mouth and nose, turning everyone into a muzzled pelican, will be what we see.

headline: Why Telling People They Don’t Need Masks Backfired
abstract: To help manage the shortage, the authorities sent a message that made them untrustworthy.
lead_paragraph: When news of a mysterious viral pneumonia linked to a market in Wuhan, China, reached the outside world in early January, one of my first reactions was to order a modest supply of masks. Just a few weeks later, there wasn’t a mask to be bought in stores, or online for a reasonable price — just widespread price gouging. Many health experts, no doubt motivated by the sensible and urgent aim of preserving the remaining masks for health care workers, started telling people that they didn’t need masks or that they wouldn’t know how to wear them.

headline: How Much Does Voting Spread Viruses?
abstract: A study shows that past elections have not led to national surges of viral disease, but it is too early to apply the research to coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Does voting spread disease?

headline: N.Y. May Need 18,000 Ventilators Very Soon. It Is Far Short of That.
abstract: Doctors are increasingly anxious that New York — like other states — won’t have enough of the breathing machines that are key to fighting the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus has swept across New York, officials have become increasingly alarmed about a bleak reality: The state may not have enough ventilators for everybody who could need one.

headline: Why the Coronavirus Might Not Hit Turnout Hard in Tuesday’s Primaries
abstract: There was significant early voting in Florida and Arizona. Illinois might be more vulnerable to a decline in voters.
lead_paragraph: Turnout is a question ahead of every election. It would be an understatement to say it is a more challenging question than usual ahead of Tuesday’s primaries, as voters head to the polls in Florida, Illinois and Arizona amid the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: How to Be Together Apart In the Time of Coronavirus
abstract: The pandemic offers an opportunity to experiment with meaningful digital gatherings, from book clubs to happy hours to religious services.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus rages, gathering is under attack. President Trump announced on Monday that Americans should avoid gatherings of more than 10 people. That means no big weddings or milestone birthday parties, no major sporting events or arena concerts.

headline: In Italy, ‘Io Resto a Casa,’ but Still I Dance
abstract: With the country in lockdown, dancers do barre exercises in their bedrooms and take classes on WhatsApp.
lead_paragraph: Dance is a social art form that happens in crowded rooms full of people. Partnering and dance instruction are all about touching. Movement requires large spaces. So what happens in a period of enforced separation and reduced square footage?

headline: I Deliver Your Food. Don’t I Deserve Basic Protections?
abstract: Like emergency income support, for starters.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — I’m a single mother, and I’ve worked hard to stay in this city, where I grew up. I graduated from the University of Washington, but no employer would give me the flexibility I needed to care for my three girls. That’s why I started delivering food for Caviar five years ago. Now I do the same for Postmates, DoorDash, Uber Eats and Instacart. I also drive for Lyft.

headline: One Simple Idea That Explains Why the Economy Is in Great Danger
abstract: What happens when a major section of machinery that is supposed to run perpetually suddenly grinds to a halt? We are about to find out.
lead_paragraph: To understand why the world economy is in grave peril because of the spread of coronavirus, it helps to grasp one idea that is at once blindingly obvious and sneakily profound.

headline: The Universal Language of Caring
abstract: Hospitals have interpreters. But doctors and patients who speak different languages do not always need a translator’s help.
lead_paragraph: The phone sitting on my patient’s bedside table looked as if it had been designed by Dr. Seuss.

headline: Concerts Are on Hold. Workers Behind the Stars Are Hurting.
abstract: Sound engineers, lighting technicians and more gig-to-gig employees who fuel the touring industry are “preparing for the worst” as the coronavirus puts a halt to live shows.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Dirks began last Thursday in Tulsa, Okla., as a lighting technician on Kiss’s arena tour. He ended the day on a bus home to Nashville as that tour — along with the rest of the multibillion-dollar concert industry — came to an abrupt halt.

headline: ‘All Around Us Is Chaos’: Inside a Rural Town Upended by the Virus
abstract: The call that upended Cynthiana, Ky., came around 5 p.m. on March 6. Officials had been bracing for the inevitable, and it had just arrived. A resident was sick. Five others would soon be, too.
lead_paragraph: CYNTHIANA, Ky. — Closing in on a week after the coronavirus had descended on his small, rural community, James D. Smith sat behind a microphone in the WCYN studio on Main Street for his regular morning show, “Coffee Break Extra.” On his head, he wore a dark blue cap that said “mayor,” and in his eyes, the stress of the past several days.

headline: Is There a Wizard Behind the Curtain?
abstract: In the time of coronavirus, it’s no longer a rhetorical question.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: We’re in a new and frightening world, Gail. Every time I get a news alert on my phone, I hear James Earl Jones’s voice in my head, saying, “Mother of God.” And every time I listen to Donald Trump’s voice, I hear Slim Pickens’s voice from “Dr. Strangelove.”

headline: Stop Saying That Everything Is Under Control. It Isn’t.
abstract: Tackling the pandemic will require a new, collective way of thinking about public health and society as a whole.
lead_paragraph: In 1941, with war tearing through Europe and Asia, and America on the precipice of joining the conflict, President Franklin D. Roosevelt compelled and inspired industries and individuals to rally for the greater good. Food was rationed without rioting, and car plants all but stopped producing automobiles in favor of tanks and fuselages. By 1944, American factory workers were building nearly 100,000 warplanes a year — or about 11 per hour.

headline: The Coronavirus Exposes Education’s Digital Divide
abstract: In China, many rural students lack the connections or hardware to learn remotely. More nations will confront the same reality as the outbreak spreads.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Like hundreds of millions of other children worldwide, Liu Chenxinhao and Liu Chenxinyuan were getting used to doing class work online. After their elementary school closed because of the coronavirus outbreak, the brothers received their homework through a smartphone app.

headline: A Movie Theater Family Says a Tearful Goodbye
abstract: As the city placed more restrictions on businesses over fears of coronavirus, a tight-knit group of workers in Brooklyn struggled to say goodbye.
lead_paragraph: See you on the other side.

headline: Can City Life Survive Coronavirus?
abstract: Cities are epicenters of capital and creativity, designed to be occupied collectively. Pandemics are anti-urban, preying on our human desire for connection.
lead_paragraph: It’s becoming harder by the hour to find the new normal.

headline: ‘Nothing Like Normal’: Covering an Infected Global Economy
abstract: A Times reporter who follows the Federal Reserve discusses the coronavirus’s impact on the world’s finances.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: She Was Abused by Her Husband. So Is the Narrator of Her New Book.
abstract: Meena Kandasamy’s second novel, “When I Hit You,” contains echoes of her own experience with domestic violence.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I HIT YOUOr, A Portrait of the Writer as a Young WifeBy Meena Kandasamy

headline: I Fled Yugoslavia in 1941. Then I Returned to Join the Resistance.
abstract: After the Germans had consolidated in northwestern Yugoslavia, I told my parents I wanted to become a freedom fighter.
lead_paragraph: This account is from “Beyond the World War II We Know,” a series from The Times that documents lesser-known stories from World War II. Before the Axis powers invaded and divided up the territory of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia in 1941, Stasha Seaton and her family were evacuated by the British government, and they eventually made their way to the United States. There, Stasha enrolled at Barnard College in New York, as her father aided the Allied war effort while working between the United States and London for the BBC. Twenty-year-old Stasha returned to Yugoslavia in 1944 to join the National Liberation struggle, a resistance campaign made up of a variety of anti-fascist left-wing groups, including smaller movements and Josep Tito’s Communist National Liberation Army.

headline: Which Consumer Lenders Are (and Aren’t) Helping the Most
abstract: Goldman Sachs, a punching bag during the last economic catastrophe, is leading the way as the coronavirus outbreak threatens consumers’ livelihoods. Ally Bank, a bailout beneficiary last time, hasn’t matched it.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday morning, Goldman Sachs, the financial partner on the new Apple credit card, said it would allow all cardholders who asked for help to skip their March credit card bill. The interest would disappear, never to be charged. And Goldman would foot the bill itself, as the financial backer of the partnership.

headline: Handmade Visions on the Crafts Trail in Mexico
abstract: A journey through lesser-known artisan villages of Michoacán reveals the ever-changing nature of their tradition.
lead_paragraph: Clambering down into the half-buried ruins of San Juan Paringuricutiro, past stone archways subsumed in lava less than 80 years ago, I glanced up over jagged spires of black basalt to the ash cone of Paricutín, one of the world’s youngest volcano, hovering like a specter on the horizon.

headline: A ‘Billions’ Star’s ‘Little Lady’ Apartment
abstract: With the opening of her musical, ‘Whisper House,’ postponed, Samantha Mathis is riding out the coronavirus in her Greenwich Village home.
lead_paragraph: With the opening of her musical, ‘Whisper House,’ postponed, Samantha Mathis is riding out the coronavirus in her Greenwich Village home.

headline: Samantha Mathis, Self-Isolating Downtown
abstract: With the opening of her musical, ‘Whisper House,’ postponed, the ‘Billions’ actor is riding out the coronavirus in her Greenwich Village rental.
lead_paragraph: The actor Samantha Mathis departed Los Angeles on a trial basis a decade ago, to see if she could make a life for herself in New York City. Or perhaps more to the point, to see if she could make a life for herself in the theater.

headline: ‘Nobody Will Tell You This but Me: A True (as Told to Me) Story,’ by Bess Kalb: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “Nobody Will Tell You This but Me: A True (as Told to Me) Story,” by Bess Kalb
lead_paragraph: You said your first words to me and you also stood up for the first time when I was there.

headline: ‘Faster: How a Jewish Driver, an American Heiress, and a Legendary Car Beat Hitler’s Best,’ by Neal Bascomb: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “Faster: How a Jewish Driver, an American Heiress, and a Legendary Car Beat Hitler’s Best,” by Neal Bascomb
lead_paragraph: The beast, long lurking in plain sight while the Allies stood idle, pounced at last. On May 10, 1940, wave after wave of German bombers, their supercharged engines in high pitch, swept across the dawn sky while armored columns rumbled overland. Into Belgium, Holland, and Luxembourg the Nazis advanced, shattering the morning quiet. Their paratroopers severed communication lines and captured essential bridges. Commandos dropped from glider planes and seized critical fortresses before they could stall any advance. In short order, panzer divisions barreled deep into foreign territory. When French and British forces hurried northeastward to Belgium to stem the attack, they fell straight into the trap of expectations entrenched from the First World War.

lead_paragraph: Late night did not stay dark long.

headline: Rick Atkinson Wins American History Book Prize
abstract: The award from the New-York Historical Society honors the first installment of his planned trilogy about the American Revolution, which emphasizes the conflict’s costs and uncertainties.
lead_paragraph: Rick Atkinson, the author of “The British Are Coming: The War for America, Lexington to Princeton, 1775-1777,” has been named the winner of the New-York Historical Society’s Barbara and David Zalaznick Book Prize, awarded each year to the best work in the field of American history and biography.

headline: Joe Biden Wins Primaries in Florida, Illinois and Arizona: Highlights
abstract: Mr. Biden captured easy victories in all three states that voted on Tuesday. Bernie Sanders’s chances of a comeback in the Democratic presidential race have all but evaporated.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. easily won the Democratic primary elections in Florida, Illinois and Arizona on Tuesday. The three states award a total of 441 delegates for the party’s presidential nomination.

abstract: How informed are you about the coronavirus outbreak? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?
lead_paragraph: How informed are you about the coronavirus outbreak? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?

headline: Euro 2020 and Copa América Are Postponed for a Year
abstract: The quadrennial championships, two of the most important events on the sport’s calendar, were scheduled for this summer but will now be moved to 2021 because of the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: The European Championship, second only to the World Cup in importance and value in international soccer, will be postponed until 2021, tournament organizers decided on Tuesday.

headline: Their School Musicals Were Canceled. Then They Found a Bigger Stage.
abstract: Videos of teenage (and older) performers sprouted on social media after a Tony-winning actress invited theater kids to share songs from shows canceled by the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Laura Benanti is a Tony-winning actress, but she still thinks of herself as a theater kid.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
lead_paragraph: $9.6 MILLION

headline: The Designer Who Wore Double-Breasted Suits as a Pre-Schooler
abstract: Wes Gordon, who took over Carolina Herrera in 2018, shares his creative inspirations.
lead_paragraph: “I was a very dapper kid,” says Wes Gordon, the 33-year-old creative director of Carolina Herrera, who at 4 was already partial to double-breasted suits, Windsor-knotted neckties and red suspenders. “I felt it was my duty to give unsolicited fashion advice to anybody around me.” Later, as a teenager, the Chicago-born, Atlanta-raised designer tracked down fashion books on Valentino and John Galliano, two early idols, and took after-school lessons with a dressmaker. “She’d make me sew along the lines of writing paper until my stitches were perfectly straight,” he says. In 2005, Gordon moved to London to study women’s wear at Central Saint Martins, spending two summers interning with Oscar de la Renta in New York (“I showed up for my interview looking like an extra from ‘Brideshead Revisited’”) before working part-time at Tom Ford’s London atelier in Chelsea. Upon graduating in 2009, he moved to Manhattan for good and launched his namesake collection from his studio apartment, where he slept on an air mattress. Despite its scrappy start, Gordon’s elegant line — full of youthful cocktail dresses, suits and jumpsuits in vibrant, happy hues — was soon picked up by Saks Fifth Avenue and Harrods, and later worn by everyone from Lena Dunham to Michelle Obama.

headline: The Coronavirus Crisis Is Showing Us How to Live Online
abstract: We’ve always hoped that our digital tools would create connections, not conflict. We have a chance to make it happen.
lead_paragraph: For someone who has barely left his house, I’ve had a shockingly busy few days.

headline: Living In ... Normal Heights, San Diego
abstract: On the lookout for lower home prices in the downtown vicinity.
lead_paragraph: On the lookout for lower home prices in the downtown vicinity.

headline: A Plan to Develop Farmland in Amish Country Meets Resistance
abstract: A proposed development addresses urban sprawl and scarce housing in rural Lancaster County, but some say it’s the right project in the wrong spot.
lead_paragraph: MANHEIM TOWNSHIP, Pa. — When Earl Hurst bought 100 acres of farmland in rural Lancaster County in 1952, he planned for the fertile fields to help sustain his family. And for a generation, they did just that.

headline: Normal Heights, San Diego: A Tight-Knit Community Within Reach of Downtown
abstract: Recently revitalized thanks to its central location, the eclectic neighborhood still offers San Diegans more space for their money.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Kendra and Anthony Rose were feeling the crunch in 2017. The couple, now married, were living in a one-bedroom apartment in North Park, the hip San Diego neighborhood that wraps around the northeast corner of Balboa Park. Mr. Rose has two children from a previous marriage, and every weekend when the kids, ages 6 and 7, would visit, the couple resigned themselves to sleeping on the sofa.

headline: What Does It Mean to ‘Shelter in Place’ in California?
abstract: Tuesday: Bay Area residents are now living under some of the nation’s tightest restrictions. Also: Lawmakers act; and a call for pet pics.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Tom Brady Lifted the Patriots. Now Comes a Second Act.
abstract: Winning six Super Bowls in New England, Brady flummoxed opponents and made Foxborough a household name. He’ll seek a new team after cutting ties with the Patriots.
lead_paragraph: Tom Brady’s six Super Bowl victories will keep him in the discussion of greatest N.F.L. players forever, but he has done something rarer in sports: He came to personify an entire region. In New England, where iconoclasm has been a virtue since the 1700s, Brady, a discarded college quarterback, was the plucky and ultimately beloved savior that turned the laughable New England Patriots into pro football’s greatest dynasty.

headline: Here’s Looking at You, Grid: A History of Crosswords and Their Fans
abstract: In “Thinking Inside the Box,” Adrienne Raphel offers a cultural and personal history of America’s favorite word puzzle.
lead_paragraph: In a 1924 editorial headlined “A Familiar Form of Madness,” this newspaper expressed its disdain for that vulgar new entertainment, that lowly diversion for idle minds, that pointless display of erudition known as the “cross-word”: “Scarcely recovered from the form of temporary madness that made so many people pay enormous prices for mahjong sets, about the same persons now are committing the same sinful waste in the utterly futile finding of words the letter of which will fit into a prearranged pattern, more or less complex.” A year later, this Olympian condescension had gotten a little desperate: “The craze evidently is dying out fast and in a few months it will be forgotten.”

headline: Sugar Is Not the Enemy
abstract: Myths about hyperactivity and sugar in children persist, despite evidence that debunks the connection.
lead_paragraph: When my older daughter was 4, her favorite snack to bring to preschool was a chocolate chip granola bar. I tucked one into her backpack almost every day, until one afternoon I opened up her backpack and saw the granola bar still sitting there. “Are you getting sick of these?” I asked her. She wasn’t. But a new teacher had taken over the class and instituted a new rule: no sugar before lunch.

headline: A Big List of Podcasts for Little Kids
abstract: Here’s a list of great shows to keep kids ages 2 through 6, and their caretakers, occupied.
lead_paragraph: My son’s podcast addiction began when he was 2, with “The Gingerbread Man.”

headline: ‘More Severe Than the Great Recession’
abstract: Time to get creative on stimulus.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: ‘Go Big’ on Coronavirus Stimulus, Trump Says, Pitching Checks for Americans
abstract: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin made the case to Republican senators on Tuesday for a $1 trillion plan, including $250 billion for direct checks to Americans by the end of April.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration called on Tuesday for urgent action to speed $1 trillion into the economy, including sending $250 billion worth of checks to millions of Americans, as the government prepared its most powerful tools to fight the coronavirus pandemic and an almost certain recession.

headline: On the Political Right, Anger and Suspicion Over Virus Precautions
abstract: An Illinois mayor’s emergency decree drew fury from some who view coronavirus preparedness as politically motivated “hysteria.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Deborah Frank Feinen, the mayor of Champaign, Ill., drafted an emergency powers declaration last Thursday to confront the coronavirus pandemic, she was proud of her city’s early preparation. But by the time she got to work the next morning, the National Rifle Association had blared a “national alert” saying “anti-gun extremists” were moving “to undermine our firearms freedom.”

headline: Grace VanderWaal Doesn’t Want to Exist Without ‘Breakfast at Tiffany’s’
abstract: The “America’s Got Talent” winner and actress in “Stargirl” can’t live without Audrey Hepburn, ramen and flea markets.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, Grace VanderWaal — a singing, songwriting, ukulele-strumming 12-year-old — auditioned for “America’s Got Talent,” and something like magic occurred. Howie Mandel called her “a living, beautiful, walking miracle” and Simon Cowell predicted she’d be the next Taylor Swift. VanderWaal went on to win Season 11.

headline: How Coronavirus Has Affected Real Estate
abstract: Some open houses have been canceled, others have new rules, and some New Yorkers are heading to the suburbs to escape the city.

headline: Flamenco Dancers Who ‘Move Between Genders’
abstract: Manuel Liñán’s “Viva!” represents something new to mainstream flamenco audiences: a frank and joyful expression of gay identity.
lead_paragraph: A dancer in a long red dress stands alone in the darkness, facing away from the audience. A keening voice rings out and the dancer’s arms flutter slightly, as if awakened by its mournful sound. “Eres una rosa,” you are a rose, the singer intones. The dancer’s body sways slightly, as if gathering energy, before turning around in one swift motion.

headline: The Last Workout
abstract: Told gyms would close imminently, some New Yorkers rushed to get one more burst of endorphins.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio wasn’t the only New Yorker who squeezed in an 11th-hour workout before gyms shut down in New York and elsewhere, along with movie theaters and nightclubs, at 8 p.m. on Monday.

headline: ‘It Is a Nightmare Out Here’: Seattle Parents Struggle to Balance Work and Child Care
abstract: One of the first major cities to face coronavirus is now dealing with a child care shortage.
lead_paragraph: First the schools closed, then the babysitter canceled.

headline: Fed Unveils Emergency Lending Programs as Companies Struggle to Raise Cash
abstract: The central bank will buy short-term promissory notes, known as commercial paper, a move it made during the 2008 financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve took a series of steps on Tuesday to prop up the American economy, saying first that it would begin buying up a type of debt that companies issue for short-term cash and then, later in the day, establishing a lending program meant to help the banks at the core of the financial system function smoothly.

headline: She Tracked Nazi-Looted Art. She Quit When No One Returned It.
abstract: A researcher stopped working for a German museum after she says she lost faith in its commitment to return works with tainted provenances.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For three years, Sibylle Ehringhaus, a veteran provenance researcher, worked with the Georg Schäfer Museum in northern Bavaria to examine the ownership history of its 1,000 oil paintings and several thousand drawings, prints and watercolors.

headline: Having Brushed Off Coronavirus Threat, Southeast Asia Begins to Confront It
abstract: The delay in containment efforts could prove dangerous, particularly in nations where the health care system can’t handle a major outbreak.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — For months, many Southeast Asian countries played down the threat posed by the new coronavirus. Some officials said that prayer would keep the disease away. Others expressed optimism that the tropical heat would slow the spread of the virus.

headline: In Upstate New York, a Hotel Dedicated to Creatives
abstract: The Maker, a new hotel in Hudson, pays tribute to the artisans and designers who have made the upstate town their own.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, Hudson — a former whaling town on the east side of the Hudson River in upstate New York — has seen a craft renaissance. A new crop of antique shops has joined the old, and a wide range of artisans and designers from New York City have made the town their own, drawn by the natural beauty and slower pace (and lower cost) of life. Hudson’s newest hotel, the Maker, pays tribute to this fact, and with more than just its name. Early on, the co-owners Lev Glazman, Alina Roytberg and Damien Janowicz decided that four of the 11 bedrooms in the hotel, which is spread across three newly fused buildings — a Georgian mansion and carriage house from the 1890s and a Greek Revival building from the 1840s — would be dedicated to a different kind of creative archetype.

headline: Africa Braces for Coronavirus, but Slowly
abstract: The virus has not yet hit most of the African continent hard, and neither has social distancing.
lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Commuters on bicycles and motorbikes wove through traffic in this West African city wearing face masks to protect their lungs — but not against coronavirus. They were protecting themselves from the fine dust blowing in from the Sahara.

headline: 10 Accessories in Green, Spring’s Liveliest Hue
abstract: The color of the moment comes in shades of emerald, lime and olive, brightening everything from platform shoes to classic bags.

headline: A Baltimore Barber Who’s With His Clients Through Life, and Death
abstract: Antoine Dow helps bring dignity to young black men whose lives were cut short by gun violence.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The barber had with him his tools of the trade — a black leather smock, a razor, clippers, scissors — and tufts of black locks he had collected from the floor of his shop.

headline: In the I.C.U., Before the Coronavirus Storm
abstract: Even as public life grinds to a halt, here in one of the intensive care units that will become ground zero for coronavirus infections, the everyday tragedies continue.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t even notice the balloons at first. With our laser focus on coronavirus, on our protocols and procedures, our carts of isolation gowns and our fears about mask shortages, it is easy to see only pandemic these days.

headline: The French Open Is Postponed, to the Surprise of the Tours
abstract: Tournament officials said it was impossible to carry out the tennis major as originally planned. Leaders on the men’s and women’s tours said the decision caught them by surprise.
lead_paragraph: The French Open, one of the four Grand Slam tournaments that define success in tennis, will be postponed until September because of the coronavirus.

headline: The Face of Houston’s Diverse Dining Scene Is a White Guy From Nebraska
abstract: The chef Chris Shepherd has promoted immigrant restaurateurs and the city, and become a big name himself in the process.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — It was Chris Shepherd’s day.

headline: Coronavirus Is Spreading. Should You Cancel Your Vacation?
abstract: Experts offer advice on how to make the best possible decision for you and your family.
lead_paragraph: With summer fast approaching, many families are wondering just how long coronavirus will remain at the center of our lives. The outbreak has sickened people worldwide and killed thousands, adding a new layer of anxiety when thinking about potential travel plans.

headline: How to Talk to Kids About Coronavirus
abstract: Keeping your own anxiety in check is key.
lead_paragraph: By now, your children may have heard about the new coronavirus, whether it’s from a snippet of a news briefing or from other kids at school. They may have family members who have been quarantined here because of recent international travel, or they may even know someone who is sick. “My patients are scared,” said Dr. Nia Heard-Garris, M.D., an attending physician at the Ann and Robert H. Lurie Children’s Hospital of Chicago.

headline: Don’t Fall for These Myths About Coronavirus
abstract: Misconceptions about what can protect you are becoming just as contagious as the virus.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus continues to spread across the globe, confusion and misconceptions about what can protect you are becoming as contagious as the virus. We spoke to doctors and experts in infectious diseases about whether there’s any truth to these common claims.

headline: Pregnant and Worried About Coronavirus? Experts Weigh In
abstract: We found answers to some of the most pressing questions posed by expecting mothers.
lead_paragraph: This article was originally published on March 6 and last updated on April 14. This is a fast-moving situation, so some information may be outdated. For the latest updates, read The New York Times’s live coronavirus coverage here.

headline: Schools Are Closing for Coronavirus. Now What?
abstract: Education may be disrupted, but that doesn’t mean our kids have to lose out.
lead_paragraph: With the new coronavirus spreading across the United States, some schools are closing for days, weeks or perhaps even longer. As head of an all-girls pre-K through 12 school outside of Philadelphia, I’ve been working with health officials and fellow administrators to help our local community wrestle with how to respond to reports of presumptive positive cases in the area. Naturally, both parents and educators are asking the same question: What happens now?

headline: Why We Love the Bouffant
abstract: The resilient ’60s style is back for yet another round. Here, how to do it. It will involve a lot of hair spray.
lead_paragraph: The bouffant is back!

headline: Glued to TV for Now, but When Programming Thins and Bills Mount …
abstract: More Netflix. Less ESPN. The pandemic means a greater number of television viewers in the short term, but signals a potential threat to the ecosystem protecting the industry.
lead_paragraph: It happened around the world, and now it’s happening in the United States: The more people stay home to avoid the coronavirus pandemic, the more they find themselves glued to their screens.

headline: A Virus Put My Asthmatic Son in the I.C.U. What Could Coronavirus Do?
abstract: Respiratory illnesses are not new to my family. But the current lack of information has me worried.
lead_paragraph: Today was the 11th morning I’ve packed lunches for my three children, prodded them to put on their shoes and hunted for library books under the couch since learning that my home state of New York had been hit by a dangerous respiratory virus.

headline: Under Lockdown for Coronavirus, Parents Struggle to Deal With Their Kids
abstract: A reporter explains how she’s managing her kids and personal fears while trapped inside a small Shanghai apartment.
lead_paragraph: As with most parents in China, when I’m not anxiously scanning my phone for the latest news of the coronavirus outbreak, I’m consumed by another pressing question: How will I survive another day stuck indoors with my kids?

headline: They Prepared for the Worst. Now Everyone’s a Prepper.
abstract: As cases of the coronavirus rise in the United States, preppers have watched with a mix of concern, weariness and even some hope that Americans will learn from their example.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, millions of people have faced a new, dread-inducing question as coronavirus cases have mounted around the world: How do you prepare a home to get through a pandemic?

headline: Elinor Ross, Met Soprano With Illness-Shortened Career, Dies at 93
abstract: In 1970 she stepped in on short notice at the Metropolitan Opera. Nine years later, Bell’s palsy sidelined her.
lead_paragraph: Elinor Ross, a soprano who made a dramatic Metropolitan Opera debut in 1970 as a last-minute replacement in the title role of “Turandot,” but whose career was over by the end of the decade, cut short by an illness that paralyzed her facial muscles, died on March 6 in Manhattan. She was 93.

headline: Tracking the Coronavirus: How Crowded Asian Cities Tackled an Epidemic
abstract: Singapore, Taiwan and Hong Kong offer successful strategies, at least so far, in battling a pandemic. But they use tactics that the U.S. and Europe may not be able to replicate.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — Two hours. That’s all the time medical teams in Singapore are given to uncover the first details of how patients contracted the coronavirus and which people they might infect.

headline: We Live in Zoom Now
abstract: Zoom is where we work, go to school and party these days.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday afternoon, Eleanor Dolan celebrated her 17th birthday in Minnesota with 20 of her closest friends. They listened to pop music and traded jokes. When the group broke out into “Happy Birthday to You,” Eleanor pulled a slice of cookie cheesecake close in front of her and pretended to blow out the toothpick she had substituted for a candle on top.

headline: Let’s Not Ration Health Care
abstract: Former Representative Tony Coelho says some medical professionals are trying to marginalize seniors and the disabled in this crisis.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Parents Need to Know About Coronavirus
abstract: The information on the risk to children and pregnant women in the U.S. seems to be changing by the hour. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: The new coronavirus is spreading rapidly throughout the world — and parents are increasingly on edge. More than 180,000 have been sickened worldwide, and more than 7,000 have died since an outbreak began in December in Wuhan, China. In the United States, cases have been rising rapidly as officials ramp up testing across the country.

headline: A ‘Drop the Mic’ Moment for a Man Who Paid College Basketball Recruits
abstract: A documentary pulls back the layers of corruption in the college game with a talent scout who was a part of it.
lead_paragraph: A federal trial last spring made a compelling case that several of the most successful college basketball teams in America thrive on illicitly paying top dollars to top recruits.

headline: China Announces That It Will Expel American Journalists
abstract: The announcement comes weeks after President Trump limited the number of Chinese citizens who can work in the United States for five state-run Chinese news organizations.
lead_paragraph: In a sharp escalation of tensions between the two superpowers, China announced on Tuesday that it would expel American journalists working for The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post. It also demanded that those outlets, as well as the Voice of America and Time magazine, provide the Chinese government with detailed information about their operations.

headline: Where Women Are Ahead of Men: Hand Washing
abstract: During a global pandemic, personal hygiene habits have far-reaching consequences.
lead_paragraph: — Rosie Frasso, program director of public health at Thomas Jefferson University

headline: Illinois Stumbles as States See Light Voter Turnout, With Many Ballots in the Mail
abstract: Florida, Illinois and Arizona pressed ahead with their presidential primary elections on Tuesday, but chaos and confusion in Illinois sent in-person turnout diving amid coronavirus fears.
lead_paragraph: Voting in major cities in Illinois was rife with confusion on Tuesday and early turnout in many areas was significantly lower than expected, leading to complaints from poll workers and clashes between Chicago officials and the statehouse.

headline: This Mysterious Ancient Structure Was Made of Mammoth Bones
abstract: The ring of skulls, skeletons, tusks and other bones was too large for a roof, scientists say, so what was it for?
lead_paragraph: Ice Age hunter-gatherers, foraging the bone-chilling, unforgiving steppes of what today is Russia, somehow completed a remarkable construction project: a 40-foot-wide, circular structure made from the skulls, skeletons and tusks of more than 60 woolly mammoths. The reason remains a mystery to archaeologists.

headline: Hundreds of Scientists Scramble to Find a Coronavirus Treatment
abstract: In an ambitious international collaboration, researchers have “mapped” proteins in the coronavirus and identified 50 drugs to test against it.
lead_paragraph: Working at a breakneck pace, a team of hundreds of scientists has identified 50 drugs that may be effective treatments for people infected with the coronavirus.

headline: German Military Laptop Sold on eBay Included Classified Missile Information
abstract: The computer was probably decommissioned years ago, but its hard drive held information relating to a weapons system that’s still in use.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Weighing in at a hefty 11 pounds, with a tiny 128 MB of working memory and a decades-old Pentium III processor, a used laptop recently bought by a German cybersecurity firm had its heyday long before the first iPhone was built.

headline: Spring Cruises Look Unlikely to Sail
abstract: With ocean-going departures from American ports suspended until at least April 11, here’s what those interested in spring cruises can expect.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the global cruise line industry all but ground to a halt, with the biggest companies suspending operations, at least in the United States, for 30 days. The decision, announced by the Cruise Lines International Association (CLIA), came after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the State Department urged Americans to avoid cruise ships, and the United States banned most travel from Europe.

headline: Review: ‘Little Fires Everywhere’ Ignites Over Race and Class
abstract: Reese Witherspoon and Kerry Washington play moms divided by nearly everything in the Hulu mini-series.
lead_paragraph: The Hulu mini-series “Little Fires Everywhere” is set in the 1990s, a fact that its script and soundtrack take great pains to remind you of: Sugar Ray and Grey Poupon, “Waterfalls” and “Before Sunrise.” There’s even a reasonable onscreen facsimile of the New York Times lobby circa 1997.

headline: In Talking About Economic Recovery, Washington Shuns the B-Word
abstract: White House officials and lawmakers trying to bolster the economy during the coronavirus crisis don’t want to hear about any bailouts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When it comes to the term bailout, lawmakers and Trump administration officials would just as soon bail out and avoid it altogether. Same goes for stimulus; many don’t find the word politically stimulating at all. And don’t even dare to mention troubled assets.

headline: Stuart Whitman, Leading Man on Big and Small Screens, Dies at 92
abstract: Known for his studied portrayals of complex characters, he earned an Oscar nomination for his role as a convicted child molester in “The Mark.”
lead_paragraph: Stuart Whitman, a ruggedly handsome actor who appeared in countless films and television shows over 50 years, earning an Oscar nomination for his role as a convicted child molester in the 1961 movie “The Mark,” died on Monday at his home in Montecito, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Paris, a Magnet for the World, Becomes a Ghost City After a Lockdown Takes Effect
abstract: France imposed the restriction at noon on Tuesday, ordering people to stay inside except for a few exceptions. One of the world’s most visited cities turned quiet suddenly.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — An exodus from Paris at the Gare Montparnasse train station. A postal worker warning of the plague, the apocalypse and repentance, with the Eiffel Tower behind him. Fear in people’s eyes, and tense moments, in a long line outside a supermarket.

headline: ‘Lost Transmissions’ Review: Fuel for the L.A. Music Scene
abstract: A record producer played by Simon Pegg wants to live “without a filter” in this movie that also stars Juno Temple.
lead_paragraph: Back in the day when pop recording artists could still score hits with songs complaining about the music industry, Shawn Mullins, in the 1998 hit “Lullaby,” observed of Los Angeles, “It’s like Nashville with a tan.” But the troubadours and orchestrators inhabiting the L.A. drama “Lost Transmissions” are so inundated with and insulated by their life challenges that they’re as ashen as Siberian exiles.

headline: Asylum Seekers Say U.S. is Returning Them to the Dangers They Fled
abstract: A new agreement allows the United States to transfer asylum seekers to Guatemala — a high-crime country that poses its own risks and offers them little protection.
lead_paragraph: CORTÉS DEPARTMENT, Honduras — Yovani has a strategy for staying alive: He will not let anyone know he is back in Honduras, he will move homes every couple of weeks and he will stay indoors.

headline: It Was Their Big Debut. Then a Pandemic Hit.
abstract: Artists, actors, dancers and authors search for a silver lining as openings are disrupted by the virus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: The mood was muted late Saturday afternoon at Ulterior Gallery, a narrow storefront space on the Lower East Side. It was meant to be the opening of Mamie Tinkler’s first solo show in New York, a joyous occasion that was canceled Friday morning. Instead, Ms. Tinkler and Takako Tanabe, the gallery’s director, decided on a lower key, staggered event, with friends drifting in throughout the afternoon. (The gallery is now open by appointment and remotely.)

headline: Watch the Footprint of Coronavirus Spread Across Countries
abstract: A satellite that detects pollution from human activity shows how the coronavirus is shutting down whole countries.
lead_paragraph: A satellite that detects pollution from human activity shows how the coronavirus is shutting down whole countries.

headline: What Does ‘Dressing for Work’ Mean Now?
abstract: If you’re suddenly working from home instead of going into an office, you have a few options.
lead_paragraph: We spend a lot of our days chatting with each other about things we see online, trying to make sense of it all. As everyone confronts the new coronavirus crisis, many of us are facing drastic changes, including illness, job loss and abandoning the office to work entirely from home.

headline: A Not-Quite-Restaurant Faces the New Reality
abstract: Mirna’s Pupuseria is one of the city’s many small, family-owned enterprises, struggling to stay in business in the time of coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The restaurants of New York City have gone dark. But what of the not-quite-restaurants: the in-betweens with just a few wobbly chairs, the lunch counters that hedge bets by selling groceries alongside hot food, the tiny spots whose very grasp at existence is a daily improvisation?

headline: The Single Most Important Lesson From the 1918 Influenza
abstract: Tell the truth. At its core, society is based on trust.
lead_paragraph: In 1918, a new respiratory virus invaded the human population and killed between 50 million and 100 million people — adjusted for population, that would equal 220 million to 430 million people today. Late last year another new respiratory virus invaded the human population, and the reality of a pandemic is now upon us. Although clearly a serious threat to human health, it does not appear to be as deadly as the 1918 influenza pandemic. But it is far more lethal than 2009’s H1N1 (swine flu) pandemic, and the coronavirus does not resemble SARS, MERS or Ebola, all of which can be easily contained.

headline: Anti-Russian Protests Erupt in Ukraine, Despite Virus Threat
abstract: Organizers of a street protest in Kyiv say resisting Russian influence is more important than honoring a ban on mass gatherings.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Ukraine, like many countries, has closed schools and banned mass gatherings to combat the coronavirus. But unlike others, it has struggled to tamp down street protests, which persist over the war in the country’s separatist east.

headline: They Eloped on the Way to Their Wedding
abstract: Brad Wilson and Brooke Cook were supposed to have a big church wedding Saturday in Dallas. But in their car, as they drove there from New York, they changed plans. In a hurry.
lead_paragraph: Brad Wilson walked out of his Manhattan apartment building and straight, it seemed, into an Isaac Asimov thriller.

headline: The Coronavirus Is Here to Stay, So What Happens Next?
abstract: There may be two to four more rounds of social distancing before this is over. Here’s what to expect.
lead_paragraph: In the last few days, most Americans, even President Trump, have come to terms with the need for social distancing. Though they feel fine, they are staying home and developing new routines — killing time baking, binge-watching, figuring out how to home-school their kids. It took far too long for Americans to accept how serious the coronavirus is. Now that we’ve finally taken the necessary measures in many places to close schools, offices, restaurants and other businesses, people are asking: How soon will it all be over? Two weeks? Four weeks? When can we go back to normal?

headline: The Coronavirus Preys on Jews’ Biggest Strength
abstract: In the Persian Jewish community of Great Neck, N.Y., “social distancing is a wedding that only has 400 people.”
lead_paragraph: My friend begged his parents not to go to the shiva. The person who had died was from a prominent family in their Long Island community, and he knew that during the traditional seven days of mourning hundreds of people would be passing through the synagogue where the shiva was being held.

headline: On-Demand Webinar: How to Use The Learning Network for Remote Learning
abstract: In this webinar, our team provides an introduction to The Learning Network and walks you through how to participate in three of our interactive student features.
lead_paragraph: Whether you are a teacher, a parent or a student who is at least 13 years old, this on-demand webinar will help you get started in using The Learning Network’s free resources for remote learning. We offer more than a dozen new writing prompts and activities each week, all based on Times articles, photographs, illustrations, videos and graphs. All of these prompts and activities are completely free for everyone.

headline: Islands in the U.S. Are Barring All Outsiders to Keep Coronavirus at Bay
abstract: “People don’t understand how fragile we are,” said one resident of an island off Maine that will turn away visitors. Communities in North Carolina’s Outer Banks will do the same.
lead_paragraph: Two famous island resorts in the Eastern United States are trying to seal themselves off by barring all visitors, taking the extraordinary measures in an effort to prevent the coronavirus from coming ashore.

headline: Europe Barricades Borders to Slow Coronavirus
abstract: Even as European countries erect barriers between one another, the E.U. announced a coordinated ban on nearly all travelers from the rest of the world.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The spiraling coronavirus epidemic tore into the fabric of Europe on Tuesday, prompting its leaders to all but wall the continent off from the rest of the world and erect barriers within it, and to throttle back or turn off the engines of ordinary life and livelihoods in hopes of slowing the deadly spread.

headline: Coronavirus, Vaccine Testing, Yoga in Nepal: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘We Are Not a Hospital’: A Prison Braces for the Coronavirus
abstract: In places where social distancing is impossible and medical care strained, bars won’t stop the infection’s spread.
lead_paragraph: Packed into a crowded federal prison complex with not enough masks, soap or hand sanitizer, and the sole doctor out sick, corrections workers in Tallahassee, Fla., were worried.

headline: A New Hurt in Italy From the Coronavirus: A Banking Crisis
abstract: The nation’s banks, long at the center of worries about European finance, look more likely to get a rescue.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Italy confronts the ravages of an unexpected threat in the coronavirus, fears are intensifying that the economic damage could trigger a far more familiar danger — a banking crisis.

headline: Brother of Manchester Bomber Is Found Guilty in Murder of 22 People
abstract: “He has blood on his hands even if he didn’t detonate the bomb,” a prosecutor said. The brother, convicted of helping plan the attack, faces life in prison.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A jury in Britain on Tuesday convicted the brother of a suicide bomber who killed 22 people at an Ariana Grande concert in Manchester in 2017, finding him guilty on all 22 counts of murder for his role in planning and executing the attack.

headline: Trump Now Claims He Always Knew the Coronavirus Would Be a Pandemic
abstract: The president tried to rewrite his history with advising Americans about the coronavirus. His own words prove him wrong.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For weeks, President Trump has minimized the coronavirus, mocked concern about it and treated the risk from it cavalierly. On Tuesday he took to the White House lectern and made a remarkable assertion: He knew it was a pandemic all along.

headline: The Left Is Still Leery of Biden. Here’s How He’s Reaching Out to Them.
abstract: The Biden campaign and a long list of surrogates are striving to engage progressive Democrats who have so far been cool to Mr. Biden’s presidential bid.
lead_paragraph: Through conversations on Capitol Hill, engagement with local activists and policy nods toward Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign and its allies are ramping up overtures to progressives, aiming to improve Mr. Biden’s standing with a key part of the Democratic coalition in an effort to unite the party around his potential nomination.

headline: We Lead Three Universities. It’s Time for Drastic Action.
abstract: Organizations nationwide need to get ahead of the coronavirus, even if it’s not in their community yet.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of the new coronavirus is teaching us all what a pandemic demands of us. As leaders of three institutions fortunate to have access to outstanding public health research, we quickly came to understand in recent weeks that if we wanted to help protect the health of our nation, we had to take drastic action.

headline: Lyle Waggoner, a TV Star as Actor and Announcer, Dies at 84
abstract: He first achieved fame as both a voice and a sketch performer on “The Carol Burnett Show.” He later became even more famous on “Wonder Woman.”
lead_paragraph: Lyle Waggoner, the sable-haired heartthrob best remembered as the announcer and a comic performer in the early years of “The Carol Burnett Show” and for playing opposite Lynda Carter on the 1970s television versions of “Wonder Woman,” died on Tuesday at his home in Westlake Village, Calif. He was 84.

headline: Power Struggle Hampers Iran’s Coronavirus Response
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani has been severely criticized for not acting forcefully against the epidemic. Now he and the military, newly empowered to intervene, are fighting over control.
lead_paragraph: More senior government figures have caught the coronavirus in Iran than anywhere else. Field hospitals have been erected in parking lots, stadiums and wedding halls to handle the overflow of patients.

headline: Lessons Learned From Earlier Corporate Bailouts
abstract: Keith Anderson, co-founder of BlackRock, writes that stock buybacks have left companies unprepared for a recession. Also: Caregivers deserve a living wage; an Indian-American childhood.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Kevin Durant Says He Has Tested Positive for the Coronavirus
abstract: At least seven N.B.A. players are known to have tested positive, including three of Durant’s teammates on the Nets.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Durant, one of the biggest stars in the N.B.A., is one of four Nets players who tested positive for the coronavirus, he told The Athletic on Tuesday.

headline: These Places Could Run Out of Hospital Beds as Coronavirus Spreads
abstract: New estimates from a Harvard research team show that, in many parts of the country, there may not be enough hospital beds and staff for coronavirus patients. A shortage of intensive care beds for the sickest patients may be even worse.
lead_paragraph: New estimates from a Harvard research team show that, in many parts of the country, there may not be enough hospital beds and staff for coronavirus patients. A shortage of intensive care beds for the sickest patients may be even worse.

headline: At Party for Donald Trump Jr.’s Girlfriend, Donors Helped Pick Up the Tab
abstract: Attendees of the bash for Kimberly Guilfoyle at the president’s private club chipped in — including financial backers of the Trump re-election campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a lavish birthday party for Donald Trump Jr.’s girlfriend, Kimberly Guilfoyle. The setting was Mar-a-Lago, President Trump’s private club in Palm Beach, Fla. The guest list included dozens of Trump family members and friends.

headline: What to Watch After ‘Tiger King’: 12 Great True-Crime Documentaries on Netflix
abstract: Restaurants are closing. And bars. And … almost everything else. What better time for a true-crime binge?
lead_paragraph: It looks as if most of us are going to spend some time at home, and goodness knows diversions are welcome. Whatever it may say about these bleak times, true-crime documentaries (in feature film and series form) have proven among the most bingeable of entertainments, drawing us ever deeper into their webs of suspects, clues and whiteboards. “Tiger King,” while not a straight true-crime series like these others, has elements of some of the more gripping stories on this list.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘No Dates, No Love, No Hope?’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: You, age 47, marry a man, age 65. There is no gap in your mental or motor skills. Then one day you are 62. He is 80. Over morning coffee, he says, “I need to write a thank-you note to Paul.” You reply, “Uh-huh. Do that.” He does not respond. You look up from your laptop. His eyes are misty. “I can’t write. That damn shake.” His doctor says the hand tremor is benign. Just old age. So here it is, writ large: age gap. You say, “I’ll write it for you.” He reaches over, grasps your hand. — Holly Mullen

headline: As the Shutdowns Due to Coronavirus Spread
abstract: Readers discuss how to mitigate the effects on businesses and suggest turning unused ships and schools into hospitals.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Virus Hot Spot, Lining Up and Anxious at Drive-in Test Center
abstract: In New Rochelle, the early epicenter of the coronavirus in New York, the state’s first drive-in facility serves those at risk or with symptoms.
lead_paragraph: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. — Any other place, any other time, the three white tents set against the Long Island Sound in the middle of a public park, with a line of vehicles waiting to get in, could have easily been the scene of a wedding or a garden party.

headline: Live Analysis: Presidential Primary Election Results
abstract: See full results and maps from the Presidential primaries.
lead_paragraph: See full results and maps from the Presidential primaries.

headline: Live Primary Election Results: Florida, Illinois and Arizona
abstract: Get the latest primary results form Florida, Illinois and Arizona on March 17.
lead_paragraph: Get the latest primary results form Florida, Illinois and Arizona on March 17.

headline: Helping Your Dog Survive During a Quarantine
abstract: Quarantine means no one goes out — and that includes your pup, unless you have a private outdoor space for them. Here’s how to help your dog thrive while you’re both stuck indoors.
lead_paragraph: The only good thing about Covid-19 is that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (C.D.C.), World Health Organization (W.H.O.) and other experts are in agreement that there are no meaningful signs that our pets can get this virus or spread it. That said, although our pets aren’t getting sick, Covid-19 is changing the lives of pets across the country, especially for dogs and in particular those living in apartments.

headline: M.T.A., Citing Huge Drop in Riders, Seeks $4 Billion Virus Bailout
abstract: Ridership has fallen 60 percent on the subways and as much as 90 percent on commuter railways.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s public transportation system, the largest in North America, is seeking a $4 billion federal bailout as the coronavirus pandemic has triggered an extraordinary free fall in ridership and left transit officials facing what is likely to be the worst economic crisis in decades.

headline: Tonie Marshall Dies at 68; French Filmmaker Took On Sexism
abstract: A French-American actress and director, she helped open up a male-dominated movie industry to more women.
lead_paragraph: Tonie Marshall, a French-American filmmaker and actress and the only female director to win a César award, France’s equivalent of the Oscars, died on Thursday in Paris. She was 68.

headline: Coronavirus Is Closing Social Security Offices. Here’s How to Get Benefit Help.
abstract: The Social Security Administration has more than 1,200 offices that serve thousands of beneficiaries every day.
lead_paragraph: The Social Security Administration operates a vast network of more than 1,200 offices around the country that help thousands of Americans every day with applications for retirement, disability and Medicare benefits.

headline: What You Need to Know About Unemployment Insurance
abstract: The coronavirus outbreak is closing down some businesses, leaving workers unsure how they can support themselves during the crisis. This is how unemployment works.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus outbreak grinds American life to a halt, many workers have already experienced sudden drops in income — if their paychecks haven’t been wiped out entirely. Unemployment insurance is a crucial safety net, providing a temporary cash cushion.

headline: Amazon Bans, Then Reinstates, Hitler’s ‘Mein Kampf’
abstract: The retailer is trying to do two contradictory things: Ban hate literature but allow free speech.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon quietly banned Adolf Hitler's manifesto “Mein Kampf” late last week, part of its accelerating efforts to remove Nazi and other hate-filled material from its bookstore, before quickly reversing itself.

headline: What the Polls Say About Florida, Illinois and Arizona
abstract: Most bets are off as worries over the coronavirus hover over voting in Tuesday’s Democratic primaries, but Joe Biden has led in surveys of all three states.
