headline: The Hardest Questions Doctors May Face: Who Will Be Saved? Who Won’t?
abstract: As coronavirus infections explode in the U.S., hospitals could be forced to make harrowing choices if pushed to the brink. Planning is already underway.
lead_paragraph: The medical director of the intensive care unit had to choose which patients’ lives would be supported by ventilators and other equipment. Hurricane Sandy was bearing down on Bellevue Hospital in New York City in 2012, and the main generators were about to fail. Dr. Laura Evans would be left with only six power outlets for the unit’s 50 patients.

headline: How You Can Help Victims of the Coronavirus Pandemic
abstract: From charities that support children to organizations that feed families, there is no shortage of ways to get involved.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus has now spread to at least 177 countries and killed tens of thousands.

headline: Thank God the Doctor Is In
abstract: Peeking out our windows, we see America shriveling.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It’s not easy being a national treasure.

headline: Lessons From My Grandma on Art, Sex and Life
abstract: She was unfailingly true to herself at a time when many doors were closed to women.
lead_paragraph: My father once asked his mother, the artist Annette Nancarrow, what she thought of Leon Trotsky. It wasn’t a political question. He just wanted her impression of the exiled Bolshevik, whom she had first met in Mexico City in the late 1930s, in the studio of her close friend (and, my father suspected, future lover) Diego Rivera.

headline: This Is Not the End of the World and You Are Not a Prepper
abstract: The prepper vision of the world is bleak and ruthless. Something better is happening now.
lead_paragraph: Some years ago, out of a perverse need to both mediate and exacerbate my own anxieties about the climate catastrophe and the threat it posed to the structures undergirding civilization, I got very into consuming doomsday prepper content online. I can’t tell you how many hours I put in watching YouTube videos of burly American men talking about emergency water filtration techniques and what items to put in your long-term wilderness bug-out bag, but I can tell you that it was far too many.

headline: Grieving in Self-Quarantine After a Missouri Shooting
abstract: “It’s all just slamming at once, and we don’t know what to do,” said a friend of 22-year-old Matthew Hicks-Morris, who was killed last weekend in a shooting at a gas station in Springfield, Mo.
lead_paragraph: The sequence of events is grim but familiar in cities across the United States. A mass shooting takes place. A public vigil is held. A community comes together with an outpouring of anger, sadness and solidarity.

headline: Don’t Put More People in New York’s Jails During a Pandemic
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo and the State Legislature can save lives by resisting calls to roll back criminal justice reforms.
lead_paragraph: The last thing New York needs right now, as it fights a deadly pandemic, is more people in jail.

headline: I Spent a Year in Space, and I Have Tips on Isolation to Share
abstract: Take it from someone who couldn’t: Go outside.
lead_paragraph: Being stuck at home can be challenging. When I lived on the International Space Station for nearly a year, it wasn’t easy. When I went to sleep, I was at work. When I woke up, I was still at work. Flying in space is probably the only job you absolutely cannot quit.

headline: Top U.S. Intelligence Official Taps New Counterterrorism Chief
abstract: Lora Shiao will be the new acting director for the National Counterterrorism Center amid a broader reshuffling of top intelligences aides and expected personnel cutbacks
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lora Shiao, a career American intelligence officer, will be the next acting director of the National Counterterrorism Center, the government’s central clearinghouse for intelligence on terrorist threats, Trump administration officials said on Saturday.

headline: Joe Biden’s Campaign Was Cash Poor. He Seized Control of the Nomination Anyway.
abstract: New figures show just how big a financial hole the former vice president was in before he pulled off a remarkable turnaround in the Democratic race.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has taken command of the Democratic primary for president despite running on a shoestring budget in a contest where Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont raised more money in February alone, $47.6 million, than Mr. Biden had spent in his previous five months combined, new federal records show.

headline: Freezers Sell Out as Consumers Stock Up
abstract: As the coronavirus pandemic continues, people are preparing to hunker down for weeks or longer.
lead_paragraph: The calls come every five minutes, Chris Rouse said, all asking for the same thing: a small chest freezer. That’s a problem for Mr. Rouse, an appliance salesman in the Town of Wallkill, N.Y. He has no more to sell.

headline: Betty Williams, Peace Laureate From Northern Ireland, Dies at 76
abstract: She and Mairead Corrigan shared the 1976 Nobel Prize for galvanizing a mass movement to protest sectarian violence during the time known as the Troubles.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Betty Williams, a grass-roots activist who shared the 1976 Nobel Peace Prize as a founder of a protest movement that mobilized tens of thousands of people to demand an end to the sectarian violence in Northern Ireland known as the Troubles, died on Tuesday in Belfast. She was 76.

headline: Here’s What Calling in the National Guard Means
abstract: The coronavirus outbreak has prompted dozens of governors to activate the National Guard. The sight of troops has stoked fears of a military-enforced quarantine, but the orders have been more mundane.
lead_paragraph: In Puerto Rico, they are taking passengers’ temperatures at the island’s largest airport. In Wisconsin, they escorted cruise ship passengers back to their houses for quarantine. In Florida, they are swabbing people’s noses near Miami to test for the coronavirus.

headline: Bill Smith, Master of Two Musical Worlds, Is Dead at 93
abstract: As Bill Smith, he was a jazz clarinetist who played with Dave Brubeck. As William O. Smith, he was a composer who pioneered unorthodox techniques for his instrument.
lead_paragraph: Bill Smith, a clarinetist and composer who forged collaborations with some of the pre-eminent jazz and classical artists of the 20th century, including an especially long and close alliance with the pianist Dave Brubeck, died on Feb. 29 at his home in Seattle. He was 93.

headline: Where Are All the Masks?
abstract: In the United States, there is a shortage of medical equipment. What’s going on?
lead_paragraph: As the heath care system strains to accommodate the unprecedented challenge of the coronavirus outbreak, many medical professionals on the front lines do not have adequate protection.

headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Eerie Streetscapes Are Stripped of Commerce
abstract: With tight restrictions in place, the city offered scenes that might follow a blizzard, overlaid on a sunny spring Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Everywhere, gates lowered. Bar stools stacked upside down. The boutiques of Soho, the specialty shops of Greenwich Village — for chess, for board games, for records — all locked away and dark. Little Italy’s signature sidewalk tables for alfresco dining had been hauled inside, leaving Mulberry Street just like any other street.

headline: Bring Your ‘A’ Game
abstract: Brendan Emmett Quigley makes the grade with this Sunday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Brendan Emmett Quigley is in the pantheon of great veteran Times constructors, and today’s grid is absorbing and clever. I found it plenty crunchy — it took two sittings to completely finish — but bright and self-assured in a welcoming way. I hope nobody gave up on it before figuring out its fun gimmick. If you were on the verge, join us and prepare to be enlightened!

headline: Scripps National Spelling Bee Is S-U-S-P-E-N-D-E-D
abstract: The sponsors, who suspended the contest because of the coronavirus, did not set a new date for the finals, making it unclear whether it would take place at all.
lead_paragraph: The national finals of the Scripps National Spelling Bee in National Harbor, Md., have been suspended, joining a long — and growing — list of events that have been canceled because of the coronavirus.

headline: Americans Coping With the Coronavirus Are Clogging Toilets
abstract: Sewage systems and toilets are backing up as consumers clean their homes with disinfectant wipes and turn to paper towels, napkins and baby wipes to cope with the lack of toilet paper.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans seem to be following the recommendations of public health officials to clean and sterilize countertops, doorknobs, faucets and other frequently touched surfaces in their homes.

headline: The Hottest Parties in Town Are Now Online
abstract: As many are quarantining or socially distancing themselves to curb the spread of the coronavirus, the party has moved to social media.
lead_paragraph: On Friday night there was one place in the country where you could take part in a social gathering and not be afraid of spreading or contracting the coronavirus.

headline: Governments and Companies Race to Make Masks Vital to Virus Fight
abstract: President Trump resists using emergency powers to compel production, saying companies will voluntarily provide much-needed protective gear.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Saturday sought to assure an anxious American public that help was on the way to overwhelmed hospitals, and that private companies had agreed to provide desperately needed medical supplies to fight the fast-spreading coronavirus.

headline: They Went Abroad to Study. Now They Are Stranded.
abstract: As borders closed and airlines canceled flights, the biggest lesson for many Americans studying abroad was this: You’re on your own.
lead_paragraph: Channing Stirrat traveled to Ecuador to study biology. Nicholas Nerli flew to Morocco to further his Arabic studies. For Adina Rombro, a study-abroad program offered a chance to dive into Peruvian culture and history.

headline: Trump Writes to Kim Jong-un Offering Help in Virus Fight, North Korea Says
abstract: The North, which says it is waging an all-out campaign against the coronavirus, expressed “sincere gratitude” for the president’s letter.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — President Trump has sent a letter to North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, expressing his willingness to help the North battle the coronavirus, North Korea said on Sunday.

headline: Christian Siriano and Dov Charney Are Making Masks and Medical Supplies Now
abstract: Fashion designers and manufacturers are rebooting their operations to help with shortages of masks and gowns in the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Last week the American fashion industry went dark as stores and factories closed, both voluntarily and by government decree, to help prevent the spread of the new coronavirus.

headline: A Closed Border, Dashed Hopes and a Looming Disaster
abstract: The United States, citing the coronavirus, is shutting off access for anyone trying to claim asylum from the Mexican border.
lead_paragraph: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — Tania Bonilla arrived in this Mexican border city on Wednesday determined to apply for asylum in the United States.

headline: Alex Fishman, Anthony Shirk
abstract: The couple met in September 2014 through the dating app Hinge.
lead_paragraph: Alex Ethan Fishman and Anthony Richard Shirk were married March 21 at their home in New York. Rabbi Gary Katz officiated. On Nov. 8, the couple is to have a celebratory ceremony led by Rabbi Matthew L. Green at the Roundhouse, an events space in Beacon, N.Y.

headline: Justine Roach, Hrishikesh Desai
abstract: The couple met in June 2017 through the dating app Bumble.
lead_paragraph: Justine Victoria Roach and Hrishikesh Padmanabh Desai were married March 21 at the home of Ms. Roach’s parents in Beverly Hills, Calif. Rabbi Laura Geller officiated at a ceremony incorporating Jewish and Hindu wedding traditions. The couple had planned to wed at the Ojai Valley Inn, a resort in Ojai, Calif., before the Centers for Disease Control recommended that events with 50 or more people should be postponed.

headline: Brittany Harris, Naseem Beauchman
abstract: The couple were Facebook friends for more than a decade, but didn’t met in person until 2017, when they matched on the League dating app.
lead_paragraph: Brittany Virginia Lucille Harris and Dr. Naseem Neon Beauchman were married March 21 at the home of Ms. Harris’s parents in Oakland, Calif. Leon F. Beauchman, the father of the groom and a Universal Life minister, officiated. The couple had originally planned to wed at the Meritage Resort and Spa in Napa, Calif., before the Centers for Disease Control recommended that events with 50 or more people should be postponed.

headline: Traffic and Pollution Plummet as U.S. Cities Shut Down for Coronavirus
abstract: A satellite that detects pollution linked to cars and trucks shows declines over major metropolitan areas, including Los Angeles, Seattle, and New York.
lead_paragraph: A satellite that detects pollution linked to cars and trucks shows declines over major metropolitan areas, including Los Angeles, Seattle, and New York.

headline: As State Pleas Mount, Trump Outlines Some Federal Action; Senate Democrats Block Stimulus Package
abstract: New York State has 15,000 cases, roughly 5 percent of the pandemic’s growing global total. Senator Rand Paul tested positive for the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our live global coverage on the coronavirus epidemic here.

headline: Corrections: March 22, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 22, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 4 about the lack of diversity in Atlanta’s theater scene misspells the surname of the artistic director of the Out of Hand theater company. It is Ariel Fristoe, not Fristo.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Bridging 2 Continents Puts Strain on Canada’s ‘Astronaut Families’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 22, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “The husbands who live overseas in China are like migrating penguins who go to search for food for their families.”

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’ and ‘Pet Sematary’
abstract: The 10th season of Larry David’s comedy wraps up, while a Stephen King adaptation comes to Amazon and Hulu.
lead_paragraph: CURB YOUR ENTHUSIASM 10 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. Throughout the 10th season of this semi-autobiographical comedy series, Larry David — playing a fictionalized version of himself — has been preparing to open a coffee shop next door to another establishment just to tick off its owner. In this season finale, he welcomes patrons into his “spite store,” gets a second opinion on his knee injury and instigates a dispute between expectant parents.

headline: How the Virus Got Out
abstract: We analyzed the movements of hundreds of millions of people to show why the most extensive travel restrictions to stop an outbreak in human history haven’t been enough.
lead_paragraph: We analyzed the movements of hundreds of millions of people to show why the most extensive travel restrictions to stop an outbreak in human history haven’t been enough.

headline: ‘His Grandmother Asked About One Woman She Said She Had Liked.’
abstract: Discussing a “horrible” rock band, dreaming of a secret life and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: A Mustang Crisis Looms in the West
abstract: With too many animals on public lands and too many on the public’s hands, the federal wild horse management program is short of money and palatable solutions.
lead_paragraph: CHALLIS, Idaho — Dawn broke over the peaks of the Lost River Range, revealing a chase in the wide open valley below. Seven wild horses crashed through the sage, dark manes billowing in the golden light, pursued by a government contractor in a glossy helicopter that dodged left and right like a mechanical Border collie, driving the band forward into a hidden corral.

headline: A Boom Time for the Bean Industry
abstract: “It’s just shocking,” one bean supplier said. “I used to be the loneliest man at the farmer’s market.”
lead_paragraph: Tim McGreevy has worked in the bean business for more than 30 years. But when he scanned the bean aisles at a grocery store in Pullman, Wash., on Sunday, he saw something he had never seen before: empty shelves.

headline: Emily St. John Mandel Is Back, With a Ponzi Scheme Instead of a Pandemic
abstract: In her new novel, the author revisits some of the techniques she used in “Station Eleven.”
lead_paragraph: THE GLASS HOTELBy Emily St. John Mandel

headline: Help Wanted: Grocery Stores, Pizza Chains and Amazon Are Hiring
abstract: Surging demand for critical products has created an immediate need for more workers, forcing some companies to alter normal hiring practices.
lead_paragraph: The volume of food and paper products passing through a warehouse just outside Los Angeles is up 30 percent from the same time a year ago. Pizza deliveries are surging as people around the country hunker down.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $450,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Fee Waivers, Virtual Art Shows and Online Cooking Lessons
abstract: Some in the travel industry are stepping up with offers for everything from online yoga classes to storage space for displaced students.
lead_paragraph: With flights canceled around the world, and bars and restaurants shutting down as efforts to control coronavirus cases accelerate, some hotels, cultural institutions and car rental companies are extending a helping hand with efforts that range from community outreach to fee waivers. Others, including museums, are coming up with virtual offerings.

headline: Young Voters Know What They Want. But They Don’t See Anyone Offering It.
abstract: For the first time, millennials and Generation Z have enough electoral clout to seriously compete with their elders. But many feel more disillusioned than empowered.
lead_paragraph: The oldest of them were just out of college on 9/11; the youngest were not yet born. Over the two decades that followed, they all came of age under storm clouds: of war, of recession, of mass shootings, wildfires and now a pandemic.

headline: She Had to Choose: Her Epileptic Patient or Her 7-Year-Old Daughter
abstract: The fragile, low-paying existence of home health aides at the epicenter of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: When New York City closed its public schools, Cindy Urena, a home health aide for Sunnyside Community Services in Queens, faced a choice: stop seeing a client with severe epilepsy or leave her 7-year-old daughter alone at home.

headline: Deniers and Disbelievers: ‘If I Get Corona, I Get Corona.’
abstract: Many have ignored the urgent calls for social distancing. How much they are worsening the coronavirus outbreak may never be known.
lead_paragraph: NOVATO, Calif. — A climbing destination on the remote eastern side of the snow-capped Sierra Nevada, Bishop, Calif., was packed last weekend, as crowded as any holiday, despite growing calls for isolation in advance of a predicted wave of coronavirus cases.

headline: Coronavirus, Recession, Skijoring: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Week in Business: Throwing Billions at the Coronavirus
abstract: Will the government's plan to save the economy work?
lead_paragraph: Greetings, fellow stir-crazed humans. While you work your way through your frozen food supply, we’re here to help you parse what’s next in business, tech and the economy, which continues to be devastated by the coronavirus pandemic. Keep calm and wash your hands.

headline: New York Has Roughly 5% of Coronavirus Cases Worldwide
abstract: The increase in cases stems from both the rapid growth of the outbreak and significantly increased testing in the state.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Monday’s live coverage.]

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Mixed-Up Brothers of Bogotá’
abstract: How two sets of twins, scrambled at birth, had their lives changed in an instant.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Getting Pregnant Was a Challenge. Then the Coronavirus Happened.
abstract: Women across the U.S. are learning that their fertility procedures need to be postponed for an indefinite period of time.
lead_paragraph: After nearly two years of trying to have a baby, Karen Rzonca, 32, was hoping that this would be the month she finally got pregnant.

headline: A Podcast Playlist to Help Distract You (for the Most Part)
abstract: A crowdsourced selection of podcast episodes for this time, from the people who love them and make them.
lead_paragraph: As you shelter in place or take other measures to help stop the spread of the coronavirus, you may find yourself with silence to fill. And though podcasts are famously calibrated for a commuter’s journey, there are plenty out there to help pass the time and calm you at home, too.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Maybe this is the moment to experiment with fermentation: Get a sourdough starter going, for bread down the line, or consider making kombucha.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. There was fog on the harbor near my home the other morning, the cobblestones wet on the street before it, the sidewalks empty in four directions. The air smelled of spring on a working waterfront: salt and seaweed, fuel and tar. It was Walt Whitman stuff, though the poet didn’t write about scent when he crossed the river, and I felt a little joy amid the tremulous, untouchable nervousness of the current moment. I went inside and fed the sourdough starter. I observed the miracle of the kombucha (above). Life’s all around us. We need to celebrate it, every day.

headline: How America Can Avoid Italy’s Ventilator Crisis
abstract: I’m one of the doctors on the front lines of the war against this virus. You can help me fight.
lead_paragraph: Without swift action, parts of the United States will run out of ventilators in the coming weeks. Early signals from New York and Seattle are alarming: both cities are already reporting intensive care unit bed shortages and looming ventilator shortages, weeks before the estimated peak of the projected coronavirus caseload.

headline: Where Is God in a Pandemic?
abstract: The honest answer is: We don’t know. But even non-Christians may find understanding in the life of Jesus.
lead_paragraph: Last summer I underwent radiation treatment. And every time I passed through the doorway marked “Radiation Oncology,” my heart seemed to skip a beat. While I was in little danger (my tumor was benign, and, yes, one sometimes needs radiation for that), I daily met people who were close to death.

headline: As U.S. Troops Leave Afghanistan, Diplomats Are Left to Fill Uncertain Mission
abstract: The future role of the American Embassy in Kabul is tied to the fate of the peace process and a military withdrawal, even as violence continues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was once a sideshow to the American military in Afghanistan and later became one of the largest diplomatic missions in the world. Now, as the United States Embassy in Kabul transitions to its newest role, its future is tied to a fragile peace process, one that will withdraw American troops even as violence continues.

headline: Geese May Not Inspire You, but They Certainly Take Your Mind Off the Virus
abstract: Watching birds that do not practice social distancing is a nice break from washing your hands and disinfecting friends.
lead_paragraph: Watch birds. Geese if you’ve got them.

headline: Eli Miller, a Sultan of Seltzer, Is Dead at 86
abstract: He began delivering sparkling water in 1960, when hundreds of seltzer men plied the streets. He continued until 2017, when there were almost none.
lead_paragraph: Long before sparkling water with brand names like Polar, Perrier and La Croix crowded bodega refrigerators and apartment dwellers used household carbonators to bottle bubbling beverages themselves, New Yorkers relied on seltzer men to deliver refreshment in clanking glass bottles.

headline: Target Apologizes for Selling N95 Masks in Seattle
abstract: The company said the masks were offered for sale “in error” at some stores in Washington State, which has been a hot spot for the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The retailer Target apologized on Saturday after coming under criticism for selling N95 masks, which are in acute demand by medical providers during the coronavirus pandemic, at some stores in Washington State.

headline: Weddings, Funerals and Life in Dire Times
abstract: Readers offer their stories of coping: the county jail as a wedding venue, a father mourning from the safety of a car, remote piano lessons and more.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday we ran a sampling of letters we received when we asked readers how they were dealing with the disruption in their lives. Below are several more responses.

headline: I Lost My Son. Support L.G.B.T.Q. Youth.
abstract: Jane Clementi, the mother of Tyler Clementi, discusses anti-transgender rights bills in state legislatures. Also: Stacking the federal courts.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The U.S. Shut Down Its Economy. Here’s What Needs to Happen in Order to Restart.
abstract: Whole sectors of the United States economy have gone dark to slow the spread of the coronavirus. Here’s what comes next.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American economy has stopped working.

headline: Warmer Weather May Slow, but Not Halt, Coronavirus
abstract: Nature may help diminish the pandemic if aggressive measures to control the spread of infections continue, experts say. That doesn’t mean the virus won’t return.
lead_paragraph: Communities living in warmer places appear to have a comparative advantage to slow the transmission of coronavirus infections, according to an early analysis by scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

headline: Germany Bans Groups of More Than 2 to Stop Coronavirus as Merkel Self-Isolates
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel went into isolation after learning that her doctor had tested positive.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany on Sunday barred groups of more than two people from gathering, except for families, and Chancellor Angela Merkel later said she herself was going into isolation because her doctor had tested positive for the coronavirus.

headline: Plácido Domingo Says He Has the Coronavirus
abstract: “I beg everyone to be extremely careful,” the opera singer said in a Facebook post on Sunday after developing a fever and cough and testing positive for the virus.
lead_paragraph: The opera star Plácido Domingo disclosed on Sunday that he tested positive for the coronavirus.

headline: A Plan to Get America Back to Work
abstract: Some experts say it can be done in weeks, not months — and the economy and public health are at stake.
lead_paragraph: These are days that test every leader — local, state and national. They are each being asked to make huge life and death decisions, while driving through a fog, with imperfect information, and everyone in the back seat shouting at them. My heart goes out to them all. I know they mean well. But as so many of our businesses shut down and millions begin to be laid off, some experts are beginning to ask: “Wait a minute! What the hell are we doing to ourselves? To our economy? To our next generation? Is this cure — even for a short while — worse than the disease?’’

headline: In Seattle, It Started With Panic. Then the Deeper Anxiety Set In.
abstract: In a state that until recently had seen more deaths from the coronavirus than any other, the stress has started to multiply. Jobs lost. Kids underfoot. Parents at risk. “It’s exhausting,” one woman said.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Shannon Koyano is a 39-year-old single mother living, nervously, in the place where the coronavirus got its first deadly foothold in America.

headline: Some Tips on How to Stay Sane in a World That Isn’t
abstract: The coronavirus outbreak has magnified all kinds of fears. Try living in the moment. Take stock of what’s working. Turn off the television.
lead_paragraph: Erasing anxiety from daily life isn’t an option for most people today. But therapists, clergy and meditation specialists say there are simple and accessible ways to overcome debilitating panic.

headline: Coronavirus Drives the U.S. and China Deeper Into Global Power Struggle
abstract: Many experts warn that an international health and economic crisis calls for more cooperation, not confrontation, between Washington and Beijing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump took the podium at the White House briefing room one afternoon last week, his prepared remarks included a reference to the “corona virus.” But a close-up photograph revealed that Mr. Trump had used one of his signature Sharpies to cross out the word “corona,” changing the phrase to “Chinese virus.”

headline: Daniel S. Greenberg, Science Journalist and Iconoclast, Dies at 88
abstract: He challenged peers who acted as “cheerleaders” for science, and influenced government science policy with a Washington-based newsletter.
lead_paragraph: Daniel S. Greenberg, a writer and editor who broke ground in science journalism by reporting on the research enterprise not with reverence but with journalistic rigor, died on March 9 at his home in Washington. He was 88.

headline: Canada Withdraws From Summer Olympics as I.O.C. Weighs Postponement
abstract: Faced with growing frustration from athletes and some national committees, the International Olympic Committee said it would decide within four weeks on the Tokyo Games.
lead_paragraph: The International Olympic Committee, faced with mounting pressure to postpone the Summer Olympics in Tokyo, said on Sunday that it would decide within four weeks whether to delay or scale down the Games.

headline: Trump Didn’t Know People Could Die From the Flu. His Grandfather Did.
abstract: What Frederick Trump’s death, in 1918, tells us about the costs of mismanaging a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: In May 1918, a German immigrant businessman, husband and father of three in Queens took his last breaths. At the time, no one really knew why he was dying.

headline: I Just Called to Say … the Phone Call Is Back
abstract: The warm timbre of a human voice in your ear is more real, more present, than text on a screen. We need that now.
lead_paragraph: The other night my friend Margot called. It’s not unusual for me to hear from Margot — we’ve been friends for more than 30 years, email frequently, have dinner every month or two, and I stay over at her house whenever I’m in town. But Margot never calls. Practically no one does; my few surviving telephonic friendships antedate the internet. But Margot has a cold, and because her husband is immunocompromised, she’d had to quarantine herself in their guest room; she was, in effect, the invalid mother confined to her room upstairs in some Victorian novel. She’d been just about to email me when she thought, why would I email? and picked up the phone.

headline: We Made Copies of Ventilator Parts to Help Hospitals Fight Coronavirus
abstract: Even in a quarantine, innovation can help.
lead_paragraph: BRESCIA, Italy — Our small city has been on lockdown for nearly two weeks. The streets are silent. Many factories are closed. The only people allowed outside are those walking their dogs, heading to the grocery store or those who have permission from the government. A few of our friends are hospitalized from the coronavirus, with many more in quarantine at home. Hundreds of people have died here.

headline: José Andrés: We Have a Food Crisis Unfolding Out of Sight
abstract: America has fed millions through disasters before. Mobilize restaurant workers now.
lead_paragraph: Writing in the middle of two devastating cholera pandemics in the early 1800s, the great French culinary thinker Brillat-Savarin articulated a truth we urgently need to grasp today: “The destiny of nations depends on how they feed themselves.”

headline: ‘This is Not Life as Usual’: Cuomo Calls on New Yorkers to Abide Isolation
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York said on Sunday that cases of the coronavirus in the state had reached 15,168, and called on New Yorkers to stop ignoring social distancing.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York said on Sunday that cases of the coronavirus in the state had reached 15,168, and called on New Yorkers to stop ignoring social distancing.

headline: Coronavirus, Angela Merkel, North Korea: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Would Having the Tokyo Games Even Be Fair to the Athletes?
abstract: For anyone losing training time, “you can’t even imagine competing in August at the Olympics,” Gregorio Paltrinieri of Italy said.
lead_paragraph: Gregorio Paltrinieri of Italy stood on the starting blocks, took his mark and knifed into the pool. Three times he hit the water, racing the 400-meter, 800-meter and 1,500-meter freestyles. But the scene at his 25-meter training facility last week in Ostia, a coastal suburb of Rome, proved a poor substitute for what he would have experienced if the Italian Olympic trials had been held, as planned, in a 50-meter facility in Riccione.

headline: Emergency Economic Rescue Plan in Limbo as Democrats Block Action
abstract: Democrats voted against moving forward on a plan expected to cost $1.8 trillion or more, seeking stronger protections for workers and stricter rules for bailed-out businesses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats on Sunday blocked action on an emerging deal to prop up an economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, paralyzing the progress of a nearly $2 trillion government rescue package they said failed to adequately protect workers or impose strict enough restrictions on bailed-out businesses.

headline: Lorenzo Sanz, Who Led Comeback of Real Madrid, Dies at 76
abstract: He helped the soccer club win its first European Cup in 32 years. He is the most prominent Spaniard to die of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: What to Do if You or a Loved One Might Have the Coronavirus
abstract: A vast majority of those infected with the coronavirus will develop only mild to moderate symptoms. But many people remain frightened and wonder how and when to seek medical care.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus spreads around the globe, the reality is that many of us will probably get it at some point. Fortunately, a vast majority of people will develop only mild to moderate symptoms that will not require hospitalization.

headline: In a Pandemic, Religion Can Be a Balm and a Risk
abstract: As scientists and politicians struggle for a response to the coronavirus, many people are turning to faith. But some practices raise public health concerns.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Down on earth, the coronavirus outbreak was felling lives, livelihoods and normalcy. A nation-spanning blessing seemed called for. So up went a priest in a small airplane, rumbling overhead at an epidemiologically safe distance from the troubles below, wielding a sacred golden vessel from a cockpit-turned-pulpit.

headline: She Was More Than a Statistic in a Pandemic: ‘We Didn’t Want Her to Get Lost’
abstract: Loretta Mendoza Dionisio, outgoing and unstoppable, died of the coronavirus, a statistic in a growing U.S. count. But her life meant much more.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 23, 2020
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Students

headline: For Children Fleeing War, a Tent Becomes a School
abstract: In northwestern Syria, children forced from their homes cannot remember a normal life. Volunteer teachers are trying to give them one.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The camp school is only a tent — cold and cramped, its floor covered by a rug whose intricate pattern is hard to make out under the crowd of kneeling students. The walls are plastic sheets. There are no desks, no chairs, no toilet, hardly any books.

headline: African Animal That Charges
abstract: Ed Sessa reminds us that we are one.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Are you still with me? We’re going to get through this, you and I.Here are five things I’m doing to stay sane, and please feel free to join in:

headline: The Virus Can Be Stopped, but Only With Harsh Steps, Experts Say
abstract: Scientists who have fought pandemics describe difficult measures needed to defend the United States against a fast-moving pathogen.
lead_paragraph: Terrifying though the coronavirus may be, it can be turned back. China, South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan have demonstrated that, with furious efforts, the contagion can be brought to heel.

headline: New York City Region Is Now an Epicenter of the Coronavirus Pandemic
abstract: The city and its suburbs account for roughly 5 percent of global cases, forcing officials to take urgent steps to stem the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks after its first coronavirus infection was discovered, the New York City region reached an alarming milestone on Sunday: It now accounts for roughly 5 percent of the world’s confirmed cases, making it an epicenter of the pandemic and increasing pressure on officials to take more drastic measures.

headline: Lost Sense of Smell May Be Peculiar Clue to Coronavirus Infection
abstract: Doctor groups are recommending testing and isolation for people who lose their ability to smell and taste, even if they have no other symptoms.
lead_paragraph: A mother who was infected with the coronavirus couldn’t smell her baby’s full diaper. Cooks who can usually name every spice in a restaurant dish can’t smell curry or garlic, and food tastes bland. Others say they can’t pick up the sweet scent of shampoo or the foul odor of kitty litter.

headline: With Live Sports Gone, Announcer Offers Play by Play of the Everyday
abstract: Nick Heath narrates his videos of people doing mundane things, like crossing the street, with the verve and dramatic flair of competitive sports.
lead_paragraph: The narration begins customarily, with the play-by-play announcer enthusiastically welcoming his audience live to a competition unfolding on the screen.

headline: Rand Paul Tests Positive for Covid-19, Fueling Anxiety in the Capitol
abstract: The Kentucky Republican is the first senator to be diagnosed with the novel coronavirus. He went about his routine for days after being tested, potentially exposing many colleagues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans were struggling to salvage a more than $1 trillion economic rescue package to respond to the coronavirus crisis when they got the message on Sunday afternoon: One of their own had been walking around the Capitol with Covid-19 for days as they debated how best to confront the rapidly spreading pandemic.

headline: ‘Wartime President’? Trump Rewrites History in an Election Year
abstract: The president is brazenly grabbing his only clear option to bolster his re-election hopes, portraying himself as a take-charge leader the country can’t afford to lose.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the economy faltering and the political landscape unsettled as the coronavirus death toll climbs, a stark and unavoidable question now confronts President Trump and his advisers: Can he save his campaign for re-election when so much is suddenly going so wrong?

headline: Prison Riots in Colombia Over Virus Fears Leave at Least 23 Dead
abstract: The deaths followed countrywide prison protests in which inmates said authorities were not doing enough to control coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — At least 23 inmates died in clashes with prison authorities over the weekend after what prisoners described as protests against officials for not doing enough to control the spread of coronavirus.

headline: Fed Could Bolster Groups of Businesses and Localities With Funds in G.O.P. Bill
abstract: Republican senators want to create $425 billion in funding to back Fed emergency lending.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans have proposed giving the Federal Reserve access to $425 billion in funding that it could use to extend emergency support to flailing businesses or struggling localities — an approach that would keep central bankers at the center of the coronavirus economic response in ways that could prove politically fraught.

headline: Citing Threat to Israeli Democracy, Netanyahu Opponents Take Battle to Supreme Court
abstract: Critics accuse Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of a “coup d’état” under the cover of the coronavirus. He says he is saving lives.
lead_paragraph: Citing a threat to Israeli democracy, opponents of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu asked the Supreme Court on Sunday to block what they described as a power grab by the caretaker government under the guise of combating the coronavirus epidemic.

headline: ‘Covid-19 Kills Only Old People.’ Only?
abstract: Why are we OK with old people dying?
lead_paragraph: “Not just old people: Younger adults are also getting the coronavirus,” a news network declared on its website last week. The words seemed to suggest that Covid-19 didn’t matter much if it was a scourge only among the old.

headline: Rupert Murdoch Put His Son in Charge of Fox. It Was a Dangerous Mistake.
abstract: The 48-year-old Lachlan Murdoch stood by as Fox News hosts played down the danger of the deadly coronavirus to their viewers.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Fox News, Suzanne Scott, reacted swiftly to the threat of the coronavirus in late February: She ordered the bright, open new offices disinfected, installed hand sanitizer stations around the office and boldly canceled the company’s major ad sales event.

headline: U.S. Stock Futures Sink as Washington Struggles Over Rescue Plan
abstract: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline: This Stimulus Bill Will Not Save the Economy From Collapse
abstract: Let’s not repeat the slow and timid response to the financial crash of 1929.
lead_paragraph: When the stock market crashed in 1929, the Dow plummeted from its September peak of 381.17 to a low of 41.22 in July 1932. Because so few Americans owned stocks, it took three years for the financial collapse to cycle though the rest of the economy. Unemployment only gradually increased, to a peak of about 25 percent in early 1933. Gross domestic product fell steadily, ultimately declining by about 30 percent.

headline: Police Tread Lightly as Pandemic Spreads
abstract: Facing sweeping new safety orders, a frightened public and health risks of close contact, many police departments have decided that, for now, less is more.
lead_paragraph: If you have a fender bender in Nashville these days, chances are you’ll be filing your report by phone. In Philadelphia, the police are trying not to take drug dealers to jail. In Hilton Head, S.C., the authorities have seemed particularly focused on one offense: gathering and drinking on the beach.

headline: Trump Bets Business Will Answer Call to Fight Virus, but Strategy Bewilders Firms
abstract: It remains unclear if the effort to enlist companies like General Motors, Apple and Hanes constitutes an effective strategy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s refusal to invoke the Defense Production Act to commandeer resources for the federal government is based on a bet that he can cajole the nation’s biggest manufacturers and tech firms to come together in a market-driven, if chaotic, consortium that will deliver critical equipment — from masks to ventilators — in time to abate a national crisis.

headline: How Trump Is Worsening the Virus Now
abstract: Medical shortages are his responsibility.
lead_paragraph: At a private New York meeting in October of 1940, William Knudsen made a desperate plea to the automobile industry’s top executives. Knudsen himself had been the president of General Motors until a few months earlier. But he had stepped down to help oversee military production at President Franklin Roosevelt’s request. The position paid $1 a year.

headline: ‘Brace Yourself’: How Doctors in Italy Responded to Coronavirus
abstract: Officials in the U.S. and elsewhere fear they’ll face a coronavirus scenario similar to Italy’s soon. Three doctors and a nurse in Lombardy, the region hit hardest by the virus, described what they faced and offered advice to those awaiting the storm.
lead_paragraph: Officials in the U.S. and elsewhere fear they’ll face a coronavirus scenario similar to Italy’s soon. Three doctors and a nurse in Lombardy, the region hit hardest by the virus, described what they faced and offered advice to those awaiting the storm.

headline: Coronavirus Has Opened the Corporate Email Floodgates
abstract: The email deluge raises questions about marketing practices as nonessential businesses closed shops and storefronts amid the spread of the new coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it was that one store where you shopped while on vacation a few years ago, or perhaps that online service that you used just last week, but it’s all the same message: Businesses have flooded everyone on their email lists with coronavirus updates, tips on staying healthy and words of encouragement — much to people’s dismay.

headline: ‘Westworld’ Season 3, Episode 2 Recap: A Band of Thugs
abstract: Maeve wakes up confused. And able to speak Italian.
lead_paragraph: One of the funniest running jokes in “Westworld” — check that, maybe the only running joke in “Westworld” — is that the hosts are virtually indistinguishable from the guests, and yet the scripted loops in the park are Z-grade genre television. The show hasn’t had the opportunity to return to that joke much recently, save for a version of the saloon heist that played out in Shogun World, but the opening of this week’s episode is clever opportunity to stick a fully woke host in a chintzy, down-the-dial World War II spy thriller.

headline: Danai Gurira Was ‘Amazed’ by Sunday’s ‘The Walking Dead’
abstract: The actress, who stars as Michonne on the zombie thriller, discussed this week’s episode and the future of her character.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for Sunday night’s episode of “The Walking Dead.”

headline: Biden Addresses a Visibility Question: ‘How Do We Get More of You?’
abstract: As President Trump appears at daily briefings, the Democratic front-runner faces the challenge of raising his profile in a presidential race that has moved almost entirely into the digital realm.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., the likely Democratic nominee against President Trump in this year’s general election, was asked a question during a virtual fund-raiser on Sunday that reflected a challenge looming over his campaign as the coronavirus outbreak intensifies.

headline: Scientists Identify 69 Drugs to Test Against the Coronavirus
abstract: Two dozen of the medicines are already under investigation. Also on the list: chloroquine, a drug used to treat malaria.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 70 drugs and experimental compounds may be effective in treating the coronavirus, a team of researchers reported on Sunday night.

headline: As I.O.C. Deliberates, Track and Field Athletes Want Summer Olympics Postponed
abstract: The I.O.C. said it would spend the next month examining whether to postpone the Tokyo Games. Nearly 80 percent of track and field athletes say to do it now.
lead_paragraph: In recent days, as leaders of the International Olympic Committee went back and forth with organizers of the Tokyo Games, sponsors, media partners and leaders of international sports federations over whether to postpone the Summer Olympics because of the coronavirus pandemic, athletes around the world tried to jump into a debate they say they have had little role in.

headline: Grim News Blunts Federal Reserve’s Crisis Response
abstract: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline: 158 Million Americans Told to Stay Home, but Trump Pledges to Keep It Short
abstract: The White House warned of an alarming spread in New York City, but the president said “our country wasn’t built to be shut down.”
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. You can find the latest coronavirus news here.

headline: No Corrections: March 23, 2020
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 23, 2020.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 23, 2020.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Suddenly, the Lowly Bean Is a Coveted Pantry Item
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 23, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “No one ever cares about beans at all. It’s just shocking. I used to be the loneliest man at the farmer’s market.”

headline: Coronavirus, Italy, Olympics: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Freud’ and ‘Crumb’
abstract: Sigmund Freud is a crime fighter in the new series on Netflix. And a documentary about Robert Crumb by Terry Zwigoff arrives on the Criterion Channel.
lead_paragraph: FREUD Stream on Netflix. There is plenty of dramatic material to be found in the life story of Sigmund Freud. He successfully pioneered the theory and practice of psychoanalysis despite widespread resistance from his colleagues in the medical community and pervasive anti-Semitic prejudice. He escaped the Nazis after Austria was annexed by Germany. And he battled cancer for the last decades of his life. But in this new German-language series from Marvin Kren, fiction supplements fact: The young Freud, played by Robert Finster, is an ambitious doctor drawn into a murder investigation alongside a psychic (Ella Rumpf) and a police inspector (Georg Friedrich).

headline: Pompeo Cuts $1 Billion in Afghan Aid as 2 Leaders Reject Push for Unity
abstract: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo failed to persuade rival Afghan leaders to support a unified government, which American diplomats consider crucial to preventing peace negotiations from falling apart.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The State Department said it was cutting $1 billion in aid to Afghanistan this year, and potentially another $1 billion in 2021, after Secretary of State Mike Pompeo failed to persuade rival Afghan leaders in a meeting on Monday in Kabul to support a unified government, which American diplomats consider crucial to preventing peace negotiations from falling apart.

headline: Word + Quiz: quid pro quo
abstract: This term has appeared in 376 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Food, a Basic Pleasure, Is Suddenly Fraught’
abstract: In this lesson, you will consider how this crisis has affected food and food rituals for people, families and communities, then consider practical things you can do to help.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Food, a Basic Pleasure, Is Suddenly Fraught,” by Kim Severson and Julia Moskin

headline: ‘Mitch, Please!’ Tours Kentucky and Roasts a Senator
abstract: Matt Jones drove through each of his state’s 120 counties to understand why Mitch McConnell polls so poorly there yet is serving his sixth full term in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: In times of national crisis, it’s important to put past differences behind us. On the other hand, here’s a new book that trolls Mitch McConnell for 500 pages. Can’t a person have a look?

headline: The Great Empty
abstract: There is a certain beauty in the expanses of public space, now vacant amid the pandemic, these photos from around the world show. There is also a reminder: True beauty comes when the builders roam the built.
lead_paragraph: There is a certain beauty in the expanses of public space, now vacant amid the pandemic, these photos from around the world show. There is also a reminder: True beauty comes when the builders roam the built.

headline: Werner Herzog Has Never Thought a Dog Was Cute
abstract: “I would assign a dog a different word.”
lead_paragraph: “I would assign a dog a different word.”

headline: What Are You Reading, Watching, Listening To, Playing and Cooking? A Place for Recommendations
abstract: What’s helping right now? What can you recommend to other teenagers?
lead_paragraph: What’s working for you right now? Have you been able to distract yourself with a movie? Find wisdom in a book? Lose yourself playing a game? Learn — or laugh — thanks to a podcast? Have fun at a digital gathering? Whether you have one idea or many, tell us in the comments.

headline: Heartburn Drugs Tied to Bone Fractures in Children
abstract: Proton pump inhibitors are sometimes needed in children with reflux, but parents should be aware they may increase the risk of fractures.
lead_paragraph: Proton pump inhibitors — the widely used heartburn drugs — may slightly increase the risk for bone fractures in children, a new study suggests.

headline: How Has Your State Reacted to Social Distancing?
abstract: Much of the country has ground to a halt. But not all of it.
lead_paragraph: Much of the country has ground to a halt. But not all of it.

headline: I’m 26. Coronavirus Sent Me to the Hospital.
abstract: Millennials: If you can’t stay at home for others, do it for yourselves.
lead_paragraph: I’m 26. I don’t have any prior autoimmune or respiratory conditions. I work out six times a week, and abstain from cigarettes. I thought my role in the current health crisis would be as an ally to the elderly and compromised. Then, I was hospitalized for Covid-19.

headline: Take Steps to Counter the Loneliness of Social Distancing
abstract: Attempts to avoid coronavirus can increase the risk of physical and emotional harm from limited social contact.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, when Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, the former surgeon general of the United States, started researching his book, “Together: The Healing Power of Human Connection in a Sometimes Lonely World,” he never anticipated how relevant the topic would be now that it is about to be published.

headline: What 9/11 Taught Us About Leadership in a Crisis
abstract: Sept. 11 changed how U.S. Special Forces operated — and offers lessons for today’s leaders.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 11, 2001, the job of every leader in the U.S. Special Operations community changed. In the ensuing years of fighting a highly complex, networked enemy, we redesigned how our organization communicated, shared information, made decisions and, most critically, maintained a cohesive culture while operating in almost every corner of the globe.

headline: From White Gloves to Latex, the Doormen of New York
abstract: Intercepting extra deliveries, swabbing the elevator buttons with Lysol and soothing the nervous rich.
lead_paragraph: They are the white-gloved sentries, standing guard at New York City’s better addresses, so signature a feature of life here that we tend to forget that in other metropolitan centers like Paris, London, Chicago or Boston uniformed doormen (and, less often, women) barely exist.

headline: They Don’t Hide From the Coronavirus, They Confront It
abstract: Millions of health care workers are running to where they are needed, sometimes risking their lives.
lead_paragraph: “I’m having flashbacks to the Boston Marathon bombing,” my daughter said.

headline: Reporting From a Center of the Coronavirus Outbreak
abstract: Mike Baker is the Seattle bureau chief for The Times. We asked him what it’s like reporting from the state with one of the deadliest caseloads in America.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: The Beautiful World Beside the Broken One
abstract: Nature is wide open for business. Here is the alternate world we need right now.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — A two-week bout with flu turned me into a person I didn’t recognize — a hopeless, coughing, exhausted person. I lay in bed, phone in hand, skipping from news outlet to news outlet: refreshing, clicking, scrolling, scrolling, scrolling. The news was always bad, every update worse than the one before.

headline: It’s a Perfect Time to Play Video Games. And You Shouldn’t Feel Bad About It.
abstract: The longer the coronavirus keeps social life and culture in isolation, the more we’ll need frivolity and escapism.
lead_paragraph: The last time I was unemployed was in the depths of the Great Recession. I had recently moved in with my girlfriend, who suddenly found herself with an out-of-work partner who rarely left the house. But she gave me some surprising advice: Play video games.

headline: ‘I Will Not Apologize for My Needs’
abstract: Even in a crisis, doctors should not abandon the principle of nondiscrimination.
lead_paragraph: Times of crisis ask us who we are as a country. As hospitals prepare for shortages in ventilators and other scarce medical resources, many people with disabilities are worried about the answer to that question.

headline: The U.S. Needs China’s Masks, as Acrimony Grows
abstract: Beijing has signaled a willingness to supply the U.S. as its outbreak spreads. Increasingly harsh language and logistical issues could make it difficult to reach deals.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — American front-line medical personnel are running desperately short of masks and protective equipment as they battle the coronavirus outbreak. China, already the world’s largest producer of such gear by far, has ramped up factory output and is now signaling that it wants to help.

headline: Spit On, Yelled At, Attacked: Chinese-Americans Fear for Their Safety
abstract: As bigots blame them for the coronavirus and President Trump labels it the “Chinese virus,” many Chinese-Americans say they are terrified of what could come next.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Yuanyuan Zhu was walking to her gym in San Francisco on March 9, thinking the workout could be her last for a while, when she noticed that a man was shouting at her. He was yelling an expletive about China. Then a bus passed, she recalled, and he screamed after it, “Run them over.”

headline: Will Our Economy Die From Coronavirus?
abstract: It will if we keep up our current strategy.
lead_paragraph: Covid-19, the most threatening pandemic of the past century, has precipitated both a health crisis and an economic crisis. The strategies that governments have adopted to deal with each crisis separately are contradictory and risk catastrophic, long-term failure.

headline: As Coronavirus Surveillance Escalates, Personal Privacy Plummets
abstract: Tracking entire populations to combat the pandemic now could open the doors to more invasive forms of government snooping later.
lead_paragraph: In South Korea, government agencies are harnessing surveillance-camera footage, smartphone location data and credit card purchase records to help trace the recent movements of coronavirus patients and establish virus transmission chains.

headline: Shopping for Dining Chairs
abstract: With so many of us working at the dining table these days, our chairs need to be multifunctional. Here’s how to choose the right ones.
lead_paragraph: With more people spending more time at home these days, dining chairs are getting a workout — as seating for meals, but also as improvised places to sit while working or home schooling.

headline: Small Businesses Seek a Crisis Lifeline Beyond Loans
abstract: Many owners fear taking on debt they are not sure they can repay and are looking to the federal government for more than low-interest disaster loans.
lead_paragraph: [Read our Coronavirus Relief Small Business F.A.Q.]

headline: The Search for E.T. Goes on Hold, for Now
abstract: A popular screen saver takes a break while its inventors try to digest data that may yet be hiding news of extraterrestrials.
lead_paragraph: One of the great science fiction fantasies of all time — that you might discover aliens texting you from outer space on your computer — is about to take a breather.

headline: The Plastic-Hunting Pirates of the Cornish Coast
abstract: The Clean Ocean Sailing initiative removes plastic waste from areas of England’s coastline that are inaccessible by foot.
lead_paragraph: The Cornish coast — with its high cliffs and inlets, lining the peninsula that juts out from England’s southwest corner — has a long association with pirates. Its rocky coves, secret anchorages and long winding creeks have historically been a haunting ground for seafaring scoundrels and salty sea dogs.

headline: Logged On From the Laundry Room: How the C.E.O.s of Google, Pfizer and Slack Work From Home
abstract: As chief executives hunker down during the pandemic, home offices have become corporate headquarters.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday morning, Chuck Robbins, the chief executive of Cisco, signed on to an companywide video conference from his home office in Silicon Valley. The connection was stable, but the quality was not great.

headline: Coronavirus, Senate, Summer Olympics: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: How Much Do You Know About the United Kingdom?
abstract: Can you find the United Kingdom on a map? What else do you know about this European nation with a population of about 67 million people?
lead_paragraph: Can you find the United Kingdom on a map? What else do you know about this European nation with a population of about 67 million people?

headline: A Surge in N.Y.C. Coronavirus Cases
abstract: Increased testing is revealing how quickly the coronavirus has spread in the state.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: The Pandemic and the Primary
abstract: How the coronavirus has changed the stakes of the presidential race — and created a crisis candidate.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: On Politics: Where’s the Relief?
abstract: Senate wrangling and presidential promises: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: A medical official at the White House took the temperature of a member of the news media in the White House briefing room on Sunday.

headline: Coronavirus ‘Attack Rate’ in N.Y. Concerns White House
abstract: The New York City region is now an epicenter of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Tuesday’s live coverage.]

headline: What Will Fill a $4 Trillion Hole in the Economy?
abstract: In an echo of 2008, partisan wrangling caused a giant stimulus bill to stumble, even as the market plunged and businesses buckled.
lead_paragraph: If you couldn’t join us on Friday for our special conference call about the business and policy implications of the coronavirus pandemic, the recording is here. The response was enormous — more than 4,000 of you signed up to participate — so we couldn’t get to all of the questions. What should we cover in future calls? Let us know. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

headline: ‘Our Industry Will Fail’: Retail Leaders Ask for Emergency Aid
abstract: Predicting millions of job losses in retail, an industry presses for federal money to save the retail clothing industries.
lead_paragraph: Over the past five days, executives from the largest American clothing brands and department stores have been engaged in urgent late-night phone calls and marathon video conferences in which they game out scenarios for their future in a world with a coronavirus pandemic.

headline: SoftBank Says It Will Sell $41 Billion in Assets to Buy Back Shares
abstract: The Japanese conglomerate has bet heavily on companies that are likely to take a significant financial hit from the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — SoftBank, operator of the world’s largest tech fund, said on Monday that it would sell as much as $41 billion in assets as it seeks to vacuum up its own shares, which have dropped precipitously in the last month amid investor concerns about the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Trump Says Coronavirus Cure Cannot ‘Be Worse Than the Problem Itself’
abstract: The president, who has watched the economy plunge amid social distancing measures, says restrictions will be reassessed.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Sunday night said that the government would reassess the recommended period for keeping businesses shut and millions of workers at home after this week, amid millions of job losses caused by the efforts to contain the spread of the novel coronavirus.

headline: 9 Delightful Articles to Help You Get Through This Week
abstract: We’re all just trying to do our best now. These articles might help a little.
lead_paragraph: What a year this month has been.

headline: The Fed Goes All In With Unlimited Bond-Buying Plan
abstract: The Federal Reserve will buy bonds as needed to calm markets, and will buy corporate debt in a series of emergency lending programs.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve, determined to try to keep the spread of the coronavirus from devastating the American economy, rolled out a series of sweeping new programs on Monday meant to shore up large and small businesses and keep markets functioning.

headline: Coronavirus Complicates Home Buying and Mortgage Refinancing
abstract: As county records office around the country shutdown, title searches and deed filings will grind to a halt.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus has snarled many spring home-buying plans, as apartment buildings ban open houses, real estate agents shutter brokerages and quarantines make it tough to even step outside.

headline: After the Fire, a Chinatown Museum Sifts Through What Survived
abstract: Families are celebrating hundreds of boxes of heirlooms that were unloaded from the scorched interior of 70 Mulberry Street.
lead_paragraph: When a fire ripped through the upper floors of the red brick building that held the archives of the Museum of Chinese in America, the staff thought that all was lost.

headline: The Medical ID Bracelet That Doesn’t Look Like One
abstract: An ID can be crucial in a medical crisis, and it doesn’t have to be something you want to hide.
lead_paragraph: In times of uncertainty, people turn to many places for peace of mind: cooking, exercising, reading the news, multiperson video chats and other virtual gatherings, fresh air. When that uncertainty stems from a global pandemic, the actions we take to protect our bodies and minds may also include washing our hands, social distancing and working from home.

headline: PG&E Will Plead Guilty to Involuntary Manslaughter in Camp Fire
abstract: The California utility faced felony charges in connection with a 2018 wildfire that killed more than 80 people.
lead_paragraph: Pacific Gas & Electric, California’s largest utility, said Monday that it had agreed to plead guilty to involuntary manslaughter in connection with the Camp Fire, the state’s deadliest wildfire.

headline: What You Get for $1 Million in California
abstract: A bungalow with a guesthouse and converted garage in San Luis Obispo, a grand Victorian in Sacramento and an Edwardian home in Berkeley.
lead_paragraph: A bungalow with a guesthouse and converted garage in San Luis Obispo, a grand Victorian in Sacramento and an Edwardian home in Berkeley.

headline: $1 Million Homes in California
abstract: A bungalow with a guesthouse and converted garage in San Luis Obispo, a grand Victorian in Sacramento and an Edwardian home in Berkeley.
lead_paragraph: When the owner, an architectural and interior designer, bought this house in 2014, it was a bare-bones 1930s bungalow with a small detached garage. In the last five years, he completely transformed the property, adding a brand-new lofted studio behind the house and turning the garage into an indoor-outdoor dining room.

headline: What Counts as an ‘Essential Business’ in California?
abstract: Monday: Californians are navigating a new reality and finding that “stay at home” isn’t a black-and-white order.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: As Postal Workers Fall Sick, Colleagues Keep Working. And Worrying.
abstract: The coronavirus has affected about two dozen Postal Service workers around the country, and fear of a greater outbreak grows.
lead_paragraph: Chris Jackson was halfway through his overnight shift sorting the mail for delivery when he and several colleagues were summoned into a windowless conference room.

headline: Throw Away One Worry This Week
abstract: We have enough on our plates right now.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday I opened my cupboard and stared at a pair of garish, orange plastic cups. I use these cups to serve my children milk, and as recently as last week, I would look at them and think: I really should throw these out. I don’t even remember where they came from, and they’re probably leeching all sorts of unpronounceable toxins into my kids’ bloodstreams every time they take a sip — which I know from our own coverage of plastics!

headline: We Need a Unified Military Command for Disaster Response
abstract: The pandemic is only one of many potential disasters that will require unity of action among the armed services.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has finally called in the military in the nation’s war against the coronavirus. But precious time was lost in the weeks since he was warned about the dangers the virus poses. We need to make sure that doesn’t happen again.

headline: Cook With Confidence
abstract: You don’t have to have all the ingredients to follow a recipe, or to make a great meal. Make the recipe your own.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Took a drive with a kid and a dog on Sunday morning, out to where the people drop away and the oystercatchers skim the shoreline, to where it’s quiet but for wind through the spartina, and the slap of the bay against the peat. We walked in companionable silence. I thought about how you’re doing, cooking every day for the first time in ages if ever, and running into recipes that may call for things like escarole and preserved lemons, crème fraîche, maple syrup, Champagne vinegar. Maybe you don’t have those ingredients. Maybe that freaks you out.

headline: Covid-19’s Economic Pain Is Universal. But Relief? Depends on Where You Live
abstract: In some countries, workers will have 90 percent of lost wages covered. In others, residents fear eviction. Nation to nation, rescue plans reflect conflicting ideas of government’s role in a crisis.
lead_paragraph: In a Queens apartment, a laid-off busboy has no idea if he will make next month’s rent or feed his family. An out-of-work waitress in Amsterdam, though, can count on the government to cover 90 percent of her wages. As a Malaysian florist anxiously burns through her savings, cafe owners in Brussels receive about $4,300 to make up for lost revenue.

headline: When Coronavirus Closes Your Lab, Can Science Go On?
abstract: Plenty of work can be done from home, but the pandemic is forcing some parts of the scientific process to be put on the shelf.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, coronavirus led to the shutdown of many university campuses and other institutions for research and learning in the United States and around the world.

headline: Big Tech Could Emerge From Coronavirus Crisis Stronger Than Ever
abstract: Amazon is hiring aggressively to meet customer demand. Traffic has soared on Facebook and YouTube. And cloud computing has become essential to home workers.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — While the rest of the economy is tanking from the crippling impact of the coronavirus, business at the biggest technology companies is holding steady — even thriving.

headline: What the Heck Is That?
abstract: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
lead_paragraph: The word AGITA has appeared in the New York Times Crossword 17 times since its debut in 1994, yet it was the entry that most of our solvers missed in the March 16 puzzle by the constructor Gary Cee. It’s enough to give a person heartburn.

headline: Joe Biden Is Trying to Be Heard on the Virus. Can He Break Through?
abstract: As President Trump holds daily briefings, Mr. Biden has kept a low profile, worrying Democrats who feel the president needs to be challenged more robustly.
lead_paragraph: With President Trump providing daily televised briefings and governors like Andrew M. Cuomo emerging as national leaders during the coronavirus pandemic, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is still grappling with how to position himself as a prominent voice on a crisis that is pushing traditional politics to the background.

headline: The Unseen Survivors of Thalidomide Want to Be Heard
abstract: The U.S. was supposed to have escaped the devastation of a drug that caused birth defects in babies overseas. This is the almost forgotten story of its toll in America.
lead_paragraph: The man on the bus was staring at her. Carolyn Farmer, 17, noticed him as she closed the Leon Uris novel “Exodus” and gathered her things.

headline: The Story of Thalidomide in the U.S., Told Through Documents
abstract: A trove of archival records shows how in the early 1960s the Food and Drug Administration investigated the use of a drug that caused severe birth defects.
lead_paragraph: In July 1962, the Food and Drug Administration sent an urgent message to its field offices with an assignment it said was “one of the most important we have had in a long time.”

headline: Woody Allen’s Memoir Is Published
abstract: Arcade Publishing released “Apropos of Nothing” on Monday. The book had ignited a backlash earlier this month, after its original publisher, Hachette, canceled its plans to release the book.
lead_paragraph: Before it had even been released, Woody Allen’s new autobiography, “Apropos of Nothing,” ignited a ferocious backlash.

headline: Thalidomide Use Did Happen Here, These Americans Say
abstract: They believe they were harmed in the thalidomide crisis of the 1950s and 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Even though thalidomide did not reach American pharmacy shelves, the drug was distributed to as many as 20,000 patients through two clinical trials run by American companies that were testing it for use in the United States.

headline: Ex-Field Organizers Sue Bloomberg Campaign, Claiming They Were Misled
abstract: Former campaign workers for Michael Bloomberg filed two proposed class-action lawsuits on Monday, arguing they and thousands of others were tricked into taking their jobs and are owed overtime pay.
lead_paragraph: Former field organizers for Michael R. Bloomberg filed two proposed class-action lawsuits against his presidential campaign Monday, arguing that they and thousands of others laid off this month had been tricked into taking jobs they were told would last until November.

headline: Jeremy Marre, Documentarian of World Music, Is Dead at 76
abstract: With a minimal camera and sound crew, Mr. Marre traveled the world to film music and musicians on home turf that was often gritty and unglamorous.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Marre, an English filmmaker who documented music from across the world with hardheaded clarity, died on March 15 at a hospital in London, where he had lived. He was 76.

headline: The Fed’s Message: The Money-Printing Presses Are Fired Up and Ready to Go
abstract: Its actions Monday show it will do anything necessary to address a glaring shortage of dollars across the economy.
lead_paragraph: The extraordinary actions of the Federal Reserve on Monday morning can be boiled down to two sentences: There is a rapidly developing shortage of dollars across the economy. And the Fed will do anything it needs to, on any scale imaginable, to end this shortage.

headline: At a Murder Mystery Weekend, Whodunit? Everyone
abstract: A critic disguised as an actress who is also a suspect in the death of the Great Merlini. Her team didn’t use “Cats” to break the case, though.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, in what already feels like a different world, I found myself onstage, holding a pen I had swiped from the hotel’s reception desk and reciting a garbled version of the dagger speech from “Macbeth.” It felt giddy, hyperreal and a little like a benign version of a nightmare — the kind of nightmare I still have even though I haven’t acted in almost two decades and my professional career, if you want to dignify it that way, lasted months. In the nightmare, I come to in the middle of a play and I don’t know any of my lines. See? Dreams do come true.

headline: Top Senate Democrat and Treasury Secretary Say They Are Near a Stimulus Deal
abstract: Hours after Democrats blocked the nearly $2 trillion package, a marathon set of private negotiations appeared to have yielded important compromises.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Treasury secretary and the top Senate Democrat said late Monday that they were on the brink of a deal on a nearly $2 trillion emergency economic aid measure to respond to the coronavirus pandemic, after a marathon day of talks as Democrats demanded stronger protections for workers and restrictions for bailed-out businesses.

headline: Alex Salmond, Scotland’s Ex-First Minister, Cleared of Sexual Assault
abstract: A jury found Mr. Salmond, who led the push for independence in a 2014 referendum, not guilty of attempted rape and sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: Alex Salmond, the former first minister of Scotland, was acquitted on Monday of sexual offenses that involved accusations from nine women.

headline: Supplements for Coronavirus Probably Won’t Help, and May Harm
abstract: Worried Americans are scrambling to buy wellness products they think will protect against coronavirus. Some may do harm.
lead_paragraph: In the past few weeks, Ashley Koff, a registered dietitian in Columbus, Ohio, has gotten a deluge of requests from people who want to know which dietary supplements they should take to protect themselves from the coronavirus.

headline: Review: ‘One Day at a Time’ Still Standing and Being Counted
abstract: The former Netflix sitcom about a Cuban-American family returns on Pop TV, slightly shorter but big on laughs and purpose.
