lead_paragraph: “One Day at a Time” recently escaped a brush with cancellation, so it’s appropriate that the new season begins with a head count to make sure that everyone’s OK.

headline: 1,000 Inmates Will Be Released From N.J. Jails to Curb Coronavirus Risk
abstract: No other state is thought to have taken such sweeping action to reduce its jail population in response to the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey will release as many as 1,000 people from its jails in what is believed to be the nation’s broadest effort to address the risks of the highly contagious coronavirus spreading among the incarcerated.

headline: These Doctors Have Specialties. Fighting Coronavirus Wasn’t One of Them.
abstract: The pandemic’s spread is creating new challenges for doctors who usually care primarily for patients with particular medical needs.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Scott Isaacs has worked as an endocrinologist for more than two decades, focused on the medical needs of adults with diabetes in the Atlanta area. He never expected to be serving on the front lines of a pandemic.

headline: The ‘Niqab Squad’ Wants Women to Be Seen Differently
abstract: A movement of Indonesian women promotes the niqab veil as a way to get closer to heaven and avoid sexual harassment. Others fear it reflects growing extremism.
lead_paragraph: TEMBORO, Indonesia — Only the rider’s eyes were visible from behind her black face veil. With a bow in her left hand and an arrow in her right, she cantered her horse toward a target, aimed quickly and let fly. The arrow struck home with a resounding pop.

headline: Lil Uzi Vert, a Hip-Hop Star Beyond Gatekeepers
abstract: The rapper’s long-awaited second studio album, “Eternal Atake,” and the deluxe version that followed provide rowdy thrills.
lead_paragraph: Lil Uzi Vert, perhaps the defining rap star of the past few years, is a cipher, a whirlwind, an alien. An accident of history. A chemical recombination of what hip-hop success sounds, looks and, maybe most importantly, feels like in an era in which the old gatekeepers have been all but sidelined. Breakout hits? One or two. Radio? Not so much. Promotional dog-and-pony show? As if.

headline: Whose Life is Worth Saving? In Washington State, People With Disabilities Are Afraid They Won’t Make the Cut.
abstract: Advocates in Washington State fear that people who are disabled could be at higher risk of death when doctors and hospitals make end-of-life triage decisions.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Groups representing people with disabilities on Monday challenged a plan that would guide hospitals in Washington State dealing with the coronavirus in the event that they do not have enough lifesaving resources for all the patients who need them.

headline: Coronavirus Makes Daily Life Confounding. Here Are Some Answers.
abstract: Welcome to Dilemmas, where we find solutions to your toughest quandaries.
lead_paragraph: How to stay safe. How to protect others. How much risk to take when the smallest act can be a risk: touching a doorknob, buying milk. Whether or not the virus has reached your neighborhood, what’s swept into everyone’s lives is a set of confounding dilemmas.

headline: Review: When Atlanta Destroyed a Housing Project to Save It
abstract: The PBS documentary “East Lake Meadows,” from the executive producer Ken Burns, tells a complicated and melancholy story of race and public policy.
lead_paragraph: The makers of “East Lake Meadows: A Public Housing Story” probably would not have chosen to premiere their documentary (Tuesday, on PBS) in the midst of an all-consuming global crisis. But as it turns out, their admirable, melancholy film syncs up well with Covid-19 anxiety — in part as a reminder that for some Americans, social and economic devastation in daily life is a pre-existing condition.

headline: Back at Work but Not on the Bench, Supreme Court Issues 3 Major Opinions
abstract: The court ruled in cases on the insanity defense, race discrimination and copyright infringement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a series of decisions, the Supreme Court on Monday ruled that states may abolish a common form of the insanity defense, that an entrepreneur suing Comcast for race discrimination must meet a demanding standard and that states are immune from claims of copyright infringement.

headline: Rosie O’Donnell Returns, With Guests in the Basement and the Bathtub
abstract: For over three hours online Sunday night, the Broadway superfan schmoozed, fund-raised and gave stars a chance to share their music.
lead_paragraph: A lot happened during the just-this-once edition of “The Rosie O’Donnell Show” that streamed live Sunday night — that would be expected with an event lasting three and a half hours. But it will be hard to top Adrienne Warren, the star of “Tina: The Tina Turner Musical,” singing “Simply the Best” in a bathtub, clad in a bathing suit worthy of a 1970s Bond girl. At the end of the song, she whipped out a tiny toy saxophone.

headline: Obamacare Turns 10. Here’s a Look at What Works and Doesn’t.
abstract: With the coronavirus, a new Supreme Court case and a blistering election debate, the Affordable Care Act is facing challenges as never before. We looked at how it’s held up to its  promise.
lead_paragraph: A pandemic. A Supreme Court challenge (again). A presidential election campaign — this time with attacks from the left as well as the right.

headline: Medical Students, Sidelined for Now, Find New Ways to Fight Coronavirus
abstract: After medical schools ended contact with patients, disappointed students organized to collect masks, work at call centers and offer child care to health workers.
lead_paragraph: As hospitals around the United States brace for an ongoing surge in coronavirus cases, one question they are grappling with is whether medical students should be deployed to help care for patients infected with the virus.

headline: How South Korea Flattened the Curve
abstract: The country showed that it is possible to contain the coronavirus without shutting down the economy, but experts are unsure whether its lessons can work abroad.
lead_paragraph: No matter how you look at the numbers, one country stands out from the rest: South Korea.

headline: Pursuing an Untold Story of Thalidomide
abstract: The drug was connected to birth defects in 10,000 babies overseas. But following the trail in the United States was more complicated.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: U.S. Olympic Committee Urges Postponing Summer Games in Tokyo
abstract: The United States added its voice to growing calls for the Tokyo Games to be rescheduled because of the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee is urging that the Summer Olympics in Tokyo be postponed because of the coronavirus pandemic, adding its large and influential voice to a growing chorus of athletes and sports federations objecting to having the Games go on as scheduled in late July and early August.

headline: Professional Athletes Trade Sports for TikTok and Toilet Paper
abstract: Giannis Antetokounmpo is playing guitar, among other things you didn’t expect to read about in the middle of March.
lead_paragraph: Another Monday, another week of global pandemic news, social distancing, political wrangling and no sports.

headline: Justin Trudeau in Home Isolation: ‘Daddy’s on an Important Phone Call’
abstract: Canada’s prime minister has been a housekeeper and single parent to three children while running the nation, after his wife tested positive for the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — He has been stuck inside his house in Ottawa since March 12 with his three young children. He has been juggling work meetings on his phone with parenting and household duties normally executed by his staff or his wife, who is sick.

headline: Remember When Japan Blasted an Asteroid? Here’s What We Learned
abstract: The Hayabusa2 spacecraft’s explosive encounter reveals that a space rock called Ryugu looks extremely young for its age.
lead_paragraph: In April last year, a Japanese spacecraft launched a strike from above on an asteroid.

headline: Democratic Convention Planners Look at Contingency Options
abstract: The coronavirus crisis has created uncertainty about whether the gathering, scheduled for mid-July in Milwaukee, can still take place.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Planners for the Democratic National Convention are looking at “contingency options” in case the mid-July gathering in Milwaukee can’t take place because of the coronavirus, officials said on Monday for the first time.

headline: Eleven States Now Letting Uninsured Sign Up for Obamacare
abstract: More coronavirus care will be covered in many states. Federal officials are considering similar action for the state markets they run.
lead_paragraph: Eleven states and the District of Columbia have opened enrollment under the Affordable Care Act to allow laid-off workers to get subsidized health insurance, and the Trump administration, which has been gunning to repeal the law, is considering opening the federal exchange to new customers.

headline: Chin Up, Extroverts: We Will Crowd Again!
abstract: As an extrovert, being isolated is horrible. But it is a necessary — and temporary — step toward stopping the spread of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: 2020 has been canceled.

headline: Mexico, the Coronavirus and the Hugging President
abstract: Mr. López Obrador deserves to be strongly criticized, but Mexicans will have to stand together to get through coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — On March 4, a few days after the first coronavirus case was discovered here, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador was asked about the infection at his daily news conference. “With the coronavirus, this idea that you can’t hug,” the president said. “You have to hug. Nothing happens.” He crossed his arms and hugged himself, a signature gesture that he uses to show him hugging the Mexican people.

headline: Where Can Domestic Violence Victims Turn During Covid-19?
abstract: Self-isolation during the pandemic can be dangerous for those in abusive relationships. Resources are limited, but there are options.
lead_paragraph: The most dangerous place in the world for a woman is her own home. According to the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence, intimate partner violence affects millions of women every year.

headline: We All Hate Bailouts, but We Need Them
abstract: To save American jobs, we need to save American businesses.
lead_paragraph: Here we go again. With business activity having declined precipitously, bailouts of troubled companies are appropriately back on the table.

headline: Routine Medical Care May Break Down, and Covid-19 Is Behind It
abstract: We run a suburban medical office, not a front-line emergency room. But the lack of protective gear also affects us, and the people who need us.
lead_paragraph: Over 12 days ago, when I walked into my otolaryngology office in Westchester County, N.Y., my office manager gave me one high-grade N-95 mask. These masks are not supposed to be reusable, but somehow I had to make it last: We didn’t have any more. I later learned that we only had 25 protective gowns — likewise designed to be single-use items — for an office of nine medical specialists. When I saw a delivery of protective medical equipment in our building the next day, I assumed it was for my office. Instead it was going to the lawyers’ office down the hall. We are finally getting 20 more masks, but our shortage remains acute.

headline: There Is a Racial Divide in Speech-Recognition Systems, Researchers Say
abstract: Technology from Amazon, Apple, Google, IBM and Microsoft misidentified 35 percent of words from people who were black. White people fared much better.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — With an iPhone, you can dictate a text message. Put Amazon’s Alexa on your coffee table, and you can request a song from across the room.

headline: Aurlus Mabele, Congolese King of Soukous Music, Dies at 66
abstract: His up-tempo hits and high-wattage performances were highlighted by spectacular dance moves. He contracted the coronavirus and died in Paris.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Trump Administration Gives Apple More Tariff Relief
abstract: Trade officials approved the company’s request to remove tariffs on the Apple Watch.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — U.S. trade officials removed tariffs on the Apple Watch, the latest Apple device to avoid the United States-China trade war that had once looked like a dire threat to the company’s business.

headline: Singalongs From Windowsills Lift Spirits During Coronavirus Crisis
abstract: Following an example set by Europeans who sang from balconies, some homebound Americans are communally belting out tunes from their windows.
lead_paragraph: The idea took root after Jenni Spinner and her wife, Rebecca Kell, watched videos of Europeans, homebound because of the coronavirus, get on their balconies and sing to raise their spirits in the face of crisis.

headline: Coronavirus Patients in Limbo as Gilead Suspends Emergency Drug Access
abstract: The company says it will switch to a broader approach for its experimental drug, remdesivir. But it was overwhelmed by demand for a potential treatment promoted by President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Overwhelmed by demand for an experimental treatment for coronavirus, the drug maker Gilead abruptly shut down its emergency access program, leaving doctors and families scrambling for answers.

headline: South Korea’s Method, Coronavirus Treatment, SoftBank: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Harvey Weinstein Tests Positive for the Coronavirus
abstract: The film producer, who is serving 23 years for sex crimes, has been isolated from other prisoners but has shown no symptoms.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Weinstein, the disgraced film producer who was convicted of two felony sex crimes in a case that helped start the #MeToo movement, has contracted the coronavirus, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Royal Ballet and Liam Scarlett Part Ways After an Investigation
abstract: The choreographer is leaving the company, although a sexual misconduct inquiry found “no matters to pursue” against him.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British choreographer Liam Scarlett on Monday left his position as the Royal Ballet’s artist-in-residence, after an investigation into accusations of sexual misconduct with dance students.

headline: A Highly Adaptable Vegetarian Skillet Chili
abstract: If you have beans and tomatoes, you’re most of the way to this simple meal.
lead_paragraph: Are you ready for another bean dish? I sure am, which is a good thing considering how many kinds of beans I have on hand. (I’m not hoarding; I’m just extremely well stocked.)

headline: The Coronavirus Bailout Stalled. And It’s Mitch McConnell’s Fault.
abstract: Senate Republicans are blocking passage of an economic bailout plan that protects jobs and wages.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated.

headline: New York Philharmonic Cancels Season Because of Coronavirus
abstract: The orchestra is anticipating a loss of $10 million and said its endowment had declined by about 14 percent.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic canceled the remainder of its season on Monday, bowing to the reality that the coronavirus pandemic will silence large-scale performances in the city for months to come.

headline: Trump’s Leadership in the Coronavirus Crisis
abstract: Readers criticize the president’s daily briefings, attack on a reporter and refusal to use the Defense Production Act.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Best Canned Tomatoes
abstract: In a taste test conducted by Wirecutter and NYT Cooking, three American brands came out on top.
lead_paragraph: At this moment, as you’re holed up at home, the best canned tomatoes are the ones you’ll grab from your cabinet to make dinner.

headline: Party Zero: How a Soirée in Connecticut Became a ‘Super Spreader’
abstract: About 50 people gathered this month for a party in the upscale suburb of Westport, then scattered across the region and the world, taking the coronavirus with them.
lead_paragraph: About 50 guests gathered on March 5 at a home in the stately suburb of Westport, Conn., to toast the hostess on her 40th birthday and greet old friends, including one visiting from South Africa. They shared reminiscences, a lavish buffet and, unknown to anyone, the coronavirus.

headline: Grieving the Losses of Coronavirus
abstract: In addition to the tragic losses of life and health and jobs, we are grieving the losses of weddings, sports and the ability to buy eggs or get a haircut.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to the coronavirus outbreak, what’s the word related to mental health that you hear most? If you said “anxiety,” you’re not alone. But if you were to sit (virtually, of course) in a therapist’s office like mine or any of my colleagues’, what you might hear just as often is the word “loss.”

headline: The Wrong Way to Fight Coronavirus
abstract: Yale health experts take strong issue with an Op-Ed essay that suggested letting the virus run its course. Also: Senator Rand Paul’s error; public works projects; lagging on disability rights.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Lil Uzi Vert Holds at No. 1, and Streaming Habits Are Shifting
abstract: During the coronavirus crisis, listeners are turning to older songs and family music, but the biggest new releases are still going strong.
lead_paragraph: During the coronavirus pandemic, millions of people are turning to streaming music services for entertainment and distraction — but how are streaming numbers holding up?

headline: Local News Outlets Dealt a Crippling Blow by This Biggest of Stories
abstract: Layoffs. Canceled print editions. Weekly papers and small dailies across the country face peril as the coronavirus cuts off ads and live events.
lead_paragraph: Once the Chocolate Pig closed, the paper was in trouble.

headline: Britain Placed Under a Virtual Lockdown by Boris Johnson
abstract: The prime minister closed all nonessential shops, banning meetings of more than two people and requiring people to stay in their homes, except for trips for food or medicine.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Facing a growing storm of criticism about his laissez-faire response to the fast-spreading coronavirus, Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced on Monday that he would place Britain under a virtual lockdown, closing all nonessential shops, banning meetings of more than two people, and requiring people to stay in their homes, except for trips for food or medicine.

headline: ‘The Glass Hotel,’ by Emily St. John Mandel: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “The Glass Hotel,” by Emily St. John Mandel

headline: Boris Stankovic, Who Paved Way for N.B.A.’s ‘Dream Team,’ Dies at 94
abstract: As the longtime head of FIBA, the international game’s governing body, he successfully lobbied to let pros play in the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Boris Stankovic, the longtime head of basketball’s worldwide governing body and a driving force in the fight to allow N.B.A. players to participate in the Olympics, died on Friday in Belgrade, Serbia. He was 94.

headline: An Argumentative-Writing Unit for Students Doing Remote Learning
abstract: Suggestions for self-guided activities that can help students practice making claims and supporting them with evidence.
lead_paragraph: Note to Teachers: Here is a PDF teacher’s guide for using this unit with students.

headline: Dip in Italy’s Cases Does Not Come Fast Enough for Swamped Hospitals
abstract: Even as new coronavirus infections appear to slow, a backlog is forcing doctors to make increasingly tough choices about treatment.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The patient had won national swimming championships in his youth but now had a lot going against him. As he waited for a kidney transplant, doctors in the northern Italian town of Brescia discovered he had heart disease and had contracted the coronavirus. But what ultimately killed him this month was the decision to give his ventilator to a younger coronavirus patient who had a better shot at survival.

headline: Whatever It Takes: How the Fed Aims to Rescue the Economy
abstract: The central bank is using tactics from the last financial crisis and deploying new ones to keep money flowing. Here are the basics.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve on Monday pledged to do, in essence, whatever it takes to keep the economy from collapsing under the weight of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: The Coronavirus Revives Facebook as a News Powerhouse
abstract: More than half of all news consumption on Facebook in America is about the virus, according to an internal report.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, Facebook could feel at times like the virtual equivalent of a sleepy bingo parlor — an outmoded gathering place populated mainly by retirees looking for conversation and cheap fun.

headline: Shouting, Finger-Pointing and Threats in a Florida City on Edge
abstract: A town’s emergency meeting turned into a shouting match and a viral video as tensions over its coronavirus response boiled over.
lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — They were both yelling.

headline: Man Convicted of Trying to Blow Up Oklahoma City Bank Gets 25 Years in Prison
abstract: Jerry Drake Varnell was arrested in 2017 after a thwarted attempt to blow up a bank in downtown Oklahoma City — a plot similar to one carried out there in 1995.
lead_paragraph: A man who was arrested in 2017 after a thwarted attempt to blow up a bank in downtown Oklahoma City — a plot that echoed the deadly bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building there in 1995 — was sentenced Monday to 25 years in prison, the authorities said.

headline: As Fox News Played Down the Coronavirus, Its Chief Protected Himself
abstract: The cancellation of an 89th birthday party for Rupert Murdoch highlights a disconnect between his family’s behavior and statements made on air by some Fox commentators.
lead_paragraph: If you were watching some of the commentators on Fox News and Fox Business in the first 10 days of March, you wouldn’t have been too worried about the coronavirus — it would be no worse than the flu, and the real story was the “coronavirus impeachment scam.”

headline: Republicans Add Insult to Illness
abstract: Greed, germs and the art of no deal.
lead_paragraph: If you want a quick summary of the state of play over fiscal stimulus legislation, here it is: Republicans insist that we should fight a plague with trickle-down economics and crony capitalism. Democrats, for some reason, don’t agree, and think we should focus on directly helping Americans in need.

headline: To Help Performers in Need, Funky Videos at Your Fingertips
abstract: The performer Taylor Mac and the playwright Suzan-Lori Parks have signed on to a video-sharing subscription service to raise money for New York colleagues in crisis.
lead_paragraph: Since the coronavirus crisis started, artists have posted songs, speeches and even Shakespeare sonnets online to cheer people up, while others have staged impromptu fund-raisers, like the one-night-only virtual return of Rosie O’Donnell’s talk show, which featured one guest calling in from the bathtub.

headline: Coronavirus Relief, PG&E, Woody Allen: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Rand Paul’s Positive Coronavirus Test Sets the (Still Meeting) Senate on Edge
abstract: The Kentucky Republican’s diagnosis has injected a shot of fear into the Senate as it scrambles to pass a relief package to respond to the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In another workplace, in another town, the news that a colleague who, days and even hours before testing positive for the novel coronavirus, had been dining and meeting and working out alongside his co-workers might have spurred some drastic measures.

headline: Eric Weissberg, ‘Dueling Banjos’ Musician, Dies at 80
abstract: His melodic banjo work on a 1973 hit single (heard in the movie “Deliverance”) helped usher bluegrass music into the cultural mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Eric Weissberg, a gifted multi-instrumentalist whose melodic banjo work on the 1973 hit single “Dueling Banjos” helped bring bluegrass music into the cultural mainstream, died on Sunday in a nursing home near Detroit. He was 80.

headline: Feeling Powerless About Coronavirus? Join a Mutual-Aid Network
abstract: A quarantine is the perfect time to get (virtually) close to your community.
lead_paragraph: A pandemic is frightening, and isolating. It is psychically frustrating: We need other people now more than ever. At the same time, other people have never been more dangerous to our health. The choice to go outside, even to help others, means assuming risk — for yourself, loved ones and strangers. It’s easy to feel powerless and alone.

headline: Texas and Ohio Include Abortion as Medical Procedures That Must Be Delayed
abstract: The moves by the states set off a new front in the political fight over abortion during the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Texas and Ohio have included abortions among the nonessential surgeries and medical procedures that they are requiring to be delayed, setting off a new front in the fight over abortion rights in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic in the United States.

headline: Why Mundane Moments Truly Matter
abstract: “How we spend our days is how we spend our lives.”
lead_paragraph: My mother and I have sipped tea with maharanis, swapped stories with Burmese nuns and bumped through the streets of Bangkok on midnight tuk tuks — but the delight we return to, again and again, is the moon. “Go outside and take a look,” she’ll command over text, and I’ll stumble out the door to glimpse at a crescent sliver. We swap cellphone photos of fuzzy white discs that are indistinguishable from the ones that preceded them but offer what feels like newfound delight. Our shared moon: a simple joy that binds us together across years and over continents.

headline: Fourteen Days. That’s the Most Time We Have to Defeat Coronavirus.
abstract: These decisive measures can prevent a decade of dislocation and extraordinary levels of deaths.
lead_paragraph: America is losing the war against Covid-19, but we can win it with decisive and extraordinary actions now.

headline: 20-Somethings Now Realizing That They Can Get Coronavirus, Too
abstract: More than 40 percent of those who have tested positive for the virus in New York City are between the ages of 18 and 44.
lead_paragraph: Marissa Crider set up strict house rules after recently taking in a third roommate in her apartment in Queens.

headline: Bankers Pledge Mortgage Help, but Want Billions
abstract: Millions of borrowers may be unable to make payments on home loans next week. The mortgage industry says it’s willing to help, but needs the government to back it up.
lead_paragraph: In just days, tens of millions of people across the United States will have to make fresh payments on their mortgages. Their lenders have come up with a plan to help borrowers who can’t pay because of the economic fallout from the coronavirus — and they want the federal government to backstop it.

headline: As Coronavirus Cases Add Up, California Frantically Counts Tests, Beds and Masks
abstract: Across a state with many large biotechnology companies, the promise of widespread access to testing for the coronavirus has not materialized.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Wildfires, earthquakes, mudslides. California knows disaster.

headline: In Daily Coronavirus Briefing, Trump Tries to Redefine Himself
abstract: The briefing has given him a unique perch from which he can talk about the pandemic and try to project leadership after initially minimizing it. But that’s not always what he has done.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s campaign rallies have been canceled for the foreseeable future. His noisy back-and-forths with reporters on the South Lawn, half drowned out by the whir of Marine One behind him, have also disappeared.

headline: A Handy Measure
abstract: These shot glasses let you mete out precious liquors, and come in handy for baking projects.
lead_paragraph: You need a drink, but you — not some mixologist — are in charge. Though professionals prefer little metal measuring containers, this set of one-and-a-half ounce glass ones, with markings for a half-ounce and an ounce, is very easy to use. And having several means that you can combine multiple spirits without rinsing in between. They’re also superb for pouring measured drams of precious Pappy Van Winkle. Use them for baking and cooking, keeping in mind that one-half ounce is a tablespoon.

headline: Meal Kits From the Chef Dan Barber
abstract: The meals, which serve two to four, are available at Blue Hill at Stone Barns.
lead_paragraph: Like a number of other chefs and restaurants, Dan Barber, the chef and an owner of Blue Hill in Manhattan, and Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Westchester County, is assembling market boxes for pickup. Each will contain ingredients and cooking instructions for a dish that will serve two to four people. Though the ingredients will vary daily, you can count on a rich broth as one of the components, along with fresh and fermented vegetables, meats, eggs and a flatbread made with freshly milled flour. They are meant to keep the restaurant staff and local farmers employed. The ingredients and recipe will change weekly.

headline: Add a Sprinkle to Breakfast
abstract: Lil Bucks, a sprouted buckwheat snack, adds a touch of flavor to granola, yogurt or salads.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing new about buckwheat, a seed (not really a grain) that’s most comfortable growing in cooler and high-altitude climates worldwide. But the form in which Emily Griffith is selling them is innovative. While living in Australia, she discovered sprouted buckwheat and created Lil Bucks, a company to make and sell the crunchy, earthy-tasting seeds. You can add them to granola, sprinkle them on salad, dust them over yogurt and so forth. Like so much these days, they’re billed as a “superfood,” but the real benefit is their fiber (5 grams in a quarter-cup), protein (6 grams in a quarter-cup), their nice texture and alluring flavor. In addition to plain, they also come flavored with matcha or cacao, neither of which add much in my view. Chunky clusters with other seeds and seasoned with chocolate or turmeric-lemon myrtle are for snacking.

headline: Japanese Food From a Swedish Kitchen
abstract: “The Japanese Table,” a new book by a Swedish cook smitten with Japan, offers nourishing, small-scale ideas for dinner.
lead_paragraph: Sofia Hellsten is Swedish, but, having lived in Japan, she’s devoted to Japanese food and dining. Her new book explores the simple everyday meals she craves, especially when not in Japan. They’re the sort of nourishing, comforting plates that are easily made and frequently feature vegetables. They’re also enjoyable to serve one or two but no more than four: perfect for troubled times in sequestered households. It’s hard to resist rice, egg and scallions in a soft, single-serving porridge; tamago omelet as egg salad in a sandwich, with miso mayonnaise; silky eggplant with miso; cod with sweet miso that might have been the ur-black cod recipe made famous by Nobu; and somen noodles in a well-seasoned dashi broth. The book does a fine job of explaining Japanese green teas, and there’s a pantry list of staples, most of which are sold online.

headline: Spanish Broths for More Than Paella
abstract: Aneto, from Barcelona, add more flavor to soups and stews.
lead_paragraph: A line of first-rate Spanish broths (chicken, fish and vegetable for soups and stews, and more focused mixtures meant for paella, specifically seafood paella) is now available. There’s even one for black, squid ink paella. These broths, made in Barcelona, are free of additives and preservatives and deliver good flavor. For paella, I might simmer the broth with a little more saffron before adding it to the rice, and it’s also excellent for risotto.

headline: Density Is New York City’s Big ‘Enemy’ in the Coronavirus Fight
abstract: New York is more crowded than any large city in the country. That helps explain why it is the U.S. epicenter of the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: New York has tried to slow the spread of the coronavirus by closing its schools, shutting down its nonessential businesses and urging its residents to stay home almost around the clock. But it faces a distinct obstacle in trying to stem new cases: its cheek-by-jowl density.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Epidemic-fighting experts explained what it would take for the U.S. to successfully stop the virus.
lead_paragraph: The wrangling on Capitol Hill over a $1.8 trillion package of measures to aid the stalling economy continued on Monday, after Democrats again blocked a version of the package that they said offered too little protection for workers and too much potential for abuse by big business.

headline: The View From Your Window
abstract: Life has changed in big ways and small for our On Politics readers from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: At Least 13,500 Americans Abroad Need Help Getting Home, State Dept. Says
abstract: About 5,700 U.S. citizens and legal residents have already returned with the government’s assistance, and flights scheduled this week could help another 1,600.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An estimated 13,500 Americans abroad have asked the State Department for help returning to the United States as the coronavirus pandemic has resulted in closed borders and suspended commercial flights, two senior officials said Monday.

headline: Webinar Wednesdays: Opportunities for Teachers and Parents on Remote Learning With The Times
abstract: During the last eight weeks of school closure, we hosted weekly webinars on teaching and learning with Times and Learning Network resources.
lead_paragraph: As schools began to switch to remote learning because of the coronavirus pandemic, we asked teachers what else we could do to help during these uncertain times. They asked for more virtual professional development opportunities and we responded.

headline: Call It ‘Coronavirus’
abstract: Disease and prejudice have long gone hand in hand. We can do better in 2020.
lead_paragraph: We’ve been down this road before, too many times. In the 14th century the Black Death provoked mass violence against Jews, Catalans, clerics and beggars; when syphilis spread in the 15th century, it was called variously the Neapolitan, French, Polish and German disease, depending on who was pointing the blame; when the plague struck Honolulu in 1899, officials burned down Chinatown. And so on, down to our times, when epidemics like Ebola, SARS and Zika fueled animus toward specific regions or peoples.

headline: Bored in Quarantine? Here’s a New York Scene You Can Color
abstract: Grab your pencils. It's time to get creative
lead_paragraph: Grab your pencils. It's time to get creative

headline: Trump Considers Reopening Economy, Over Health Experts’ Objections
abstract: The president is questioning whether stay-at-home orders have gone too far. But relaxing them could significantly increase the death toll from the coronavirus, health officials warn.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the United States entered Week 2 of trying to contain the spread of the coronavirus by shuttering large swaths of the economy, President Trump, Wall Street executives and many conservative economists began questioning whether the government had gone too far and should instead lift restrictions that are already inflicting deep pain on workers and businesses.

headline: Here Come the Death Panels
abstract: Obamacare didn’t lead to rationing. The mismanagement of the coronavirus will.
lead_paragraph: We were told that if America passed Obamacare, it would result in death panels.

headline: Trump Has Given Unusual Leeway to Fauci, but Aides Say He’s Losing His Patience
abstract: The president has become increasingly concerned as Dr. Anthony S. Fauci has grown bolder in correcting his falsehoods about the spread of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has praised Dr. Anthony S. Fauci as a “major television star.” He has tried to demonstrate that the administration is giving him free rein to speak. And he has deferred to Dr. Fauci’s opinion several times at the coronavirus task force’s televised briefings.

headline: In Pandemic, Justice Dept. Seeks Video Court Hearings and Home Detention
abstract: Lawmakers are said to be skeptical about other Trump administration ideas, including expanding presidential power to curb asylum and suspending deadlines for arraignments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Invoking the coronavirus crisis, the Justice Department has asked Congress to let more federal inmates serve their time at home and to steer scarce masks and testing kits to federal prisons ahead of other agencies, according to draft legislation submitted last week to congressional leaders.

headline: Colorado Abolishes Death Penalty and Commutes Sentences of Death Row Inmates
abstract: The state had executed just one person since reinstating the death penalty in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Colorado abolished its seldom-used death penalty on Monday, joining a growing number of states that have eschewed capital punishment as a deterrent to the most serious crimes.

headline: Start-Ups Jump the Gun on Home Kits for Coronavirus Testing
abstract: After a federal warning, companies have stopped marketing kits that let consumers collect their own saliva or throat swabs and send them to labs.
lead_paragraph: Last week, two high-profile San Francisco health start-ups began marketing at-home coronavirus kits that let people collect their own saliva samples or oral throat swabs and then send the specimens to commercial labs to be tested for the virus.

headline: As Federal Government Mobilizes, Local Officials Say Response Remains Too Slow
abstract: Signs of a large-scale federal response to the coronavirus outbreak have begun to appear, generating praise from local officials but also pleas that they need much more.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal emergency response teams toured a convention center in New York City on Monday, a sign that a much-needed temporary hospital is on the way. California has received hundreds of thousands of masks for those on the front lines of the outbreak. And President Trump said desperately needed protective equipment was on its way to Washington State.

headline: Proof That God Loves Us
abstract: Olivia Mitra Framke knows how to show us a good time.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — The constructor Olivia Mitra Framke won me over in 2017, when she made her New York Times Crossword debut by crowning a certain jazz great queen. Since then, Ms. Framke has had two other puzzle in The Times, and she has also been published in USA Today, The Chronicle for Higher Education and the Crossword Club.

headline: How to Stay Sane When the World Seems Crazy
abstract: Stop and take a breath. The world will keep spinning.
lead_paragraph: Our constant, relentless exposure to news and headlines has a way of inspiring near-constant dread. As distressing news continually filters to the top of our feeds, phones and TVs, it isn’t uncommon to feel more than a little nervous about the state of the world.

headline: See Which States and Cities Have Told Residents to Stay at Home
abstract: In an attempt to stop the spread of the coronavirus, a vast majority of states and the Navajo Nation have given directives, affecting more than nine in 10 U.S. residents.
lead_paragraph: In an attempt to stop the spread of the coronavirus, a vast majority of states and the Navajo Nation have given directives, affecting more than nine in 10 U.S. residents.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 5, Episode 6 Recap: A Modest Proposal
abstract: Kim would like to marry Jimmy if she doesn’t leave him. Lalo would like to destroy Gus if he doesn’t kill him. And Mike plays private eye.
lead_paragraph: In the history of romance, there have no doubt been plenty of ultimatums of the sort that Kim delivers at the end of this episode. What sets this one apart is its preamble. Right before Kim states that she and Jimmy need to either break up or marry, she catalogs Jimmy’s shortcomings, and it’s a pretty compelling list. He’s a liar. He’ll always be a liar. He snookered her in front of her peers and managers. He’s done it before. He’ll do it again.

headline: 3 Newspapers Ask China to Reverse Decision to Expel American Journalists
abstract: The publishers of The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post released a statement critical of China’s revocation of Americans’ credentials.
lead_paragraph: The publishers of The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post on Tuesday released a statement critical of the Chinese government’s decision to bar American journalists for the three publications from working in China.

headline: Stocks Surge on Hopes for Economic Rescue Deal
abstract: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline: Corrections: March 24, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, March 24, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about President Trump’s hesitance to use emergency powers to compel the production of medical gear misidentified the type of masks in heavy use in the New York-Presbyterian hospital system. The system uses 4,000 non-N95 masks a day, not N95 masks.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Joining Athletes, U.S. Committee Pushes for Delay of Tokyo Games
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 24, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “The parameters going forward have not been determined, but the Games are not going to start on July 24, that much I know.”

headline: Trump Expresses Outrage at Having to ‘Close the Country’ to Slow Virus
abstract: Fleeing New Yorkers told to quarantine as Trump says the U.S. should reopen ‘by Easter.’

headline: Man Fatally Poisons Himself While Self-Medicating for Coronavirus, Doctor Says
abstract: An Arizona man and his wife ingested a fish tank cleaning additive made with the same active ingredient as chloroquine phosphate, which President Trump has referred to as a “game changer.”
lead_paragraph: An Arizona man died and his wife was hospitalized after officials said they treated themselves on Sunday with a deadly home remedy for the new coronavirus — a popular fish tank additive that has the same active ingredient as an anti-malaria drug.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘One Day at a Time’ and ‘Council of Dads’
abstract: The fourth season of a beloved family sitcom lands on Pop TV, while a new drama series airs on NBC.
lead_paragraph: ONE DAY AT A TIME 9:30 p.m. on Pop TV. Fans of this sitcom — a remake of Norman Lear’s original — were up in arms last year when Netflix canceled the show after three seasons. Now, they can rejoice: The series has found a new home on Pop TV — and this premiere will also air on TV Land and Logo — meaning the Cuban-American Alvarez family will be around to cheer up viewers suffering from the coronavirus blues. The fourth season opens with a census taker (Ray Romano) dropping by the family’s Los Angeles home. The trailer suggests there will be plenty of talk about sex and relationships: When the son, Alex (Marcel Ruiz), says the family needs boundaries, the mother, Penelope (Justina Machado), answers with: “Boundaries are for white people. Next thing you know, we’re eating Lunchables in separate rooms and grandmama lives in a home!”

headline: How Trump Sanctions on Iran Will Worsen the Pandemic
abstract: Tehran doesn’t have the resources to enforce quarantines and take other measures to contain the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: The toll of the eight-year war between Iran and Iraq, which killed as many as one million people in the 1980s, is feared to pale in comparison to that of the coronavirus epidemic: Iranian researchers have estimated that the outbreak, which has already killed more than 1,500 people in the country, will peak around late May and could result in 3.5 million deaths.

headline: Coronavirus, United Kingdom, Disney Plus: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Word + Quiz: fuselage
abstract: This word has appeared in 31 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Why Olympic Leaders Clung to the Plan to Have the Summer Games in Tokyo
abstract: The International Olympic Committee had said the Tokyo Games would offer hope against the coronavirus this summer, even as sports leaders and medical experts insisted that the event be delayed.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, as the coronavirus spread across the world, Thomas Bach, the president of the International Olympic Committee, held on to the dream that opening an Olympic Games on July 24 in Tokyo could serve as a celebration of triumph over a pandemic that has killed thousands of people, closed down countries and devastated the world economy.

headline: Welcome to the Virosphere
abstract: SARS-CoV-2, the cause of the pandemic, belongs to one of 6,828 named species of virus. Hundreds of thousands more species are known, with perhaps trillions waiting to be found.
lead_paragraph: In January, Chinese virologists isolated the virus that causes Covid-19. Earlier this month, a team of virologists gave this new virus a new name: SARS-CoV-2.

headline: Brady’s Big Move
abstract: How do you feel about Tom Brady leaving the Patriots?
lead_paragraph: Last week, Tom Brady, the only N.F.L. quarterback to win six Super Bowls, announced that after 20 seasons with the New England Patriots, he would not return to the team. He will now play for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

headline: Golf Rounds Surged as Coronavirus Advanced. Now the Game Is Retreating.
abstract: Drawn by open-air acreage, free time and new social distancing guidelines, recreational golfers in the U.S. were playing in droves this month. Then courses started shuttering.
lead_paragraph: As recently as a week ago, recreational golfers flocked to the fairways of public and private golf courses as a respite from stay-at-home guidelines and lifestyle prohibitions caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Golf, with its wide open spaces, still seemed safe.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Photos From a Century of Epidemics’
abstract: In this lesson, students will explore global epidemics from the 1918 flu to Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Photos From a Century of Epidemics” by Alan Cowell

headline: ‘Unworthy Republic’ Takes an Unflinching Look at Indian Removal in the 1830s
abstract: Claudio Saunt’s new book reckons with the history and legacy of the expulsion of 80,000 Native Americans from their homes.
lead_paragraph: The steamboat: For many Americans in the 19th century, it was a symbol of power and progress, a triumph of technology that ferried goods and people upriver with impressive speed.

headline: Set in a Notorious Prison, a Novel Probes Iran’s Torturers and Their Victims
abstract: “Then the Fish Swallowed Him,” the first novel in English by the Iranian-born Amir Ahmadi Arian, makes for unnerving reading.
lead_paragraph: THEN THE FISH SWALLOWED HIM By Amir Ahmadi Arian

headline: What Does Our Body Temperature Say About Our Health?
abstract: Humans seem to have cooled over the past 150 years. What does that mean for us now?
lead_paragraph: As public health officials struggle to contain the spread of the coronavirus, determining whether a person has a fever is now a high-stakes matter, and using temperature guns to screen people has become a visible strategy for detecting possible cases. “Any infectious disease — one of the cardinal signs of infection is raised body temperature,” says Waleed Javaid, the director of infection prevention and control for the Mount Sinai Downtown Network. But there’s a catch: “That means you know the body temperature before you raised it.”

headline: How to Harvest Caviar
abstract: You’re looking for firm, equal-size eggs about three millimeters in diameter. If you see smaller, white eggs, they aren’t mature.
lead_paragraph: “You need a female fish,” says Josh Lang, site manager at Sterling Caviar’s white-sturgeon farm in Elverta, Calif. It’s nearly impossible to ascertain a sturgeon’s sex from the outside; Lang and his team use ultrasound on 3-year-old fish to spot testes and ovaries. (Male fish and females with small ovaries are killed for meat.) When the fish are 6, start yearly biopsies by inserting a thin flexible sampling straw into the abdomen and pulling out a few eggs. “To determine whether it’s ready, you need to see, touch and taste it,” Lang says.

headline: I’m a Calamity Obsessive. After My Trip to Italy, I Was the Calamity.
abstract: I wasn’t planning to be on vacation in a pandemic. It changed the way I’ll think about risk forever.
lead_paragraph: I wasn’t planning to be on vacation in a pandemic. It changed the way I’ll think about risk forever.

headline: The Sometimes Amusing, Sometimes Appalling Life of a Lady-in-Waiting
abstract: In her new memoir, Anne Glenconner reflects on her nearly three decades of service to Princess Margaret.
lead_paragraph: LADY IN WAITINGMy Extraordinary Life in the Shadow of the CrownBy Anne Glenconner

headline: New & Noteworthy Visual Books, From Los Angeles Graffiti to Korean Art
abstract: A selection of recent visual books of note; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: THE CITY BENEATH: A Century of Los Angeles Graffiti, by Susan A. Phillips. (Yale University, $50.) From Japanese internees and hobos at the turn of the 20th century to taggers at the turn of the 21st, these graffiti artists reveal Los Angeles’s underground history.

headline: Getting Through, Making Memories and Being the Grown-Ups
abstract: You can’t change the world, but you can help shape the way your children experience this and remember it. And you will. You’re the person they need.
lead_paragraph: I’m not here to tell you what the “good thing” is about the coronavirus situation, because there is no good thing about a pandemic, not ever. That doesn’t mean there won’t be acts of heroism, because there will be, and heartwarming stories, because we’ll have those too, and even — if we’re lucky — moments of scientific brilliance. But we still have to get through the bad stuff. And getting through the bad stuff with your kids may be your act of heroism, your heartwarming story, and even your moment of scientific brilliance.

headline: I Think Sex for Pay Is Wrong. Should I Stay With a Partner Who Disagrees?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what to do if your partner thinks exchanging money for sex is OK and more.
lead_paragraph: I am a man in my 20s, currently in a relationship with a 50-some-year-old man. We have been dating monogamously for about six months, and it’s been a rewarding relationship for both of us. It recently came up that before we were together, he paid people for sex in two instances. He described both those instances as involving “good” intentions between the two parties.

headline: When a Sinister Enemy Attacks New York, the City Fights Back
abstract: N.K. Jemisin’s “The City We Became” is a love letter to the city and its residents, but explicitly welcomes foreignness and plurality.
lead_paragraph: THE CITY WE BECAME

headline: The Right Way to Fight Fake News
abstract: Social media platforms need to make sure their anti-misinformation strategies are empirically grounded.
lead_paragraph: Social media companies have been under tremendous pressure since the 2016 presidential election to do something — anything — about the proliferation of misinformation on their platforms.

headline: Should More Defendants Be Claiming Insanity?
abstract: Susan Nordin Vinocour’s “Nobody’s Child” uses one case as a prism for examining the history and future of the insanity defense in American courtrooms.
lead_paragraph: NOBODY’S CHILD A Tragedy, a Trial and a History of the Insanity DefenseBy Susan Nordin Vinocour

headline: In a Time of Crisis, Her Voice Was the One That Galvanized Alaska
abstract: Genie Chance felt the earth move under her feet, and then she got to work. Jon Mooallem tells her story in “This Is Chance!”
lead_paragraph: THIS IS CHANCE!The Shaking of an All-American City, a Voice That Held It TogetherBy Jon Mooallem

headline: Wresting Insight, and Poetry, From Pain
abstract: “Pain Studies,” by Lisa Olstein, and “Constellations,” by Sinead Gleeson, plumb the authors’ experiences with suffering to creative effect.
lead_paragraph: PAIN STUDIESBy Lisa Olstein

headline: Readers’ Ideas for Finding Community and Cheer at Home
abstract: As much of the world adjusts to a new normal of restricted living, our readers share tips for finding everyday joys.
lead_paragraph: Many of us are now entering the second, third or fourth week of restrictions on our movements, and it is becoming ever clearer that overcoming this crisis will be a marathon, not a sprint. As we all collectively adjust to our unique situations, we asked New York Times readers to share their ideas for pursuing the traveler’s spirit of discovery, curiosity and delight within their new limitations at home. Following are their responses, which have been edited for clarity and length.

headline: I’m on the Front Lines. I Have No Plan for This.
abstract: We’re not allowing visitors in the I.C.U. My patients will suffer in solitary confinement.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — As an I.C.U. doctor I’m used to giving bad news, but I was not prepared for this.

headline: The Comfort of Childhood Media During Lockdown
abstract: All I want to do is play Myst, an immersive computer game I was obsessed with when I was 11.
lead_paragraph: We are entering Week 3 of social isolation, and I have regressed. The plush yellow duck of my youth has waddled out of storage and into my bed. Real pants are a distant memory. And all I want to do is play Myst, an immersive adventure computer game from the 1990s that I was obsessed with when I was 11.

headline: This Is the Face of an Undocumented Immigrant. Don’t Look Away.
abstract: Karla Cornejo Villavicencio’s new book combines memoir and reporting to tell the stories behind the headlines.
lead_paragraph: THE UNDOCUMENTED AMERICANSBy Karla Cornejo Villavicencio

headline: Cooking Through a Crisis With Grandma, Virtually
abstract: At a moment when the present is terrifying and the future is uncertain, we’re returning to the recipes of the past.
lead_paragraph: When my grandmother turned 91 two weeks ago, I called to wish her a happy birthday and we made plans to celebrate over dinner later in the month. But in a matter of days, like everyone else, we saw the world change around us and our plans evaporated. Now I’m self-quarantined in Brooklyn and my grandmother is in Florida. We won’t be seeing each other in person any time soon.

headline: How to Get Money to Small Businesses, Fast
abstract: The single best thing Congress can do to stanch economic bleeding is to enact a temporary national moratorium on small business debt collections.
lead_paragraph: [Read our Coronavirus Relief Small Business F.A.Q.]

headline: Economic Stimulus Is the Wrong Prescription
abstract: We need liquidity to help businesses and individuals get through this necessarily tough time.
lead_paragraph: Despite several days of intense negotiation, the Senate has so far failed to pass a bill to infuse over a trillion dollars into the ailing U.S. economy. While there can be no doubt that swift action is vital, too many politicians and policymakers seem to think the goal should be to stimulate the economy back into action.

headline: How to See the World When You’re Stuck at Home
abstract: When you are quarantined or cancel your trip, you can still go on a journey. The secret? The author Reif Larsen says it’s Google Street View.
lead_paragraph: The other day, anxious in my desk chair, I became a virtual traveler, staring at photos of public spaces abandoned in the wake of the coronavirus global pandemic: a soccer game in Germany, played in front of thousands of empty seats, the Piazza San Marco in Venice, vacant save for a few confused pigeons, the huge empty courtyard at the Great Mosque in Mecca, usually filled to the brim with worshipers circumnavigating the Ka’bah. These are places built for humans, but there were no humans. It was like peering into what a future might look like after we are gone, a disaster movie without the movie part.

headline: Trump Doesn’t Have the Attention Span to Fight Coronavirus
abstract: He already seems to be losing interest. Look elsewhere for hope.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: How are you doing, Bret? I haven’t seen you in a while. In fact, I haven’t seen anybody, except my husband, the grocery store cashier and the dry cleaner.

headline: Stay Vigilant, Says a Curfew Veteran
abstract: Human adaptability is both a strength and a threat.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — As New York City was moving toward a full confinement mode, I got an email from the daughter of a Palestinian friend from the West Bank. She lives and works in the city and was looking for advice from a veteran of long-term confinements. “I was too young at the time of the Israeli military curfew in 2002 to remember,” she wrote, and then asked: “How did you all manage?”

headline: Some Pregnant Women in New York City Will Have to Deliver Babies Alone
abstract: “I have not stopped crying,” said an expectant mother who learned that her husband could not be with her when she gives birth.
lead_paragraph: Women giving birth at two leading New York City hospital networks are being told they must labor without spouses, partners or doulas by their side — leaving the expectant mothers anxious and frightened about their upcoming deliveries.

headline: You’ve Got Mail. Will You Get the Coronavirus?
abstract: The practice of disinfecting mail dates back to the invention of quarantine. There’s little evidence it needs to be invoked today.
lead_paragraph: Scientists agree that the main means by which the SARS-CoV-2 virus jumps from an infected person to its next host is by hitching a ride in the tiny droplets that are sprayed into the air with each cough or sneeze. But with deliveries now at holiday levels as locked-down Americans shop online rather than in person, the question remains: Can you catch the coronavirus from the parcels and packages your overburdened mail carrier keeps leaving at your door?

headline: Who Should Be Saved First? Experts Offer Ethical Guidance
abstract: Well before rationing caused by coronavirus, protocols were established about “who lives and who dies.”
lead_paragraph: How do doctors and hospitals decide who gets potentially lifesaving treatment and who doesn’t?

headline: Virus Brings States to a Standstill: Sessions Halt, Budgets Crater, Plans Wait
abstract: State legislatures are facing chaos amid the coronavirus crisis, with revenue projections suddenly expected to dip and major agendas put on hold.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus has wreaked havoc on statehouses across the United States, derailing policy agendas, forcing legislators to set aside plans for spending on education, road construction and opioid addiction, and draining state coffers with startling speed.

headline: Trump Thinks He Knows Better Than the Doctors About Coronavirus
abstract: His comments about reopening the economy sooner rather than later show us what he really values.
lead_paragraph: First, President Trump ignored the coronavirus, dismissing its threat to the public. Then briefly he took it somewhat seriously. He gave an address from the Oval Office, followed by one of the more sober-minded news conferences of his administration. A day later, he was back to his usual antics, attacking the press, amplifying propagandists and spreading misinformation. He has even promised a miracle cure.

headline: ‘I Just Don’t Think We Have the Luxury to Have Dreams Anymore’
abstract: Young people have a deep desire for radical change because we see the broken path ahead.
lead_paragraph: PLANO, Texas — A month ago, I was sitting in a coffee shop with a friend, talking about how crazy it was to want to be a writer. At that point, the coronavirus had yet to factor into our summer plans or pop up in the predictive text on our smartphones. That day, our biggest concern was whether my friend should settle for a summer internship in a financially stable industry or take a chance on journalism.

headline: Is Marijuana an ‘Essential’ Like Milk or Bread? Some States Say Yes
abstract: In most cases, marijuana businesses must, like restaurants, limit themselves to takeout or delivery. Black-market dealers are also busy, but feel little need to abide by official orders.
lead_paragraph: With the coronavirus pandemic spreading rapidly across the country, millions of Americans are being told by state and county officials to take refuge at home, and only venture out to get things they really need. Groceries, naturally. Prescription drugs, of course. Gas for the car. Urgent medical care.

headline: Nearly a Million Children Left Behind in Venezuela as Parents Migrate
abstract: Seven years into an economic crisis, mothers and fathers have been forced to go abroad in search of work, leaving hundreds of thousands of children in the hands of relatives, friends — and sometimes, one another.
lead_paragraph: MARACAIBO, Venezuela — In their final minutes together, Jean Carlos, 8, held his mother’s hand like an anchor and promised to “take deep breaths” so he wouldn’t cry. His sister, Crisol, 10, hid angrily in the kitchen. His brother, Cristian, 12, hauled a blue suitcase into the yard.

headline: One City’s Road to Recovery Offers Lessons, and Hope
abstract: Lawrence, Mass., once an industrial power, set out to reverse a long decline with the Federal Reserve’s help. Now it faces a new economic challenge.
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE, Mass. — It’s got to be hard to fall farther than Lawrence.

headline: A Medical Class ‘Minted by the Pandemic’
abstract: Across the nation, medical students are graduating directly into the path of an epic health crisis.
lead_paragraph: Preparations for the Cadaver Ball, at the Vanderbilt University School of Medicine, begin in the fall. Radial Grooves, an a cappella group, selects two songs to perform; the campus hip-hop and bhangra groups choreograph routines. This year’s theme was the “Roaring 2020s,” which was a relief to the class president, Varun Menon, because it meant that the only costume he needed was a tuxedo. (Last year’s class president had the unfortunate task of tracking down a full P.T. Barnum get-up, when the theme was “The Greatest Show.”)

headline: Should Public Preschool Be a Right for All Children?
abstract: When do you think the government should begin financing and supporting a child’s education?
lead_paragraph: In “Public School Is a Child’s Right. Should Preschool Be Also?” Claire Cain Miller begins the article with a question:

headline: ‘The City We Became,’ by N.K. Jemisin: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “The City We Became,” by N.K. Jemisin
lead_paragraph: He forgets his own name somewhere in the tunnel to Penn Station.

headline: For Drive-In Theaters, an Unexpected Revival
abstract: A retro tradition get a (temporary) boost from social-distancing edicts.
lead_paragraph: Jen Philhower, 48, a part-time office manager in Austin, Texas, is one of the many Americans adjusting to almost every group activity being canceled, as people move indoors and into isolation to avoid spreading the novel coronavirus.

headline: Falling Ill, Testing Negative
abstract: I had the symptoms. But did I have the coronavirus?
lead_paragraph: As of this writing, the United States has tested approximately 313,000 people for the coronavirus, and more than 270,000 have tested negative. I’m one of them. Here’s my story, offered without a definite conclusion.

headline: A Teardown? Not Even Close
abstract: A couple of experienced renovators were looking for a house in the Bay Area to demolish — until one with a strong ‘midcentury vibe’ won their hearts.
lead_paragraph: A couple of experienced renovators were looking for a house in the Bay Area to demolish — until one with a strong ‘midcentury vibe’ won their hearts.

headline: Instead of Tearing It Down, They Rescued It
abstract: A couple of experienced renovators were looking for a house in the Bay Area to demolish — until one with a strong ‘midcentury vibe’ won their hearts.
lead_paragraph: When Mike and Kari Zazzara began looking for a home where their family could spread out in Marin County, Calif., they thought what they wanted was a teardown.

headline: Facebook, Don’t Exploit Us in Our Time of Need
abstract: Who seems poised to benefit from social distancing? Big Tech.
lead_paragraph: My relationship with social media? It’s complicated, to say the least.

headline: Coronavirus, Anthony Fauci, Olympics: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Virus Cases Approaching 21,000 in N.Y.
abstract: The White House said the virus “attack rate” in and around the city was five times that of other areas.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Why the American Approach Is Failing
abstract: “Shelter in place” orders and the closing of businesses are a reaction to the failure to act earlier to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: As the Coronavirus Approaches, Mexico Looks the Other Way
abstract: “This is going to be as bad as Italy or worse.” As much of the world shuts down amid the worsening coronavirus pandemic, Mexico City’s streets are bustling and the country’s president insists on calm.
lead_paragraph: “This is going to be as bad as Italy or worse.” As much of the world shuts down amid the worsening coronavirus pandemic, Mexico City’s streets are bustling and the country’s president insists on calm.

headline: Is Pausing Contributions to SEP I.R.A.s a Good Move?
abstract: Self-employed workers use the vehicles to save for retirement. As the coronavirus concerns build, taking a break could be smart.
lead_paragraph: “I’m self-employed. Given economic uncertainty around the coronavirus outbreak, should I still make a contribution to my SEP I.R.A.?”

headline: Turning Back the Clock on Aging Cells
abstract: Researchers report that they can rejuvenate human cells by reprogramming them to a youthful state.
lead_paragraph: Researchers at Stanford University report that they can rejuvenate human cells by reprogramming them back to a youthful state. They hope that the technique will help in the treatment of diseases, such as osteoarthritis and muscle wasting, that are caused by the aging of tissue cells.

headline: Rome’s Homeless Don’t Have the Luxury of Staying Home
abstract: How do you wash your hands without a sink? Stock up on food without money? Or shelter in place when you live on the streets? Charities in the Italian capital are struggling to respond.
lead_paragraph: ROME — For more than two weeks, the Italian government has trumpeted a central message for containing the spread of the coronavirus: Stay home.

headline: Restarting the Economy Is About Lives Versus Livelihoods
abstract: President Trump signaled that he’s open to lifting restrictions soon on social distancing in an effort to restart the U.S. economy.
lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: On Politics: The Economy Won’t Distance
abstract: A new Trump narrative runs counter to the medical consensus: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Mike Pence, left, and Attorney General William Barr conferred as President Trump spoke at the daily White House coronavirus briefing on Monday.

headline: White House Tells Travelers From New York to Isolate as City Cases Soar
abstract: Federal officials said that anyone who left New York recently should self-quarantine at home for 14 days.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Wednesday’s live coverage.]

headline: Real Estate’s Spring Sales Season Slows to a Trickle
abstract: With coronavirus closing offices and shutting down open houses, brokers and sellers hope that sales will pick up again in the summer.
lead_paragraph: By the looks of things in New York City’s real estate market, spring will be a little late this year.

headline: Cathy Yan on the Rerelease of ‘Birds of Prey,’ the Harley Quinn Movie
abstract: The director reflects on her experience making the spinoff, which is getting an accelerated on-demand release amid the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Before Warner Bros. released “Birds of Prey (and the Fantabulous Emancipation of One Harley Quinn)” in February, the studio hoped it would be the next hit in the movie series based on DC superheroes. The film stars Margot Robbie as Harley Quinn, the impish criminal introduced in “Suicide Squad,” as she strikes out on her own after a breakup with the Joker and assembles her own gang of antiheroes (including Ella Jay Basco, Mary Elizabeth Winstead, Jurnee Smollett-Bell and Rosie Perez).

headline: A Good Death Is a Rite of Irish Life. Amid Coronavirus, That Looks Different.
abstract: In Ireland, wakes and funerals typically involve entire communities. But social distancing is changing how those rituals play out.
lead_paragraph: When Betty Ryan died at her home in rural Ireland of complications from cancer last week, her family was understandably distraught.

headline: I.O.C. and Japan Agree to Postpone Tokyo Olympics
abstract: The decision came after swelling resistance from nations and athletes to holding the Games amid the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A week ago, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan and Thomas Bach, president of the International Olympic Committee, were promoting the Summer Olympics in Tokyo as the balm the world needed to show victory over the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Plan Beats No Plan
abstract: The first-mover advantage in Congress.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Don’t Forget About the Census in California
abstract: Tuesday: Here’s what you need to know to be counted. But first, an update from Gov. Gavin Newsom.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
lead_paragraph: $5.3 MILLION

headline: Bohemian or Business: Identities Collide in Miami’s Coconut Grove
abstract: The city’s development boom has finally caught up to a lush haven of shade trees and cafes. Some worry the neighborhood growth is too fast.
lead_paragraph: With its profusion of parks and shade trees, Coconut Grove is celebrated for being one of the greenest parts of sun-baked Miami.

headline: Texas Tries to Balance Local Control With the Threat of a Pandemic
abstract: Texas is the largest state that has not issued a statewide stay-at-home order. With many regions untouched by the coronavirus, Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick wants the economy moving again.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In Texas, where distrust for the state and federal governments runs deep, the State Legislature meets by law as infrequently as possible, once every two years.

headline: ‘Crip Camp’ Review: After Those Summers, Nothing Was the Same
abstract: This feel-good documentary recounts the ties of a Catskills summer camp to American disability rights activism in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: No matter how fondly you recall your time at sleepaway camp, chances are your experiences weren’t as formative as the ones recounted in “Crip Camp: A Disability Revolution,” a documentary streaming on Netflix. The film, directed by a former camper, Jim LeBrecht, and Nicole Newnham, makes the case that a Catskills summer camp for the disabled fostered a sense of community and creativity that fed directly into the American disability rights movement in the 1970s.

headline: China to Ease Coronavirus Lockdown on Hubei 2 Months After Imposing It
abstract: The province will let people outside Wuhan leave for the first time since late January. Despite the official sign of confidence, many fear the virus is still spreading silently.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese province of Hubei, where the coronavirus pandemic began, will on Wednesday begin allowing most of its 60 million residents to leave, ending nearly two months of lockdown and sending a strong signal of the government’s confidence that its tough measures have worked to control the outbreak.

headline: They Overcame Marriage Fears
abstract: Alexa Pulitzer and Seth Levine, both children of divorced parents, say communication is the key to a happy relationship.
lead_paragraph: Because marriage is an ever-evolving experience, we constantly shift, change and, in some cases, start over. In It’s No Secret, couples share thoughts about commitment and tell us what they have learned, revealing their secret to making it work. (Answers are edited for context and space.)

headline: Weekly News Quiz for Students: Congressional Emergency Relief, Joe Biden, Tom Brady
abstract: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?
lead_paragraph: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?

headline: Parents Share Their Tiny Victories While Working From Home With Kids
abstract: Celebrate the little wins.
lead_paragraph: Working from home with kids can be chaos, with interrupted conference calls and meltdowns between meetings, among other challenges. As we try to adjust to this new normal during the coronavirus pandemic, we want to celebrate the small wins from working while parenting. NYT Parenting readers shared their best tips:

headline: The Agonizing Wait for My 4-Year-Old’s Coronavirus Test Results
abstract: As my son’s temperature spiked, so did my anxiety.
lead_paragraph: With his skinny legs poking out of his cotton shorts, I watched my 4-year-old son walk across the empty street toward our neighborhood park last week.

headline: In World’s Most Vulnerable Countries, the Pandemic Rivals the 2008 Crisis
abstract: As capital flees emerging markets, those countries are absorbing the most potent economic shocks of the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: In New Delhi, a fruit vendor whose sales have dropped by half now dilutes the milk she serves to her five children. In central Turkey, a company that runs hot air balloon rides for tourists has banished its 49 employees to indefinite leave while cutting their wages by half.

headline: Janet McTeer Gets a Thrill Out of Watching James Bond. But She Wants to Play Him, Too.
abstract: The actress, whose latest season of “Ozark” arrives on Netflix March 27, says her husband’s poetry and “The Terminator” are essential to her life.
lead_paragraph: For her portrayal of complicated women, Janet McTeer frequently sends audiences into fits of rapture. That includes the co-chief theater critics of The New York Times: Jesse Green called her “a riveting Shakespearean” (in the title roles of “Bernhardt/Hamlet”); and Ben Brantley wrote that she was “the theater’s timely answer to the Hale-Bopp comet” (for her Tony Award-winning Nora in “A Doll’s House”).

headline: Anna Wintour and Tom Ford Are Creating a Fashion Rescue Fund
abstract: They are repurposing the money from an existing award to help the industry get through the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Fashion is no longer just waiting for the government to swoop in and save it.

headline: America’s Next Top Barista
abstract: Competitors trained for months in hopes of winning at the U.S. Coffee Championships in February.
lead_paragraph: Competitors trained for months in hopes of winning at the U.S. Coffee Championships in February.

headline: A Cake to Bring Comfort (to Parents and Kids)
abstract: Amid school closures, canceled trips and uncertainty, head to the kitchen and bake.
lead_paragraph: My family’s color-coded, Google-calendar lives were upended two weeks ago when our daughters’ school abruptly closed, and my husband and I began to work from home in an effort to flatten the coronavirus curve. Suddenly, we went from being busy commuters, who typically see our 5- and 7-year-olds on the weekends and for brief stints in the mornings and evenings, to working full-time at home, while home schooling our girls. Our once color-coded life has become a colorful circus.

headline: Coronavirus Spurs a Wave of Suspect Websites Looking to Cash In
abstract: Hundreds of e-commerce sites are popping up daily to sell virus-fighting products. Many are being shut down for making exaggerated claims or selling phantom products.
lead_paragraph: A popular technology company that has helped launch thousands of online retail sites has become a favorite tool for fly-by-night businesses looking to cash in on the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Density Is Normally Good for Us. That Will Be True After Coronavirus, Too.
abstract: The very thing that has made cities vulnerable in a pandemic has protected them in other disasters.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York was blunt about the rationale behind this time of quarantine.

headline: The Evening News Is Back
abstract: The network newscasts had lost relevance, thanks to cable and digital media. Now, the coronavirus has put tens of millions of viewers back in the 6:30 p.m. habit.
lead_paragraph: Ten million people watched “The Voice” last week, the biggest audience for the NBC reality show in a year.

headline: Great Leadership in a Time of Crisis
abstract: Books from the past show us how John Kennedy, Franklin Roosevelt and Winston Churchill confronted the crises they faced.
lead_paragraph: It was, Arthur Schlesinger Jr. wrote long afterward, “the most dangerous moment in human history.” On the morning of Tuesday, Oct. 16, 1962, John F. Kennedy had reviewed photographic evidence of the deployment of Soviet nuclear missiles in Cuba, just 90 miles off America’s shores. Thus began 13 days of existential crisis. The whole nature of life, the shape and future of humanity, was at stake. The Cuban missile crisis is a thrilling tale — but it is also a chilling one, for the showdown could easily have gone another, darker way, and none of us would be here to learn its lessons.

headline: As Tourism Plummets in Thailand, Elephants Are Out of Work, Too
