lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — In a few hours, Stephen Bruner, the singer and bassist professionally known as Thundercat, had a sold-out show to play at the Fox Theater, a former 1920s movie palace on Telegraph Avenue. Somewhere inside the Fox, there was a dressing room with his name on it. But Bruner’s plan for the afternoon was to stay on the bus, where he feels at home.

headline: There’s No Need for Recipes Now
abstract: Put your own riff on ingredients, using what you have, or riff on Melissa Clark’s riffs: She’s got five highly adaptable recipes worth your time.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I roasted some black sea bass, the fillets painted with a mixture of mayonnaise and sesame oil, oyster sauce, a dash of lime juice, another of honey. I served the fish over rice with a stir-fry of cabbage and pickled chiles. It was fantastically delicious and required no recipe because I was cooking off the top of my head as so many of us are these days. I just stared into the pantry for a while and waited for the muse to arrive with her gift. And then there it was: dinner, salty-sweet-crunchy-spicy-rich. So great!

headline: A Year of ‘What If’ for the N.B.A.
abstract: In this week’s newsletter, Marc Stein discusses the postponement of the Olympics and the basketball connection to his late father.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: As Latin America Shuts Down to Fight Virus, Brazil and Mexico Are Holdouts
abstract: The leaders of the region’s two largest nations — Mexico and Brazil — have largely dismissed the dangers and have resisted calls for a lockdown.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Most leaders in Latin America reacted to the arrival of the coronavirus in the region with speed and severity: Borders were shut. Flights were halted. Soldiers roamed deserted streets enforcing quarantines, and medical professionals braced for an onslaught of patients by building field hospitals.

headline: Jane Goodall Is Self-Isolating, Too
abstract: She’s in England, in the house she grew up in, and she has a few thoughts about chimpanzees, the coronavirus pandemic and the loo paper shortage.
lead_paragraph: Jane Goodall is in isolation these days along with everyone else, since a fund-raising tour was canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic. She is staying at her family home in England, not in Tanzania, her primary home when not on the road.

headline: Trapped at Sea by Covid-19 Lockdowns, Crew Members Plead for Help
abstract: The seafarers who deliver gas, food and medicine are being forced to keep working. They cannot leave the ship: ‘We want to go home.’
lead_paragraph: When Capt. Nilesh Gandhi’s oil tanker docked in coronavirus-ravaged China early last month, he understood that he would not be able to disembark and fly home as planned. He would have to keep working, at least until Singapore.

headline: Dancers Still Need Daily Class. No Barre? Just Grab a Chair.
abstract: We checked in with American Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet to see how the companies were keeping dancers fit, and together.
lead_paragraph: “Are we sweating a little bit?” the ballet master Carlos Lopez said leaning forward and squinting into computer screen. Above his image was a scrolling row of squares — thumbnail videos of dancers from American Ballet Theater — waiting for him to give instructions for the next exercise.

headline: Far-Right Faction of German Populist Party Vows to Dissolve
abstract: The Wing, a group inside the Alternative for Germany party, promised to close down after a warning from the country’s intelligence service, but the change may be mostly cosmetic.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The leaders of a far-right faction inside Germany’s right-wing populist opposition have asked the group’s members to “cease their activities,” an apparent surrender that analysts cautioned was more likely to be a tactical move in the troubled party’s internal power struggles.

headline: A Riff on Sesame Noodles for When You Tire of Peanut Butter Sandwiches
abstract: Excellent cold and at room temperature, make a batch of these nutty, creamy, crunchy noodles in advance, to eat whenever you like.
lead_paragraph: If you stocked your pantry with loads of peanut butter, you might be getting tired of perpetual P.B.&J.s. Or in my case, peanut butter spread on banana slices and sprinkled with flaky sea salt. (Try it before you knock it.)

headline: Citing Death Penalty, U.K. Court Blocks Giving Evidence on ISIS ‘Beatles’ to U.S.
abstract: The decision raised the question of whether the Trump administration will promise not to seek the execution of two ISIS detainees accused of abusing hostages.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The British government must withhold key evidence from the United States for the trial of two Islamic State detainees because the Trump administration has not provided assurances that the men will not be executed, the British Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday.

headline: The Activist Star of ‘Crip Camp’ Looks Back at a Life on the Barricades
abstract: Judy Heumann, a galvanizing force for disability rights in the new Netflix documentary, explains how summer camp set her path.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Crip Camp: A Disability Revolution,” due Wednesday on Netflix after winning accolades at the Sundance Film Festival, drops viewers directly into the lives of disabled teenagers at Camp Jened in the Catskills in the 1970s. There were fun and games — and serious conversation that would propel the nascent disability rights movement.

headline: How New York Changed After the Worst Tragedy Too Few Remember
abstract: Thirty years ago, 87 people died when a jealous lover set a fire at the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx. An oral history of what happened next.
lead_paragraph: Before the fire was out and the smoke had lifted, Ruben Valladares was already in the emergency room with second- and third-degree burns covering half his body. The ambulance call report, handwritten at 3:47 a.m. and updated several times over the next hour, detailed the location of his injuries: “Upper and Lower,” “Entire Face, Back and Buttocks,” “Resp Burns to Nose.” Nurses would note in his chart that Mr. Valladares wasn’t opening his eyes spontaneously.

headline: Nurses Share Coronavirus Stories Anonymously in an Online Document
abstract: A health care worker in New Jersey created a digital venue for people in the field to chronicle poor working conditions that may put patients at risk. “It is disgusting,” one nurse wrote.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,200 health care workers have used a private online document to share their stories of fighting the coronavirus pandemic on the front lines.

headline: Let Them Eat $70 Veal Parm
abstract: The hoarders, the deliverers and what the coronavirus says about class in America.
lead_paragraph: Conservatives’ complaints that the media exaggerates the threat of the coronavirus to make President Trump look bad are at this point drearily familiar. But a few days ago, the Fox News host Steve Hilton added a new twist, an additional reason “our ruling class and their TV mouthpieces” are “whipping up fear.”

headline: New York Nightlife Goes Online
abstract: Clubs like Nowadays, House of Yes and Marie’s Crisis are live-streaming D.J. sets and singalongs.
lead_paragraph: Last Saturday night, when all of New York City’s bars and clubs were closed, a DJ known as Physical Therapy set up a turntable, mixer and webcam in his walk-up apartment in the Ridgewood section of Queens.

headline: How to Clean Your Home for Coronavirus
abstract: It takes only a few minutes, but cleaning high-traffic surfaces once a day can make a difference in preventing the spread of infection.
lead_paragraph: It takes only a few minutes, but cleaning high-traffic surfaces once a day can make a difference in preventing the spread of infection.

headline: How to Wash Your Hands
abstract: It’s one of the most important things you can do to protect yourself, your family and your community. And if you’re like us, you’ve probably been doing it wrong.
lead_paragraph: It’s one of the most important things you can do to protect yourself, your family and your community. And if you’re like us, you’ve probably been doing it wrong.

headline: The Merry-Go-Round Stopped. What Sort of Art Will Emerge?
abstract: The pandemic has not only shut down museums and galleries. It has canceled an entire way of life for contemporary artists — and forces a reconsideration of what all that flying was good for.
lead_paragraph: No museums, no galleries, no fairs, no art schools; no openings, no studio visits, no arguing over beers, no gauche private-jet partnerships. In a matter of days, the world of contemporary art went from a reverberant global network to a ghost town, sheltering in place as the coronavirus endangers our cities and our livelihoods. Like every other sector, art is having to go digital. There is no shortage of artists and critics (including me, all too often) who have bemoaned the way Instagram and other platforms have transformed contemporary art. Count your blessings: Now Instagram is almost all we’ve got.

headline: How Becoming Guardian to an Adult Prepared Me for Motherhood
abstract: Our relationship didn’t fit into the usual mother-son framework, but it gave me a crash course in parental responsibility.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence had been part of my family lore for my entire life. His memory was infallible, and he had a gift with dates. He could calculate which day of the week your birthday would be on in 2050 within a few seconds. Lawrence was also developmentally disabled and had been institutionalized most of his life.

headline: ‘Plz Cancel Our Cleaning’: Virus Leads Many to Cast Aside Household Help
abstract: One family laid off its nanny but wondered if she would video chat with the children for free. Across the country, undocumented household workers are being cast out with little help.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — Late last week, Maria Zamorano, 50, picked up her cellphone to check her messages. “Hi, plz cancel our cleaning for tomorrow,” said one. “Maria, I’m going to have to cancel tomorrow’s cleaning. Thank you,” said another.

headline: Select Film Festivals and Indie Movies Figure Out Online Access
abstract: They were canceled or postponed amid the coronavirus outbreak, but these ad hoc efforts let you support filmmakers and art houses without going to a theater.

headline: Neighbors Are Reaching Out on Nextdoor
abstract: Homebound city dwellers are turning to a neighborhood app to connect, organize and help each other without risking physical contact.
lead_paragraph: “I’m 84 years old, so staying confined to the house for protection,” wrote Marcia Savin, a children’s book author and teacher who lives alone in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn, on the neighborhood social networking app Nextdoor.

headline: Citing Virus, Putin Suspends Vote on Keeping Him in Power
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia postponed a referendum on a constitutional change to term limits and ordered a weeklong national holiday to help halt the spread of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Calling for “discipline and responsibility” in the face of the coronavirus, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Wednesday announced the postponement of a referendum next month on whether he can govern until 2036.

headline: Trump’s Briefings Are a Ratings Hit. Should Networks Cover Them Live?
abstract: The president’s viewership has rivaled the audiences for hit reality shows and prime-time football. But some worry about misinformation.
lead_paragraph: President Trump is a ratings hit, and some journalists and public health experts say that could be a dangerous thing.

headline: Big-Name Hotels Go Empty and Smaller Owners Are Hurt
abstract: More than 90 percent of the hotels in the U.S. are franchised, and these owners say their business has been devastated by the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: It all started to fall apart for Vinay Patel about a week ago.

headline: A Sewing Army, Making Masks for America
abstract: With overrun hospitals facing an acute shortage of masks, people are pulling out their sewing machines to fill the void.
lead_paragraph: They are scrounging for fabric, cutting it up, stitching it together. They are repurposing drapes, dresses, bra straps, shower curtains, even coffee filters. They are building supply chains, organizing workers, managing distribution networks.

headline: The Wealthy Flee Coronavirus. Vacation Towns Respond: Stay Away.
abstract: Tensions mount between New Yorkers with the means to retreat to their second homes and those who live in the towns year round.
lead_paragraph: People with second homes in the Catskills region of New York are being warned to stay away in venom-laced Facebook posts and blunt messages from county officials.

headline: ‘None of Us Saw It Ending This Way’: Peace Corps Volunteers Evacuate Abruptly
abstract: When the agency suspended all operations for the first time in its history, more than 7,000 volunteers in about 60 countries packed their bags, said their goodbyes and rushed to get home.
lead_paragraph: The urgent update from the Peace Corps landed abruptly in the email inboxes of volunteers on March 15: It was time to evacuate.

headline: Jessie Reyez Is Yelling and Loving at the Same Time
abstract: The 28-year-old musician’s debut album “Before Love Came to Kill Us” is meant to motivate people to think about their mortality. Now she’s releasing it during a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Since 2016, Jessie Reyez, a Canadian songwriter whose parents came from Colombia, has built a fervent audience for songs that delve into loyalty and betrayal, ambition and obstacles, heartbreak and vengeance — songs that map the messy, volatile mood swings of 21st-century romance. The 2016 single that brought her international attention, “Figures,” is a ballad built on doo-wop guitar picking that veers between anger and tears; it has been streamed more than 63 million times on YouTube alone.

headline: The Coronavirus and the Postponement of the Olympics, Explained
abstract: Your questions answered on what happened and what’s next with the Summer Olympics now not happening this year in Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of uncertainty amid the coronavirus pandemic, the International Olympic Committee and local organizers of the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo announced on Tuesday that the Games would be postponed.

headline: Climate and the $2 Trillion Stimulus Package
abstract: Also this week, how drought can help the coronavirus spread
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox. (And find the website version of this week’s letter here.)

headline: Virus Rules Let Construction Workers Keep Building Luxury Towers
abstract: The laborers, deemed “essential” by New York, work side by side, often sharing portable toilets that rarely have soap or hand sanitizer.
lead_paragraph: On the Upper East Side of Manhattan, where, like most New Yorkers, residents are largely staying home as the city reels from the coronavirus pandemic, construction workers building a luxury condominium tower are being forced to continue working in confined and often unsanitary conditions.

headline: Economic Crisis Prompts a Showdown, and a Shutdown, in Suriname
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic is but one factor in a confrontation between the South American nation’s business sector and its authoritarian government.
lead_paragraph: PARAMARIBO, Suriname — Suriname ground to a halt on Wednesday as its banks, shops and factories shuttered in a showdown between its beleaguered private sector and its authoritarian government over how to respond to a deepening economic crisis.

headline: Albert Uderzo, 92, Co-Creator of French Comic Series Asterix, Dies
abstract: He teamed up with the writer René Goscinny to create the mustachioed Gaul, whose adventures have sold hundreds of millions of comic books worldwide.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Albert Uderzo, a co-creator of Asterix, one of France’s most revered and longest-running comic book series, died on Tuesday at his home in Neuilly-sur-Seine, a suburb of Paris. He was 92.

headline: Gilead Withdraws Request for Special Orphan Status on Experimental Virus Treatment
abstract: Critics said the company was profiteering from the coronavirus pandemic by seeking tax and monopoly benefits under a program intended to encourage drug development for rare diseases.
lead_paragraph: Bowing to criticism that it was exploiting the coronavirus pandemic, the drugmaker Gilead said on Wednesday that it would no longer seek orphan-drug status for remdesivir, an experimental drug that is being tested as a possible treatment.

headline: Coronavirus Doesn’t Slow Trump’s Regulatory Rollbacks
abstract: The administration is pushing ahead with efforts to roll back environmental protections and impose new limits on how science can be used for making rules.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As much of his government battles the coronavirus outbreak, President Trump is pushing ahead with major reversals of environmental regulations, including a restriction on scientific research that some doctors worry would complicate future pandemic controls.

headline: How to Prevent a Coronavirus Depression
abstract: Think of the strategy as a three-legged stool: mutually reinforcing supports that can’t really work in isolation.
lead_paragraph: There is little doubt that economic data in the weeks to come will obliterate all modern records in their awfulness.

headline: The Winners of Our 2020 Vocabulary Video Contest for Middle Schoolers
abstract: Need a break from the news? Spend a few minutes with these 15-second videos created by students, ages 10-14.
lead_paragraph: This is the first year we have been experimenting with offering our contests, which have long been open to students 13 years old and up, to younger students. And so far, we have not been disappointed with the results.

headline: Britain’s Soap Operas Offer Escape From Coronavirus. For Now.
abstract: Filming has stopped on shows like ‘EastEnders’ and ‘Coronation Street,’ and episodes will air less frequently. Some fans are worried they’ll run out.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last week, Joe Simnett, 19, a college student who lives in Derbyshire, northern England, received some shocking news.

headline: 7 New Books to Watch for in April
abstract: Julia Alvarez’s first new novel in 14 years, an overview of conservative thought, “Notes From an Apocalypse” and more.
lead_paragraph: It’s been 14 years since Alvarez, the author of “In the Time of the Butterflies,” “How the García Girls Lost Their Accents” and other books, published a new novel. Now she returns with the story of Antonia Vega, a retired professor mourning her husband and puzzling over the sudden disappearance of a sister who is “always in crisis.” Antonia’s relationships, with her siblings and with an undocumented teenager she befriends, fuel the story.

headline: Airlines’ New Operating Mode: Flexible
abstract: With pandemic-related travel restrictions in place, airlines are showing a new generosity when it comes to rebooking. Here are the policies of the biggest U.S. carriers.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the coronavirus pandemic and government-imposed restrictions on travel, many airlines are relaxing their ticket-change policies and allowing travelers to rebook without a penalty anywhere from a few to 12 months out.

headline: The Winners of Our 2020 Vocabulary Video Contest for High Schoolers
abstract: The world is a scary place right now. Let us offer you a break from it with these delightful videos created by teenagers.
lead_paragraph: The world is a scary place right now. Let us offer you a break from it with these delightful 15-second videos created by teenagers.

headline: Amid Desperate Need for Ventilators, Calls Grow for Federal Intervention
abstract: President Trump wants the private sector to fill the urgent need for the lifesaving devices. Experts say that strategy may doom the thousands who will need them in the coming weeks.
lead_paragraph: As hospitals prepare for a flood of desperately ill patients unable to breathe on their own, mechanical ventilators have become the single most important piece of equipment that can mean the difference between life and death.

headline: Governors Tell Outsiders From ‘Hot Zone’ to Stay Away as Virus Divides States
abstract: State-to-state travel rules are rarely seen in the United States, but the virus has left some states urging outsiders not to come.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Florida has a message for New Yorkers: Please don’t visit. And if you do, prepare to sit in quarantine or risk jail. Hawaii, which also thrives on tourism, is asking visitors to stay away for a month. And Alaska is requiring a 14-day quarantine for anyone entering from, as Alaskans put it, Outside.

headline: Review: ‘Unorthodox,’ a Stunning Escape From Brooklyn
abstract: A young Hasidic woman’s flight from her marriage and community makes for a modern-day period piece with a striking star performance.
lead_paragraph: Anna Winger was one of the creators behind “Deutschland 83” and “Deutschland 86,” the spy thriller series about East German espionage and the ordinary people who became caught up in the Cold War’s machinations. So “Unorthodox,” a four-part series about a young woman escaping a Hasidic community in present-day Brooklyn, might seem like a departure for her.

headline: Richard Marek, Editor of Hemingway, Baldwin and Ludlum, Dies at 86
abstract: He shepherded more than 300 books into print, including James Baldwin’s “If Beale Street Could Talk” and Robert Ludlum’s “The Bourne Identity.”
lead_paragraph: When Richard Marek was a young editor at Scribner’s in Manhattan in the early 1960s, he was entrusted with one of the literary world’s most important manuscripts, “A Moveable Feast,” Ernest Hemingway’s intimate portrait of his life as an unknown writer in Paris in the 1920s.

headline: Julia Miles, 90, Dies; Pushed for Gender Parity in the Theater
abstract: Concerned that female directors and playwrights were underrepresented in New York theaters, she founded Women’s Project in 1978 to cultivate their work.
lead_paragraph: Julia Miles, who dedicated her career to ensuring that women playwrights and directors had a stage of their own, died on March 18 at a care facility in Ridgefield, Conn. She was 90.

headline: Fine Print of Stimulus Bill Contains Special Deals for Industries
abstract: Small banks, retailers and for-profit colleges got provisions they wanted. So did Boeing. Among those who could potentially benefit: President Trump’s company.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Restaurants and retailers will get a tweak to federal tax law they have been seeking for more than a year that could save them $15 billion. Community banks are being granted their long-held wish of being freed to reduce the amount of capital they have to hold in reserve.

headline: My Coronavirus Routine: A Neighborhood Primal Scream
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic has inspired us to connect with one another while social distancing, no screens required.
lead_paragraph: A few days into social distancing, I learned my daughters’ school would be closed indefinitely. And as the school where I teach had crash-landed into its own eerie spring break, the walls of my house started to close in. My wife and I set up Google Hangout and Google Meet, and weighed the prospects of third-grade virtual reading groups and of all the screen time our daughters might have as we slouched toward our de-limbed lives.

headline: No Single Player Can Win This Board Game. It’s Called Pandemic.
abstract: I created a cooperative game to encourage people to play together. Covid-19 is making it more relevant than ever.
lead_paragraph: Our new reality became very immediate for my wife Donna and me in late February, when she came down with nasty, flulike symptoms and couldn’t get tested for the coronavirus for four long weeks. When she finally did, we were relieved the test came back negative.

headline: A Simple Plan to Help Our Hospitals
abstract: Doctors and nurses are overwhelmed. Nursing and medical students can relieve some of the pressure.
lead_paragraph: Covid-19 is a global pandemic, driving all sorts of large-type drama: cratering economies, overrun medical systems and ongoing political tumult. But in terms of managing it, the devil, as with all health care, is in the details.

headline: ‘What Are the Symptoms?’ ‘What Should I Do if I Feel Sick?’ and Other Coronavirus Questions
abstract: Here’s what to do if you feel sick and are worried it may be the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: More than six months on and the coronavirus continues to spread across the globe. In the United States, where the economy is slowly reopening, infection rates in certain states are surging to pre-lockdown levels.

headline: Jane’s Five Money Moves for 2015
‘The Occupant’ Review: Knock First
abstract: A once-successful man becomes a stalker in this Netflix thriller.
lead_paragraph: Javier (Javier Gutiérrez), the graying ad executive and status-conscious sociopath at the center of David and Àlex Pastor’s sardonic noir “The Occupant,” once made a fortune convincing people that perfection could be theirs for the cost of a fridge. Alas, Javier’s decades-old tagline — “The life you deserve!” — no longer sells, according to his humiliating job interview with two hip marketers who make him feel as musty as the bottom of a work space kombucha keg. When Javier is forced to downsize his family from luxury digs back to a small apartment in a blue collar corner of Barcelona, his aspirational mantra mutates into malevolence toward the up-and-coming young patriarch Tomás (Mario Casas), who’s taken over the lease without realizing that the former resident still has a key to let himself in to use the bathroom (and worse).

headline: Terrence McNally’s ‘Unique Gift’
abstract: “Terrence’s life speaks to what is best and bravest in us all,” says a reader who knew the playwright.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: On the Schedule: Chess, Horse Racing and Children Lifting
abstract: Even the National Spelling Bee was canceled. But you can watch professional athletes work out at home with their children (as both coaches and weights).
lead_paragraph: We’ve been focused on the loss of professional sports worldwide because of the coronavirus, but competitions of all kinds are being postponed and canceled. On Wednesday, the N.H.L. became the latest North American league to announce a round of schedule changes, postponing its scouting combine, annual awards ceremony and draft, all of which had been set to take place in June. There was also deflating news about the Scripps National Spelling Bee and the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.

headline: How to Manage Stress Eating (or Not Eating)
abstract: Coronavirus-related anxiety and changes in your routine may have turned your usual eating habits upside down. Here are some tips to help.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic is unlike anything most of us have ever experienced.

headline: My City Is on the Brink of Disaster. Here’s What That Looks Like.
abstract: Coronavirus has brought us to our knees. But we are still New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: The view from the Brooklyn Bridge is as dazzling as ever.

headline: ‘Threshold’ Resurrects the Angry, Ambitious Young Man
abstract: In Rob Doyle’s novel, a character of the same name drifts, from Paris to Thailand, Croatia and Sicily, doing drugs, mourning his heroes and avoiding writing.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to reading in an emergency, in a moment of crisis and uncertainty, comfort seems to be the order of the day — old favorites, regressive pleasures, cozy classics.

headline: What if I Can’t Pay My Rent Now?
abstract: With a 90-day moratorium on evictions in place, renters can rest easier. What happens after that is less clear.
lead_paragraph: Q: My partner and I are freelancers in creative fields. We suddenly have no work or income because the response to the coronavirus has effectively shut down our industries. The rent is due on our Brooklyn market-rate apartment on April 1 and if we pay it, we will rapidly deplete our very modest savings. What are we supposed to do?

headline: Becoming a Man, Virtually
abstract: We couldn’t have guests, but the bar mitzvah ceremony would go on.
lead_paragraph: My son Zane celebrated his bar mitzvah this past Saturday. And to think I had been worried about a late-season snowstorm.

headline: Coronavirus, India’s lockdown, Jamal Khashoggi: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Tony Awards Postponed Amid Coronavirus Crisis
abstract: The 74th annual ceremony and television broadcast won’t happen until Broadway reopens. How shows will be eligible remains to be determined.
lead_paragraph: Broadway’s biggest night will have to wait.

headline: Birth, in Two Words
abstract: Titanic contractions. Rocket ship. Vomiting chaos. We asked for your birth stories, and you delivered.
lead_paragraph: “Just get them out, I’m ready,” Lisa Lau remembered thinking when her water broke at 35 weeks and 2 days. She had endured what she called “the worst pregnancy ever.” She had hyperemesis gravidarum, was told she had an “incompetent cervix,” and was prescribed three weeks of bed rest and weekly fluid I.V. infusions, before her scheduled cesarean.

headline: Floyd Cardoz, 59, Dies; Gave American Fine Dining an Indian Flavor
abstract: He was the first chef born and raised in India to lead an influential New York City kitchen, at Tabla. He died in the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Stunned by Our Leaders’ Statements on the Coronavirus
abstract: Readers are dismayed by President Trump’s evocation of “packed churches” at Easter and a Texas politician’s suggestion that older people be willing to die. Also: The need for more tests; solar power in the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sanders Is Ready to Debate Again. Biden Says ‘We’ve Had Enough Debates.’
abstract: “I think we should get on with this,” Joe Biden said, dismissing the idea that another debate is needed with his rival, Senator Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: A day after Senator Bernie Sanders’s campaign indicated that he would participate in a presidential debate next month if one is held, Joseph R. Biden Jr. expressed impatience with the idea, saying that “we’ve had enough debates” and adding that his focus was on combating the coronavirus crisis.

headline: What Do Children Have to Say About Learning From Home?
abstract: We would like to hear from students about their experiences with remote learning, including what they like and what they don’t.
lead_paragraph: Parents,

headline: Food Supply Anxiety Brings Back Victory Gardens
abstract: Americans were once urged to plant in every patch of available soil — and produced about 40 percent of the nation’s fresh vegetables.
lead_paragraph: “Small things count,” read a headline in the tiny, insistent pamphlet published by the National War Garden Commission in 1919. The pitch made gardening a civic duty.

headline: Colleges Get Billions in Coronavirus Relief, but Say Deal Falls Short of Needs
abstract: Congress’s emergency coronavirus bill would provide colleges and universities with about $14 billion to weather shutdowns and move to distance learning. That is unlikely to be enough.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The $2 trillion stimulus package passed by the Senate on Wednesday will send about $14 billion to colleges and universities that are hemorrhaging money as they close their campuses and try to stay afloat with distance learning.

headline: A Homeless Family Navigates a Life Warped by the Coronavirus
abstract: April Goode and four of her children moved into a hotel room in New Jersey in February. She had no job and no car. Then the pandemic hit.
lead_paragraph: April Goode awoke shortly before 7 a.m. after a night of restless sleep atop two sleeping bags and a blanket on the floor of her hotel room. Her four children were asleep on the two full beds. Ms. Goode turned on the television and kept the volume low.

headline: Britain Enlists an Army of Volunteers to Help Fight the Coronavirus
abstract: The government has recruited more than 400,000 people to care for senior citizens who have been told to stay at home for 12 weeks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two days after Prime Minister Boris Johnson imposed a lockdown on Britain to curb the spread of the coronavirus, the government has recruited an army of more than 400,000 volunteers to help elderly people quarantined in their homes, as well as the beleaguered public health system.

headline: Need to Escape? Stream These 12 Great Foreign-Language TV Shows
abstract: The fact that they’re subtitled means they require close attention. Maybe it’s not a bad thing to put down the phone.
lead_paragraph: Subtitled television shows have always been a great way to travel vicariously, and that particular thrill has grown exponentially in a time of homebound self-containment.

headline: 13 Deaths in a Day: An ‘Apocalyptic’ Coronavirus Surge at an N.Y.C. Hospital
abstract: Hospitals in the city are facing the kind of harrowing increases in cases that overwhelmed health care systems in China and Italy.
lead_paragraph: In several hours on Tuesday, Dr. Ashley Bray performed chest compressions at Elmhurst Hospital Center on a woman in her 80s, a man in his 60s and a 38-year-old who reminded the doctor of her fiancé. All had tested positive for the coronavirus and had gone into cardiac arrest. All eventually died.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Uzo Aduba Reads ‘How Bibliophiles Flirt’
abstract: The “Mrs. America” and “Orange Is the New Black” actress reads an essay about a book lover’s embarrassing secret.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: How to Get Health Insurance if You’re Worried About Coronavirus or Have Lost Your Job
abstract: There are more options for getting coverage than in past economic crises.
lead_paragraph: Most working-age Americans get their health insurance through their employer. Which means a job loss during the coronavirus pandemic could mean losing your health insurance.

headline: In Praise of a Normal, Boring Country
abstract: A cartoonist finds solace in Estonia's grit, thrift, and good cheer.
lead_paragraph: A cartoonist finds solace in Estonia's grit, thrift, and good cheer.

headline: The Fed Asks for BlackRock’s Help in an Echo of 2008
abstract: BlackRock will advise the Federal Reserve on the purchase of billions of dollars in bonds and securities. The terms of the agreement were not disclosed.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve has turned again to BlackRock.

headline: A Deluged System Leaves Some Elderly to Die, Rocking Spain’s Self-Image
abstract: Even amid the coronavirus crisis, the tragedy unfolding in Spain’s nursing homes has shocked a nation that takes pride in its reverence for older people and in its health care system.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain prides itself on being a tight-knit society that respects parents and grandparents, where powerful bonds across generations mean that the elderly play an integral part in family life, beyond just helping to look after grandchildren.

headline: Can It Still Be ‘Euro 2020’ in 2021? Sponsors Hope So
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic pushed the European Championship to 2021. For companies with warehouses full of Euro 2020 merchandise, it may be better to pretend nothing has changed.
lead_paragraph: European soccer’s governing body, UEFA, posted a message on its Twitter account on Friday evening with a seemingly innocuous update: Its European Championship — another sporting casualty of the coronavirus outbreak — would still be known as Euro 2020, even though it has been postponed until 2021.

headline: Floyd Cardoz Showed How to Honor a Cuisine by Bending It
abstract: The chef, who died Tuesday, created Indian-American dishes that surprised and still linger in the memory.
lead_paragraph: When I heard the name Floyd Cardoz, my mind always went straight to watermelon curry.

headline: In Israel, a Time to Pray Amid a Health Crisis
abstract: When an emergency medical team had a break, they stopped to pray, one member facing Mecca and the other Jerusalem. A photo of it struck a chord.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli ambulance system normally fields about 6,000 calls a day. Since the coronavirus crisis began, it has been averaging an astounding 100,000 calls a day.

headline: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Who Vanished on C.I.A. Mission to Iran Is Most Likely Dead, U.S. Concludes
abstract: The retired agent, Robert Levinson, was said to be the longest-held American hostage in history. A scandal erupted inside the C.I.A. over his disappearance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Trump administration officials have concluded that Robert A. Levinson, the retired F.B.I. agent who disappeared in Iran in 2007 on an unauthorized mission for the C.I.A., died while in Iranian custody, his family announced on Wednesday.

headline: Can You Become Immune to the Coronavirus?
abstract: It’s likely you can, at least for some period of time. That is opening new opportunities for testing and treatment.
lead_paragraph: As the number of people infected with the coronavirus surpasses 450,000 worldwide, and more than one billion are locked in their homes, scientists are wrestling with one of the most pressing questions of the pandemic: Do people who survive the infection become immune to the virus?

headline: Essential? Retailers Like Guitar Center and Michaels Think They Are
abstract: Some chains are loosely interpreting what it means to be a critically important business.
lead_paragraph: At some Guitar Center stores, employees are still allowing customers to try out models of guitars. Dillard’s, a department store chain popular in the South, is still welcoming shoppers looking for clothing and makeup. And Michaels, the arts and crafts chain, says it is keeping many of its stores open to provide supplies to parents teaching their homebound children. “We are here for the makers,” the retailer said in an email to one concerned customer.

headline: Military Judge in 9/11 Trial at Guantánamo Is Retiring
abstract: Col. W. Shane Cohen had served on the case for less than a year and set a January 2021 jury selection date that now appears uncertain.
lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

headline: This Coronavirus Crisis Is the Time to Ease Sanctions on Iran
abstract: Letting up on “maximum pressure” would also be a wise diplomatic move.
lead_paragraph: Iran is in terrible shape. It is among the countries worst hit by the coronavirus — more than 27,000 documented cases to date. Sanctions have choked its economy. Tensions with Washington remain high and the government is incompetent.

headline: Standing Rock Sioux Tribe Wins a Victory in Dakota Access Pipeline Case
abstract: A federal judge on Wednesday struck down permits for the pipeline and ordered a new environmental review of the project.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a significant victory for the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe, a federal judge on Wednesday ordered a sweeping new environmental review of the Dakota Access Pipeline.

headline: Coronavirus Helps Bring Down Kosovo’s Government, With Nudge From U.S.
abstract: Kosovo’s prime minister lost a no-confidence vote on Wednesday, partly because of disputes over how to respond to the pandemic. Critics say American diplomacy also played a role.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The coronavirus crisis contributed for the first time to the collapse of a national government on Wednesday after a majority of lawmakers in Kosovo voted to bring down the country’s ruling coalition, following a political dispute related in part to the pandemic.

headline: Man Suspected of Planning Attack on Missouri Hospital Is Killed, Officials Say
abstract: According to officials, the man had expressed racist and anti-government sentiments.
lead_paragraph: A man suspected of planning to attack a Missouri hospital was killed during a shootout with F.B.I. agents, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: How to Get More Sleep Tonight
abstract: Sleep has never been more important. Here are our most concrete recommendations for getting some.
lead_paragraph: Many people spend their nights now tossing and turning, struggling to unglue from the constant scroll of coronavirus news updates.

headline: Coronavirus and Firearms: Are Gun Shops Essential Businesses?
abstract: Coronavirus anxiety has contributed to a boom in gun sales, but some states have ordered dealers to close alongside other businesses.
lead_paragraph: Groceries. Gasoline. Medical care. Marijuana, in some places. All have been designated essential to society in more than a dozen states that have ordered many other businesses to close.

headline: How the Yankees’ Minor Leaguers Spent 2 Weeks in Quarantine
abstract: A positive coronavirus test for a teammate meant every Yankees minor leaguer had to spend two weeks isolated in Florida. They got creative to keep busy and stay in shape.
lead_paragraph: Thursday was supposed to be Major League Baseball’s opening day. Two weeks later, on April 9, Minor League Baseball was supposed to hold its own.

headline: Coronavirus, Stimulus, Cabin Fever: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: V.A. Criticized for Effort to Keep Some Veterans Away From Private Care During Outbreak
abstract: By Wednesday morning, the White House sought to correct the impression that the department was putting a pause on the Mission Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An effort by the Department of Veterans Affairs to prevent some veterans from seeking health care outside its centers drew heavy criticism from lawmakers and a vocal Fox News ally of the president, who suggested the department’s bureaucracy could undermine a signature program of President Trump’s term.

headline: ‘People Are Dying’: 72 Hours Inside a N.Y.C. Hospital Battling Coronavirus
abstract: An emergency room doctor in Elmhurst, Queens, gives a rare look inside a hospital at the center of the coronavirus pandemic. “We don’t have the tools that we need.”
lead_paragraph: An emergency room doctor in Elmhurst, Queens, gives a rare look inside a hospital at the center of the coronavirus pandemic. “We don’t have the tools that we need.”

headline: After the Lockdown, Fear and Chaos in India
abstract: As panic about the virus escalates, the middle and upper classes are hoarding food, supplies and medicines without a thought for the millions of poor who stand to starve and die.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On Tuesday evening, India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, ordered a strict nationwide lockdown for the next 21 days to battle the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Trump Gets a Bump
abstract: He’s making overly optimistic promises for the country, but new polling is promising for him.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Trump Wants to ‘Reopen America.’ Here’s What Happens if We Do.
abstract: Many could die if we ease up too soon.
lead_paragraph: Many could die if we ease up too soon.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: A $2 trillion package to help the U.S. ride out the pandemic is expected to pass quickly in both houses of Congress.
lead_paragraph: The deal hammered out overnight in Washington for about $2 trillion in federal aid to help the U.S. ride out the pandemic is expected to pass quickly in both houses of Congress — though there was some last-minute squabbling on Wednesday — and get President Trump’s signature soon after that.

headline: Stimulus Money to Protect Elections Falls Short, Critics Say
abstract: State officials and voting rights advocates say the $400 million to safeguard elections in the coronavirus stimulus package is far less than what states will need to implement voting by mail.
lead_paragraph: The $2 trillion stimulus package that was approved by the Senate on Wednesday contains $400 million to address one of the most uncertain impacts of the coronavirus outbreak — its potential to wreak havoc with voting, including the presidential election in November.

headline: Lessons From Lockdown
abstract: Our lives have been upended in ways that portend dire consequences for the country.
lead_paragraph: Two Thursdays ago, I flew to Los Angeles to meet my daughter and cheer her on at her final international Olympic qualifier in fencing. She never boarded her flight because the event was canceled. Now, the entire Olympics is postponed.

headline: Here’s a Coronavirus Quiz
abstract: Test your currency with current events.
lead_paragraph: Test your currency with current events.

headline: Man Pleads Guilty to New Zealand Mosque Massacre
abstract: An Australian white supremacist charged with killing 51 worshipers at two mosques in New Zealand last year changed his plea to guilty in a surprise move.
lead_paragraph: An Australian white supremacist charged with killing 51 worshipers at two mosques in New Zealand last year changed his plea to guilty on Thursday, a move that surprised survivors and relatives of the victims who had hoped to see swift justice for the deadliest act of violence in the country’s history.

headline: Twitter Blocks The Federalist for Promoting Coronavirus Parties
abstract: The action comes as misinformation about the virus has spread rapidly on social media.
lead_paragraph: Twitter on Wednesday temporarily locked the account of a conservative website after it promoted an article suggesting that the medical community should consider intentionally infecting people with the coronavirus at “chickenpox parties” to help slow the spread of the virus.

headline: Richard Reeves, Columnist and Author on Presidents, Dies at 83
abstract: His books on Kennedy, Nixon, Clinton and others could be as unsparing as his syndicated column. He was also a familiar face on PBS public-affairs programs.
lead_paragraph: Richard Reeves, a journalist and author who explored the presidency, the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II, the role of the media and other aspects of American history in muscular, passionate and occasionally acerbic prose, died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 83.

headline: Our Writers Are Also Stuck at Home, So Let’s Chat
abstract: Farhad Manjoo, Elizabeth Bruenig, Charles Blow and other Opinion columnists and writers will be chatting every day at 1 p.m. Eastern.
lead_paragraph: These are strange and scary times. So many people are stuck at home, escaping only for walks during which we wave at people from a safe distance.

headline: Sound in a Circus Act
abstract: Alex Eaton-Salners flies toward the sun.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — One thing I try to hammer home as often as possible is that to be a good solver, you need to be able to think in terms of what other meanings a word might have. The word “book,” for example, is both a noun (“Have you read this book?”) and a verb (“When the coronavirus is a thing of the past, let’s book a weekend away”).

headline: A Cruel Motive for a Costly Delay
abstract: Republican senators threatened to block trillions of dollars in aid amid the coronavirus pandemic to deprive low-wage workers of needed help.
lead_paragraph: This editorial has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: White House Weighs Tariff Delay
abstract: The Trump administration is considering postponing tariff payments on some imported goods for 90 days as part of its response to a faltering economy
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is considering postponing tariff payments on some imported goods for 90 days, according to people familiar with the matter, as it looks to ease the burden on businesses hurt by the pandemic.

headline: Corrections: March 26, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, March 26, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the global competition for a coronavirus vaccine misstated the relationship of one company, Sanofi, to others working in the field. It is working independently on a vaccine, not with Eli Lilly, Johnson & Johnson, Roche and Takeda.

headline: W Magazine Goes on Hiatus, Furloughs Much of Its Staff
abstract: The magazine was sold by Condé Nast just last June.
lead_paragraph: W, the hefty fashion bible known for publishing the adventurous work of top-tier photographers, had long been one of the magazine industry’s most august titles. While it costs less to run than Vogue, it is nevertheless expensive.

headline: A Man Coughed on a Wegmans Employee. Now He’s Charged With a Felony.
abstract: George Falcone told an employee at a grocery store in New Jersey that he had the coronavirus, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey man was charged with making a terroristic threat after he intentionally coughed near a supermarket employee and told her he had the coronavirus, the authorities said on the same day that the Justice Department warned of similar threats to spread the virus.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Construction Workers Balk at Being Kept on the Job
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, March 26, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “I’m essential to the pocketbooks of rich contractors and essential for spreading the virus, but that’s about it.”

headline: When Your Restaurant’s Star Dish Is Blamed for Spreading Coronavirus
abstract: As restaurants around the world close or retool to enforce social distancing, Hong Kong’s hot pot eateries offer a cautionary tale and some good advice.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — What began as a classic Lunar New Year celebration ended with nearly a dozen members of a family sickened and a city of seven million on edge.

headline: Even Before Coronavirus, America’s Population Was Growing at Slowest Rate Since 1919
abstract: As births drop, deaths accelerate and immigration slows, the country is closer than ever to an overall decline.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American population is growing at its slowest pace since 1919, new government data shows, as a drop in births and an acceleration in deaths put the country closer than ever to an overall decline.

headline: New Mexico Agrees to Revamp Its ‘Broken’ Foster Care System
abstract: In a legal settlement set to be announced on Thursday, New Mexico said it would overhaul its foster care system, in what advocates said could serve as a national model.
lead_paragraph: Kevin S., a teenage victim of sexual abuse, has spent most of his life cycling in and out of nearly a dozen foster homes in New Mexico and treatment centers across the West, including one where he claimed he was restrained and “repeatedly harmed” by staff members and other residents.

headline: Europe’s Leaders Ditch Austerity and Fight Pandemic With Cash
abstract: As Britain and the European Union respond to a public health emergency and economic crisis, they are abandoning dogmatic frugality and embracing Keynes.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A British prime minister from the party of Margaret Thatcher has effectively nationalized the national railway system, while forsaking budget austerity in favor of aggressive public spending. Germany has set aside its traditional detestation for debt to unleash emergency spending, while enabling the rest of the European Union to breach limits on deficits.

headline: U.S. Now Leads the World in Confirmed Cases
abstract: Unemployment data set a bleak record and hospitals struggled with an influx of sick patients and lack of equipment. But the White House coronavirus response coordinator dismissed talk of shortages.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read live updates on the coronavirus pandemic here.

headline: G.M. Suspends Production Indefinitely and Cuts Paychecks
abstract: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘1917’ and ‘Unorthodox’
abstract: Sam Mendes’s World War I drama is available for digital rental. And a series based on a memoir by Deborah Feldman debuts on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: 1917 (2019) Rent on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. “1917” may not be the most obvious candidate for at-home viewing, given the emphasis it puts on technical wizardry, but those who missed this ambitious World War I drama from Sam Mendes when it was on the big screen can now rent it from many online platforms. Set in April of the year it’s named for, “1917” stars Dean-Charles Chapman and George MacKay as a pair of British soldiers sent on a dangerous mission to deliver a message to troops on the front line. Their journey, shot by Roger Deakins (who won an Oscar for his cinematography), is made to look as if it were filmed in a single long take. “The round-faced Chapman brings loose, affable charm to his role, while MacKay, a talented actor who’s all sharp angles, primarily delivers reactive intensity,” Manohla Dargis wrote in her review for The New York Times. “This lack of nuance can be blamed on Mendes, who throughout seems far more interested in the movie’s machinery than in the human costs of war or the attendant subjects — sacrifice, patriotism and so on — that puff into view like little wisps of engine steam.”

headline: Boris Johnson Is Not Cut Out for This Crisis
abstract: Britain needs a leader, not a joker.
lead_paragraph: Update: On March 27, Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced in a video posted on Twitter that he had tested positive for coronavirus. He will continue to lead the government while self-isolating.

headline: Coronavirus, Spain, New York: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Word + Quiz: sedulous
abstract: This word has appeared in one article on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Fresh From Iran’s Coronavirus Zone, Now Moving Across Afghanistan
abstract: Thousands of Afghans returning each day bring a risk of widespread infections to the border city of Herat and beyond in a country with little capacity to test for or treat Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: HERAT, Afghanistan — Afghanistan has already imported its epidemic. And each day it adds to it, as thousands more displaced Afghans continue to flow across the border from Iran, which has reported among the world’s highest numbers of Covid-19 cases and deaths.

headline: Helpers
abstract: What heroic acts — big or small — have you witnessed during the coronavirus pandemic?
lead_paragraph: Fred Rogers — known to generations simply as “Mr. Rogers” — famously said he was always comforted by something his mother would tell him during times of disaster: “Look for the helpers. You can always find people who are helping.”

headline: You Are Your Safest Sex Partner. Betty Dodson Wants to Help.
abstract: The nonagenarian masturbation icon is not slowing down.
lead_paragraph: What does it take to make Gwyneth Paltrow blush? Not much more, it turns out, than some explicit coaching on how to tone her pelvic floor. Her instructor, Betty Dodson, the fine artist turned sex educator and evangelist for female self-stimulation, was preaching the benefits of the Kegel-like exercise that Ms. Dodson maintains can help trigger an orgasm.

headline: A Promoter’s Screen Tests Involved Sex on Camera, Lawsuits Charge
abstract: Actresses and models have sued a Brooklyn agent, saying he pressured them into sex. A film depicting one encounter opens online this week.
lead_paragraph: A young actress named Pearl arrives at an apartment in Brooklyn to meet her talent agent for a screen test. But there’s been a change in plans, the agent gently informs her: To make the footage really pop, Pearl will strip nude and have sex with him on camera.

headline: ‘God Will Protect Us’: Coronavirus Spreads Through an Already Struggling Pakistan
abstract: While Pakistan’s government and military are at odds over how to respond, doctors are protesting to get equipment and more testing, and clerics are refusing to limit mosque gatherings.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — Doctors are refusing to show up for work. Clerics are refusing to close their mosques. And despite orders to stay at home, children continue to pack streets across Pakistan to play cricket, their parents unwilling to quarantine them in crowded homes.

headline: She’s an Honors Student. And Homeless. Will the Virtual Classroom Reach Her?
abstract: This week New York City’s public schools began remote learning. But for the more than 100,000 students who are homeless, virtual education may be out of reach.
lead_paragraph: This week New York City’s public schools began remote learning. But for the more than 100,000 students who are homeless, virtual education may be out of reach.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Eating Ice Cream With a Fork
abstract: Can a different tool deliver a tastier bite of this creamy treat?
lead_paragraph: Maya writes: My dad eats ice cream with a fork, straight from the carton, leaving fork tracks. He says it makes it taste better. He’s always trying to get me to do it, and he even forced us to buy “ice cream forks.” Please tell him to let me eat my ice cream with a spoon and stop bugging me.

headline: Yes, You Can Channel Your Stress Into Creativity. Here’s How.
abstract: An art critic shares his best advice for transforming that uncomfortable feeling into a thing of beauty.
lead_paragraph: DRAW IT OUT “My book came out last Tuesday. There was no event. My 45-day book tour? Happily, rightfully, canceled,” says Jerry Saltz, author of “How to Be an Artist,” which makes its debut at No. 12 on the hardcover nonfiction list this week. The art critic, self-proclaimed “failed artist” and winner of the 2018 Pulitzer Prize for criticism is weathering the pandemic with his wife, the Times art critic Roberta Smith, in northwestern Connecticut. Thankfully, he has some words of wisdom for cooped-up people looking to put their nervous energy to good use:

headline: Finding Support After Calling Off the Wedding
abstract: Some brides have daily calls or texts with brides they know after postponing their weddings. Others turn to strangers on social media to help with the effects of coronavirus on long-awaited plans.
lead_paragraph: When Jenna Yarema, a psychotherapist in Austin, Texas, had to postpone her March 29 wedding because of the coronavirus pandemic, there was one consolation: Her childhood best friend was supposed to get married two months later and dealing with the exact same issue. “We’ve been going old-school and calling each other,” she said. “I think we’ve spoken every day.”

headline: Attention, Working Writers: Lorrie Moore Admires What You Do
abstract: “I also admire the ones who are taking a break and not working.”
lead_paragraph: “I also admire the ones who are taking a break and not working,” says the novelist and story writer, whose “Collected Stories” came out this month.

headline: She Wanted an Investment Property She Could Live In. Here’s Where She Found It.
abstract: To keep her budget in check, a young buyer considered adding roommates or leaving Manhattan. Which of these three homes did she choose?
lead_paragraph: To keep her budget in check, a young buyer considered adding roommates or leaving Manhattan. Which of these three homes did she choose?

headline: Poem: How to Survive This
abstract: From Barbara Kingsolver’s timely forthcoming collection of poems, “How to Fly (In Ten Thousand Easy Lessons),” a potent how-to for awkward, complicated days.
lead_paragraph: In the novelist Barbara Kingsolver’s timely forthcoming collection of poems, “How to Fly (In Ten Thousand Easy Lessons),” one section of potent how-tos help guide readers through awkward, complicated days. Refreshing in their direct address — “O misery” — and succinct language, they place momentary dramas into context and provide a wider window in. “Remind me again,” this poem says — but the cure is not immediate, the challenge continues. At least a good night’s rest might help. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: I Never Planned on Being a Playboy Pinup
abstract: In 1995 I modeled as part of a feature on “Women of the Internet.” As the magazine ceases print publication, I’m feeling weirdly nostalgic.
lead_paragraph: The makeup artist spends two hours perfecting your makeup — MAC’s Blankety and Faux lipstick over Spice lip liner, the 1990s nude-lip bombshell trifecta, then tops it all with shimmering crystal gloss.

headline: How Do You Think the Primaries and 2020 Presidential Election Should Proceed?
abstract: Amid the coronavirus pandemic, many people are worried about the safety and feasibility of voting in person. Should elections be canceled or postponed, or should states make health and safety adjustments?
lead_paragraph: The featured article asks the question: “So, what happens when immovable dates become negotiable — when everything does — in the throes of a pandemic? What must hold firm when nothing seems to?”

headline: When the World Stops, Traveling in John Keats’s ‘Realms of Gold’
abstract: In 1820, the British poet spent 10 days quarantined in the Bay of Naples as typhus raged, an enforced stillness mirrored by our own.
lead_paragraph: In October of 1820, typhus raged in Naples. With his artist friend, Joseph Severn, the British poet John Keats rocked in the city’s harbor for 10 days, not nearly the quaranta giorni — 40 days — that give us our word quarantine.

headline: Who Knew Grocery Shopping Could Be So Stressful?
abstract: Pushing a shopping cart, braving crowded aisles and even unpacking bags feel perilous. Here’s our guide to shopping during the coronavirus crisis.
lead_paragraph: As much of the world practices social distancing to stop the spread of coronavirus, trips to the grocery store are one of the few reasons many of us still are allowed to leave the house.

headline: The Coronavirus Becomes an Excuse to Restrict Abortions
abstract: Texas and Ohio say the procedures are nonessential and must yield to the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Ohio’s attorney general ordered abortion clinics in the state to stop performing most surgical abortions. On Monday, the attorney general of Texas issued a stricter directive, applying to “any type of abortion that is not medically necessary to preserve the life or health of the mother” and threatening jail for providers.

headline: Doctors Are Writing Their Wills
abstract: “You feel radioactive,” say doctors who are treating coronavirus patients while trying, desperately, to protect their own families.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Au works at Emory St. Joseph’s Hospital in Atlanta. These days she feels like she works at Chernobyl.

headline: We Must Vote in November. This Is How to Ensure That We Can.
abstract: Elections should not be among the victims of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Voters should not have to choose between casting a ballot and risking their health. They should not have to endure confusion over the location of polling places or the availability of vote-by-mail. Yet voters might face exactly those problems in November if we do not act now to protect the election from Covid-19.

headline: What’s The Best Fix For a Recession?
abstract: And a firsthand account of America’s testing fiasco.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:

headline: Outbreak Ravages N.Y. Budget; Governor Calls Aid Deal ‘Terrible’ for State
abstract: The pandemic is causing a statewide economic slowdown that could result in a loss of $15 billion in tax revenue.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus felled the fixtures of New York’s economic engine: Broadway is dark, Times Square is deserted and Wall Street is in tumult.

headline: My Dad Has Coronavirus. I Don’t Know if I Should Say Goodbye.
abstract: For over a week, my family has been caught in limbo, preparing for the worst.
lead_paragraph: Update: The writer’s father is recovering, and plans to return to work when he is able to.

headline: God Doesn’t Want Us to Sacrifice the Old
abstract: Christianity teaches that every single human life is valuable, even during a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: My grandmother always kept several freezers and multiple pantries loaded down with food, and hid emergency cash in a cubbyhole behind the medicine. As a child, I rolled my eyes at these habits, but she would say, “If you had lived through the Great Depression, you would understand.” I now realize that when I, or my children, are elderly we will be saying similar things to our own grandchildren: “If you lived through the Great Pandemic, you would understand.” I hope the lessons we take from our country’s experience with Covid-19 aren’t about food or avoiding the spread of germs, but about how we treat the most vulnerable among us. A pandemic is no time to turn our eyes away from the sanctity of human life.

headline: When Our (Fictional) Presidents Are Tested by Their Moments
abstract: Sometimes these leaders of the free world rose to the challenge, and sometimes they sunk as low as you can get.
lead_paragraph: Calm authority, an effortless intimacy with the facts, an empathy that’s felt, not merely read off a page: When the American president becomes comforter-in-chief by dint of a national crisis, it’s the toughest part of the gig.

headline: Job Vacancies and Inexperience Mar Federal Response to Coronavirus
abstract: Unfilled jobs and high turnover mean the government is ill equipped for a public health crisis, said many former and current federal officials and disaster experts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Of the 75 senior positions at the Department of Homeland Security, 20 are either vacant or filled by acting officials, including Chad F. Wolf, the acting secretary who recently was unable to tell a Senate committee how many respirators and protective face masks were available in the United States.

headline: What Judaism Teaches Us About the Fear of Death
abstract: A conversation with the Princeton scholar Moulie Vidas on mortality and the embrace of life in Judaism.
lead_paragraph: This is the second in a series of interviews with religious scholars from several faiths — and one atheist — on the meaning of death. The idea for this series, and the content of this interview, originated shortly before the pandemic. Yet all of it has obviously taken on a deeper and more urgent relevance in the midst of this crisis. The essential ideas being discussed here are ones that people everywhere, religious or not, are grappling with.

headline: Should We Still Go Shopping (Online)?
abstract: It has become a moral question as much as a consumer issue.
lead_paragraph: Every day, since late last week, the emails have been landing in my inbox. “New Sale Markdowns!” “Enjoy an additional 20% off!” “Flash 40% Off Sale!”

headline: Will the Supreme Court Protect ‘Ministers’ From Their Church?
abstract: A case will determine the extent to which religious groups are shielded from employee lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court, now even more invisible than usual, may seem beside the point these days, although we saw from the batch of opinions handed down on Monday that the justices are still at work. The 11 cases that were fully briefed and ready for argument this week and next will be heard eventually. I want to focus on one of those cases, a largely overlooked religion case that will have a great deal to tell us about the court’s receptivity to the increasingly audacious claims of religious supremacy now hurtling its way.

headline: ‘It’s a Leadership Argument’: Coronavirus Reshapes Health Care Fight
abstract: Joe Biden and other Democrats were already talking about health care before the coronavirus, but the outbreak gives new urgency to a central issue for the party.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the thorniest debates in American politics is over health care. Now add a pandemic.

headline: In Coronavirus, Industry Sees Chance to Undo Plastic Bag Bans
abstract: Backers of single-use plastic bags, battered by a series of bans nationwide, are using the health scare to argue their bags are cleaner and safer.
lead_paragraph: They are “petri dishes for bacteria and carriers of harmful pathogens,” read one warning from a plastics industry group. They are “virus-laden.”

headline: What Made New York So Hospitable for Coronavirus?
abstract: Despite some obvious suspects, scientists say chance may have played a big role in the explosion of cases.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it was inevitable that New York City and its suburbs would become an epicenter of the coronavirus epidemic in the United States. The population density, reliance on public transportation and constant influx of tourists — all would seem to make the metropolitan area a target.

headline: Will the Coronavirus Make Restaurants Like Mine Extinct?
abstract: If it can, the devastated industry should start from scratch after the epidemic and finally take care of its workers.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I laid off all 30 of my employees and closed the restaurant I’ve run for over a decade, Dirt Candy. I’ve worked shoulder to shoulder with many of these people every night for years.

headline: She’s 10, Homeless and Eager to Learn. But She Has No Internet.
abstract: Thousands of students living in shelters and doubled up in overcrowded apartments have not received web-enabled devices for online learning.
lead_paragraph: Allia Phillips was excited about picking up an iPad from her school in Harlem last week. She did not want to miss any classes and hoped to land on the fourth-grade honor roll again.

headline: The World Is Running Out of Places to Store Its Oil
abstract: A chaotic mismatch between the supply and demand for oil is saturating the world’s ability to store it all.
lead_paragraph: The world is awash in crude oil, and is slowly running out of places to put it.

headline: Meet the Team Producing the Newspaper From Home
abstract: In response to the coronavirus pandemic, nearly all editors and designers are working remotely for the first time in the history of The Times.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Surging Traffic Is Slowing Down Our Internet
abstract: With people going online more in the pandemic, internet traffic has exploded. That’s taking a toll on our download speeds and video quality.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In late January, as China locked down some provinces to contain the spread of the coronavirus, average internet speeds in the country slowed as people who were stuck inside went online more and clogged the networks. In Hubei Province, the epicenter of infections, mobile broadband speeds fell by more than half.

headline: New Orleans Faces a Virus Nightmare, and Mardi Gras May Be Why
abstract: Louisiana may be experiencing the world’s fastest growth in new cases. Medical experts said Mardi Gras might have accelerated the crisis.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Yanti Turang, an emergency room nurse at a New Orleans hospital, walked out into the parking lot in full protective gear early this month to meet a woman with flulike symptoms who had just returned home after a layover in South Korea. The woman was immediately taken to an isolation room.

headline: ‘We’re in Disaster Mode’: Courage Inside a Brooklyn Hospital Confronting Coronavirus
abstract: Test kits and protective gear have been in short supply, doctors are falling sick, and every day gets more difficult. But the staff keeps showing up.
lead_paragraph: It was not even 9 in the morning and Dr. Sylvie de Souza’s green N95 mask, which was supposed to form a seal against her face, was already askew.

headline: It’s Opening Day. Baseball Is Closed.
abstract: Instead of red, white and blue bunting and crowds flooding ballparks, we have players holed up in homes and endless questions about when baseball will return. When it does, it will be more important than ever.
lead_paragraph: Leave it to Rogers Hornsby, who starred for the St. Louis Cardinals a century ago, to find the words that neatly fit our troubled times.

headline: Coronavirus, Jobless Claims, New Zealand: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Virus Cases in State Top 30,000
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said there were signs that density-control measures could be slowing the virus’s spread.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: What You Can Do About Coronavirus Right Now
abstract: You have an essential role to play in slowing the spread of the new coronavirus. Here is some practical advice from doctors and public health experts on how to protect yourself and your community.
lead_paragraph: You have an essential role to play in slowing the spread of the new coronavirus. Here is some practical advice from doctors and public health experts on how to protect yourself and your community.

headline: A Historic Stimulus Bill
abstract: After years of polarization, both parties in the Senate have unanimously passed a $2 trillion economic relief package — the largest in modern American history.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: A.I. Versus the Coronavirus
abstract: A new consortium of top scientists will be able to use some of the world’s most advanced supercomputers to look for solutions.
lead_paragraph: Advanced computers have defeated chess masters and learned how to pick through mountains of data to recognize faces and voices. Now, a billionaire developer of software and artificial intelligence is teaming up with top universities and companies to see if A.I. can help curb the current and future pandemics.

headline: A Family Heirloom, Restored From Hood to Taillights
abstract: A Ford Model A that has been part of one family’s lives across five generations got a 30-year restoration.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — “We’ll get this done by the end of summer.”

headline: How You Can Protect Your Community, Not Just Your Own Health
abstract: The drastic changes in economic and social behavior needed to stop the coronavirus require active community engagement, two economists say. Here are lessons from the Ebola epidemic.
lead_paragraph: Stemming the spread of the coronavirus is already requiring radical changes in behavior.

headline: Online, the Show Goes On. But It’s Just Not the Same.
abstract: The recorded performances that theaters in Germany have put online while they are closed don’t live up to the real thing, our critic says.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Germany’s robust cultural scene was among the first casualties of the coronavirus. On March 10, the country’s hundreds of theaters and opera houses began shutting down. Stages will remain dark until at least April 19.

headline: F.A.Q. on Stimulus Checks, Unemployment and the Coronavirus Plan
abstract: The $2 trillion relief package is sending money directly to Americans, greatly expanding unemployment coverage and making a number of other changes.
lead_paragraph: [Read our Coronavirus Relief Small Business F.A.Q.]

headline: Preparing for Millions of Layoffs
abstract: Unemployment claims are about to dwarf anything seen before.
lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: ‘Tape’ Review: That’s (Not) Entertainment
abstract: Two aspiring actresses face the same abuser in Deborah Kampmeier’s over-sauced revenge story.
lead_paragraph: A horror movie of sorts, Deborah Kampmeier’s “Tape” is a bludgeoning feminist tract, a grim P.S.A. about casting-couch predation and female subjugation. Leaden with references to rape culture and objectification — as well as the entertainment miscreants Roman Polanski and Bill Cosby — the script is suffocatingly, almost comically, on the nose. “Tape,” in short, is a terrible movie about appalling behavior.

headline: ‘Banana Split’ Review: Preparing for the Worst and Finding a Bestie
abstract: Rivals Hannah Marks and Liana Liberato bond behind a boyfriend’s back in this familiar but engaging teenage comedy.
lead_paragraph: The comedy “Banana Split” hits the ground running with a montage that recaps a two-year high school relationship. While most of the movie doesn’t run on fast-forward, it never quite loses its snap. The plot centers on April (Hannah Marks), who, while still reeling from her breakup with Nick (Dylan Sprouse), discovers that he has found a new girlfriend, Clara (Liana Liberato), who has just moved to Los Angeles.

headline: ‘Vivarium’ Review: This Is Not Your Beautiful House
abstract: Jesse Eisenberg and Imogen Poots play a young couple trapped in a housing project and given an onerous task: child rearing.
lead_paragraph: Jesse Eisenberg and Imogen Poots play Tom and Gemma, a young couple looking for a home. Gemma’s a schoolteacher and Tom a landscaper, so they’re not getting too fancy. They look into a suburban housing development called Yonder.

headline: On Politics: The Bill’s Being Sold. Does It Have the Goods?
abstract: Criticism from Cuomo and provisions for interest groups: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo on Monday at the Javits Center in New York, where workers from the Federal Emergency Management Agency were constructing a makeshift hospital for coronavirus patients.

headline: N.Y.C. Death Toll Hits 365 as Case Count Tops 23,000
abstract: Governor Cuomo said that one factor in the rising death toll across the state was older patients staying on ventilators longer.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Friday’s live coverage.]

headline: ‘Resistance’ Review: Save the Children
abstract: In this disjointed Holocaust drama starring Jesse Eisenberg, a French actor leads Jewish orphans to safety.
lead_paragraph: Dousing us alternately in treacle and ice water, Jonathan Jakubowicz’s World War II drama, “Resistance,” strains to find a cohesive tone. Outlining the true story of how the young Marcel Marceau, the renowned French actor and mime, helped Jewish orphans survive Nazi-occupied France, the movie aims to wrestle uplift from tragedy.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘5 Key Things in the $2 Trillion Coronavirus Stimulus Package’
abstract: In this lesson, students will consider what the largest economic stimulus measure in modern history means for businesses and workers, and consider the question: Is it enough?
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “5 Key Things in the $2 Trillion Coronavirus Stimulus Package” by Catie Edmondson

headline: Fed’s Powell Says U.S. Must Get Virus Under Control Before Economy Restarts
