abstract: The Federal Reserve chair voiced a reassuring, if uncertain, message in a rare televised interview as the coronavirus grinds America’s economy to a halt.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said during a rare television interview on Thursday that the United States “may well” be in a recession already, but that it should get the coronavirus under control before getting back to work.

headline: The Least Our Freeloading Son Could Do Is Practice Social Distancing
abstract: We do everything for him. Why can’t he do this one thing for us — and for the public?
lead_paragraph: My wife and I have a 25-year-old son who has sadly failed to launch. He lives in a shared apartment with many roommates. Still, he brings his dirty laundry home and eats dinner with us frequently because, we suspect, it’s free. He hasn’t found anything like a career path. We can almost deal with all of this. What we can’t deal with is his irresponsible behavior during our national period of “social distancing” to help contain Covid-19. When we challenge him about his partying and hanging out with large groups of friends, he shrugs us off — as if he wasn’t endangering himself and others. Any advice?

headline: Can Hip Rolls Help? Finding Uplift in Debbie Allen’s Instagram Class
abstract: Our writer hadn’t thought much about fun or joy, or about the bawdiness that comes out of a funk beat. But Ms. Allen had.
lead_paragraph: It was a gray Wednesday afternoon when I stepped onto my Brooklyn rooftop, balanced my phone gingerly on a tub of tar and a chimney railing, and began to dance.

headline: Europe Fumbled Coronavirus at First. Can It Manage the Pandemic Now?
abstract: A crisis that shut borders across the continent could yet end with a stronger European Union.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — With the rapid spread of the new coronavirus, the flattened world has developed a few speed bumps. With trade disrupted and economies paralyzed, some consider that the nation-state is back, as if it ever went away.

headline: ‘The Platform’ Review: An Accidentally Timely Political Allegory
abstract: Netflix’s gnarly class commentary certainly isn’t subtle. But it gets the job done.
lead_paragraph: Galder Gaztelu-Urrutia’s horror thriller “The Platform” has been a regular fixture on Netflix’s daily Top 10 since it hit the streaming service last Friday, and no wonder: with its generous helpings of cannibalism, suicide, starvation, blood, guts and feces, how could it not be a crowd-pleaser? A gnarly mash-up of midnight movie and social commentary, the picture is overly overt but undeniably effective, delivering genre jolts and broad messaging in equal measure.

headline: Japan’s Virus Success Has Puzzled the World. Is Its Luck Running Out?
abstract: The country has not widely tested. Its people are going about their lives, even crowding into clubs that had previous outbreaks. But now Japan is warning of the risk of rampant infection.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan had only a few dozen confirmed coronavirus infections when the 30-something nurse with a slight sore throat boarded a bus to Osaka, the country’s third-largest city, to attend a Valentine’s weekend performance by pop bands at a music club.

headline: Worried About Paying Your Rent or Mortgage in California?
abstract: Thursday: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced protections for homeowners. But many renters are still on the hook. Also: Cultivating your own garden.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The T List: Four Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: A postcard from an elusive desert landscape — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Why the U.S. Lagged Behind in the Drive to Postpone the Summer Olympics
abstract: New leadership was intended to build trust and confidence following an abuse scandal, but athletes say they are frustrated the organization fell behind in the groundswell to postpone the Games.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, after revelations a team doctor had abused hundreds of gymnasts, the United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee underwent an overhaul designed to restore and instill confidence and trust among thousands of American athletes.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, Turtle Bay and Jackson Heights, Queens.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, Turtle Bay and Jackson Heights, Queens.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens
abstract: This week’s properties are in Clinton Hill, Turtle Bay and Jackson Heights.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Purchase, N.Y., and a two-bedroom in Darien, Conn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Purchase, N.Y., and a two-bedroom in Darien, Conn.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Purchase, N.Y., and a two-bedroom in Darien, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: How Long Will This Last?
abstract: A long time, under almost any scenario.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Apollo Theater’s Amateur Night Auditions Go Digital
abstract: The coronavirus has made in-person auditions impossible, so contestants can submit videos up to five minutes in length for the chance to compete for $20,000.
lead_paragraph: Ella Fitzgerald first performed at Amateur Night at the Apollo Theater in Harlem when she was 17 years old. “She started her singing career here,” said Kamilah Forbes, the Apollo’s executive producer.

headline: ‘It’s a Wreck’: 3.3 Million File Unemployment Claims as Economy Comes Apart
abstract: The weekly figure is among the first data on the economic toll of the vast disruption of normal life and commerce caused by the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: More than three million people filed for unemployment benefits last week, sending a collective shudder throughout the economy that is unlike anything Americans have experienced.

headline: Unprepared for the Worst: World’s Most Vulnerable Brace for Virus
abstract: Crowded camps, depleted clinics and scarce soap and water make social distancing and even hand-washing impossible for millions of refugees.
lead_paragraph: In an embattled enclave in Syria, doctors have seen patients die from what looks like the coronavirus but are unable to treat them because they lack beds, protective gear and medical professionals. A refugee camp in Bangladesh is so cramped that its population density is nearly four times that of New York City, making social distancing impossible. Clinics in a refugee camp in Kenya struggle in normal times with only eight doctors for nearly 200,000 people.

headline: The Saint Who Stopped an Epidemic Is on Lockdown at the Met
abstract: Quarantined in Sicily, van Dyck painted a daughter of Palermo who saved the city from an outbreak. Our critic went to see her in an empty museum.
lead_paragraph: He is dapper, beaming with the confidence of youth; he does not have the temperament for sheltering in place. It’s springtime, the year is 1624, and the 25-year-old Anthony van Dyck is sailing south, to Sicily, where he has been invited to paint the island’s Spanish viceroy.

headline: How We Got By: New Yorkers’ Advice for Getting Through a Crisis
abstract: Tales from the worst days of people's lives.

headline: More Than 3 Million Americans Lost Their Jobs Last Week. See Your State.
abstract: Official statistics have revealed how severely coronavirus has hurt the job market. But it may take several months before we know whether this economic disaster will resemble a storm or a long winter.
lead_paragraph: Official statistics have revealed how severely coronavirus has hurt the job market. But it may take several months before we know whether this economic disaster will resemble a storm or a long winter.

headline: Doctors Expect a ‘Huge Spike’ in Pediatric Injuries at Home
abstract: With children cooped up at home because of the coronavirus, experts warn they may be at higher risk for bumps, scrapes, broken bones and more.
lead_paragraph: I was on a work call last week when I first heard her wails. I peeked out the window next to my desk and saw my 5-year-old splayed across our driveway, next to her bike, screaming. Then, I saw my 8-year-old help her stand up. I texted my husband: “I think she’s hurt.” Two minutes later, he was carrying my daughter inside.

headline: Venezuelan Leader Maduro Is Charged in the U.S. With Drug Trafficking
abstract: Federal prosecutors accused President Nicolás Maduro of participating in a narco-terrorism conspiracy, in a major escalation of the Trump administration’s efforts to pressure him to leave office.
lead_paragraph: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela was indicted in the United States on Thursday in a decades-long narco-terrorism and international cocaine trafficking conspiracy in which, prosecutors said, he led a violent drug cartel even as he ascended to the top of government.

headline: Trump’s ‘Disaster Diplomacy’ Has So Far Had Few Results
abstract: North Korea and Iran have not taken him up on the offer for aid on combating the coronavirus. And Russia and China have extended similar offers of help to the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the coronavirus raced across the globe earlier this year, the Trump administration offered assistance to a pair of longtime American enemies, Iran and North Korea. The responses hardly amounted to a diplomatic breakthrough.

headline: 18 Cookbooks for Comfort
abstract: In this uncertain time, here are the cookbooks Food reporters and editors turn to for reliably delicious results.
lead_paragraph: In the age of Google, when practically every recipe imaginable is just a few clicks away, real-life cookbooks are often relegated to a crowded shelf or tossed into the “donate” pile. Now that many of us are stuck at home, perhaps it’s time to dust off (or buy) a good old-fashioned cookbook and dirty the pages by cooking something from it. If you’re in the market, here are the cookbooks Food reporters and editors love for the most reliable results.

headline: Coronavirus Is Idling North Korea’s Ships, Achieving What Sanctions Did Not
abstract: North Korean ships distance themselves from Chinese ships and territory, bringing the country’s revenue stream from illicit exports of coal and other commodities to a sudden halt.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has called the coronavirus “the invisible enemy.” But when it comes to sanctions on North Korea, the pathogen may turn out to be his administration’s most effective ally.

headline: W.N.B.A. Will Hold ‘Virtual’ Draft in April
abstract: The league is keeping its scheduled date of April 17 but adapting the format to allow draftees to have their moment in the spotlight no matter where they are.
lead_paragraph: The W.N.B.A. plans to hold its draft as scheduled in April, using video conferencing in hopes of recreating the moment so many athletes say they dream about: when a league commissioner hands them a jersey and their professional lives begin.

headline: On Russia-China Border, Selective Memory of Massacre Works for Both Sides
abstract: The countries agree a mass killing occurred on the Amur River in 1900. They would just prefer not to discuss it right now.
lead_paragraph: VERKHNE-BLAGOVESHCHENSK, Russia — The crime scene is a riverbank from which Russian Cossacks drove thousands of Chinese to their death by drowning in the Amur River 120 years ago. On a nearby hill stand a bronze memorial statue and a concrete Orthodox cross.

headline: The New Travel Document: Photograph of an Empty Plane
abstract: The dramatic falloff in air travel is captured in travelers’ photographs of their recent flights.
lead_paragraph: The story of air travel’s shutdown can be told in numbers.

headline: GoFundMe Confronts Coronavirus Demand
abstract: Americans are turning to crowdfunding to cover coronavirus-related costs while the government prepares to deliver on its stimulus plan. But most campaigns aren’t meeting their goals.
lead_paragraph: When the governor of Connecticut ordered all restaurants in the state to close on March 16, Colt Taylor quickly applied for a disaster loan from the Small Business Administration and called an emergency meeting to tell the 31 employees at his two restaurants that he could no longer pay them.

headline: U.S. Army Halts Training Over Coronavirus but Then Changes Its Mind
abstract: The infection rate within the American military has shot up to a degree some officials find alarming.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Army earlier this week ordered a halt to most training, exercises and nonessential activities that require troops to be in close contact, military officials said, but abruptly reversed itself days later even as the infection rate within the American military shot up.

headline: A Paris Opera Conductor Comes Full Circle
abstract: Philippe Jordan talks about his new role in Vienna and his farewell to Paris: a new staging of Wagner’s “Ring,” which he conducted there in 2010.
lead_paragraph: After over a decade as music director of the Paris Opera, the conductor Philippe Jordan is preparing to enter a new phase of his career at the Vienna State Opera. He bids farewell with the same work that won over the French capital’s audience in 2010: Wagner’s “Ring.”

headline: Onetime Relic, Then Hipster Fad, Milkmen Embrace Flood of Clients
abstract: An industry that symbolized the distant past has grown in recent years. Now, with the coronavirus, milkmen are deluged with customers.
lead_paragraph: LEEDS, England — The problem, for Peter Critchley, is that the phone just keeps ringing. At least 30 calls a day, every day. Then there is the online backlog: He has 100 more requests on his website to wade through every evening. He has already added some 600 new customers, and more just keep coming.

headline: Benny Gantz, Breaking Vows, Says He Would Serve Under Netanyahu
abstract: Citing the coronavirus pandemic, Mr. Gantz, who nearly defeated Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in three straight elections, said he would explore forming a “national emergency government.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was set to hold onto power after his chief rival, Benny Gantz, reversed himself Thursday and signaled that he would be open to serving in a Netanyahu-led government.

headline: Bad Bunny Finds Gold in the Past, While J Balvin Is Trapped in the Future
abstract: New albums by two of Latin pop’s biggest stars find them chasing inspiration in opposite directions, with contrasting results.
lead_paragraph: “Safaera” arrives in the middle of Bad Bunny’s second album, “YHLQMDLG,” like a gut punch of memory. The mood is early to mid-2000s: the hard-snapping vintage reggaeton production redolent of the Luny Tunes’ pioneering “Mas Flow” compilations; the tinny, wobbly melody line familiar from Missy Elliott’s “Get Ur Freak On”; the guests, Jowell & Randy and Ñengo Flow, flashes from the genre’s past.

headline: Pablo Escobar’s Hippos Fill a Hole Left Since Ice Age Extinctions
abstract: Invasive herbivore mammals seem to restore functions missing in some food webs and ecosystems since the Pleistocene era.
lead_paragraph: When Pablo Escobar died in 1993, the Colombian drug kingpin’s four adult African hippopotamuses were forgotten. But the fields and ponds along the Magdalena River suited them. One estimate puts their current population at 50 to 80 animals: By 2050 there may be anywhere from 800 to 5,000 in a landscape that never before knew hippos.

headline: Fossils Show Raptors Prowled North America Late in Dinosaurs’ Era
abstract: They were smaller than the creatures that savaged “Jurassic Park,” but may have had superior ability to stalk and take down prey.
lead_paragraph: One day in 2008, a lethal weapon from a bygone era spilled out of a hillside in New Mexico.

headline: Small Businesses Will Get Help Paying Workers, if They Can Wait
abstract: The stimulus package includes more than $370 billion in government-backed bank loans that, in some cases, borrowers won’t have to repay.
lead_paragraph: [Read our Coronavirus Relief Small Business F.A.Q.]

headline: How to Freeze Just About Everything
abstract: Wondering how you can make the most of your freezer and your food? Melissa Clark can help.
lead_paragraph: The pantry is all well and good for laying in nonperishables. But what about your freezer?

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Coronavirus Protective Measures
abstract: How can social distancing affect the chain of coronavirus transmission?
lead_paragraph: This graph appeared elsewhere in The New York Times.

headline: ‘I Never Knew Anyone Less Jaded’: Admiring Terrence McNally
abstract: Audra McDonald, Lin-Manuel Miranda and Joe Mantello on a versatile collaborator who came to know “he didn’t have to repeat himself.”
lead_paragraph: One builds a lot of relationships over a career covering nearly six decades, and the playwright Terrence McNally, who died of coronavirus complications on Tuesday, could count on an extraordinary number of them. Many of these bonds were distinguished by an enduring loyalty, and they ranged widely in the American performing-arts scene — McNally wrote plays, books for musicals, opera librettos and screenplays. Below are reminiscences from his collaborators and peers. Some were collected by email, others by telephone; they have been edited for length and clarity.

headline: The Challenge of Feeding Kids During Coronavirus
abstract: It’s OK to let children indulge in their favorite foods while riding out the crisis. Plus: resources for food-insecure families.
lead_paragraph: As we slog through another week of self-isolation, quarantine or even total lockdown, parents stuck at home with young children are grappling with how to keep everyone well-fed … meal after meal, snack after snack, day after day. I’ve rounded up some common questions and sought answers from two dietitians, a pediatrician and an anti-hunger advocate.

headline: What to Know About Making a Will in the Age of Coronavirus
abstract: Estate planning lawyers we talked to this week said they had been getting more calls since the outbreak worsened.
lead_paragraph: When Joel Solomon sold his financial services firm in mid-January, he had been planning to call his estate lawyer to update his will and trusts. But with coronavirus cases spiking, Mr. Solomon and his wife, Nancy, decided to act immediately.

headline: When Dementia Meets the Coronavirus Crisis
abstract: Disruptions in routines and the need for hands-on care are among the special challenges for dementia patients and their caregivers.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus advances, it is taking a particularly harsh toll on the many who are caring for a loved one with dementia or Alzheimer’s, the most common form of dementia. According to a report by the Alzheimer’s Association, more than 16 million Americans are providing unpaid care for those with Alzheimer’s or other types of dementia. For them the virus is “really a double whammy,” said Lynn Friss Feinberg, a senior strategic policy adviser at AARP’s Public Policy Institute. “You’re worrying about your own health and that of your family member.”

headline: The Fourth Wall Is My Laptop Screen
abstract: When theaters closed by the pandemic stream their shuttered plays online, watching sharpens the longing for the real thing.
lead_paragraph: I wanted to climb right through the screen into a seat a few rows from the stage.

headline: Coronavirus on Long Island: 6 Die in Outbreak at Retirement Community
abstract: An upscale waterfront community in New York and a nursing home in New Jersey are the latest epicenters, sparking fears of an even bigger outbreak among a vulnerable, confined population.
lead_paragraph: The first sign appeared two weeks ago, when an employee tested positive for coronavirus. By Wednesday, Peconic Landing, an upscale elder community on the North Fork of Long Island, announced its sixth death from the virus, sparking fears of an even bigger outbreak among a vulnerable, confined population.

headline: A Pod From Both Our Houses
abstract: A new season for a new time.
lead_paragraph: From our living rooms to yours, “Still Processing” is back.

headline: An Omelet With an Unexpected Creamy Filling: Tahini
abstract: Cheese is the typical omelet filling, but for a similar richness that’s also dairy-free, try tahini.
lead_paragraph: I’ve spent the past year so enamored of jammy-yolked eggs that I almost forgot about the beauty of a classic French omelet.

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Are you finding it tough to read right now? Week in and week out, the authors who answer our By the Book questions tell us that their ideal reading experience involves nesting in place with all outside obligations erased — a pretty good description of where the coronavirus pandemic has obligingly left us, if you can tune out the crippling anxiety and the very real, very scary implications for our health and our economy and the fabric of our society. It turns out that peace of mind is as important for reading as time and a comfortable chair. Who knew?

headline: Don’t Get What’s So Great About Westerns? Start Here
abstract: The films of Budd Boetticher and Randolph Scott are short but complex and suspenseful. And the wide-open vistas are sure nice, right now.
lead_paragraph: Even those of us who have devoted tens of thousands of hours to watching films have blind spots — important pathways of cinema history that we’ve never ventured down, or, perhaps even more embarrassingly, major movies whose greatness we’ve never quite grasped. But being shut in is the perfect time to open doors. So here is a new column, focusing on gateway movies. If you’re unfamiliar with an essential director, I will recommend the ideal place to start. If you’ve always felt a particular type of movie was not for you, the goal is to change that.

headline: Dance, Theater and More: Works to Experience at Home This Weekend
abstract: Our writers are usually busy covering performances. Coronavirus changed that. Here are their suggestions for what to watch, read or listen to while we’re housebound.
lead_paragraph: The saxophonist and composer Roscoe Mitchell is best known as a founding member of the Art Ensemble of Chicago. But even when operating outside that pan-stylistic group, his approach contains multitudes. When I reviewed Mitchell’s concerts at the Park Avenue Armory in 2019, I marveled at his solo-saxophone heroics and meditative chamber music designs.

headline: Desperately Seeking Hope and Help for Your Nerves? Try Reading ‘Hope and Help for Your Nerves’
abstract: Claire Weekes, a pioneer in treating anxiety, offered simple and soothing advice that has come to influence much of our approach to panic.
lead_paragraph: I felt the rumblings of a panic attack just now, while I was typing. It starts with a burning sensation in my temples. My chest tightens up a little, suddenly corseted, and my vision tunnels like one of those old Western photos in which everyone is grim-faced. That is merely the prequel.

headline: New York Art Galleries: The Virtual Experience
abstract: Tarsila do Amaral’s drawings are among dozens of landscapes of Brazil you can view from home. Ditto with Guanyu Xu’s photo installations.
lead_paragraph: Lecturing in Buenos Aires two years ago, the novelist J.M. Coetzee — born in South Africa, now a citizen of Australia, and teaching regularly in Argentina — argued that the southern hemisphere has a big problem: Its artists and writers can only win global attention by pleasing “the cultural gatekeepers of the metropoles of the north,” who “decide which stories by the south about itself will be accepted.” It’s exactly these contesting gazes on the spaces of the south, by colonizers and colonized, that animate a rich exhibition staged by the Brazilian gallery Mendes Wood DM at its New York outpost.

headline: Baseball Season Opens With a Dash of Imagination
abstract: Complaints of baseball’s slow pace yielded to the universal wish that this game would last forever.
lead_paragraph: Professional baseball greeted a new season this afternoon with an Opening Day game for the ages, an extra-inning masterpiece that vividly unfolded on the sun-dappled field of the imagination. The crack of the bat could almost be heard, the blur of white almost seen, the communal joy nearly felt.

headline: Neanderthals Feasted on Seafood, Seabirds, Perhaps Even Dolphins
abstract: Scientists say that a discovery in a seaside Portuguese cave further challenges popular images of Neanderthals as meat-eating brutes.
lead_paragraph: Neanderthals are often portrayed chowing down on mammoth meals and woolly rhino ribs. But an analysis of their leftovers from a coastal cave in Portugal suggests fish and mollusks claimed a special place on their Paleolithic palates.

headline: A Glamorous, ’70s-Style Retreat in Downtown Manhattan
abstract: The interior designer Alex P. White transformed two rooms with little natural light into a moody oasis.
lead_paragraph: A concrete-ceilinged two-room apartment on the fourth floor of an 11-story building on Manhattan’s Lower East Side gets little natural light — very little. But this didn’t prove particularly daunting for the New York- and Los Angeles-based interior designer Alex P. White, 50, who was tasked with designing this compact space on Orchard Street last spring. White, who trained as an artist before working with the acclaimed interior designer Kelly Behun and then going out on his own three years ago, favors dark, moody lighting anyway; his Instagram page is filled with vintage photos of interiors that, unlike the bright rooms seen in home magazines today, were taken after sundown. After all, says White, “that’s when we spend the most time at home — at night.” For this project, White stuck to his druthers, making lighting a key component in what became an atmospheric oasis that recalls both the minimalism and the glamour of the ’70s.

headline: Donald Judd’s Plain-Spoken Masterpiece
abstract: Yes, it’s better to see this great flutter of planes, volumes and edges in person. But an online visit is the next best thing.
lead_paragraph: Donald Judd’s large, untitled installation piece in unfinished plywood at Gagosian Gallery is a plain-spoken giant that, surprisingly, has quite a bit to say. In its complexity and openness, it seems like almost nothing else Judd (1928-1994) ever made, and it hasn’t been seen in New York since 1981, when it debuted at the Castelli Gallery in SoHo a year after its completion.

headline: Australia’s Record Heat Means Another Blow to Great Barrier Reef
abstract: For the third time in five years, abnormally warm water has caused a “mass bleaching” of coral, and some of it will not survive. Scientists say global warming is killing reefs worldwide.
lead_paragraph: Record-breaking warm waters have bleached large parts of Australia’s Great Barrier Reef this year, as they did in 2016 and 2017, scientists reported on Thursday — the latest sign that global warming threatens the health of one of the world’s most important marine ecosystems.

headline: Broadcasting From Closets at Home, Daily Podcasts Come of Age
abstract: As the pandemic sequesters millions at home, an emerging category of intimate news programs offers a comforting voice.
lead_paragraph: When it’s time to get to work, after a morning teleconference and a cup (or two) of coffee, Cardiff Garcia combs his hair, heads into the closet of his Upper West Side apartment and hangs a blanket over his head. Waiting for his FaceTime call is Stacey Vanek Smith, who answers from a makeshift fort — her own blanket, stretched over two side chairs — that she rebuilds each day in her Brooklyn living room.

headline: On ‘Beef House,’ Family Sitcoms Get the Tim and Eric Treatment
abstract: The comedy duo wanted to make a sitcom for Adult Swim about a house full of awkward men (and, somehow, one woman). It’s as weird as Tim and Eric fans would expect.
lead_paragraph: The press tour had been canceled. Everything is canceled. But as anyone familiar with the comedy of Tim Heidecker and Eric Wareheim would appreciate, there was something almost too appropriate about having to view their faces as degraded images on a stuttering, grainy video stream amid a general feeling of discomfort.

headline: A Pianist’s Final Message: Overlooked Works by a Son of Bach
abstract: When he died in February, Peter Serkin was putting the final edits on his recording of a trove of pieces by C.P.E. Bach.
lead_paragraph: Peter Serkin had a lifelong fascination with the piano works of Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach. Perhaps he saw in him a kindred spirit. Like Mr. Serkin, whose father was the great pianist Rudolf Serkin, C.P.E. was the son of a famous musician: Johann Sebastian Bach.

headline: Significance of Pangolin Viruses in Human Pandemic Remains Murky
abstract: Scientists haven’t found evidence that the new coronavirus jumped from pangolins to people, but they do host very similar viruses
lead_paragraph: Pangolins, once suspected as the missing link from bats to humans in the origin of the coronavirus pandemic, may not have played that role, some scientists say, although the animals do host viruses that are similar to the new human coronavirus.

headline: Stop Yelling Out the Window. Just Give Doctors the Masks You’re Hoarding.
abstract: Empty gestures of solidarity aren’t going to bring back the gear that has grown legs and walked out of my hospital.
lead_paragraph: “Any thoughts?” my father asked me in an email. The subject line read “#Solidarityat8.”

headline: Shakespeare Survived Quarantine With a Little Help From His Patrons
abstract: Our support system for creative professionals is abysmal. Artists shouldn’t feel bad about feeling uninspired during a crisis.
lead_paragraph: It’s a common refrain when devastating things happen: Creativity will thrive in these conditions. I’ve seen it said in recent days as tours are canceled, TV and film production is postponed and creatives are forced into self-isolation because of the coronavirus.

headline: With Meetings Banned, Millions Struggle to Stay Sober On Their Own
abstract: Addiction experts are calling the coronavirus pandemic a national relapse trigger. Online support groups, doctors and even federal agencies are rushing to aid people in recovery.
lead_paragraph: On March 13, a dozen people gathered at a Cleveland outpatient clinic for their daily therapy group. They represented a patchwork of addictions: to alcohol, crack cocaine, methamphetamine, marijuana, heroin. They were freshly out of jail, out of marriages, out of work. The newest member had enrolled just a week earlier.

headline: Art Basel Shifts to September Amid Coronavirus Concerns
abstract: The 50th edition of the world’s biggest modern and contemporary fair joins a growing list of canceled and postponed art events.
lead_paragraph: Art Basel, the centerpiece of Europe’s summer art market calendar, has postponed its June edition in Switzerland until September as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Read the Letter From President Trump to America’s Governors
abstract: “We pledge to marshal every resource and power we have to overcome and vanquish this threat,” the president wrote about the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Thursday sent a letter to governors that said the federal government hoped to provide a risk assessment for individual counties as testing capabilities for the novel coronavirus expand.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Living Through a Pandemic
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: The rapidly-developing coronavirus crisis is dominating global headlines and altering life as we know it. Many schools worldwide have closed. In the United States alone, 55 million students are rapidly adjusting to learning and socializing remotely, spending more time with family, and sacrificing comfort and convenience for the greater good.

headline: An Israeli Mom Ranted About Online Learning, and the Internet Replied: ‘Same’
abstract: A mother of four talks about her newfound fame after her 90-second diatribe racked up millions of views.
lead_paragraph: Even the interview started in a way that was indicative of our current global shared reality.

headline: Introducing the ‘Grandparents’ Academy’
abstract: A way to tap the wisdom and knowledge of our elders and keep our children from losing their minds.
lead_paragraph: Law and order is on the verge of breaking down — within the confines of my own house. My two kids, 11 and 13, aren’t just cooped up; they’re in full revolt. They have some homework assignments to do but no regular online classes to engage them. So my wife and I are taking shifts, almost like prison guards, imposing TV shutdowns and mandatory yard time.

headline: Online Help to Stay Sober During a Pandemic
abstract: Though face-to-face counseling and in-person group meetings have been suspended to curb the spread of the coronavirus, there are many virtual options newly available for support.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has put severe stress on millions of people in recovery for substance use issues, as well as on friends and family who are trying to stand by them. Connection is considered an antidote to addiction, but the bans on gatherings have abruptly shut down support groups, leaving many people floundering for safety nets.

headline: Bonanza for Rich Real Estate Investors, Tucked Into Stimulus Package
abstract: A small change to tax policy could hand $170 billion in tax savings to real estate tycoons.
lead_paragraph: The federal government’s planned $2 trillion economic rescue package includes financial aid for individuals and industries that are struggling to survive the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: A Ban on Religious Garb in Public
abstract: The nonprofit Becket — Religious Liberty for All discusses the Quebec case and its American counterpart. Also: Two stories about birthdays.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Coronavirus in Japan, New York Hospitals, Maduro Indictment: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: To Slow Virus, China Bars Entry by Almost All Foreigners
abstract: Beijing halted most international flights, making it hard for citizens to return. And it blocked even foreigners with Chinese residency or visas from entering.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Worried that international travelers might trigger a second wave of coronavirus infections, China announced late Thursday night that it was suspending practically all entry to the country by foreigners and was halting almost all international passenger flights as well.

headline: Coronavirus Protective Masks to Be Made From M.L.B. Uniform Material
abstract: The deal will send masks to health professionals in the Northeast with the distinctive pinstripes of the Yankees and the Philadelphia Phillies.
lead_paragraph: Had the baseball season not been postponed because of the coronavirus, players across the country would have been decked out in crisp new uniforms for opening day on Thursday. Now, some uniforms will be put to better use.

headline: Things to Do in N.Y.C. This Weekend While Staying Inside
abstract: A weekly guide to maintaining a social life while social distancing.
lead_paragraph: This week, New York became the epicenter of the coronavirus pandemic, and starting at 8 p.m. Sunday, all nonessential businesses have closed and residents have been ordered to stay at home as much as possible.

headline: Mississippi Governor Clarifies Order Defining Most Businesses as Essential
abstract: Gov. Tate Reeves issued a supplement to an executive order about essential businesses, saying it was a standard for local leaders, who had already issued their own.
lead_paragraph: Days after issuing an executive order that broadly defined most businesses as essential during the coronavirus shutdown, Gov. Tate Reeves of Mississippi said on Thursday that it was not meant to interfere with decisions made by local governments.

headline: National Cathedral, Nasdaq, Businesses and Unions Locate Troves of N95 Masks
abstract: One stockpile was in the cathedral’s crypt. Others were with companies like Goldman Sachs. And a health care union said it found 39 million more.
lead_paragraph: Joe Alonso, the head stonemason at the Washington National Cathedral, had tended to the building for 35 years. He knew its nooks and crannies.

headline: Escaping Into ‘Babylon Berlin’ and ‘My Brilliant Friend’
abstract: New seasons of two top-notch international series, on Netflix and HBO, offer comfort viewing that’s outside the comfort zone.
lead_paragraph: For some, comfort viewing during the Covid-19 pandemic will take the form of familiarity: shows they’ve watched before, or shows that take place in their own everyday worlds. Why challenge yourself when daily life is challenging enough?

headline: As Coronavirus Crisis Unfolds, Sanders Sees a Moment That Matches His Ideas
abstract: With the odds of winning long, some Democrats wonder why Bernie Sanders is still in the presidential race. He’s still pushing his agenda, though it’s not clear who’s listening.
lead_paragraph: Both hands were waving — over here, over there, a full wingspan on display — as Bernie Sanders directed his most biting sarcasm at his “Republican friends.”

headline: Maurice Berger, Curator Outspoken About Race, Is Dead at 63
abstract: An influential art historian, he called out racism in the museum world, and in the broader culture as well.
lead_paragraph: Maurice Berger, who as a curator and a writer was a forceful voice against both overt and subtle racism in the art world and other arenas, died on Sunday at his home in Craryville, N.Y. He was 63.

headline: Film Club: ‘She’s an Honors Student. And Homeless. Will the Virtual Classroom Reach Her?’
abstract: How is the coronavirus exposing education’s digital divide?

headline: On Job Just 6 Weeks, U.K.’s Finance Chief Shines in Crisis
abstract: Britain’s chancellor, Rishi Sunak, a virtual unknown not long ago, is winning praise for leading the response to the virus.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Rishi Sunak was elected to Parliament in 2015, he recalled a piece of advice from his father-in-law, Narayana Murthy, a technology billionaire who is one of India’s richest men. “In God we trust,” Mr. Murthy told him, “but everyone else needs to bring data to the table.”

headline: The Heroism of Health Workers in the Coronavirus Crisis
abstract: Readers acknowledge the risks that doctors, nurses and many others are taking and offer their gratitude.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Blood Plasma From Survivors Will Be Given to Coronavirus Patients
abstract: In people who have recovered, plasma is teeming with antibodies that may fight the virus. But the treatment beginning in New York is experimental.
lead_paragraph: Can blood from coronavirus survivors help other people fight the illness?

headline: Coronavirus Threatens an Already Strained Maternal Health System
abstract: No visitors. Induced labor. Converted delivery wards. Tens of thousands of women across the country are giving birth in unprecedented circumstances.
lead_paragraph: — Smita Nadia Hussein, a mother of two, who gave birth on March 17 in Morristown, N.J.

headline: How Should I Do Laundry Now?
abstract: The new coronavirus has made many people stressed about clothes and cleanliness, especially those living in cities.
lead_paragraph: Now that millions of Americans are being advised to stay at home as much as possible to help limit the spread of the new coronavirus, people are re-evaluating how to manage daily tasks and chores while sticking to social distancing measures.

headline: On Coronavirus, We’re #1
abstract: But we’re doing some things right despite Trump.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to believe, but just a month ago Donald Trump and his henchmen were dismissing the coronavirus as a nonevent. On Feb. 26 Trump declared that “You have 15 people, and the 15 within a couple of days is going to be close to zero.” His remark came a day after Larry Kudlow, his administration’s chief economist, declared that the virus was almost completely contained, and that the economy was “holding up nicely.”

headline: The U.S. Now Leads the World in Confirmed Coronavirus Cases
abstract: Following a series of missteps, the nation is now the epicenter of the pandemic.

headline: Viral Challenges Are What’s Keeping Us Occupied
abstract: “Until tomorrow” and other games are the chain mail letters of social isolation.
lead_paragraph: In the past two weeks, Instagram has been overrun with viral challenges.

headline: New York City Ballet Cancels Its Season but Will Pay Employees
abstract: City Ballet says it will lose about $8 million with the disappearance of its spring season because of the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: New York City Ballet announced on Thursday that it was canceling its spring season because of the coronavirus pandemic, but the company plans to pay its dancers, musicians and other employees through May 31, the date the season was to have ended.

headline: A Dilemma for Some: Should You Still Hire a Cleaner?
abstract: Infectious disease experts recommend erring on the side of caution, but what if that means pausing a service that provides peace of mind to clients and a steady source of money to low-income workers?
lead_paragraph: Public health officials have stressed the importance of keeping a clean house to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Can Trump Legally Order the Country Back to Work From Coronavirus by Easter?
abstract: Such a declaration, in the midst of a health crisis, would have to come from local authorities.
lead_paragraph: While the president of the United States is often referred to as the most powerful leader on earth, there are limits to those powers, and one of them is that he cannot order Americans to leave their homes and go to work.

headline: Education Dept. Hits Penn State Again for Sexual Misconduct Procedures
abstract: Eight years after the Jerry Sandusky abuse scandal, the Education Department said the university still needed to overhaul its procedures.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Education Department announced Thursday that it had ordered Pennsylvania State University to make significant changes to the way it investigates complaints of sexual misconduct after a recent investigation found the school continued to mishandle cases years after the Jerry Sandusky child sex abuse scandal.

headline: Congress Addresses Housing Crunch Amid Coronavirus Pandemic
abstract: The economic stabilization package includes more than $12 billion for housing and protection from evictions and foreclosures, as the pandemic hits cities already in housing crises.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress’s $2.2 trillion stabilization package headed for likely final passage on Friday will allocate more than $12 billion in funding for federal housing and rental assistance, a belated recognition that Americans cannot shelter in place from the coronavirus if they have no shelter.

headline: FIFA Races Toward a Plan to Help Soccer Clubs Survive Shutdown
abstract: With leagues and clubs around the world scrambling to sort out issues from player compensation to future transactions, the global governing body is trying to provide a new framework.
lead_paragraph: With soccer’s global calendar upended by the coronavirus, FIFA is scrambling to draft new regulations for player contracts and transactions between clubs in an effort to create a road map out of the sport's unprecedented shutdown.

headline: Expert Advice: Should ‘Snowbirds’ Stay or Go?
abstract: Because they are older, this population is at higher risk of Covid-19 complications. Here’s how to think about heading North or staying put.
lead_paragraph: For the millions of Americans who make the migration between North and South as the seasons change, the coronavirus outbreak has created a difficult dilemma: Are they better off staying where they are, or heading home? Because they are older, the so-called snowbirds, are at higher risk of Covid-19 complications.

headline: Snowbirds Ask: Should We Stay or Should We Go?
abstract: Millions of older Americans make an annual migration between the North and the South. The coronavirus pandemic has them questioning their plans to return home.
lead_paragraph: Travel and travel planning are being disrupted by the worldwide spread of the coronavirus. For the latest updates, read The New York Times’s Covid-19 coverage here.

headline: Woody Allen’s New Memoir Is Sometimes Funny — and Tone Deaf and Banal
abstract: Allen’s “Apropos of Nothing,” recently released after being canceled by its original publisher, covers his childhood in Brooklyn, his career and the abuse allegations against him.
lead_paragraph: During the Cuban missile crisis, the writer Christopher Isherwood was surprised to find himself going to the gym. “If we are to be fried alive,” he wrote in his diary, “it seems funny to be working out.”

headline: ‘The Other Option Is Death’: New York Starts Sharing of Ventilators
abstract: To keep coronavirus patients breathing, hospitals are pioneering a little-tested method.
lead_paragraph: A New York hospital system has begun treating two patients instead of one on some ventilators, a desperate measure that could help alleviate a shortage of the critical breathing machines and help hospitals around the country respond to the surge of coronavirus patients expected in the coming weeks.

headline: Work Out With Venus Williams. Then Debate Stefon Diggs.
abstract: Have you always wanted to work out with a professional athlete? Now may be the time. Here’s how athletes are keeping busy today.
lead_paragraph: We’ve come to the phase of the coronavirus quarantine when stir-crazy athletes are starting Twitter debates and live-streaming workouts. Look, we’re not complaining. We’ve got a sports section to fill here. There are plenty more potential top five lists out there, and we need to keep exercising, too.

headline: U.S. Officials Push for Expelling Suspected Chinese Spies at Media Outlets
abstract: Trump administration officials are discussing taking action after China said it would expel almost all American journalists for The New York Times, The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As China moves forward with expelling almost all American journalists from three major American newspapers, Trump administration officials have intensified discussions over whether to evict employees of Chinese media outlets who they say mainly act as spies.

headline: Stephen Curry Hosts Coronavirus Discussion on Instagram Live
abstract: More than 50,000 viewers, including former President Barack Obama, were watching at the peak of the 30-minute chat with Dr. Anthony S. Fauci.
lead_paragraph: As the N.B.A.’s hiatus extended into its third week on Thursday, Golden State Warriors guard Stephen Curry made use of his off time by hosting an Instagram Live discussion about the coronavirus with Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and the most visible medical figure in the U.S. during the outbreak.

headline: Five Brands Offering Easy, Elegant Loungewear
abstract: From modern housecoats to silk pajamas, a selection of labels making clothes that will upgrade your working-from-home look.
lead_paragraph: With increasing numbers of people now working from home, it has become clear that we each fall into one of two camps: those who dress up for their working day — think: makeup, jewelry and real pants — and those who favor workout clothes and blankets. Regardless of this divide, video conference calls have become a near unavoidable reality and require a certain level of decorum — at least from the waist up. Luckily, the past few years have seen a surge in brands offering fashion-forward loungewear that can bridge the public-private gap with designs that are both comfortable and presentable. Below, a selection of labels that cater to every level of low-maintenance dressing, with pieces from luxurious knits to sophisticated sweats.

headline: Coronavirus, New Orleans, Betty Dodson: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A N.Y. Nurse Dies. Angry Co-Workers Blame a Lack of Protective Gear.
abstract: “I’m okay. Don’t tell Mom and Dad. They’ll worry,” he wrote to his sister. He may be the first nurse in New York City to die from the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Kious Kelly, a nurse manager at a Manhattan hospital, texted his sister on March 18 with some devastating news: He had tested positive for the coronavirus and was on a ventilator in the intensive care unit. He told her he could text but not talk.

headline: The Moral Meaning of the Plague
abstract: The virus is a test. We have the freedom to respond.
lead_paragraph: It can all seem so meaningless. Some random biological mutation sweeps across the globe, murdering thousands, lacerating families and pulverizing dreams.

headline: Trump’s Baseless Claim That a Recession Would Be Deadlier Than the Coronavirus
abstract: The opposite is more likely to be true, according to research and experts.
lead_paragraph: President Trump, in saying that he wanted to reopen the economy by Easter, has argued that an economic downturn would be more deadly than the coronavirus.

headline: E.P.A., Citing Coronavirus, Drastically Relaxes Rules for Polluters
abstract: The agency said it would not penalize companies that violate rules on monitoring and reporting pollution discharges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday announced a sweeping relaxation of environmental rules in response to the coronavirus pandemic, allowing power plants, factories and other facilities to determine for themselves if they are able to meet legal requirements on reporting air and water pollution.

headline: Curly Neal, Globetrotters’ Dazzling Dribbler, Dies at 77
abstract: He admitted he “didn’t know anything about being funny” when he joined the comedic basketball team, but he became one of its biggest stars.
lead_paragraph: Fred “Curly” Neal, whose dribbling wizardry made him one of the most well-known members of the beloved Harlem Globetrotters traveling basketball team, died on Thursday at his home near Houston. He was 77.

headline: It’s the Largest Relief Deal in U.S. History. Is It Enough?
abstract: $2 trillion is a lot of money. How much it helps depends on where it’s going.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Trump Says He Will Label Regions by Risk of Coronavirus Threat
abstract: The federal guidelines are meant to help states decide whether to relax or enhance the quarantine and social distancing measures they have put in place.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said Thursday that he planned to label different areas of the country as at a “high risk, medium risk or low risk” to the spread of the coronavirus, as part of new federal guidelines to help states decide whether to relax or enhance their quarantine and social distancing measures.

headline: The Coronavirus Economy: When Washington Takes Over Business
abstract: The $2 trillion aid package is expected to save jobs and bail out companies, but it reorders the relationship between government and private industry.
lead_paragraph: The $2 trillion coronavirus rescue package that the Senate passed on Wednesday will fundamentally transform the U.S. government by placing thousands of businesses and millions of workers on federally funded life support.

headline: Being Together While Staying Apart
abstract: At a time when so many of us are isolated in our homes to avoid catching and spreading coronavirus, we need to take a lesson from the highly connected teens and 20-somethings in our lives.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Well newsletter. Every Wednesday, we email readers with news about health, fitness and nutrition and advice about living well. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: An Open Letter to President Trump
abstract: The nation craves a plan, not hunches.
lead_paragraph: Dear President Trump,

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Take a break, steer into the skid, keep hanging on: Our TV critic has some great recommendations.
lead_paragraph: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every week for new suggestions on what to watch.

headline: How the Senate Debate Over the Coronavirus Stimulus Bill Unfolded
abstract: Tension filled the Senate floor as Republicans and Democrats argued over what should, and should not, be included in a stimulus bill for coronavirus relief.
lead_paragraph: Tension filled the Senate floor as Republicans and Democrats argued over what should, and should not, be included in a stimulus bill for coronavirus relief.

headline: As Coronavirus Spread, Largest Stimulus in History United a Polarized Senate
abstract: Markets shuddered as the $2 trillion economic stabilization package stalled before negotiators cemented a historic deal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Senator Chuck Schumer walked the two miles from his apartment to the Capitol early Sunday morning, getting his steps in since the Senate gym had been shut down to stem the spread of the novel coronavirus, he knew he and his fellow Democrats had a momentous decision to make.

headline: At Walmart, the Coronavirus Makes It Feel Like Black Friday
abstract: No matter how ill I have been, I’ve always gone to work.
lead_paragraph: LONG BEACH, Calif. — Over the four years I’ve worked at a Walmart, a handful of days stand out as extremely stressful, even dangerous. But right now, we retail associates are putting our health and safety at risk as people stock up for weeks (perhaps months) of isolation.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The U.S. now has more coronavirus cases than any other country, and New York’s hospitals are being pushed to the brink.
lead_paragraph: At least 81,578 people in the U.S. are known to have been infected with the coronavirus, including more than 1,000 deaths. That’s more cases than any other country has recorded, according to data gathered by The New York Times.

headline: Weaving a Way Out of Isolation
abstract: You can craft your way to a sense of community, says the artist Liza Lou. She’s creating her “comfort” project on Instagram in real time.
lead_paragraph: “It’s one thing to decide to be isolated,” said the artist Liza Lou, who in the best of times longs for uninterrupted solitude in her Los Angeles studio, as so many artists do. “It’s another to be told that you must be,” she added. “Something we crave can quickly become onerous.”

headline: How Will the Spending Be Spun?
abstract: American politics were rewired after the Great Recession. The current crisis could shake things up again.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Why Is America Choosing Mass Unemployment?
abstract: European countries are paying to preserve jobs during the coronavirus crisis. Sadly for American workers, the United States is charting its own path.
lead_paragraph: Thursday’s news that more than three million Americans filed for unemployment benefits last week, a total far higher than in any previous week in the modern history of the United States, has been greeted with surprising equanimity by the nation’s political leaders.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Season 1 Finale Recap: Another Goodbye
abstract: As the first season of “Picard” comes to an end, our recapper asks, “Who was this show really about anyway?”
lead_paragraph: It turns out that a show called “Star Trek: Picard” ends up actually being about Data.

headline: After Considering $1 Billion Price Tag for Ventilators, White House Has Second Thoughts
abstract: A deal with General Motors and Ventec Life Systems to produce tens of thousands of the critical lifesaving devices seemed imminent. Then the announcement was pulled back.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House had been preparing to reveal on Wednesday a joint venture between General Motors and Ventec Life Systems that would allow for the production of as many as 80,000 desperately needed ventilators to respond to an escalating pandemic when word suddenly came down that the announcement was off.

headline: Make Abortion More Available During the Pandemic — Not Less
abstract: This crisis has underscored the need for greater access to reproductive health care.
lead_paragraph: It’s hardly new for anti-abortion politicians to seize on any excuse to try to restrict women’s bodily autonomy, but it is a new low to exploit a pandemic that’s already cost hundreds of American lives, and threatens many thousands more.

headline: With No Basketball Tournament, N.C.A.A Slashes Payments to Universities
abstract: The annual payment to conferences was cut to a total of $225 million, down from the $600 million that was budgeted before the coronavirus led to widespread cancellations in sports.
lead_paragraph: College athletic departments got their first indication  of how the coronavirus pandemic might hurt their bottom lines when the N.C.A.A. announced on Thursday that it would slash its distribution of men’s basketball tournament revenue by about $375 million, a cut of nearly two-thirds.

headline: Early Graduation Could Send Medical Students to Virus Front Lines
abstract: Hundreds of fourth-year students at universities in Boston and New York could start caring for patients months ahead of schedule.
lead_paragraph: The battle to treat an ever-growing number of patients infected with the new coronavirus just gained its newest recruits: soon-to-be medical graduates. Several medical schools in Massachusetts and New York announced this week that they intended to offer early graduation to their fourth-year students, fast-tracking them into front-line hospital care as the need for medical workers surges.

headline: Opera Star, Charged With Sexual Assault, Is Fired by University of Michigan
abstract: David Daniels, a professor of voice and one of the world’s leading countertenors, was dismissed one year after he and his husband were charged with sexually assaulting another singer.
lead_paragraph: The University of Michigan on Thursday fired David Daniels, a professor of voice and one of the world’s leading countertenors, one year after he and his husband were charged with sexually assaulting another singer.

headline: Skilled at Dodging
abstract: Kyle Dolan flutters by with a fortified Friday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — First of all, it is Friday, I guarantee it. I’m doing a few posts for Deb, which is rocking my tiny routine right now — it is appalling how quickly I’ve settled into a stream of 24-hour periods with absolutely no variation. I believe that Ms. Amlen is perfecting her drone navigation skills and preparing to fly an amplifier over crowds in her neighborhood, broadcasting the admonition to “just go inside!”

headline: Bill Pullman Digs Deeper on ‘The Sinner’ Season 3 Finale
abstract: The actor talked about the explosive season ending, his dream of Keanu Reeves and what it was like to be buried alive.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for the Season 3 finale of “The Sinner.”

headline: Where the U.S. Stands Now on Coronavirus Testing
abstract: The pace of coronavirus testing in the United States has seen a meteoric rise in the past week. But the country still lags in tests relative to its population, despite having the world’s most reported coronavirus cases.
lead_paragraph: The pace of coronavirus testing in the United States has seen a meteoric rise in the past week. But the country still lags in tests relative to its population, despite having the world’s most reported coronavirus cases.

headline: Man Charged With Making Death Threats to Nancy Pelosi in Coronavirus Rant
abstract: Gavin Weslee Blake Perry, 27, of Wichita Falls, Texas, wrote on Facebook that Democrats were terrorists and should be shot on sight, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A Texas man, ranting on social media about the congressional response to the coronavirus outbreak, has been charged with making death threats to Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other Democrats, federal prosecutors announced on Thursday.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Job Losses Soar; U.S. Virus Cases Top World
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, March 27, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “A large part of the economy just collapsed.”

headline: Corrections: March 27, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, March 27, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the retirement of Col. W. Shane Cohen, the military judge presiding in the Sept. 11 death penalty trial at Guantánamo Bay, misstated the target start date of the trial. It is Jan. 11, 2021, not Jan. 22, 2021.

headline: On the Front Lines of a Pandemic, ‘I Love You’ Can Mean ‘Goodbye’
abstract: Separated from family and worried about patients and colleagues, an internist where the U.S. outbreak began counts losses and blessings.
lead_paragraph: “I love you,” I said to my wife. Then, quietly: “Goodbye.”

headline: For France, Coronavirus Tests a Vaunted Health Care System
abstract: The country goes into the battle with the contagion better prepared than most. Even so, a doubling of cases every four days has the structure creaking and straining.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — One of the world’s best health care systems is facing its severest test ever, and whether it succeeds will say much about the ultimate adequacy of a well-funded, well-equipped and broadly accessible national treatment plan.

headline: Migrant Farmworkers Whose Harvests Feed Europe Are Blocked at Borders
abstract: Legions of seasonal workers from Eastern Europe who harvest crops from Spain to Sweden can’t get in, forcing a rapid rethink of how to secure food at Europe’s farms.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When Europe tightened its borders to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, France’s biggest farmers sounded an alarm: The workers they rely on from other countries to harvest much of the nation’s food could no longer make the trip.

headline: Trump Signs $2 Trillion Bill as U.S. Virus Cases Pass 100,000
abstract: President Trump, who had questioned the need for additional ventilators, pushed industry to make more. A new survey of mayors found dire shortages of urgently needed supplies.
lead_paragraph: Read about the latest developments in the coronavirus pandemic here.

headline: Airlines Tell Employees to Prepare for Difficult Times
abstract: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline: What India Needs to Fight the Virus
abstract: The country has three to four weeks to create an enormous, affordable and easily available testing infrastructure, contain local outbreaks and prepare for the avalanche of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On Tuesday evening, Prime Minister Narendra Modi ordered 1.3 billion Indians to stay inside their homes for 21 days in an unprecedented bid to stem the spread of the coronavirus in the country.

headline: What if Restaurants and Pubs Disappear in Australia?
abstract: The relaxed country is known for its rich restaurant and bar culture. What will happen if its hospitality industry crumbles?
lead_paragraph: During a week when the news has been so bleak, when we’ve heard about the deaths of colleagues and artists and beloved educators, when much of the world’s population is in lockdown, the closing of a pub might not strike you as a tragedy. And yet the news that my local pub was going out of business finally undid me. After weeks of gritting my teeth as my own work dried up, my husband’s new business shuttered, my son came home from school indefinitely, and my best friend lay with her newborn in a hospital where no visitors were allowed (including her husband), I relented and crumpled when I heard about the pub.

headline: Coronavirus, France, Lockdown: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Word + Quiz: flounce
abstract: This word has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Making the Cut’ and ‘Uncorked’
abstract: A reality series with Tim Gunn and Heidi Klum hits Amazon. And a father-son drama debuts on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: MAKING THE CUT Stream on Amazon. “It’s an ambush!” Is that quote from the new James Bond movie? No? How about “1917”? Wrong again. It’s Tim Gunn speaking in the first episode of this new Amazon fashion-design reality series. When he says it, Gunn and Heidi Klum, his co-host, have just arrived at a fancy Manhattan hotel, where the show’s international group of contestants have gathered — each apparently unaware that Gunn and Klum are about to walk in, surprise them and kick off the competition. The group’s first challenge? Designing for a fashion show near the Eiffel Tower. Rewards for the season’s winner include mentorship and $1 million. Also, this: “The winner will get to create a collection that will be sold on Amazon,” Klum says.

headline: ‘Uncorked’ Review: A Fresh Take on the Father-Son Drama
abstract: A young man seeks to become a master sommelier in this drama from Prentice Penny.
lead_paragraph: In “Uncorked,” now streaming on Netflix, the father-son drama gets a refreshing upgrade. Elijah (Mamoudou Athie), a scattered but well-meaning young adult, has finally figured out his dream: to become a master sommelier, a designation reserved for the best wine stewards in the world. The only problem is that his father, Louis (Courtney B. Vance), wants him to focus on learning how to run their family’s barbecue joint in Memphis.

headline: News Quiz: Coronavirus, Chloroquine, Kenny Rogers
abstract: Did you follow the headlines this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the headlines this week?

headline: The Virus Is Coming to Myanmar, but the Pain Has Already Begun
abstract: Economic fallout from the pandemic has upended lives in the impoverished country, where the first coronavirus cases are only now being reported.
lead_paragraph: HLAING THARYAR, Myanmar — When he was 12, Ko Naing Lin survived a cyclone that killed his father, a small-town doctor, and at least 130,000 others in the Irrawaddy Delta of Myanmar. A life of lazy soccer games, plentiful fish curry and reprimands to finish his homework — “Now, or else what will become of you?” — ended.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Considering Kurt Vonnegut and Who Survives
abstract: This week, Lorrie Moore discusses her life as a reader in By the Book. In 1985, Moore wrote for the Book Review about “Galápagos,” Kurt Vonnegut’s novel about a group of survivors stranded on the Galápagos Islands because of an apocalypse.
lead_paragraph: This week, Lorrie Moore discusses her life as a reader in By the Book. In 1985, Moore wrote for the Book Review about “Galápagos,” Kurt Vonnegut’s novel about a group of survivors stranded on the Galápagos Islands because of an apocalypse.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Coronavirus Spread
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: ‘We Take the Dead From Morning Till Night’
abstract: No country has been hit harder by the coronavirus than Italy, and no province has suffered as many losses as Bergamo. Photos and voices from there evoke a portrait of despair.
lead_paragraph: No country has been hit harder by the coronavirus than Italy, and no province has suffered as many losses as Bergamo. Photos and voices from there evoke a portrait of despair.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Savage Feast’ and ‘The Bird King’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: SAVAGE FEAST: Three Generations, Two Continents and a Dinner Table (A Memoir With Recipes), by Boris Fishman. (Harper Perennial/HarperCollins, 368 pp., $17.99.) Fishman, who immigrated to America from Minsk when he was 9, unspools his family’s story through the foods they prepared and ate. Meals, Max Watman wrote in his review in these pages, “are the language of this book, the waypoints and transitions, the narrative beats and instigative sparks that drive the storytelling.”

headline: In Protest or Celebration, Four Poets Evoke a Sense of Endings
abstract: The end of relationships, the end of life, the end of civilization: Collections from Major Jackson, Carolyn Forché, Victoria Chang and Danez Smith imagine the worst.
lead_paragraph: THE ABSURD MAN

headline: What if I Need to Go on a Ventilator?
abstract: A critical care doctor explains what treatment for coronavirus looks like in the intensive care unit.
lead_paragraph: Late one recent night, I found myself on the phone with my patient’s brother, trying to explain respiratory failure and Covid-19, the disease caused by the new coronavirus. He had been unable to sleep, he told me, after hours spent online in a futile attempt to understand what might be happening in his sister’s room in our hospital’s intensive care unit.

headline: How My Dad Became the Traveler I Once Was
abstract: We are in a loop in which parent becomes child and child becomes parent over and over, like the sun and the moon in revolutions and stages, rising and setting in each other’s light.
lead_paragraph: My dad was 51 years old the first time he traveled abroad. He came to visit me in Southern France, on my first trip overseas, at age 20. I was spending a year in Aix-en-Provence, and my dad and stepmom and little brother gamely traipsed around fields of lavender, knocking their heads on the entrances to Lilliputian restaurants and politely not making snide remarks about my new penchant for wearing skirts over jeans.

headline: When Black Tie Is Replaced by Plaid Pajamas
abstract: Stacey Bendet, Debbie Bancroft and Wes Gordon are keeping their social distance.
lead_paragraph: With the New York gala circuit on hiatus because of the coronavirus outbreak, here is how some patrons and society figures are spending their time (and money) while self-isolated. Interviews have been edited for space.

headline: A Natural Classroom, Run by Wolves
abstract: Their reintroduction to Yellowstone has been a scientific and tourism bonanza.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years ago this month, 14 wolves from Canada were released into an ocean of elk on the rugged sweep of sagebrush steppe and pine forest of Yellowstone National Park to see what would happen.

headline: QVC: Quarantine, Value, Convenience
abstract: TV shopping remains an essential American service.
lead_paragraph: After Gov. Tom Wolf ordered all “non-life-sustaining” businesses in several counties in Pennsylvania to shutter last week — as one of a growing number of  governors to issue “stay at home” or “shelter in place” orders to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus — only the most Dickensian remained in operation.

headline: What the World Needs Now Is Grace
abstract: The opiate epidemic offers lessons on isolation and recovery that resonate during the coronavirus battle.
lead_paragraph: The past five years have been a remarkable time for America’s opiate-addiction epidemic, now a generation old.

headline: A Riding Center for the Disabled Struggles to Care for Its Herd
abstract: An organization that provides therapeutic riding lessons for people with disabilities said a tearful goodbye amid fears over the spread of coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The first horse to be loaded onto the trailer was Mr. Big. Corina Papa leaned in close and whispered a tearful goodbye.

headline: $2 Trillion Coronavirus Stimulus Bill Is Signed Into Law
abstract: Dozens of lawmakers rushed back to Washington to thwart a stall tactic from Representative Thomas Massie of Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday signed a sweeping $2 trillion measure to respond to the coronavirus pandemic, but not before a late objection from a lone rank-and-file Republican forced hundreds of lawmakers to rush back to the capital even as the virus continued to spread through their ranks.

headline: D.J.T. Is No F.D.R.
abstract: Roosevelt’s first inaugural cleared the way for action, pointing the country toward a singular goal. Where is that spirit now?
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic may plunge the United States into its worst social and economic crisis since the Great Depression. But our response — from the president’s blame-shifting rhetoric to the Senate’s inadequate relief package — has yet to rise to the scale and scope of the challenge.

headline: Dogs, at Least, Love Home Quarantine
abstract: Mine and I still walk, and we talk a whole lot more.
lead_paragraph: Next to me on the couch, one of my dogs twitches his feet and curls his lower lip in his sleep. His tail thumps on a soft pillow. An “urph” — maybe a stifled bark — escapes his mouth and he wakes himself up, looking at me accusingly. “That was you!” I tell him.

headline: The U.S. Is About to Vastly Increase Its Debt. That’s a Good Thing.
abstract: The case is strong for spending a large amount of money in the short term to fend off worse economic woes down the road.
lead_paragraph: The United States government is poised to take on a huge amount of debt to contain the effects of the coronavirus pandemic, with budget deficits on a scale not seen since World War II looking likely.

headline: No Longer Just a Walk in the Park
abstract: The new terror, and the intensifying debate, over going outside.
lead_paragraph: I’m 77 years old and I want/need to walk. The two buildings in my complex have a basketball court between them. I have previously taken the freight elevator down 36 stories at 5:30 a.m., meeting no one but armed anyway with mask, gloves, wipes and hand sanitizer. I walked for 35 minutes and went back upstairs, again meeting nobody. Should I force myself to continue? I am simply afraid to go outside.

headline: When Walking the Dog Is ‘a Piece of Paradise’
abstract: There’s a sliver of solace for people who are isolated at home by the coronavirus: more time to walk pets. But professional dog walkers are losing work.
lead_paragraph: Serena Brennan, 25, a social worker at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, has been spending her days — many of them without a mask — tending to patients suffering from the coronavirus.

headline: The Religious Right’s Hostility to Science Is Crippling Our Coronavirus Response
abstract: Trump’s response to the pandemic has been haunted by the science denialism of his ultraconservative religious allies.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump rose to power with the determined assistance of a movement that denies science, bashes government and prioritized loyalty over professional expertise. In the current crisis, we are all reaping what that movement has sown.

headline: Trump’s Environmental Rollbacks Find Opposition Within: Staff Scientists
abstract: Federal scientists and lawyers, told to undo regulations that some have worked on for decades, have embedded data into technical documents that environmental lawyers are using to challenge the rollbacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has made rolling back environmental regulations a centerpiece of his administration, moving to erase Obama-era efforts ranging from landmark fuel efficiency standards and coal industry controls to more routine rules on paint solvents and industrial soot.

headline: I Became a Disciplined Investor Over 40 Years. The Virus Broke Me in 40 Days.
abstract: I’ve survived — and even prospered through — four stock-market crashes. But nothing prepared me for this.
lead_paragraph: It’s Thursday morning, March 19 — four weeks into the coronavirus crash of 2020. The Dow Jones industrial average has opened down another 700 points, after plunging below 20,000 a day before. It’s down 30 percent in a month, the steepest drop ever, even worse than during the Great Depression.

headline: A Virus’s Effects: Coughs, Chills and Sometimes a Forgiving Spirit
abstract: Cities are halting evictions and utility shut-offs, and law enforcement officials are freeing some low-level offenders from jail. But how long should the generosity last?
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Rent collections are being delayed. Water restored. Jailhouse doors are swinging open.

headline: The Toilet Paper Had Armed Guards, and Other Coronavirus Stories
abstract: Small, striking moments from a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The Covid-19 pandemic is gutting the global economy and forcing entire nations into quarantine. While reporting on devastation that is incomprehensibly big, our reporters have been accumulating in their notebooks some moments that are compelling because they are small.

headline: Capturing a World of Emptiness
abstract: How a team of photographers documented the quiet desolation of cities during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: How a Dance Video Director Spends His Sundays
abstract: Life in New York has shifted since Redha Medjellekh was photographed in February. But his message in the video below remains the same: Keep dancing.
lead_paragraph: Redha Medjellekh has created videos for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and for corporate clients like Target. His company, Red Is Dancing, also produces social commentary, like his response to the 2015 Paris terrorist attacks, “Paris Is Kissing,” and a tribute to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: Seattle Is Living Your Coronavirus Future
abstract: This city is well ahead of the rest of the nation in the cycle of denial, panic, action.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — You relish the little things here in Seattle: Toilet paper is back on some shelves, the hoarders sated for the moment. Instead of making vodka, distilleries are rolling out hand sanitizer. The dreaded daily number of new coronavirus cases shows that while the curve is not yet flat, the rate has gone both down and up on different days this week, carrying our hopes on the bumpy ride.

headline: Reinventing Easter, Passover and Other Holiday Meals in a Time of Limits
