lead_paragraph: For chicken hatcheries, the weeks leading up to Easter are always the busiest. Spring is in the air for people shaking off long winters spent watching Netflix under a blanket who had hoped to emerge into a world of budding flowers, green grass and baby animals.

headline: As Virus Spreads, China and Russia See Openings for Disinformation
abstract: The two powers amplify discredited conspiracy theories and sow division as they look to undermine the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — China and Russia have both seized on the novel coronavirus to wage disinformation campaigns that seek to sow doubts about the United States’ handling of the crisis and deflect attention from their own struggles with the pandemic, according to American intelligence officials and diplomats.

headline: The Nordic Way to Economic Rescue
abstract: In the face of the pandemic, Denmark is effectively nationalizing private payrolls, in contrast to the patchwork American system.
lead_paragraph: The unleashing of cash by Congress to combat the catastrophe of the pandemic amounts to the traditional American prescription — in gargantuan form. The $2 trillion package of spending expands the standard unemployment insurance system, while setting aside a pool of money that is supposed to aid distressed companies.

headline: ‘We are Trying to Protect Our Own’: The Towns Keeping Part-Timers Out
abstract: Defenders of property rights find something else they want to defend: Their own communities.
lead_paragraph: John Lowry vacationed in Door County, Wis., when he was a child. He loved it so much that 30 years ago he moved there. It’s not in his nature to tell people who share his fondness for what he calls “the Cape Cod of the Midwest” to please just stay away.

headline: Neighbors, Strangers and Tyler Perry Provide Hope and Distraction From Virus Fears
abstract: It’s grim out there. But in music, messages of hope — and goofy stuff online — people are trying to provide ways to get through a scary time.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Neighbors have shared messages of togetherness, etching them on sidewalks in chalk. Performers have shared their music. Restaurants have shared their food, handing out free meals and giving homeless people a place to dine together, just as long as they stayed six feet apart.

headline: A Wall. A Ball. That’s All: Your New Social-Distancing Workout
abstract: Long-ignored vertical slabs all over the city are having a moment.
lead_paragraph: In a park along the Hudson River in Manhattan’s Battery Park City, New Yorkers are queuing up — six feet apart, of course — for their turn to play with a wall.

headline: April Bills Loom. The Economy Hangs on How Many Are Left Unpaid.
abstract: With businesses and personal finances hit hard by a loss of income, the first of the month may mean triage in deciding what to pay.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, as on the first day of any month, many companies and households will have bills to pay. This time, a lot will simply pile up.

headline: Sabrina Ionescu’s Big Moment Wasn’t the One She Expected
abstract: The Oregon star had been called “the puppet master” by Kobe Bryant, but faced tragedy and canceled games in what was supposed to be a dream college season.
lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — Sabrina Ionescu woke not long after dawn in her small apartment, laced up her black Nikes and walked across a deserted street to the looming arena where she had spent the last four years creating memories.

headline: Infinite Visions Were Hiding in the First Black Hole Image’s Rings
abstract: Scientists proposed a technique that would allow us to see more of the unseeable.
lead_paragraph: A year ago a team of radio astronomers startled the world with the first photograph of a black hole, lurking like the eye of Sauron in the heart of a distant galaxy. Now it appears there was more hiding in that image than we had imagined.

headline: Pandemic Mars Putin’s Coronation and Endangers Russia’s Veterans
abstract: President Vladimir Putin’s grand plans to celebrate the 75th anniversary of victory in World War II, and his own leadership, may be foiled by the coronavirus, which also threatens war heroes.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When local officials bearing flowers and a medal arrived to pay tribute to a 93-year-old grandmother and war veteran at her home north of Moscow, they didn’t get quite the welcome they expected.

headline: Strangers in an Empty Dorm
abstract: The couple met as students a week before classes began at Grinnell College in 2009. He was there early for a canoe trip; she was a student adviser.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Platt answered the knock on his dormitory door a week before classes began at Grinnell College in August 2009. He found Sarah Mayer standing there.

headline: Trump Backtracks After Cuomo Criticizes Quarantine Idea
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo compared the president’s suggestion that he was considering a quarantine on the New York region to “a declaration of war on states.”
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Sunday’s live coverage.]

headline: The New Rules of Running Now
abstract: It’s difficult to balance the risks of exercising outside against the benefits.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Taliban Attack Afghanistan Amid Growing Coronavirus Threat
abstract: Insurgents launched major assaults as preparations continued for a prisoner exchange and as diplomats worked to revive the peace plan.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban on Saturday attacked several provinces in northern Afghanistan, overrunning large parts of one district even as American diplomats expressed optimism that a peace process stalled over the release of prisoners was getting back on track.

headline: New Orleans Restaurants, Used to Disasters, Reckon With Something Worse
abstract: The dining and bar scene, so central to the city’s identity, emerged strong from Hurricane Katrina. But the coronavirus crisis is different.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Tommy Tommaseo is not nostalgic for Hurricane Katrina.

headline: They Celebrated Basketball and a Birthday. Then Came Coronavirus.
abstract: A tight social circle bound by New York City basketball is hit hard by Covid-19, with three dead and others ailing.
lead_paragraph: The connections in New York City basketball run deep. Generations of boys and young men starred on the playgrounds, on the school courts, on the A.A.U. circuit. If you did not play with someone, you probably played against him.

headline: Coronavirus May Add Billions to U.S. Health Care Bill
abstract: Insurance premiums could spike as much as 40 percent next year, a new analysis warns, as employers and insurers confront the projected tens of billions of dollars in additional costs of treating coronavirus patients.
lead_paragraph: With so much still uncertain about how widespread hospitalizations for coronavirus patients will be around the United States, a new analysis says premiums could increase as much as 40 percent next year if the pandemic results in millions of Americans needing hospital stays.

headline: No Fan of Sports, a Graphic Novelist Learns to Follow the Bouncing Ball
abstract: In “Dragon Hoops,” Gene Luen Yang intercuts the thrilling wins and crushing losses of one high school team with basketball’s own turbulent history.
lead_paragraph: Like “American Born Chinese” — his groundbreaking 2006 Y.A. debut, and the first graphic novel to be a finalist for the National Book Award — Gene Luen Yang’s DRAGON HOOPS (First Second, 446 pp., $24.99; ages 14 to 18) weaves multiple story lines of American identity and anxiety into a comics format.

headline: Eat Cake for Breakfast!
abstract: This week’s popular dishes, including pasta e ceci and no-knead bread.
lead_paragraph: The week’s most popular dishes include Melissa Clark’s recipe for pantry crumb cake (above); roasted potatoes with anchovies and tuna; and Mark Bittman’s no-knead bread. Find more recipes in the collection below.

headline: Race/Related: Covid-19 and the Collapse of America’s Welfare State
abstract: “In the United States, people are supposed to survive on their own. Those who cannot, are often left to sink.”
lead_paragraph: [Race affects our lives in countless ways. To read provocative stories on race from The Times, sign up here for our weekly Race/Related newsletter.]

headline: Covid-19 Brings Out All the Usual Zombies
abstract: Why virus denial resembles climate denial.
lead_paragraph: Let me summarize the Trump administration/right-wing media view on the coronavirus: It’s a hoax, or anyway no big deal. Besides, trying to do anything about it would destroy the economy. And it’s China’s fault, which is why we should call it the “Chinese virus.”

headline: A Box of Secrets Led to the Story of Her Father’s Painful Wartime Past
abstract: Ariana Neumann’s father had nightmares and an ID card in a different name. In her memoir, “When Time Stopped,” she unspools the past he kept hidden for so long.
lead_paragraph: WHEN TIME STOPPED A Memoir of My Father’s War and What RemainsBy Ariana Neumann

headline: A World Without Partisan Gerrymanders? Virginia Democrats Show the Way
abstract: In a rare move, a group of lawmakers voted to give up their own redistricting power.
lead_paragraph: Politicians rarely give up power voluntarily. They never give it up when they have free rein to lock it in for at least a decade, and exact long-overdue revenge against their political opponents.

headline: We Can Safely Restart the Economy in June. Here’s How.
abstract: Get tough now. Test widely to isolate those infected, and slowly revive businesses with workers and customers who have developed immunity.
lead_paragraph: The argument that harsh restrictions on business and social interaction during the Covid-19 pandemic will do more harm than good has real power. Unemployment is projected to rise to 30 percent in a few months, and an economic contraction in the second quarter of 15 percent or more has been forecast.

headline: Virus as Metaphor
abstract: There’s a long history of illness being used to stoke hatred. We cannot succumb to it now.
lead_paragraph: President Trump and some of his allies have made a point of calling the coronavirus a “Chinese virus,” the “Wuhan virus” or, simply, a “foreign virus.” Senator Tom Cotton of Arkansas even suggested the Chinese had devised the virus as a biological weapon. They would like us to believe that the disease is like a foreign invasion, an alien attack on the people of the United States.

headline: When the Mundane Becomes Heroic
abstract: These are the people still working on a single block in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: On March 20, in an effort to control the growing number of coronavirus cases in New York — New York City in particular — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo issued an executive order requiring all nonessential businesses to keep their workers at home. Restaurants, grocery stores, pharmacies, convenience stores and hardware stores are all deemed essential, and all are allowed to remain open.

headline: Tom Coburn, the ‘Dr. No’ of Congress, Is Dead at 72
abstract: His prolific use of a bill-blocking measure earned him his nickname, but he also won grudging respect on Capitol Hill as a political maverick.
lead_paragraph: Tom Coburn, an ultraconservative Oklahoma Republican and family physician who in 16 years in Congress crusaded for limited government, using a rule-book technicality to block so many bills that frustrated legislators called him “Dr. No,” died on Saturday in Tulsa. He was 72.

headline: In a Town Where Meth Is Eclipsing Opioids, Everyone Feels the Pain
abstract: One Kentucky community has seen a wave of violence and homelessness as methamphetamine use returns.
lead_paragraph: LOUISA, Ky. — Home deliveries from the local food bank now require a police escort. A shop owner has started to carry her gun to work. And the local constable, who rarely had to pull his weapon in the past, has drawn it a dozen times over the past year.

headline: Coronavirus Crisis Awakens a Sleeping Giant: China’s Youth
abstract: How the ruling Communist Party manages the coming months will help shape how hundreds of millions of young people see its authoritarian political bargain for decades to come.
lead_paragraph: Students have flooded social media to organize donations for Chinese doctors battling the coronavirus epidemic. Workers have marched in the streets to demand compensation for weeks of unemployment during citywide lockdowns. Young citizen journalists have taken to YouTube to call for free speech.

headline: Trump to Issue Travel Advisory for N.Y. Region, Backing Off Quarantine Threat
abstract: The suggestion of a quarantine, which would have been a drastic exercise of power, drew swift condemnation and surprised top officials in the area.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said Saturday night that he would not impose a quarantine on New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, but would instead issue a “strong” travel advisory for the region to be enacted by the governors of the three states.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, !!? — #%&?!!
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — I assume that I’m not alone in feeling shellshocked by today’s puzzle, like finding out that the bus driver you say hello to every morning is actually a Formula One driver when she is called upon to cut off a fleeing vehicle on the highway. One minute you’re settling in for your pleasant regular commute, the next you’re holding on for dear life trying to make sense of the situation.

headline: A Unanimous Senate Vote That Nobody Seemed to Agree On
abstract: Lawmakers unanimously approved a historic government aid package, but the debate was vicious.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a four-year stretch marked by an acrimonious fight over a Supreme Court vacancy, the poisonous Kavanaugh confirmation and a bitter impeachment trial, was it too much to hope that a global health and economic crisis could suddenly rid the Senate of its own partisan infection?

headline: How the Young Deal With the Coronavirus
abstract: High school and college students urge their cohort to take the threat seriously, and adults reassure the young that past adversities and uncertainties have been overcome.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Alone on the Road, a Trucker’s Long Haul as America Fights the Virus
abstract: Darrell Woolsey does not know when he will go home to Wyoming and his wife and three children.
lead_paragraph: Like so many other long-haul truckers, pumping wares of a gasping economy through the arteries of the nation’s highway system, Darrell Woolsey sees the changing landscape through his windshield.

headline: Medical Expert Who Corrects Trump Is Now a Target of the Far Right
abstract: Dr. Anthony Fauci, the administration’s most outspoken advocate of emergency virus measures, faces a torrent of false claims that he is mobilizing to undermine the president.
lead_paragraph: At a White House briefing on the coronavirus on March 20, President Trump called the State Department the “Deep State Department.” Behind him, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, dropped his head and rubbed his forehead.

headline: Cuomo Postpones New York’s Primary Election to June 23 Because of Coronavirus
abstract: New York became the latest state to move its primary in an attempt to limit the risk of spreading the virus.
lead_paragraph: New York will postpone its April 28 presidential primary until June 23, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Saturday, buying time for the state to administer an election as it struggles to respond to the escalating coronavirus outbreak.

headline: With Coronavirus Disrupting College, Should Every Student Pass?
abstract: College students across the country are pushing to abolish grades, saying the only letters that matter now are C-O-V-I-D.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Polanco was living in a dormitory just two weeks ago, taking classes and thinking mostly about getting good grades and life after graduation. Now he is back in Clifton, N.J., home schooling his 12-year-old sister, doing household chores and worrying about the health of his relatives in the Dominican Republic.

headline: The Lost Month: How a Failure to Test Blinded the U.S. to Covid-19
abstract: Aggressive screening might have helped contain the coronavirus in the United States. But technical flaws, regulatory hurdles and lapses in leadership let it spread undetected for weeks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Early on, the dozen federal officials charged with defending America against the coronavirus gathered day after day in the White House Situation Room, consumed by crises. They grappled with how to evacuate the United States consulate in Wuhan, China, ban Chinese travelers and extract Americans from the Diamond Princess and other cruise ships.

headline: The U.S.’s Slow Start to Coronavirus Testing: A Timeline
abstract: Technical flaws, regulatory hurdles and failures of leadership impeded early screening in the United States, allowing the pandemic to spread.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization says that Chinese health officials in Wuhan revealed a “cluster of cases of pneumonia of unknown cause.”

headline: Rational Panic, but Also Rational Hope
abstract: We need to recognize any signposts leading up and out.
lead_paragraph: For far too long, America’s response to the coronavirus lacked what you might call rational panic. From the experts to the markets to the president and his cable-television court, an irrational calm prevailed when a general freak-out might have prepared us for the crisis.

headline: Who Killed Keylan Knapp?
abstract: My childhood friend has joined America’s “deaths of despair.”
lead_paragraph: Among the kids who boarded my No. 6 school bus each morning near Yamhill, Ore., were the Knapps, five smart and rambunctious children whose family had recently bought their first home and were full of confidence in the future.

headline: What Shakespeare Teaches Us About Living With Pandemics
abstract: Plague erased social, gender and personal differences. Shakespeare responded by emphasizing people’s unique and inerasable difference. His work is a narrative vaccine.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, England — Twitter has been taunting us: When he was in quarantine from the plague, William Shakespeare wrote “King Lear.”

headline: Germany Has Relatively Few Deaths From Coronavirus. Why?
abstract: The country is not immune to the pandemic. So what explains its current low fatality rate?
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Europe is in crisis.

headline: The Healing Power of ‘Steven Universe’
abstract: The hit cartoon series has helped me process my biracial identity.
lead_paragraph: For most of my life, Taiwan was a place that lived in my head. My mother told me her origin stories like a series of tall tales, full of pitched, tin roofs and fields of underbrush that my grandmother used to drive through on her moped, lifting her legs to avoid snake bites.

headline: ‘Women Will Not Be Forced to Be Alone When They Are Giving Birth’
abstract: In response to some private hospitals’ decision to bar partners, New York will order all hospitals to allow partners in delivery rooms, despite the coronavirus risk.
lead_paragraph: Women preparing to give birth at some hospitals in New York City will no longer have to labor alone,  state officials said Saturday.

headline: Instacart Shoppers Plan to Strike Over Coronavirus Protections
abstract: As many as 200,000 workers could walk off the job unless demands for improved equipment and hazard pay are met.
lead_paragraph: Workers for Instacart, a tech company that delivers groceries and other household items ordered through an app, plan a nationwide strike on Monday, maintaining that the company has not provided them with supplies to protect them from being infected during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Russian State Oil Company Rosneft, in Sudden Move, Sells Assets in Venezuela
abstract: The U.S. had imposed sanctions on two Rosneft oil trading subsidiaries this year for helping Venezuela’s authoritarian president, Nicolás Maduro.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The Russian state-controlled oil firm Rosneft said Saturday it was ceasing operations in Venezuela and selling all of its assets in the country, signaling a shift in Kremlin strategy that could further rattle Venezuela’s crumbling economy.

headline: The Race for Virus Money Is On. Lobbyists Are Standing By.
abstract: Companies see the outbreak as a chance to cash in, do some good, or both. Among the early winners: the Washington influence industry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government is open for coronavirus business, and the scramble to get some of it is on.

headline: N.Y.C.’s 911 System Is Overwhelmed. ‘I’m Terrified,’ a Paramedic Says.
abstract: With coronavirus cases mounting, emergency workers are making life-or-death decisions about who goes to a hospital, and who is left behind.
lead_paragraph: The first of many calls that night involved a 24-year-old man who had a fever, body aches and a cough that sounded like a cement mixer.

headline: Ray Mantilla, Percussionist Who Transcended Genres, Dies at 85
abstract: He was adept at a range of instruments, particularly the congas and timbales, and he could make himself at home in almost any ensemble.
lead_paragraph: Ray Mantilla, a percussionist and bandleader whose career spanned six decades and an array of styles in jazz, Latin music and beyond, died on March 21 in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: Finding Comfort in a Bottle of Familiar Wine
abstract: In times of fear and anxiety, we find solace in foods that conjure up memories and emotions. Why not wines?
lead_paragraph: Like so many others, my wife and I have been self-isolating in our apartment, doing our best to stay close to our loved ones from afar, and cooking the foods that we find most comforting: split-pea soup, various bean dishes, spaghetti and meatballs, just for starters.

headline: Keep the Change
abstract: Ricky Cruz’s Sunday debut rewards scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Ricky Cruz is 22 years old and this is his second puzzle for The Times this month, as well as his first Sunday grid. As Will Shortz says in the print introduction, Mr. Cruz is a video game concept artist, creating detailed environments for 3-D games; this is his attempt to turn a crossword “into a fun visual experience.”

headline: Rhode Island Pulls Over New Yorkers to Keep the Virus at Bay
abstract: Police and National Guard troops are deployed to warn visitors they must self-quarantine, as local resentment builds toward people fleeing coronavirus hot spots.
lead_paragraph: Police officers were watching Rhode Island’s highways, bridges and bus stops. National Guard troops were trudging through resort towns with clipboards, knocking on doors. They were all hunting for fleeing New Yorkers and their telltale Empire State license plates.

headline: U.S. Civil Rights Office Rejects Rationing Medical Care Based on Disability, Age
abstract: Medical providers must not engage in “ruthless utilitarianism” in deciding who gets lifesaving treatment for the coronavirus, a federal civil rights officer warned.
lead_paragraph: The director of the federal health department’s civil rights office said on Saturday that his office was opening a series of civil rights investigations to ensure that states did not allow medical providers to discriminate on the basis of disabilities, race, age or certain other factors when deciding who would receive lifesaving medical care during the coronavirus emergency.

headline: Tokyo Olympics Organizers Considering July 2021 for Opening Ceremony
abstract: The 2020 Summer Games, postponed because of the coronavirus pandemic, would start July 23, 2021, under a plan organizers are considering.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Summer Olympics in Tokyo, postponed because of the coronavirus pandemic, will likely open on July 23, 2021, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: National Enquirer Publisher Is Cutting Employees’ Pay
abstract: American Media is the latest media outlet to announce cuts as the coronavirus has shaken the economy and the advertising market.
lead_paragraph: American Media Inc., the publisher of The National Enquirer, Men’s Journal, Us Weekly and other titles, is cutting the pay of its employees by more than 20 percent, a spokesman said on Saturday, as the coronavirus has shaken the economy and the advertising market.

headline: 6 Siblings Killed in House Fire in Rural Indiana, Officials Say
abstract: The five youngest siblings lived at the family home, which was destroyed in the fire, and the eldest had been staying there for a few weeks, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Six siblings, ranging in age from 25 to 10 years old, were killed in a fire that destroyed a family home in rural Indiana early Saturday morning, officials said.

headline: FEMA Says at Least 7 People at the Disaster Agency Have the Coronavirus
abstract: Union officials at FEMA say they would like to know where they work in order to warn other employees who might  be exposed and to avoid putting the public at added risk.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The agency leading the nation’s coronavirus response said that seven of its employees had tested positive for the virus with another four cases pending, though in a letter to its employees’ union, it declined a request to say where they were located, prompting criticism from the union that the agency was jeopardizing public health.

headline: 4-Year-Old Girl, Lost in the Woods for 48 Hours, Is Found Unharmed
abstract: “Ecstatic may not be a good enough word — it was extremely emotional,” Sheriff Jay Jones of Lee County, Ala., said of finding Evelyn Sides, better known as Vadie.
lead_paragraph: Evelyn Sides, better known as Vadie, and her dog Lucy were playing in the backyard of a family friend’s house on Wednesday when they suddenly wandered off into the deep Alabama woods. When the friend who had been watching 4-year-old Vadie realized she was missing, she called 911.

headline: Tornado Strikes Jonesboro, Ark., Injuring 22, Officials Say
abstract: Many residents were staying home because of the coronavirus pandemic, reducing the number of those hurt, the mayor said.
lead_paragraph: A tornado cut through the heart of Jonesboro, Ark., on Saturday evening, leaving 22 people with minor injuries and damaging a mall, local business and an airport, according to the authorities.

headline: Figuring Out Home Schooling in the Age of Coronavirus
abstract: Two journalists, with five children between them, discuss what life is like with schools closed and kids at home.
lead_paragraph: — Corinne Purtill, a Los Angeles-based journalist who covers health, science and technology

headline: Mike Longo, Jazz Pianist, Composer and Educator, Dies at 83
abstract: Best known for his long association with Dizzy Gillespie, Mr. Longo, who died of the coronavirus, also led a big band and promoted the work of other musicians.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: How Much Should the Public Know About Who Has the Coronavirus?
abstract: Amid calls for more transparency, a debate is raging among public health experts over how much data on the spread of the virus should be released.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — When the first case of the coronavirus in Silicon Valley was discovered in late January, health officials were faced with a barrage of questions: What city did the patient live in? Whom had he come in contact with? Which health clinic had he visited before he knew he was infected?

headline: North Korea Launches Two Short-Range Ballistic Missiles
abstract: The country has carried out a handful of similar tests this month. The missiles fell into waters between the North and Japan.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles off its east coast on Sunday, a week after its leader received a letter from President Trump offering to help the country fight the coronavirus, the South Korean military said.

headline: James L. Dolan, the Knicks Owner, Tests Positive for the Coronavirus
abstract: Dolan is the first N.B.A. owner to publicly confirm
lead_paragraph: James L. Dolan, the owner of the Knicks, has tested positive for the coronavirus, the team announced Saturday night in a statement.

headline: Margaret Walker, Aran Clair
abstract: The couple met at Princeton, from which they graduated.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Frances Matilda Walker and Aran Lundgren Clair were married March 25 on the plaza of the Arlington Courthouse in Arlington, Va. Isabel Kaldenbach, a civil celebrant authorized by the Arlington County Circuit Court, officiated. The couple originally planned to marry at the First Presbyterian Church in Nashville before the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended that events with 50 or more be postponed.

headline: Jenna Kaye-Kauderer, Scott Steinberg
abstract: They are to hike with their families through Medicine Bow–Routt National Forests in Colorado to find a spot for the ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Jenna Blair Kaye-Kauderer and Scott Michael Steinberg are to be married March 29 in Medicine Bow-Routt National Forests in Steamboat Springs, Colo. Halley Kaye-Kauderer, the bride’s sister, who is affiliated with Open Ministry, is to officiate. The couple had originally planned to wed at the Champagne Powder Room, an events space at the top of the mountain, before the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended that events with 50 or more be postponed.

headline: Tracy Meng, Kyle Matson
abstract: The couple attended the same church and worked for the same San Francisco company, but they were brought together by the dating app Hinge.
lead_paragraph: Tracy Lingchen Meng and Kyle Andrew Matson were married March 28 at their home in San Francisco. James W. Carson, a friend of the couple who was deputized as a temporary officiant by Marin County, Calif., officiated.

headline: Trump Extends Social Distancing Guidelines to April 30 as U.S. Cases Top 140,000
abstract: The global count has passed 700,000, an official warns Britain that some kind of lockdown may last for months and Joe Biden urges mail-in elections.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read our global live coverage on the coronavirus pandemic here.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Driving the Long Haul, and Sensing a Slowdown
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 29, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “I live in something smaller than a jail cell all the time. I hear other people complaining and I’m like, get over it. There’s a lot of us living like this all the time, coronavirus or not.”

headline: Corrections: March 29, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 29, 2020.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article on Page 32 about the Stellenbosch Triennale misidentified a member of the Asafo Black collective from Ghana. He is Jeffrey Otoo, not Daniel Mensah.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Portrait of a Lady on Fire’ and ‘Beef House’
abstract: Watch a tender romance on Hulu, or try out a new sitcom from Tim Heidecker and Eric Wareheim.
lead_paragraph: PORTRAIT OF A LADY ON FIRE (2019) Stream on Hulu. Much of this moving love story from the filmmaker Céline Sciamma is told through intense gazes and delicate gestures. Marianne (Noémie Merlant), an artist in 18th-century France, is commissioned to paint a portrait of Héloïse (Adèle Haenel), a lonely noblewoman who is soon to be married off. The portrait is a gift for Héloïse’s future husband, but she is dreading the wedding and refuses to sit for the painting. So her mother hires Marianne as a companion and asks her to create the artwork in secret after observing Héloïse’s every move. Her looks don’t go unnoticed. The more time Héloïse and Marianne spend alone, the deeper they fall into a passionate affair. The main draw here is the romance, but the movie is also a tale of sisterhood: an examination of women breaking free from the shackles of tradition, class and patriarchy.

headline: India’s Coronavirus Lockdown Leaves Vast Numbers Stranded and Hungry
abstract: The sudden shutdown of businesses has upended the lives of millions of migrant laborers in Indian cities. More than a dozen migrants have died, and anger is rising.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In one of the biggest migrations in India’s modern history, hundreds of thousands of migrant laborers have begun long journeys on foot to get home, having been rendered homeless and jobless by Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s nationwide lockdown to contain the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Judge Urges Release of Migrant Children After 4 Test Positive for Coronavirus in Detention
abstract: “The threat of irreparable injury to their health and safety is palpable,” said lawyers seeking the release of thousands of migrant children being held in federal custody.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Concerned that thousands of migrant children in federal detention facilities could be in danger of contracting the coronavirus, a federal judge in Los Angeles late on Saturday ordered the government to “make continuous efforts” to release them from custody.

headline: ‘I Saw Another Woman on the Platform Do an Obvious Double Take’
abstract: Seeing a familiar face while waiting for the No. 6, a snack on the go and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Egypt’s Female Lion Tamers Show the Men How to Do It
abstract: The broader struggle for women’s equality may be lagging in Egypt, but six women dominate the field of lion taming in the country.
lead_paragraph: GAMASA, Egypt — At her apartment in a seaside town, Luba el-Helw, a working Egyptian mother, faced multiple demands. She juggled business calls, prepared a chicken dish and parried the demands of her three sons, aged 4 to 8, who were stretched out before the TV.

headline: Rich Europeans Flee Virus for 2nd Homes, Spreading Fear and Fury
abstract: In France and the rest of Europe, the affluent decamp cities to spend their confinement in vacation homes, widening class divides.
lead_paragraph: ÎLE DE NOIRMOUTIER, France — On their peaceful island off France’s Atlantic Coast, some of the locals watched, with growing dread and rage, the images from Paris. As rumors began circulating about an imminent nationwide lockdown to stem the coronavirus outbreak, hordes of Parisians jammed into trains, an odd surfboard sometimes sticking out of the crowd.

headline: Is the U.S. Headed Toward a Short British-Style Election?
abstract: Party conventions are in jeopardy, campaigning is on hold and local candidates are playing the role of good Samaritan instead of traditional politician.
lead_paragraph: From the White House to the county courthouse, the coronavirus pandemic has drastically upended the 2020 elections.

headline: The Week in Business: Throwing Money at a Pandemic
abstract: As unemployment numbers broke a grim record, Congress rushed to pass a $2 trillion rescue bill.
lead_paragraph: There’s no way to sugarcoat the devastating numbers that came out this past week. As the United States surpassed China in the number of confirmed coronavirus cases, record-high jobless numbers brought the economic toll of the pandemic into sharp focus. Congress rushed to push through a rescue bill. But will it be enough?

headline: The U.S. Tried to Build a New Fleet of Ventilators. The Mission Failed.
abstract: As the coronavirus spreads, the collapse of the project helps explain America’s acute shortage.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen years ago, a group of U.S. public health officials came up with a plan to address what they regarded as one of the medical system’s crucial vulnerabilities: a shortage of ventilators.

headline: They Asked Black Artists About Inspiration. Here, They Share Their Own.
abstract: Staff members from across The New York Times on 21st-century African-American artistry.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Crisis in the Sahel Becoming France’s Forever War
abstract: Riding along with French troops hunting Islamist militants in France’s unwinnable West African war.
lead_paragraph: AWAGATE FOREST, MALI — For two days, dozens of armored vehicles carrying 180 elite soldiers with the French Foreign Legion lumbered over West Africa’s scrubby savanna to reach a suspected hide-out for Islamist militants.

headline: Coronavirus, New York, Sabrina Ionescu: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Krzysztof Penderecki, Polish Composer With Cinematic Flair, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Penderecki’s modernist compositions turned up in films like “The Exorcist” and influenced a generation of edgy rock musicians.
lead_paragraph: Krzysztof Penderecki, a Polish composer and conductor whose modernist works jumped from the concert hall to popular culture, turning up in soundtracks for films like “The Exorcist” and “The Shining” and influencing a generation of edgy rock musicians, died on Sunday at his home in Krakow. He was 86.

headline: ‘Thousands of People Will Pass Away’ From Virus, Cuomo Warns
abstract: Mayor de Blasio said the city had only a week’s worth of medical supplies as the death toll continued to climb.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Monday’s live coverage.]

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘What I Learned When My Husband Got Coronavirus’
abstract: An editor at The Times shares an intimate essay about her family’s fight against the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: They Create Nightmare Worlds for TV. Now They’re Living in One.
abstract: Amid the pandemic, the producers of dystopian dramas like “The Handmaid’s Tale” and “Westworld” see their work in a different light.
lead_paragraph: They tried to warn us.

headline: 8 Killed After Philippine Plane Bursts Into Flames
abstract: All on board, including a doctor, a nurse and foreign nationals, were killed after the plane, used in the country’s coronavirus response, caught fire as it took off in Manila for Japan.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — A plane used as an air ambulance by the Philippine health department to fight the coronavirus outbreak burst into flames as it took off from Manila’s airport for Japan on Sunday night, killing all onboard, the airport said.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Pasta with white sausage sauce, a spicy white bean stew, kimchi soup are just a few of the very good things you can make this week.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. My friend David Carr, who died in 2015, had a line about newspapering that’s true of cooking as well. David, one of the great journalists of his generation and a voice in The Times I miss every day, would deploy it as a plain statement of fact, nothing to be ashamed of, generally after a long day of work that didn’t amount to much on the page. Big sigh, then: “Sometimes it’s not very good.”

headline: Now Playing Nightly on Instagram: Sketch Comedy’s Newest Star
abstract: Names big and small are pivoting to online humor, but the standouts are the character-driven performers who were there all along, especially Meg Stalter.
lead_paragraph: Everyone in comedy is now either an internet star or an aspiring one.

headline: Cuomo: ‘Thousands Will Pass Away’
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said on Sunday that 237 people had died since the day before, the largest one-day increase in the state since the coronavirus outbreak began.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said on Sunday that 237 people had died since the day before, the largest one-day increase in the state since the coronavirus outbreak began.

headline: Oil Prices Crash, Virus Hits, Commerce Stops: Iraq Is in Trouble.
abstract: Iraq depends on oil revenues, which have plummeted. The country is so desperate it is asking for donations to help it weather the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — When Iraq recorded its first cases of coronavirus, its health minister asked the government for $5 million in emergency funds. But there were no funds to be had.

headline: A Health Crisis, as Seen From Inside a Prison
abstract: An inmate talks about the AIDS experience, and a leader in prison education stresses the value of in-person teaching.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Grandchildren: ‘Our Joy and Our Job’
abstract: A grandmother suggests ways of helping children and families in this difficult time. Also: The lack of diversity at Stuyvesant High School in New York.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Looking for Uplifting Stories in a Dark Time
abstract: We ask readers for examples of how the pandemic has brought out the best in humanity.
lead_paragraph: The world is facing a crisis as the coronavirus spreads. But sometimes challenges bring out the best in people. There are stories of citizens going out of their way to help one another as well as supporting local businesses, crafting masks, setting up food banks, etc. We’d like to hear about your uplifting experiences in the midst of this tragedy.

headline: How Skiing Through a Pandemic Can Create a Community Crisis
abstract: North American ski resorts have closed in response to the coronavirus, but mountain sports have still drawn crowds, alarming public safety officials.
lead_paragraph: As winter sports resorts in North America closed in response to the coronavirus outbreak, skiers and snowboarders began flocking to backcountry trails or to slopes where they could trek uphill and then take a downhill run. Though the activities are not forbidden, public officials have begun imploring the skiers and snowboarders to scale back.

headline: A Fight Over Money, Loyalty and Who Gets Credit for an Artist’s Rise
abstract: Derek Fordjour and the gallery that once worked with him are battling in court over pieces he promised to create before his career took off.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, when Derek Fordjour was a little-known art student at Hunter College, before Michael Ovitz and Beyoncé began collecting his work, before his paintings came to sell for more than $100,000, the fledgling artist struck a deal with a New York gallery.

headline: Tech Giants Prepared for 2016-Style Meddling. But the Threat Has Changed.
abstract: After spending billions to avoid a repeat of 2016, the tech giants are careening from crisis to crisis as their foes change tactics.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The day after the New Hampshire primary last month, Facebook’s security team removed a network of fake accounts that originated in Iran, which had posted divisive partisan messages about the U.S. election inside private Facebook groups.

headline: How Russia’s Troll Farm Is Changing Tactics Before the Fall Election
abstract: The Kremlin-backed Internet Research Agency, which interfered in the 2016 election, is using different methods to hide itself better.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of November’s election, American intelligence officials and others are on high alert for mischief from Russia’s Internet Research Agency.

headline: The Coronavirus Is Upending Life in Rural America, Too
abstract: People here are stocking up on groceries and toilet paper — and guns and ammo and, soon, morel mushrooms.
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Iowa — How are things in my state during the pandemic? In a nearby town, about 20 miles away, people are caught up in it like many Americans. There’s been a run on canned goods, frozen pizzas and, of course, toilet paper.

headline: Who Will Win the Fight for a Post-Coronavirus America?
abstract: Every disaster shakes loose the old order. What replaces it is up to us.
lead_paragraph: The scramble has already begun. The possibilities for change, for the better or the worse, for a more egalitarian or more authoritarian society, burst out of the gate like racehorses at times like these.

headline: Liberty University Brings Back Its Students, and Coronavirus Fears, Too
abstract: The decision by the school’s president, Jerry Falwell Jr., to partly reopen his evangelical university enraged residents of Lynchburg, Va. Then students started getting sick.
lead_paragraph: Updated March 30, 2020: This story has been changed to reflect the first known positive coronavirus test of a Liberty University student.

headline: What Social Distancing Looked Like in 1666
abstract: Humanity has been surviving plagues for thousands of years, and we have managed to learn a lot along the way.
lead_paragraph: A lot of English people believed 1666 would be the year of the apocalypse. You can’t really blame them. In late spring 1665, bubonic plague began to eat away at London’s population. By fall, roughly 7,000 people were dying every week in the city. The plague lasted through most of 1666, ultimately killing about 100,000 people in London alone — and possibly as many as three-quarters of a million in England as a whole.

headline: How Asian-American Leaders Are Grappling With Xenophobia Amid Coronavirus
abstract: As Asian-Americans face racist attacks and President Trump has tied the virus to China, community and political leaders have tried to comfort constituents. But even they admit to feeling unnerved.
lead_paragraph: Soon after President Trump first uttered the phrase “Chinese virus,” Representative Grace Meng got a call from her parents, who had read about it in the newspaper. Had Mr. Trump, they wondered, really given the coronavirus that corrosive moniker?

headline: Nothing Matters Anymore (Except What Actually Does)
abstract: There’s so much I did two months ago that seems ludicrous now.
lead_paragraph: I was committed to dying without ever learning the Electric Slide. You know how everyone has a thing, one of those random eccentricities people associate with you? I was the “guy who always sits during the Electric Slide.” Do you realize how resolute you must be, as a 41-year-old black American man, to attend decades worth of cookouts, birthday parties, game nights, family reunions and wedding receptions and not allow yourself to learn the World’s Mildest Line Dance?

headline: Michael Sorkin, 71, Dies; Saw Architecture as a Vehicle for Change
abstract: Mr. Sorkin, who died of the coronavirus, promoted social justice in his prodigious output of essays, lectures and designs.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: China Created a Fail-Safe System to Track Contagions. It Failed.
abstract: After SARS, Chinese health officials built an infectious disease reporting system to evade political meddling. But when the coronavirus emerged, so did fears of upsetting Beijing.
lead_paragraph: The alarm system was ready. Scarred by the SARS epidemic that erupted in 2002, China had created an infectious disease reporting system that officials said was world-class: fast, thorough and, just as important, immune from meddling.

headline: Community Radio Fights to Stay Live (and Weird) Despite Coronavirus
abstract: Local stations have cut down on D.J.s coming to the studio, but playlists and personalities are holding strong as small stations get a chance to build bigger audiences.
lead_paragraph: “Greetings, virus people!”

headline: What Sept. 11 Taught Us About Confronting Catastrophe
abstract: Unused emergency gurneys, a defining image from 9/11, have much to tell us today, when there isn’t a bed to spare. A veteran E.R. nurse explains.
lead_paragraph: From careful planning and much drilling, medical workers knew without being told that they should roll a fleet of gurneys and wheelchairs onto the sidewalk outside St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, New York’s last mortal catastrophe.

headline: ‘A Heart-Wrenching Thing’: Hospital Bans on Visits Devastate Families
abstract: To curb the risk of spreading the coronavirus, hospitals nationwide are banning visits from family and friends.
lead_paragraph: The last time Peter John Dario saw his father alive was on March 14, at the entrance to a hospital in Edison, N.J. An employee took him away in a wheelchair, telling Mr. Dario and his mother gently but unequivocally that they could not go in the building.

headline: Coronavirus, India’s Lockdown, North Korea: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Teachers’ Herculean Task: Moving 1.1 Million Children to Online School
abstract: New York City’s 75,000 public school educators are facing a challenge unlike anything in their careers. For students to avoid permanent setbacks, the success of remote learning is critical.
lead_paragraph: In the days before remote instruction began, Chauntae Brown, a second-grade teacher at P.S. 80 in Jamaica, Queens, scrambled to teach parents without Wi-Fi how to use cellphone hot spots. She rummaged in her garage to find materials — a world map, a “Welcome” sign, an apple-shaped chalkboard — to transform her living room wall into a classroom. She grabbed a plastic tiara because, she said, “I’m the queen of this castle.”

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 30, 2020
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Students

headline: Gargling for Coronavirus? What Science Can Tell Us
abstract: There is no firm proof that gargling prevents respiratory infections caused by coronavirus — or any virus or bacteria. But there’s also little downside.
lead_paragraph: As Americans search for ways to fight the spread of the coronavirus, one popular topic that has generated interest on the internet is gargling. What’s behind the gargling claim, and is there any medical proof that gargling may help to fight coronavirus or other respiratory infections?

headline: Typographic Flourish
abstract: It’s Monday, and Lee Taylor is calling us names.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Hey, it’s Lee Taylor, making her Monday debut! She’s constructed a couple of Sunday grids for us, which makes for an interesting progression and a perfect segue to a suggestion for solvers. If you’re feeling good about solving a puzzle like today’s, take a crack at Ms. Taylor’s Sunday puzzle from 2015. Its theme is really cute and approachable, disagreeing clichés like “You can’t judge a book by its cover” and “Clothes make the man.” If solving a Sunday is on your social distancing bucket list, it’s not a bad one to try.

headline: White House Airlifts Medical Supplies From China in Coronavirus Fight
abstract: Officials have teamed up with medical supply companies to speed the arrival of masks, gloves, gowns and other goods.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A commercial aircraft carrying 80 tons of gloves, masks, gowns and other medical supplies from Shanghai touched down in New York on Sunday, the first of 22 scheduled flights that White House officials say will funnel much-needed goods to the United States by early April as it battles the world’s largest coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Bail Out Journalists. Let Newspaper Chains Die.
abstract: The coronavirus is likely to hasten the end of advertising-driven media, our columnist writes. And government should not rescue it.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Green was musing the other day about buying 261 newspapers.

headline: Trump Is Hurting His Own Re-election Chances
abstract: Don’t be fooled by snapshot polls.
lead_paragraph: The strangest part of President Trump’s coronavirus response is that it’s almost certainly damaging his chances of re-election.

headline: The Psychological Trauma That Awaits Our Doctors and Nurses
abstract: Don’t underestimate the moral anguish of deciding who gets a ventilator.
lead_paragraph: This is the moment to pray for the psychological welfare of our health care professionals. In the months ahead, many will witness unimaginable scenes of suffering and death, modern Pietàs without Marys, in which victims are escorted into hospitals by their loved ones and left to die alone.

headline: Coronavirus Slowdown in Seattle Suggests Restrictions Are Working
abstract: Officials in Washington State worry that their gains are precarious, but they see evidence that containment strategies have lowered the rate of virus transmission.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The Seattle area, home of the first known coronavirus case in the United States and the place where the virus claimed 37 of its first 50 victims, is now seeing evidence that strict containment strategies, imposed in the earliest days of the outbreak, are beginning to pay off — at least for now.

headline: A City Hunkered Down to Survive an Outbreak. That Helped in a Tornado, Too.
abstract: Jonesboro, Ark., came through a devastating tornado without any deaths, partly because businesses were closed and people were sheltered at home from the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Some in Jonesboro, Ark., saw a miracle on Saturday after a tornado roared through town. It tore through businesses already closed by the coronavirus and  neighborhoods where people had already been told to social distance by hunkering down at home. Not a soul died.

headline: Trump Said He Was the President of Manufacturing. Then Disaster Struck.
abstract: For a leader who has embraced the language of a wartime president, it is as if the Pentagon asked for missiles and bombers but wouldn’t say how many or where they should be delivered.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump came to office, he promised a new day with America’s manufacturers, casting himself as the first president who understood their needs. He toured factory floors, often handing out his signature “Make America Great Again” hats.

headline: The Politics of a Pandemic
abstract: Trump wants us to see him as defeating a foreign enemy.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic is first and foremost a global public health crisis. But here in the United States — as is likely true in other countries — the response to it is heavily overlaid with political calculations. It is both obvious and inevitable. The crisis is unfolding in the lead-up to the election.

headline: Trump Extends Social Distancing Guidelines Through End of April
abstract: The president, facing grim figures from his health advisers, starkly reversed an earlier upbeat assessment that the country could relax the guidelines by Easter.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump retreated Sunday from his desire to relax coronavirus guidelines by Easter, announcing instead that all Americans must continue to avoid nonessential travel, going to work, eating at bars and restaurants, or gathering in groups of more than 10 for at least another month and perhaps until June.

headline: ‘Group of Local Vigilantes’ Try to Forcibly Quarantine Out-of-Towners, Officials Say
abstract: A group of residents from an island town in Maine cut down a tree and dragged it into the middle of a road.
lead_paragraph: A group of residents from an island town in Maine cut down a tree and dragged it into the middle of a road in an attempt to forcibly quarantine three roommates they believed could have the new coronavirus after arriving from out of state, law enforcement officials said on Saturday.

headline: ‘Westworld’ Season 3, Episode 3 Recap: Predators and Prey
abstract: Dolores is learning that we humans have our redeeming moments. Caleb learns that humans and Dolores aren’t so different.
lead_paragraph: Much of the first two seasons of “Westworld” was about the hosts wresting control of their destinies and exercising the same freedoms enjoyed by their human tormentors, who had cast them as attractions in a sadistic Disneyland for the global elite. But now that the action has shifted to the human world, the premise has been turned on its head: How much control do humans have over their destinies? It turns out to be far less than they might imagine.

headline: As Governors Plead for Tests, Trump Promises Ventilators to Europe
abstract: Maryland, Virginia and Arizona issued statewide stay-at-home orders, and the F.D.A. granted emergency approval for the use of two malaria drugs to treat some coronavirus patients.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read our global live coverage on the coronavirus pandemic here.

headline: Ford Joins Effort to Make Ventilators
abstract: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline: Coronavirus, Social Distancing, Sweden: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Quotation of the Day: Crisis Pits Patient Privacy Against Public Need to Know
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 30, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Public health depends a lot on public trust. If the public feels as though they are being misled or misinformed, their willingness to make sacrifices — in this case social distancing — is reduced.”

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘The Good Doctor’ and ‘The Schouwendam 12’
abstract: The medical drama completes its third season. And a Dutch mystery series drops on Acorn TV.
lead_paragraph: THE GOOD DOCTOR 10 p.m. on ABC. In the second part of the season finale, the doctors at San Jose St. Bonaventure Hospital continue to respond to the major earthquake that rocked their city. The crisis is testing their ingenuity and pushing their personal issues to the surface. Dr. Shaun Murphy (Freddie Highmore), the protagonist of the series, is still reeling from his latest rejection by Lea (Paige Spara), who cited Shaun’s autism as a reason not to pursue a romantic relationship with him. Undeterred, he revealed in the last episode that he hadn’t lost hope. Lea, who was trapped after the earthquake hit and eventually rescued, overheard Shaun’s comments and responded emotionally. But before they could address them, an aftershock left Shaun stranded with a patient in the flooding basement of a collapsed building.

headline: Corrections: March 30, 2020
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 30, 2020.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Sacred Heart Is No Hockey School. $60 Million Could Change That.
abstract: Under its athletic director, Bobby Valentine, the small Connecticut university is expanding its facilities in the hopes of becoming a college hockey power.
lead_paragraph: FAIRFIELD, Conn. — Sacred Heart, a Roman Catholic university tucked in the tidy suburbs along Connecticut’s southern coast, has been around since 1963 and has had a men’s ice hockey program for 27 seasons — including nine straight losing seasons entering this one.

headline: Scary Times for U.S. Companies Spell Boom for Restructuring Advisers
abstract: Corporations are saving cash, cutting costs and refinancing debt to manage the economic fallout of the coronavirus. Restructuring and bankruptcy experts are already getting calls.
lead_paragraph: Freedom Mortgage, one of the nation’s largest mortgage lenders, is looking for additional financing as millions of homeowners are expected to stop making mortgage payments. The Cheesecake Factory said this past week it wouldn’t be able to make rent payments on its leases because of lost business. And giant companies from Kraft Heinz to Ford have tapped billions of dollars in credit from banks in preparation for an uncertain future.

headline: Online, Virtual Games Escape the New Reality
abstract: With their ability to be played online, e-sports are one of the last bastions of competitive sports in a world upended by the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: NEWNAN, Ga. — A few blocks from downtown, inside a building with a brick and stucco facade, two men were immersed in an e-sports event, one of the safer competitions remaining in a sporting world upended by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: The Suffering and Scientific Legacy of a Large Family Consumed by Schizophrenia
abstract: Robert Kolker’s “Hidden Valley Road” is a vividly told story of both a very unfortunate family and a long misunderstood affliction.
lead_paragraph: Donald Galvin was a sophomore at Colorado State when he first checked into the campus health clinic to get treated for a cat bite, offering no further explanation of what had occurred. Two years and several visits later, he arrived at the clinic with another cat bite — only this time he told a doctor what happened to the cat.

headline: New York Was Not Designed for Emptiness
abstract: The energy, the traffic, the crowds are all gone. Only the vacant streets remain, waiting for the actors to return to the stage.
lead_paragraph: The energy, the traffic, the crowds are all gone. Only the vacant streets remain, waiting for the actors to return to the stage.

headline: Has Your School Switched to Remote Learning? How Is It Going So Far?
abstract: What does a “school day” now look like for you? Are you able to stay on task? Do you have enough work to do — or too much? What do you miss the most about going to school in person every day? What do you miss the least?
lead_paragraph: Has your school shifted to remote learning in response to the global pandemic? How is it going so far?

headline: Ann Patchett on Why We Need Life-Changing Books Right Now
abstract: The novelist Ann Patchett doesn’t have children and didn’t read middle-grade books. Then she picked up one by Kate DiCamillo and couldn’t stop until she’d read them all.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how it happened: In early November 2018, Kate DiCamillo came to Nashville while she was on tour for her novel “Louisiana’s Way Home.” It’s the middle book of a trilogy that started with “Raymie Nightingale” and ended last year with “Beverly, Right Here.”

headline: The Hawaii of ‘Sharks in the Time of Saviors’ Is Modern, Yet Mystical
abstract: Kawai Strong Washburn’s debut novel envisions an archipelago of Indigenous peoples who refuse to be erased.
lead_paragraph: SHARKS IN THE TIME OF SAVIORS By Kawai Strong Washburn

headline: Andrew Cuomo, Stop a Coronavirus Disaster: Release People From Prison
abstract: This is a public health crisis that threatens to become a humanitarian disaster.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has been an exemplar of leadership in this time of crisis, someone to whom other state and local officials are looking for guidance. On Friday, the governor took the crucial step of ordering the release of 1,100 people from New York’s jails and prisons. But he must do more. If we don’t act fast, we jeopardize the lives of many. Worse yet, we risk creating a uniquely deadly incubator for the virus.

headline: Is Maduro’s Indictment Anything More Than an American Bluff?
abstract: Venezuela’s leader will use the charges against him to bolster support.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — On Thursday, in the midst of the world’s most serious health and economic crisis since perhaps the Great Depression, the Trump administration charged President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela with narco-terrorism, drug trafficking and money laundering. The State Department offered a $15 million reward for information leading to the arrest of Mr. Maduro and also indicted other senior officials, including the country’s defense minister, Vladimir Padrino López, who is charged with conspiracy to smuggle narcotics.

headline: Trump Won the Internet. Democrats Are Scrambling to Take It Back.
abstract: In the era of big data, memes and disinformation, the Democrats are trying to regain their digital edge as the president and his loyalists dictate the terms of debate.
lead_paragraph: The deceptively edited video that purported to show Joseph R. Biden Jr. endorsing President Trump’s re-election bounced relentlessly around the internet, falsely painting the former vice president as too confused to know what office he was running for or whom he was vying to run against.

headline: Are Bike Lanes Really Safe?
abstract: I’ve had two recent cycling accidents in which I had the right of way but inattentive drivers cut me off.
lead_paragraph: In just the last eight months, I’ve had two cycling accidents when inattentive drivers made right turns and cut me off. So far I’ve been lucky, escaping with bloody scrapes and a bent bike wheel. But I can’t help wondering how long my luck will last.

headline: Paul Theroux Recalls a Fear-Filled Lockdown
abstract: In 1966, the writer was in Uganda at a time of curfew and violence. It shaped his thinking about travel writing’s imperative to bear witness.
lead_paragraph: In this season of infection, the stock market little more than a twitching corpse, in an atmosphere of alarm and despondency, I am reminded of the enlightenments of the strict curfew Uganda endured in 1966. It was, for all its miseries, an episode of life lessons, as well as monotonous moralizing (because most crises enliven bores and provoke sententiousness). I would not have missed it for anything.

headline: The Power of Passover During a Plague
abstract: Most Jews in history have not been free, whether from murderous regimes, famines or pandemics like this one. What we have been is devoted to the idea that we deserve to be.
lead_paragraph: This year, Passover falls at the beginning of April — smack in the middle of what some experts estimate will be the peak of the coronavirus pandemic in America. It’s not just the timing of the holiday — built around a retelling of the Jews’ exodus from slavery in Egypt — that feels off. It’s that every aspect of its story and rituals now seems almost cruelly ironic.

headline: Testing is Just the Beginning in the Battle Against Covid-19
abstract: We need a comprehensive strategy to prevent the spread of the disease.
lead_paragraph: As the United States scrambles to expand testing for coronavirus infections, the nation’s capacity for putting into place what should follow a positive result — isolating the infected and quarantining their contacts — is profoundly limited. Yet these two steps are essential for controlling the spread of Covid-19.

headline: Americans Are Already Too Diseased to Go Back to Work Right Now
abstract: The huge burden of obesity and other chronic conditions among people in the U.S. puts most of us at direct risk.
lead_paragraph: Public health measures to slow the spread of Covid-19 have already taken a staggering toll on the economy, with the prospect of worse to come. The strategy at the heart of prevention, physical distancing, will continue to be tremendously disruptive to society.

headline: ‘I Didn’t Know Whether to Mourn or to Celebrate’: An Afghan Reporter’s Girlhood Education
abstract: As a U.S. peace deal with the Taliban unfolds, a Times journalist recalls how a visit to one of Afghanistan’s most progressive rural schools triggered a bittersweet flashback to her own childhood dreams.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Retiring to New York City — and Getting a Roommate
abstract: A teacher from Maine decided to move to New York. Sharing an apartment was the only way to make it work.
lead_paragraph: Connie Ottmann, a high school English teacher from Maine, had always wanted to live in New York City. And last summer, when she was 66, seemed the right time to do it.

headline: How America Can Reopen
abstract: If summer is to bring any sense of normalcy, the country’s leaders must act quickly.
lead_paragraph: Three months into a global pandemic that is straining the fabric of America’s society, political leaders say that the nation is facing a stark choice between economic prosperity and the preservation of human life. Andrew Cuomo, the governor of New York, has given voice to the sentiments of many by insisting that every life is priceless and that the government must be prepared to sacrifice prosperity to prevent deaths. “We will not put a dollar figure on human life,” he declared.

headline: The Pandemic Book Club
abstract: How to get through this cataclysm even halfway calm: Enter a slower world.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — In a recent Facebook post, Tiffany Lauderdale Phillips described taking a call at her bookstore in Franklin, Ind.: “Wild Geese Bookshop, this is Tiffany.”

headline: Inside G.M.’s Race to Build Ventilators, Before Trump’s Attack
abstract: The automaker and its partner, Ventec, had spent more than a week figuring out how to make thousands of the lifesaving devices when the White House said G.M. was “wasting time.”
lead_paragraph: While much of the U.S. economy has ground to a halt because of the coronavirus outbreak, several dozen workers in orange vests and hard hats were hauling heavy equipment on Sunday at a General Motors plant in Kokomo, Ind.

headline: President Trump’s Prime-Time Pandemic
abstract: The coronavirus briefings have given Donald Trump a regularly scheduled reality show again — or, rather, a create-your-own-reality show.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve gotten to like this room,” President Trump said March 23 in the White House briefing room.

headline: Families Scramble to Find Baby Formula, Diapers and Wipes
abstract: Panic buying has left stores and diaper banks empty of baby essentials as shutdowns and quarantines expand across the country.
lead_paragraph: Until Catie Weimer’s baby, Arlo, was 4 months old, he would scream and pull his head away from the bottle every time she tried to feed him formula. If she got any of it into him, he’d vomit. He was born at 37 weeks, and she was already worried that he was on the small side when she learned that he had a milk protein allergy and was put on the hypoallergenic formula Alimentum.

headline: Is Your Grocery Delivery Worth a Worker’s Life?
abstract: Workers around the country are walking off the job to protest a lack of protective equipment, safety measures, even soap.
lead_paragraph: Millions of white-collar workers are telecommuting from home to stay safe as the coronavirus extends its terrifying reach across America. But millions of other workers — supermarket cashiers, pharmacists, warehouse workers, bus drivers, meatpacking workers — still have to report to work each day, and many are furious that their employers are not doing enough to protect them against the pandemic.

headline: Nurses Die, Doctors Fall Sick and Panic Rises on Virus Front Lines
abstract: The pandemic has begun to sweep through New York City’s medical ranks, and anxiety is growing among normally dispassionate medical professionals.
lead_paragraph: A supervisor urged surgeons at Columbia University Irving Medical Center in Manhattan to volunteer for the front lines because half the intensive-care staff had already been sickened by coronavirus.

headline: For Shut-In Pilgrims, the World’s Holiest Sites Are a Click Away
abstract: The pandemic has closed holy sites across the globe, but virtual reality is providing worshipers a digital window into ceremonies during touchstone holidays.
lead_paragraph: For nearly two years, Eilat Lieber, director and chief curator of the Tower of David Museum in Jerusalem’s Old City, has been excited for this April, when Passover, Easter and Ramadan — touchstone holidays of three major  religions — would collide for the first time in nearly two decades.

headline: Coronavirus Sweeps Through Detroit, a City That Has Seen Crisis Before
abstract: Cases of the virus were being reported around the city and in the Police Department. “Every day I drive home, I start crying,” a nurse said.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It has seen its population plummet, houses fall to ruin, and the largest municipal bankruptcy in the nation. Now another crisis has descended on Detroit: the coronavirus.

headline: Jobs Aren’t Being Destroyed This Fast Elsewhere. Why Is That?
abstract: It’s not too late to start protecting employment or to make medical care for Covid-19 free.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic is laying bare structural deficiencies in America’s social programs. The relief package passed by Congress last week provides emergency fixes for some of these issues, but it also leaves critical problems untouched. To avoid a Great Depression, Congress must quickly design a more forceful response to the crisis.

headline: Bogotá’s Cacophony Is Hushed by Virus as Congested Streets Empty Out
abstract: In normal times, Colombia’s crowded capital reverberates with never-ending noise. But under quarantine, the city was overtaken by an extraordinary sound: silence.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — The typical Bogotá morning starts at dawn and quickly becomes an eight million-person roar.

headline: These Days, Even a Michelin Star Chef Has to Sell Takeout
abstract: Many restaurants had been planning for a future in which delivery made up a sizable share of their business. They just didn’t expect that moment to arrive right now.
lead_paragraph: For nearly three years, the chef T.J. Steele refused to offer delivery at Claro, his Michelin star restaurant in the Gowanus neighborhood of Brooklyn.

headline: Coronavirus, New York, China: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Quarantine the Sick in New York’s Hotels
abstract: Asking the mildly ill to self-isolate at home only endangers other people in their households.
lead_paragraph: New York City today is like Wuhan, the city in central China with the first known Covid-19 outbreak, in late January.

headline: Number of Coronavirus Deaths in N.Y. Verges on 1,000
abstract: "Thousands of people will pass away," the governor warned.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: How Much Do You Know About Bangladesh?
abstract: Can you find Bangladesh on a map? What else do you know about this South Asian nation with a population of about 165 million people?
lead_paragraph: Can you find Bangladesh on a map? What else do you know about this South Asian nation with a population of about 165 million people?

headline: Back From the Brink
abstract: “You always live in fear that you’re never going to wake up.” What one medical professional learned after being the first confirmed coronavirus patient in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Facebook Aims $100 Million at Media Hit by the Coronavirus
abstract: With grants and marketing spending, the social media giant hopes to support outlets doing essential local reporting but struggling with a drop in advertising.
lead_paragraph: Facebook announced on Monday that it would dole out $25 million in grants to local news outlets and spend $75 million in a marketing drive aimed at news organizations internationally in response to the coronavirus-prompted economic downturn, which has caused advertising to plummet and has threatened media industry revenues.

headline: ‘Live! From the Basement …’
abstract: Why was Stephen Colbert in a bathtub? Working from home for some jobs requires extra creativity.
lead_paragraph: Savannah Guthrie, a co-anchor of NBC’s “Today” show, broadcasts from the basement of her home in upstate New York. Stephen Colbert drew laughs when he delivered his “The Late Show” monologue from his bathtub; and Jimmy Fallon can be found juggling “The Tonight Show” duties with his two daughters, who scribble his graphics in crayon.

headline: A Failure of Policy and Planning
abstract: When the coronavirus crisis required ramping factories to make ventilators, the government’s ability to harness factory capacity crumpled.
lead_paragraph: The goal of “opening up” the U.S. economy by April 12 didn’t last long — social-distancing guidelines have been extended to April 30. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

headline: 914 Dead in N.Y.C., and City’s Virus Case Count Tops 38,000
abstract: The outbreak’s toll continued to rise amid a hopeful sign: the arrival of a Navy hospital ship to ease the strain on the city’s overwhelmed hospitals.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Tuesday’s live coverage.]

headline: On Politics: Trump Backs Off a Promise
abstract: Social distancing will continue, and all eyes are on New York: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: President Trump and Defense Secretary Mark Esper watched the Comfort, a Navy hospital ship, depart Norfolk, Va., for New York City on Saturday to support the city’s response to the coronavirus.

headline: Xinjiang Returns to Work, but Coronavirus Worries Linger in China
abstract: The Chinese region, where hundreds of thousands of Muslims are held in indoctrination camps, has been an information void. Uighurs fear a lockdown in the region drove many to hunger.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In the Xinjiang region of northwestern China, the government says, major construction projects have resumed, oil field workers are back on the job, garment factories are making masks and spring planting is underway. Students returned to school last week, and one class was greeted by the region’s top Communist Party leader, who wore a mask while speaking to them.

headline: Can Japan’s Economy Get Any Worse? It May Soon Find Out
abstract: As the coronavirus has prolonged a deep slump in Japan, one ray of hope has come from its avoidance of a crippling lockdown. But it’s unclear whether that can last.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Even before the new coronavirus, Japan’s economy was in trouble. Exports were plummeting on slowing demand from China, and a tax increase at home was keeping shoppers out of stores. The numbers were stark: Economic output contracted 7.1 percent in the last quarter of 2019.

headline: Word + Quiz: adjutant
abstract: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Summer Olympics in Tokyo to Start on July 23, 2021
abstract: The new date for the Games, postponed for a year in response to the coronavirus pandemic, gives athletes time to recalibrate their training schedules.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of uncertainty around having the Summer Olympics and when, organizers of the event on Monday provided some clarity: The Games in Tokyo will start July 23, 2021, almost exactly a year later than originally scheduled.
