But, some couples have still managed to declare their love with creative, quarantine-approved marriage proposals.

headline: Animal Crossing Is the Perfect Way to Spend Quarantine
abstract: Can’t go outside? The new Switch video game offers a candy-colored substitute for real life.
lead_paragraph: When my parents call me these days to ask what’s new, I have nothing to tell them. I live alone, and I’ve been sequestered in my apartment for almost three weeks. Monday is Wednesday is Saturday.

headline: Changing Lives: We Are (Still) in This Together
abstract: In tales of collective adaptation, homebound college students are not going anywhere and a San Francisco newspaper proves there is no minimum age for quality journalism.
lead_paragraph: With parents clamoring to find something — anything — for their kids to do while quarantined, Chris Colin, a freelance journalist in San Francisco, gave his neighbors an assignment. The 44-year-old, who has two kids, put out a call for young reporters and artists to contribute to “Six Feet of Separation, a youth newspaper for Bernal Heights and beyond.”

headline: Has Your Dystopian Play Come in Handy?
abstract: These nine playwrights spent years dreaming up cataclysms and plagues. Did that prepare them for the current crisis? Sometimes.
lead_paragraph: In many cities, the threat of the novel coronavirus and the efforts to slow its spread have altered daily life dramatically. Ordinary objects (doorknobs, soap) seem transformed, banal activities — biting a nail, buying milk — freighted with danger. New vocabulary has emerged, as have new habits and new ways of navigating a narrowed landscape.

headline: Las Vegas Places Homeless People in a Parking Lot, 6 Feet Apart
abstract: The casinos are deserted and thousands of hotel rooms are empty. But when the city needed space for a temporary homeless shelter, officials chose an outdoor parking lot.
lead_paragraph: The casinos are deserted and thousands of hotel rooms are empty. But when Las Vegas, gripped by the coronavirus, needed space for a temporary homeless shelter, officials chose a location that does not have walls, or even a roof: an outdoor parking lot.

headline: Chicken, Artichokes and a Beloved Moroccan Passover Dish
abstract: Esther Soussan Berman passed away in 2010, but her recipe, for golden chicken thighs and fresh artichokes, still has a place on her family’s holiday tables.
lead_paragraph: As an artichoke lover, I am always game for a new recipe, especially before Passover when the thorny vegetable is beautifully in bloom.

headline: Why Asia’s New Wave of Virus Cases Should Worry the World
abstract: After a surge in cases tied to international travelers, China, Hong Kong, Singapore and other places that seemed to have the epidemic under control have imposed stricter measures.
lead_paragraph: In China, international flights have been cut back so severely that Chinese students abroad wonder when they will be able to get home. In Singapore, recently returned citizens must share their phones’ location data with the authorities each day to prove they are sticking to government-ordered quarantines.

headline: Kathy Valentine of the Go-Go’s Would Like to Talk to You About Memes
abstract: The musician’s list of cultural must-haves includes her collection of kitsch, reruns of “The Office” and early punk and hip-hop photographs.
lead_paragraph: On New Year’s Eve 1980, Kathy Valentine, not yet 22, played her first show with a fledgling Los Angeles group called the Go-Go’s. Less than 18 months later, their debut album, “Beauty and the Beat,” hit No. 1 on the Billboard chart. They were the first all-female rock band to earn that distinction.

headline: House Tour | Kelly Wearstler
abstract: The designer invites T into her 12,000-square-foot historic Beverly Hills home.
lead_paragraph: The designer invites T into her 12,000-square-foot historic Beverly Hills home.

headline: Kelly Wearstler’s Home Is Filled With Hollywood Secrets
abstract: The designer’s house in Los Angeles abounds with treasures from the city’s cinematic past — and her own equally dramatic creations.
lead_paragraph: The interior designer Kelly Wearstler’s 12,000-square-foot home in Beverly Hills, Calif., a striking white 1920s Spanish hacienda-style mansion surrounded by three acres of immaculately landscaped gardens, isn’t just a place for her to unwind at the end of the day. “I call it my laboratory,” she says one mild morning in February. “I’m always bringing in new pieces of art or chairs or accessories.”

headline: Sanders Argues He Has ‘Narrow Path’ and Says He Wants to Push His Issues
abstract: In an interview with Seth Meyers on “Late Night,” Bernie Sanders said that raising consciousness on the issues he cares about is an argument for continuing his campaign.
lead_paragraph: [Read more: Bernie Sanders has officially ended his 2020 presidential campaign.]

headline: Captain of Aircraft Carrier Pleads for Help as Virus Cases Increase Onboard
abstract: “We are not at war,” the captain of the carrier Theodore Roosevelt wrote. “Sailors do not need to die. If we do not act now, we are failing to properly take care of our most trusted asset — our sailors.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The captain of an American aircraft carrier deployed to the Pacific Ocean has pleaded with the Pentagon for more help as a coronavirus outbreak aboard his ship continues to spread, officials said Tuesday. Military officials say dozens of sailors have been infected.

headline: ‘August,’ by Callan Wink: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “August,” by Callan Wink
lead_paragraph: August flew back to Michigan for Thanksgiving. It was his first time on an airplane, and even though he tried to be nonchalant about it, he held his breath during takeoff and let it out loud enough after they were finally airborne that his seatmate looked at him sidelong. His father met him at the airport in Grand Rapids. He shook August’s hand and threw his bag in the back of his truck, and they started the drive north.

headline: Waiving Rent and Making Masks, Afghans Meet Coronavirus With Kindness
abstract: The health crisis, which has become a fresh test of survival for a country where life has been a daily fight for decades, has provoked a shared sense of responsibility and spontaneous acts of generosity.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Around the time his hometown turned into the epicenter of coronavirus in Afghanistan and the government began a lockdown, Mohamed Kareem Tawain, an 80-year-old dentist in the western city of Herat, had a dream one night: that he took some money from his wife to distribute for charity, but found no one on the streets to give it to.

headline: A Coronavirus Thriller Was Finished Just Before the Shutdown
abstract: A Canadian filmmaker read the headlines, and a few weeks later a shoot was underway on a story addressing xenophobia and the pandemic. Then film festivals were canceled.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, B.C. — In between the time the coronavirus started to make headlines but before life shut down to restrain the pandemic, an independent filmmaker conceived, shot and finished postproduction on a movie about the contagion.

headline: Frightened Doctors Face Off With Hospitals Over Rules on Protective Gear
abstract: Many hospitals bar doctors and other staff members from wearing protective masks in public areas. Some have been disciplined for pushing back.
lead_paragraph: Just after 6:30 on a recent morning, Dr. Henry Nikicicz, an anesthesiologist in Texas, finished an emergency intubation of a man in his 70s who was suffering severe respiratory distress. Then the doctor’s own trouble began.

headline: Nine Inch Nails Faces the Pandemic With Hope, Despair and Noise
abstract: On a pair of free albums, “Ghosts V: Together” and “Ghosts VI: Locusts,” Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross’s suspenseful sounds feel very much of the moment.
lead_paragraph: Timing may not be everything, but it’s a lot. Last Thursday, Nine Inch Nails — which currently means Trent Reznor and his partner in film scoring, Atticus Ross — released a pair of albums free online: “Ghosts V: Together,” and “Ghosts VI: Locusts.”

headline: Sardines and Celery: A Perfect Pairing
abstract: When you tire of sardines on toast, this crunchy salad is a great alternative for the tinned fish.
lead_paragraph: Sardines on toast — maybe drizzled with olive oil and topped with onions, or slathered with butter and rubbed with garlic — is always a sustaining meal. Especially now.

headline: Problems in F.B.I. Wiretap Applications Go Beyond Trump Aide Surveillance, Review Finds
abstract: The bureau has routinely botched work on surveillance applications for its national security investigations, an inspector general said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An inspector general uncovered pervasive problems in the F.B.I.’s preparation of wiretap applications, according to a memo released Tuesday about an audit that grew out of a damning report last year about errors and omissions in applications to target a former Trump campaign adviser during the Russia investigation.

headline: Dining and Driving on the Empty Freeways of Los Angeles
abstract: There’s no traffic. Drive-throughs are open. But anxiety is everywhere.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s good form to keep a schedule in isolation, something I’ve never been good at, until now: I wake up at 4 in the morning, I look at my phone in total darkness for three hours, check the news, the number of new cases, the death count. I mute, then unmute, the family WhatsApp. Then I get in my car, and I drive.

headline: Oil Companies on Tumbling Prices: ‘Disastrous, Devastating’
abstract: The use of gasoline and other fuels is dropping as Saudi Arabia and Russia increase production, sending oil prices to their lowest level in a generation.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The once mighty oil industry is shrinking quickly around the world, hunkering down in survival mode.

headline: Coronavirus Presents an Existential Threat to Some Pro Tennis Events
abstract: It is already difficult for the lowest events on the men’s and women’s tours, even in a good economy. Now, the upending of the sports calendar by the coronavirus means some tournaments may not exist next year.
lead_paragraph: The moment Bob Moran received word that the professional tennis tournament he runs in Charleston, S.C., was being called off because of the coronavirus pandemic, he halted construction on the grandstands being erected just outside his office.

headline: C.D.C. Weighs Advising Everyone to Wear a Mask
abstract: Widespread use of nonmedical masks could reduce community transmission. But recommending their broad use could also cause a run on the kind of masks that health care workers desperately need.
lead_paragraph: Should healthy people be wearing masks when they’re outside to protect themselves and others?

headline: Out of Retirement, Into the Coronavirus Fight
abstract: These are a few of the retired nurses, doctors and other health care workers helping to shore up a system under siege.
lead_paragraph: As the fast-rising tide of sick people overwhelms hospitals and infects the doctors and nurses delivering care, officials across the country and around the world have asked retired health care workers to help reinforce systems in crisis. Raising their hands, they feel at once resolute and torn, weighing their expertise and desire to serve against their heightened vulnerabilities.

headline: The Safety Net Got a Quick Patch. What Happens After the Coronavirus?
abstract: The emergency legislation enacted by Congress with support from Republicans and President Trump has intensified a long-running debate about whether the United States does enough in ordinary times to protect the needy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump and congressional Republicans spent the last three years fighting to cut anti-poverty programs and expand work rules, so their support for emergency relief — especially in the form of directly sending people checks, usually a nonstarter in American politics — is a significant reversal of their effort to shrink the safety net.

headline: How to Sew a Fabric Face Mask
abstract: A sewing pattern to use with common household materials
lead_paragraph: Guidance on whether to wear a face mask varies locally. But the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has recommended that all Americans, healthy and sick, wear basic cloth masks in public — a result of concerns that as many as 25 percent of people infected with the new coronavirus may not show symptoms.

headline: The Coronavirus Hasn’t Slowed Classical Music
abstract: As closures give way to a deluge of live streams, performances have never been more accessible.
lead_paragraph: A classical music critic in New York City could conceivably never spend an evening at home.

headline: CNN’s Chris Cuomo, Brother of Governor, Tests Positive for Coronavirus
abstract: The CNN anchor, 49, is “feeling well” and will continue hosting his prime-time show from home, where he is quarantined.
lead_paragraph: Chris Cuomo, the CNN anchor and younger brother of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, has tested positive for the coronavirus, the network said on Tuesday.

headline: Breads Bakery, Eli’s Market and Others Offer Holiday Packages
abstract: Several vendors across the city are selling Passover and Easter menus for pickup and delivery.
lead_paragraph: In normal times, many people enjoy communal Passover Seder dinners in restaurants, and there are usually many worth recommending. Similarly, Easter Sunday is often a time for festive brunches and dinners, frequently in restaurants. But this year is different, with dining rooms shuttered and diners staying in. Still, there will be festivities, and eating. Here are a number of places ready to help with meals and foods for the holidays for pickup and delivery:

headline: ‘We Are in a Cage:’ Spanish Town Lives Under a Lockdown Within a Lockdown
abstract: A town near Barcelona has withdrawn into itself to contain the spread of the coronavirus. Dozens have died at an overstretched hospital, and the cost of confinement goes far beyond illness.
lead_paragraph: LA POBLA DE CLARAMUNT, Spain — When María José Rodríguez heard on local television that her town in northeastern Spain would be locked down within hours, she knew she had to leave or risk losing her family’s business.

headline: The Larger Costs of Closing a Local Museum During Coronavirus
abstract: The Underground Museum in Los Angeles has become not only an art destination but a community lifeline.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The low-slung building on Washington Boulevard here might seem like a nondescript storefront sandwiched between a carpet installation business and a lawn mower repair shop.

headline: How ‘Unorthodox’ Captured One Woman’s Flight From Hasidic Brooklyn
abstract: Deborah Feldman left her ultra-Orthodox Jewish community for a new life in Berlin. She talked about what it has been like having her autobiography adapted for Netflix.
lead_paragraph: The writer Deborah Feldman’s pantry was already stocked for the apocalypse. That’s how her Hasidic Holocaust survivor grandparents raised her. They “believed in the end of the world, had seen the end of the world and always prepared me to live through the end of the world,” she said by telephone from her Berlin apartment. The day before, Chancellor Angela Merkel told Germans to self-isolate in hopes of slowing the spread of coronavirus. And while many were out panic shopping, she hadn’t been to the market once.

headline: Trump’s Rollback of Pollution Rules
abstract: A reader says the president is using the coronavirus crisis to make our air dirtier. Also: The virus’s human toll; Palestinian refugees; the cost of flooding.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: JPMorgan Announces New Diversity Push
abstract: The bank said it would make diversity training mandatory for all employees after a New York Times report about racism at its Arizona branches.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase is increasing its efforts to diversify its work force and customer base after a Dec. 11 New York Times report showed a black customer and a black employee each struggling to gain access to the same opportunities as their white peers at the country’s largest bank.

headline: Are You Home Alone? We Are Too
abstract: Living by yourself brings its own set of challenges when you’re stuck inside.
lead_paragraph: We spend a lot of our days chatting with each other about things we see online, trying to make sense of it all. As everyone copes with the new coronavirus crisis, many of us are facing drastic changes, including illness, job loss and abandoning the office to work entirely from home.

headline: N.F.L. Plays on Twitter and Brackets for Everything
abstract: New Orleans Saints Coach Sean Payton shared his favorite plays on Twitter, alternative brackets are still getting busted and a Swedish soccer friendly was canceled after bettors swarmed.
lead_paragraph: We have been learning in recent days what athletes do when they’re stuck at home, including working out in creative ways.

headline: Will the Coronavirus Threaten Our Food?
abstract: The supply chain has plenty of vulnerabilities.
lead_paragraph: Two terminals for the Port of Houston were shut down for a day this month after an employee tested positive for coronavirus, and Pennsylvania briefly closed most of its truck stops and service areas to slow the spread of the virus, threatening to also slow the distribution of food and other goods. Some meat packagers around the country were at three-fourths capacity because of illness.

headline: 40-Year-Olds, How Are You Doing?
abstract: We’d like to hear about how the U.S. economy is treating you.
lead_paragraph: Are you better off than your parents? Research suggests that many Americans born in 1980 have had a harder time jumping up the economic ladder than the generation before.

headline: Self-Quarantine Is No Time for an Instagram-Ready Kitchen
abstract: Right now it’s more important that your space is designed for comfort rather than social media.
lead_paragraph: How have I lived this way for this long? I feel like I don’t even know you.

headline: 40% of N.Y. Tenants May Not Pay Rent This Month. What Happens Then?
abstract: Many unemployed tenants won’t be able to pay April rent. There will be a domino effect on landlords, real estate industry officials said.
lead_paragraph: The true economic toll of all but shutting down New York City to stem the spread of the coronavirus is likely to become clearer on Wednesday when April rent is due.

headline: Airlines Refused to Collect Passenger Data That Could Aid Coronavirus Fight
abstract: Public health officials have been pushing airlines for years to gather more traveler data, but airlines have balked, citing cost and time.
lead_paragraph: For 15 years, the U.S. government has been pressing airlines to prepare for a possible pandemic by collecting passengers’ contact information so that public-health authorities could track down people exposed to a contagious virus.

headline: Who Are the Voters Behind Trump’s Higher Approval Rating?
abstract: Despite the president’s slow performance on the coronavirus and his series of falsehoods, some independent voters and Democrats are giving him a measure of credit for his handling of the crisis.
lead_paragraph: Justin Penn, a Pittsburgh voter who calls himself politically independent, favored Joseph R. Biden Jr. in a matchup with President Trump until recently. But the president’s performance during the coronavirus outbreak has Mr. Penn reconsidering.

headline: Wartime Production Law Has Been Used Routinely, but Not With Coronavirus
abstract: The Defense Production Act has been invoked hundreds of thousands of times in the Trump years. But with the pandemic, the president sees it as a “break the glass” last resort.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chemicals used to construct military missiles. Materials needed to build drones. Body armor for agents patrolling the southwest border. Equipment for natural disaster response.

headline: Seven Comedians to Watch on Instagram and Twitter
abstract: These funny men and women are especially good at “front-facing camera comedy” on social media.
lead_paragraph: The comedians doing the most assured work online didn’t need to adjust for the coronavirus shutdown. As I wrote recently, the standouts were already on the web, particularly in the growing genre of “front-facing camera comedy.” Here are seven worth watching:

headline: Chloe Aaron, a Top PBS Executive, Is Dead at 81
abstract: As one of TV’s highest-ranking women in the 1970s, she worked to broaden the audience for public television.
lead_paragraph: Chloe Wellingham Aaron, who, when she became senior vice president for programming at PBS in 1976, was “believed to be the highest-ranking woman executive at the network level in the history of television,” as the announcement of her hiring put it, died on Feb. 29 at her home in Washington. She was 81.

headline: National Gallery of Art Returns Picasso Work to Settle Claim
abstract: The heirs of a Jewish banker said the portrait of a woman was among the works he sold under duress when the Nazis took power.
lead_paragraph: The National Gallery of Art in Washington announced it will return a pastel drawing by Pablo Picasso, “Head of a Woman,” to the heirs of a prominent German-Jewish banker who was persecuted by the Nazis.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘We Met, and Then the City Shut Down’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: We met, and then the city shut down. On an early spring day that brought Chicago outside, we exchanged numbers at the end of an ultimate Frisbee game and made plans to meet again. But then the bars, restaurants and coffee shops closed. So we adapted. We dated on my couch and across my kitchen table. We picked up takeout, alternated secret glances over a puzzle, ate cinnamon pancakes. We didn’t talk about the pandemic until, lying in bed, we laughed at our sudden and unexpected domestic intimacy, entwined while quarantined. — Madison Moore

headline: Coronavirus Health Workers, Overwhelmed and Underprotected
abstract: Readers praise those who are risking those lives and offer ideas for how to help them.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Kious Kelly, a Nurse in the Covid Fight, Dies at 48
abstract: He may have been the first New York City nurse to be claimed by the virus. His death has been a rallying cry.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Why This Economic Crisis Differs From the Last One for Women
abstract: Unlike the financial crash of 2008, this downturn will likely lead to more job losses for women, according to new research.
lead_paragraph: — A new study by researchers at Northwestern University, the University of Mannheim in Germany and the University of California, San Diego.

headline: We Need Amazon During the Coronavirus. That’s a Problem.
abstract: With competitors closing, online retail giants are poised to be the only ones standing after the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Powell’s, a beloved bookstore chain in Portland, Ore., laid off more than 300 people in mid-March, temporarily closed its five storefronts and issued a dire warning for the years to come. “When we do open our stores again, we expect the landscape of Oregon, and all of our abilities to spend money on books and gifts, will have changed dramatically,” wrote Powell’s chief executive, Emily Powell. “We see the path ahead more clearly: it is dark and scary.”

headline: E.U. Tries Gentle Diplomacy to Counter Hungary’s Crackdown on Democracy
abstract: European leaders were reluctant to pick a fight with Prime Minister Viktor Orban a day after he secured powers to rule by decree indefinitely.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s written response to Hungary’s effective suspension of democracy omitted one important word: Hungary.

headline: Should I Start Wearing a Mask?
abstract: The C.D.C. now recommends we cover our faces in public. Here is our guidance on how to best protect yourself, whether you have a mask or not.
lead_paragraph: To mask or not to mask?

headline: Parents and Schools Are Struggling to Care for Kids With Special Needs
abstract: Coronavirus has meant rethinking education as we know it, and it’s OK to take it slow.
lead_paragraph: During the second week of March, Hope Pardee, a teacher for visually impaired children in Connecticut, developed what she and her physician suspected were classic symptoms of infection with the new coronavirus — sore throat, dry cough, headache and a high fever. But as soon as she recovered, Pardee faced another daunting prospect: home schooling her 6-year-old twins.

headline: Coronavirus, Vladimir Putin, India’s Workers: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: How Powell and Mnuchin Became the Duo in Charge of Saving the Economy
abstract: The deal makers face their biggest challenge yet: keeping companies afloat long enough to get America past the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On March 15, as economic devastation from the coronavirus showed no signs of abating, Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, aimed the full weight of the central bank against the problem.

headline: Don’t Overdo the Coronavirus Stockpiling
abstract: How to shop for food responsibly, without overstocking your bunker — and why you should only buy what you need.
lead_paragraph: Grocery store shelves have been cleaned out, despite the fact that there is currently no lack of food in the country. Although the empty shelves may look worrisome, there is no need to grab that last box of keto pea protein linguine if it’s not something you already eat.

headline: Steven Dick, British Diplomat in Hungary, Dies at 37
abstract: Mr. Dick, the deputy British ambassador to Hungary, always dreamed of working for the Foreign Office.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series remembering the people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Who Says You Can’t Give Tony Awards in an Abbreviated Season?
abstract: Our chief theater critics have no nickel-plated medallions to hand out, but they find plenty to celebrate among shut-down Broadway offerings.
lead_paragraph: When coronavirus closed the theaters on March 12, there were still 16 shows left to open in the Broadway season. Audiences will get to see some of them later, others probably not — but what of the more than 20 plays, musicals and miscellaneous offerings that had already faced the press? It seemed unfair not to celebrate them, so on Friday, just after it was announced that the Tony Awards will not go on as usual this year, we sat down (in cyberspace) to devise a Tonys of our own. Naturally, we made our own rules.

headline: At the Top of the Covid-19 Curve, How Do Hospitals Decide Who Gets Treatment?
abstract: Guidelines that could determine which coronavirus patients get prioritized for lifesaving care vary by state, involving factors such as age, health problems, pregnancy and cognitive abilities.
lead_paragraph: A hospital in Washington State projects that it may not have enough ventilators in two weeks. New York State could be thousands of ventilators short of what it needs. In Michigan, a hospital system has prepared warnings for patients about what will happen if it gets more patients than it can handle.

headline: How We Use Our Bodies to Navigate a Pandemic
abstract: Your partner is a stranger, and the sidewalk is a stage. Our dance critic asks: Will social distancing bring us back to our bodies?
lead_paragraph: One day, before the coronavirus pandemic, a river of pedestrians — half manic, half clueless — was feeding onto the escalator at the West Fourth Street subway station during rush hour. Blocking the escalator entrance were people gazing at their phones. Once they finally stepped on, they planted themselves on the left. It was a mess.

headline: Jan Howard, Singer and Writer of Country Hits, Dies at 91
abstract: A female star in Nashville when there weren’t many others, she found success as Bill Anderson’s duet partner and as a solo artist singing about the heartache she knew all too well.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Jan Howard, a pioneering woman in country music who wrote and sang about heartache and experienced it herself, died on Saturday at her home in Gallatin, Tenn., near Nashville. She was 91.

headline: White House Economists Warned in 2019 a Pandemic Could Devastate America
abstract: A study published last fall went unheeded. One of its authors now says economic shutdowns to fight the coronavirus could last up to eight months.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — White House economists published a study last September that warned a pandemic disease could kill a half million Americans and devastate the economy.

headline: April Dunn, Louisiana Fighter for Disability Rights, Dies at 33
abstract: Ms. Dunn, who succumbed to the coronavirus, successfully pushed for legislation that provided alternative ways to gain a high school degree.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Gun Ownership Soars in Brazil Under Bolsonaro
abstract: A year into his presidency, Jair Bolsonaro and his sons have helped fuel a gun rights movement that had little popular support, or political clout, in the country before he took office.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — President Jair Bolsonaro has galvanized gun culture in Brazil.

headline: Roberto Stella, Regional Doctor with a National Presence, Dies at 67
abstract: Dr. Stella was listed as the first Italian physician to die of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: International Center of Photography Wants Your Images of the Pandemic
abstract: Artists, both professional and otherwise, can submit their photos on Instagram using the hashtag #ICPConcerned.
lead_paragraph: So far, the images have a range: A woman wearing a mask and blue plastic gloves. Empty streets. A pair of dogs in a misty park. The inside of a deserted subway car. A woman hugging a tree. Two children with their faces pressed against a window.

headline: ‘Tiger King’: What Happened to Carole Baskin’s Husband, Don Lewis?
abstract: A popular Netflix documentary has brought a Florida sheriff a flood of new theories in the unsolved disappearance.
lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — Like much of America, Chad Chronister recently binge-watched the chronicles of an eccentric roadside zookeeper known as Joe Exotic and his archenemy, an animal activist who wanted him to stop profiting off big cats.

headline: Congressman Max Rose Deploys With National Guard for Coronavirus Relief
abstract: The freshman Democrat and combat veteran will help set up hospitals in his Staten Island district and other parts of New York City.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Max Rose, a freshman Democrat from New York, announced on Tuesday that he would deploy with the National Guard on Wednesday to assist the hard-hit city’s coronavirus response efforts, making him the first member of Congress to do so.

headline: As Virus Hobbles Economy, Companies Race to Tap Credit and Raise Cash
abstract: The clamor for corporate funding is raising concerns about a financial reckoning reminiscent of 2008.
lead_paragraph: In a single week in March, as financial markets convulsed and major parts of the economy began shutting down, banks made over $240 billion in new loans to companies — twice as much in new lending as they would ordinarily extend in a full year.

headline: When Will Social Distancing Let Up?
abstract: No one knows, but here are some educated guesses.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Another Wholesale Grocery Opens to the Public
abstract: Chefs’ Warehouse, in Ridgefield, Conn., sells goods to businesses affected by the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Wholesale suppliers that normally deliver pallets of pasta and boxes of beef to commercial kitchens have also been hit hard during the coronavirus pandemic. Their clients include closed businesses and institutions like restaurants, caterers and clubs. The Chefs’ Warehouse in Ridgefield, Conn., is the latest wholesale grocer to open its inventory to the public. (Baldor Specialty Foods did so two weeks ago.)

headline: Coronavirus, Masks, Wildlife Safari: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Governors Fight Back Against Coronavirus Chaos: ‘It’s Like Being on eBay With 50 Other States’
abstract: A chorus of governors from across the political spectrum is challenging the Trump administration’s assertion that the United States is well-stocked to test and care for coronavirus patients.
lead_paragraph: A chorus of governors from across the political spectrum is publicly challenging the Trump administration’s assertion that the United States is well-stocked and well-prepared to test people for the coronavirus and care for the sickest patients.

headline: With the Coronavirus, It’s Again Trump vs. Mother Nature
abstract: The president’s failure to understand his limits is very costly.
lead_paragraph: Today’s news quiz: What do these data points have in common?

headline: Where Are the Senate Battleground States? Look at the Ads
abstract: New ad buys reveal the key states where both parties think control of the Senate will be decided.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti, your host on Tuesdays for our coverage of all things media and messaging.

headline: ‘Tiger King’: What to Read if You’re Obsessed With the Netflix Series
abstract: Go on a deep dive with these articles that expand the story of Joe Exotic and Carole Baskin.
lead_paragraph: It’s impossible to know whether or not the Netflix docu-series “Tiger King: Murder, Mayhem and Madness” would have become such a sensation were we not all spending most of our waking hours inside. The show’s subtitle itself feels like it was made for a different time, one in which the show really had to sell itself to potential viewers. (“It has murder, mayhem and madness.”)

headline: The Quarantinis Are Flowing and the Store Is Out of Milk Bones
abstract: A journal of the Plague Year: Week 3.
lead_paragraph: My daughter and I get in the car and head north. Just as the sun sets, we arrive at our home in the Belgrade Lakes region of Maine, eight hours after leaving New York City and Barnard College. It’s March 12, two days after the president said, “Be calm. It’s really working out. And a lot of good things are going to happen.”

headline: Fox’s Fake News Contagion
abstract: The network spent too long spraying its viewers with false information about the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: You can relax, Sean Hannity, I’m not going to sue you.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The C.D.C. is considering a recommendation that many more people — maybe everyone — wear masks in public.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is having second thoughts about masks.

headline: Infected but Feeling Fine: The Unwitting Coronavirus Spreaders
abstract: The C.D.C. director says new data about people who are infected but symptom-free could lead the agency to recommend broadened use of masks.
lead_paragraph: As many as 25 percent of people infected with the new coronavirus may not show symptoms, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention warns — a startlingly high number that complicates efforts to predict the pandemic’s course and strategies to mitigate its spread.

headline: Coronavirus Doesn’t Care Where You Come From. Trump Still Does.
abstract: Hostility toward immigrants is hurting the fight against the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks ago, with much of the United States already gearing up to limit the spread of the coronavirus, the Trump administration’s chief immigration judge sent out a stern order to immigration courts nationwide to take down all public health posters, printed in English and Spanish, on how to deal with the pandemic. “Per our leadership,” the order said, immigration judges did not have the authority to post fliers. “If you see one (attached), please remove it.”

headline: Coronavirus May Kill 100,000 to 240,000 in U.S. Despite Actions, Officials Say
abstract: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s leading infectious disease expert, and Dr. Deborah L. Birx, who is coordinating the response, called it “our real number” but pledged to try to reduce it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The top government scientists battling the coronavirus estimated on Tuesday that the deadly pathogen could kill 100,000 to 240,000 Americans as it ravages the country despite social distancing measures that have closed schools, banned large gatherings, limited travel and forced people to stay in their homes.

headline: How to Touch Up Your Roots at Home
abstract: Here’s what you should and shouldn’t do.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Bodt has been mulling over the relevance of hair color in our new lives.

headline: Before You Adopt: Planning a Lifelong Commitment to Your Pet’s Health
abstract: Ask yourself these questions and think about these issues before you adopt. Your life — and that of your new pet — will be better for it.
lead_paragraph: You’re scrolling Instagram when it happens: the tilted head, the floppy ears. Fluffy or Fido is looking for a home and there’s an empty place at the foot of your bed.

headline: Coronavirus Spreads in Veterans’ Home, Leaving ‘Shuddering Loss for Us All’
abstract: The mayor of Holyoke in Massachusetts confronted the superintendent of the Holyoke Soldiers’ Home after hearing rumors that infections were spreading.
lead_paragraph: NEWTON, Mass. — The mayor of Holyoke, Mass., got an unsigned letter over the weekend that deeply disturbed him.

headline: Hellmut Stern, 91, Dies; Violinist Returned to Germany After Fleeing
abstract: He joined the Berlin Philharmonic after years in exile, setting what a colleague called “a unique example of reconciliation and forgiveness.”
lead_paragraph: Hellmut Stern, who fled Germany with his family as a child to escape the Nazis, then returned years later to join the Berlin Philharmonic as a violinist and later became a leading member of the orchestra, died on March 21 at his home in Berlin. He was 91.
